HEADLINE: The Heartland Hunkers Down; 
Cincinnati Area Is Taking Job Losses in Stride, for Now

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: CINCINNATI 

 BODY:
Even as the economy worsens, the giant Procter & Gamble, the most prominent corporation with headquarters here, is still relying on a softer approach to shrinking its work force, offering early retirement packages and other incentives instead of handing out pink slips.
 Across the Ohio River near the airport, tiny Pilot Air Freight is struggling to cope with the downturn in business and the added costs of increased security. But it has not yet laid off any of its 15 employees. Instead, it cut costs by requiring each of them to take off a week without pay on a rotating basis. 
 "Businesses have been crawling into a shell across the country and their behavior is just beginning to affect the broader community," said Mark M. Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com, a data-gathering and consulting firm in West Chester, Pa. That is certainly the case in the Cincinnati metropolitan area, a sprawling 13-county area in Ohio and Kentucky with 1.7 million people where the median income and the mix of companies roughly mirror the nation as a whole. 
Indeed, for all the growing economic distress here and elsewhere, so far the deterioration has been gradual and few among the newly unemployed express desperation -- yet -- about finding work. Despite the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 and the sudden acceleration nationally in job cuts and unemployment, the downturn here resembles a slowly leaking tire rather than a blowout.
That could change. The air is beginning to leak more rapidly. With layoffs piling up and many companies increasingly reluctant to hire, the nation is clearly in a recession and wages are going up more slowly, on average, than six months ago, according to government data.
But the surge in unemployment, to a rate of 5.4 percent last month, is still well below the peak of 7.5 percent in 1992, when the United States was struggling out of its last recession. During the long expansion of the 1980's, for that matter, the unemployment rate was rarely as low as it still is today. 
That shows here in Cincinnati. Even among the well-dressed unemployed men and women who filled the basement assembly hall of a suburban church on a recent Monday morning, the mood was remarkably sanguine. A year ago almost no one showed up at these spirit-lifting weekly sessions of the Job Search Focus Group, and it nearly disbanded. With the surge in layoffs, attendance has surged, too.
Yet being laid off has not yet turned into a particularly frightening experience for Agnes Hudak, a 41-year-old nurse and hospital administrator, or for many of the 85 others gathered at the Community United Methodist Church in the northern suburb of Hyde Park. The conversation and testimonials were all about how to behave in an interview, how to display just the right amount of eagerness, how to follow up without seeming pushy -- how, in sum, to land a new job that has close to the same status and pay as the lost one.
"I could go out today and get work as a floor nurse and earn $45,000," Ms. Hudak said. She had earned $63,000 a year as the manager of patient support services at Mercy Hospital, until Mercy, seeking to cut costs, combined her operation with two others, dropping two of the managers. Her last day was Sept. 10. 
The terrorist attacks hit some parts of the economy harder than others, of course. Over the last 15 years, Cincinnati's big hub airport -- it is Delta Air Lines' second largest -- gave rise to an outsized hotel and convention industry that today provides nearly 10 percent of the metropolitan area's 890,000 jobs. Hotel occupancy rates were falling before the terrorist attacks, and they fell again in response. A few restaurants have closed. Layoffs in the travel industry have passed the 1,500 mark.
A mid-October convention of the Electrical Manufacturing and Coil Winding Association, scheduled to draw 5,000 delegates, drew only 3,000. And in a joint e-mail to thousands of local companies, the Chamber of Commerce and the Convention and Visitors Bureau urged them to hold their meetings and conferences in local hotels, not out-of-town.
Less noticeably, the many small companies in the new commercial neighborhoods around the airport are struggling to regain their stride. Pilot Air Freight, for example, is once again sending freight in Delta cargo bays, but its growth has been hampered in a different way -- by the complicated security procedures required to get clearance for the shipments of new customers.
"In the past, you might sign a new client, throw the first shipment in the car and come rushing back, excited that you had hooked one," said Michael Schwartz, Pilot's president. "We can't do that anymore and it is slowing our growth."
Because of the terrorism, revenues plunged in September, to $2.1 million from $2.7 million in August, and are only now recovering, Mr. Schwartz said. But he can only hold on for so long. "I think we can overcome the security issues faster than we can overcome the downturn in the economy," he said. "Ultimately we may have to adjust head count."
Empower MediaMarketing, an advertising agency, has delivered pink slips to 30 of its 140 employees. But Brian McHale, the president, speaks of a pickup in business lately. "We expect to be in a position to rehire early next year," he said.
Whether he is right or wrong about that, Empower's departed employees were among the 49 percent of Greater Cincinnati's work force averaging $20 an hour in pay. From the ranks of this large group come the laid off workers crowding into the Hyde Park church on Monday mornings. But for all the step-up in job losses, the unemployment rate in Greater Cincinnati has only recently approached 4 percent from 3.4 percent on average last year.
By historical standards, 4 percent is low, close to what would have been considered full employment even in the 1960's. So is the national unemployment rate, despite the jump to 5.4 percent in October from 4.9 percent in September, reported by the Labor Department last Friday. 
That helps to explain why Ms. Hudak is holding out and why Matt Guye, 34, a salesman laid off on Aug. 2 from a $45,000-a-year job, also resisted accepting a substantial pay cut. Encouraged by others at the job group, he recently turned down $30,000 a year to sell insurance, although Mr. Guye has four children and a stay-at-home wife. Last week he finally took a job selling forklifts and similar equipment for $39,000 a year, plus commissions and the promise of future promotions.
"If I took a lesser job, I would be selling myself short," he said. "I did that once, after an earlier layoff. I don't want to do it again. I've made commitments based on a certain lifestyle."
While Mr. Guye scrambles, the downturn is hardly visible among the 1,400 members of the New Prospect Baptist Church, in a low-income black neighborhood where underemployment and low wages are always a problem. Most of the parishioners work as post office clerks, or in similar civil service jobs, or in the private sector where there is still a demand for hospital orderlies, fast food servers, physical therapists, security guards and warehouse workers, at $6 to $10 an hour.
"Only one member of my congregation has told me that he was laid off, and he worked at a hotel," said the Rev. Damon Lynch III, New Prospect's pastor and the leader of the Cincinnati Black United Front. "Middle class people are getting laid off, but they have not fallen far enough to bump the people below them. If the downturn continues, that may happen."
The downturn is particularly noticeable in the sudden reluctance of business to expand, after five years of booming, sometimes reckless expansion. "There is a lot of wait and see," said Stephen J. Schrantz, an executive vice president of Fifth Third Bank, who reports that lending activity for capital investment is sluggish. "They are not borrowing to add capacity when they do not need more capacity."
The pullback has cut deeply into a strategy that Cincinnati had counted on for new jobs and economic growth. Like many cities, Cincinnati has been lavish in offering tax breaks and other subsidies to companies willing to expand, whether they were outsiders seeking a new site or companies already here and planning to put up a warehouse, expand a factory or build a new office complex. Japanese auto parts makers were willing to set up shop in the Cincinnati area to supply several auto assembly plants in Kentucky, Ohio and southeastern Indiana. 
Today, though, postponement is the rule. Fidelity Investments, a unit of FMR, has put off an expansion of its telephone customer service center on the Kentucky side of the river. DHL Worldwide Express, the air freight company, has delayed the construction of a new package sorting facility near the airport. Four Japanese projects are on hold "while Japanese executives wait for their companies to decide that it is O.K. to travel again," said Joseph Kramer, vice president for economic development of the Greater Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce.
The damage is evident in the chamber's scorecard for 2001. Through the first 10 months, there were only 148 projects involving $1.4 billion in capital spending in the metropolitan area, well off the pace of 255 projects and $2.4 billion last year. And even that exaggerates the growth: several of this year's major projects represented consolidations rather than expansions. Sara Lee, for example, consolidated its food division headquarters in a new office building in suburban Blue Ash, closing facilities in Memphis and Chicago. That added 200 jobs in Cincinnati, but for the national economy as a whole, the consolidation represented a net job loss.
With business expansion on hold, consumers and government are being called on to step into the breach. There is evidence of erosion on those fronts as well, although the evidence is more mixed. Sales tax revenue, an indicator of consumer spending, is falling in central Cincinnati, but holding steady or rising in outlying, wealthier neighborhoods. Credit card debt and home equity loans are rising, Fifth Third Bank reports, but savings account balances are rising faster. "People are telling us," Robert P. Niehaus, an executive vice president, said, that "they want cash readily available just in case."

HEADLINE: OPEC Says Oil Quotas Could Drop Up to 6.5% 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The secretary general of OPEC said yesterday that it might reduce oil production as much as 1.5 million barrels a day, or 6.5 percent, since prices have fallen to a two-year low.
 There is the probability of a million-barrel-a-day to a 1.5-million-barrel-a-day cut, the agency reported, citing the secretary general, Ali Rodriguez Araque, who spoke at a news conference in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, during the three-day Council on Petroleum Conference of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. 
 Ministers from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries are scheduled to meet on Nov. 14 in Vienna. OPEC wants oil prices to be $22 to $28 a barrel and has lowered production quotas three times this year, by a total of 3.5 million barrels a day. 
OPEC has been lobbying with independent producers like Russia, Norway and Mexico to join a new round of supply curbs. Only Oman, a Persian Gulf state that pumps about one million barrels of oil a day, has said it supports another reduction. The group will need support from outside nations to succeed, Mr. Rodriguez said.
In New York, crude oil for December delivery fell 16 cents yesterday, to $20.02 a barrel, a two-year low. In London, Brent crude oil for December delivery fell 33 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $19.44 a barrel on the International Petroleum Exchange.
"OPEC is in a very tough situation," said John Cairns, an oil and gas economist in Singapore at IDEAglobal, a research firm. "Demand has gone down to such an extent, and they have to react.
"But the size of the cuts they are going to have to do is very large, and they will be very difficult to enforce."
The International Energy Agency said last month that world oil demand would rise at the slowest pace in 17 years because the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks had reduced travel and undermined an already slowing world economy.
Oil analysts have been skeptical that OPEC will succeed with a new reduction, given that members exceeded their official production quotas by 850,000 barrels a day last month, according to PetroLogistics, a consulting company.
Compliance with quotas is now at 90 percent within OPEC, Mr. Rodriguez said, but he gave no details. "The first issue is full compliance of our commitments," he said.
Indonesia will ask OPEC at the meeting next week to lower output by 500,000 barrels a day, Baihaki Hakim, president director of the state oil and gas company, Pertamina, said on Oct. 26. Mr. Rodriguez said last month that production cuts would be 700,000 to one million barrels a day.

HEADLINE: Nicaragua Voters Reject Ortega's Bid for the Presidency 

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
Enrique Bolanos, a businessman who was arrested and stripped of property in the 1980's for his outspoken opposition to Sandinista rule, was elected president of Nicaragua today, defeating his nemesis, Daniel Ortega, by a surprisingly wide margin.
 Strong voter turnout led Mr. Bolanos's Liberal Party to capture an estimated 53.7 percent of the vote compared with 44.7 percent for Mr. Ortega, the Sandinista leader, after 13 percent of the nation's precincts had been tallied. 
 Political analysts said the margin of victory, which defied opinion polls showing the two candidates in a statistical tie, resulted both from fear of the Sandinistas' past and declarations by American officials who doubted the sincerity of Mr. Ortega's statements that he had moderated his political views and wanted a national reconciliation. 
Campaign workers were carried triumphantly atop shoulders to Mr. Bolanos's headquarters as the crowd screamed "Strikeout! Strikeout!" in celebration of Mr. Ortega's third defeat at the polls since the Sandinistas were voted out of office in 1990.
"Yesterday we made long lines and stood in the sun and rain to show our commitment to the country," Mr. Bolanos told the cheering crowd. "We are making history in this great civic journey. Nicaragua won, and we have made another step to consolidating democracy."
Mr. Bolanos's campaign had focused heavily in recent weeks on what he termed the Sandinistas' responsibility for an economic and social disaster as well as their leader's ties to nations that supported terrorists. By contrast, Mr. Bolanos today struck a conciliatory tone, describing the Sandinistas as a "modern" political party. "I congratulate the Sandinista Party and their candidate, Daniel Ortega," he said. "I congratulate them with all my heart. Nicaraguan brothers, I invite you to accompany me in building a new Nicaragua."
Mr. Ortega, addressing supporters at midday at party headquarters, where the word "President" had been painted out over his name, appeared subdued and gracious in conceding defeat. He said that members of his political coalition, the National Convergence, which included former enemies, would continue to work together.
"The economic situation in which the nation finds itself is so grave that the Convergence will support the governability of the country," he said. "We are going to support the democracy which should go to strengthen the independence of our institutions." 
Mr. Ortega's supporters and advisers criticized the United States for what they saw as its meddling in internal affairs, likening it to the American effort to support the contra resistance army.
"We must congratulate Washington because their intimidation tactics worked," said the Rev. Miguel D'Escoto, a former Sandinista foreign minister. "They are now into electoral terrorism among a people here where the wounds are still open. We did not lose 5,000 people like in New York, we lost 50,000 in a war that was invented, organized, armed and financed by the United States."
Mr. Bolanos faces an economy that has been battered in recent years by falling coffee prices and a debilitating drought. Investor confidence had plummeted this year, with business owners nervous about both a possible Sandinista victory and rampant corruption under the current administration of President Arnoldo Aleman. Foreign reserves have fallen and several banks have failed.
Both voters and analysts suggested that Mr. Bolanos's background in business and with civic groups, as well as the support of Washington, might help repair the economy.
Political analysts said his margin of victory might help to counter the continued influence of Mr. Aleman, who as a former president will assume a leadership post in the National Assembly. The position gives Mr. Aleman immunity from prosecution, although Mr. Bolanos has vowed that no one will be above the law.
Mr. Bolanos, 73, was born in Masaya, a community southeast of Managua famous as the cradle of the country's best artisans. He studied industrial engineering at St. Louis University in Missouri, and owned many agricultural businesses, including cotton plantations and coffee processing plants.
In the 1980's, when domestic political groups were powerless to confront the Sandinista government, Mr. Bolanos was the vocal president of the Superior Council of Private Enterprise of Nicaragua, a business coalition. He refused to go into exile or stop criticizing Sandinista confiscations of businesses and land.
"He has been a successful businessman with a definite character and impeccable honor," said Dr. Anastasio Somaribba, the current president of the private enterprise council. "He has the determination of a man with a clear idea of where he wants to go."
Mr. Bolanos was detained several times during Sandinista rule, including one arrest for six days in 1989 with other leaders of his business group. In 1986, he and his wife returned from church to find a masked man going through his files. The couple's cries for help scared him away. Three times during the 1980's, various businesses and properties were confiscated by the government, costing him a total of $9 million, for which Mr. Bolanos says he has yet to be fully compensated.
Although he is low key in public, acquaintances say he is warm and open in private. 
The election on Sunday took place with hardly any glitches, and fears of violence or fraud failed to materialize. The only tumult in the streets today were joyful Liberals dancing, cheering and letting off fireworks.
"The country has clearly demonstrated its political maturity," said Jannis Sakellariou, the chief of the European Union's electoral observation mission.
The country also demonstrated that it was still unwilling to accept Mr. Ortega's repeated insistence that he had changed, even as he waged a largely positive campaign that focused on helping the poorest. 
It was not clear if Mr. Ortega's third unsuccessful presidential run would lead the Sandinistas to select a new leader. 
Mr. Ortega would not speculate. "Let the oven get cold," he said. "It is premature for that talk."

HEADLINE: Some New Talents Gain as Stores Buy American 

BYLINE:  By GINIA BELLAFANTE 

 BODY:
A few days after the attack on Pearl Harbor in December 1941, Hattie Carnegie, the shopkeeper, dress manufacturer and employer of personages as varied as Norman Norell and Lucille Ball, received a frantic phone call in her Manhattan workroom. It came from a friend in San Francisco, one of the Magnin brothers, proprietors of the department store that bore the family name.
 "The Japanese are at our door, close up," is how Pauline Trigere, who then worked as a designer for Ms. Carnegie, remembered Mr. Magnin's announcement. Ms. Carnegie, fearing fabric shortages and a diminished interest in shopping, temporarily shut down her operation. Ms. Trigere, stunned and unemployed, went to Boston to visit friends. "I slept for 24 hours straight," she remembered. She soon returned to New York, rented part of the Carnegie studio herself and got into business. By February, she had a line of 11 dresses. 
 As the fashion world wonders what will become of itself in an America beset by terrorism, it may serve as some inspiration to be reminded that the World War II years conferred upon New York its status as a pre-eminent disseminator of style. "American couture became what it was in 1942, '43," Ms. Trigere said. "The minute Americans couldn't get to Paris anymore." 
During the early 40's, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia organized committees to explore ways to lure editors and buyers to Manhattan. Vogue, Harper's Bazaar and the publicist Eleanor Lambert, who established the Coty Awards in 1943, worked in consort promoting American design. By the late 40's, names like Trigere, Norell and Claire McCardell had become essential to anyone's understanding of fashion.
Though the current geopolitical crisis is unlikely to leave American enterprise isolated to such a point, it could boost novice designers here who might otherwise have gone overlooked in favor of the young Belgian or the renegade Dutchman. Vogue's November issue already seems a harbinger of a fomenting spirit of Americana. 
Fear of traveling left empty seats at the spring 2002 shows in Milan and Paris last month -- seats that would have been filled by American buyers who use time abroad not only to evaluate runway collections, but also to traipse back alleys and fire escapes for the undiscovered talent crocheting the most glorious bell-sleeved vicuna cardigan known to man or woman.
Large and well-financed European labels have brought their collections to buyers in New York, meaning there will be no shortage of Prada next spring. But that buyers at Henri Bendel, say, spent one-third less time in Europe than in recent seasons means that independent European designers lost out on attention that was directed instead at their American counterparts.
Bendel's has added seven new, young American designers to its roster, said Ed Burstell, the store's fashion director. Among them are Zac Posen, 20, a New Yorker, and another downtown designer, Jess Holzworth. Michael Soheil's order at Bendel's doubled over last season. Mr. Soheil's career got a jump-start when he was asked to participate in a group show sponsored by Vogue in September -- a show for young designers whose presentations were canceled after Sept. 11.
"Every retailer is looking for news, and if it is not coming from Europe it has got to come from somewhere," Mr. Burstell said. Sarah Hailes and Beth Buccini, owners of Kirna Zabete in SoHo, usually spend over two weeks in Europe each season. This time out, their trip lasted only four days and was limited to Paris. They've dropped the Londoner Jessica Ogden for next season and added three young New Yorkers to the mix: the team of Lutz & Patmos, Behnaz Sarafpour and Alvin Valley. 
Bendel's has also increased orders from other young Americans already represented. "Someone like Alice Roi has become more important for us," Mr. Burstell said. Another designer, a Chicago native, Alicia Bell, was surprised to discover that Bendel's wanted more from her for next spring.
Eliminated by Nordstrom for next season, Ms. Bell, whose clothes fall under the category of romantically tweedy, said that her business won't suffer despite the gloom she had anticipated. "I picked up a lot of new boutiques in places like Houston, North Carolina -- places I never thought I'd reach. Frankly, I'm shocked."
Someone like Tess Giberson, a designer who makes all her pieces herself in her West 14th Street studio, is also oddly poised to do well at a time when buyers want to place small orders. 
Indeed, it is small boutique owners who don't necessarily have the budgets or inclination to travel who will turn to such producers more readily now. Last year, Delia Seaman, the owner of Curve, an innovative shop in Beverly Hills, decided that the way she could compete with the Barneys of the world was to venture off to unchartered fashion territories like Argentina. Ms. Seaman said she will now concentrate on Los Angeles design. "I don't feel as if it is safe to be an American anywhere anymore," said Ms. Seaman, who dreads even flying to New York. Also, "retail is awful, the economy is terrible, and when you go to Europe for a buy it's a $25,000 minimum order," she said. 
Marisa Hartington got the idea to increase her representation of American designers when she received a call from Gianfranco Ferre's office in Italy shortly after Sept. 11. The owner of Marissa Collections, a boutique in Naples, Fla., Ms. Hartington had planned to present a Ferre runway and trunk show in November. But Mr. Ferre decided not to fly, and Ms. Hartington chose to be host to a show of Americans only. 
A purveyor of labels like Jil Sander and John Galliano, Ms. Hartington said her store is 70 percent European, but that by next spring it would be 50 percent American. "The American designers offer what we want right now," Ms. Hartington said. "Because costumy clothes are really over." 
Complications that might arise from shipping across the Atlantic could also move some to reconsider Europeans. "I'm worried about deliveries and what might get held up at customs," said Lynwood Holmberg, the women's wear buyer at Mario's, a store that caters to the monied technocrats of Seattle. Another concern, she said, is that shipping companies are already increasing their fees because of greater security costs.
Of course, there is another reason to traffic in American fashion, namely, patriotism. "There was a woman in the store recently, a former Microsoft executive, who was going to a wedding in France," Ms. Holmberg said. It was important to her that she wear something American. She bought a gown by Robert Danes.

HEADLINE: Triton Reports Bigger Loss 

DATELINE: BERWYN, Pa., Nov. 5 

 BODY:
Triton PCS, the wireless telephone company, said today that its third-quarter loss widened from the similar quarter last year and it added fewer subscribers than expected but revenue rose 50 percent as customer turnover remained low. 
 "Even under challenging economic conditions, we continued to exceed expectations," Michael Kalogris, chairman and chief executive of Triton said, for many crucial operating and financial measurements, like average monthly revenue per subscriber. 
 Triton sells wireless service in Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Tennessee and Kentucky under the name SunCom.
Shares of Triton closed down 85 cents, or about 2.6 percent, at $31.50 on the New York Stock Exchange. The company reported its results after regular trading hours.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Fed Is Facing a Challenge In Rate-Cutting Campaign
After nine interest rate cuts this year, the Federal Reserve may be preparing to temper its campaign to revive the economy, analysts said. The Fed is all but certain to lower its benchmark rate today. But economists and investors are divided over whether the cut will be a half-percentage point or a quarter-point.
 Whichever choice it makes, the Fed faces a series of tricky trade-offs. It is under pressure to bolster consumer confidence, support stock prices and be seen as responding aggressively to the surge in unemployment. At the same time, Fed officials are clearly concerned about overdoing their rate cuts. Page C2. 

Cisco Results Beat Expectations
Cisco Systems posted a first-quarter loss as sales fell 32 percent from those in the period a year earlier. But the results exceeded Wall Street's expectations and signaled that the company's steep, yearlong slide has apparently stopped. For the first time this calendar year, Cisco's revenue increased from the previous quarter, surpassing the company's projections of flat to slightly weaker sales. Before Cisco announced its results, its shares closed at $17.90, up 64 cents. Market Place. C6.

Stocks Rally Before Fed Meeting
Stocks rallied, led by technology issues, as investors showed optimism before the regular meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers. The Nasdaq composite index rose 47.92 points, or 2.7 percent, to 1,793.65. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 117.49 points, or 1.3 percent, to 9,441.03. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 15.64 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,102.84. C8.

Swissair to Sell Business to E.D.S.
Swissair agreed to sell its ticketing and reservations unit, Atraxis, to Electronic Data Systems as it begins shedding its profitable subsidiaries. World Business, Section W.

Low-Wage Jobs Hit Hard in New York
Workers in traditionally low-wage industries, like restaurants and hotels, retailing and transportation, have been hit hard in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, according to a new analysis by the New York State Department of Labor. B1.

Insurers Favor Senate Aid Plan
With time running short for Congress to adopt a plan that would help the insurance industry deal with losses from future terrorist attacks, the insurers say they strongly favor a Senate plan that would require them to pay for the first $10 billion in damage. B5.

Prudential Strategist to Depart
Greg A. Smith, a longtime investment strategist and one of the least bullish on Wall Street, has resigned from Prudential Securities. Mr. Smith, 56, said he planned to leave his job by Dec. 31 after holding it for almost 20 years. He said the demands of the job, especially the frequent travel, became too taxing and that he might try managing money full time. C2.

OPEC May Cut Oil Output by 6.5%
The secretary general of OPEC said that the group might reduce oil production as much as 1.5 million barrels a day, or 6.5 percent, since prices have fallen to a two-year low. C7.

Airline Orders $15 Billion in Jets
Emirates, the national airline of the United Arab Emirates, placed nearly $15 billion in new orders for jets from Boeing and Airbus and announced a new joint venture with Airbus to set up an aviation-services company. C4.

Northwest Cuts Some Leisure Fares
Northwest Airlines reduced some of its advance-purchase fares aimed at leisure travelers by 25 percent, seeking to lift demand. C8.

Morgan Combines Bond Operations
To better cope with a rising number of companies whose debts have been reduced to junk status, J. P. Morgan Chase said that it would combine parts of its European corporate bond operations. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE LIABILITY; 
Insurance Companies Favor a Plan to Limit Terrorism Losses

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
With time running short for Congress to adopt a plan that would help the insurance industry deal with losses from future terrorist attacks, the insurers say they strongly favor a Senate plan that would require them to pay for the first $10 billion in damage.
 While they would prefer to shoulder less than $10 billion initially, they say a House plan, which provides long-term loans, is less appealing because it sets no limits on how big their losses might eventually be. 
 Without some measure of their potential losses, the insurers say, they cannot set prices and provide coverage against terrorist attacks. The Bush administration and banking and real estate executives have said that such coverage is crucial for the economy. Bankers, for example, say they would not make loans on projects unless they were insured against terrorist attacks. 
Despite their dissatisfaction, the insurers are reluctant to criticize either proposal because they would rather have some assistance than none. If debate over the plan bogs down, the insurers could be left without a decision by Congress when it recesses for Thanksgiving on Nov. 16. It is unclear whether Congress will go back into session before the end of the year. 
About 70 percent of the commercial insurance policies are renewed annually in January, and insurers are saying they will not include terrorism coverage unless some way is found to limit their risks. 
The insurers now expect the Senate and the House to pass their respective bills and try to work out the differences in joint conferences. The House Financial Services Committee is expected to vote on its measure on Wednesday; the Senate Banking Committee is expected to act within a few days.
So far, the insurers have no compromise plan that would meld the two approaches, but the White House initially offered a plan similar to the one being advanced by the Senate, and its influence may break the deadlock.
Another aspect of the Senate plan, similar to the White House's proposal, is that the government would pay for 90 percent of the losses from a terrorist attack after the insurers paid the first $10 billion. 
Over the next several days, insurance executives and lobbyists plan to try to convince legislators of the benefits of the Senate plan.
One adjustment they are seeking is to find a way to apply the $10 billion deductible to insurance companies in proportion to their market size. 
"We don't do business as a group," said Julie A. Rochman, a senior vice president of the American Insurance Association, a trade group. "We do business as individual companies."
The House plan, which makes insurers eligible for long-term loans after $100 million in losses, addresses the losses of companies individually and may, in part, serve as a guide for adjusting the Senate plan, the insurers say. 
The insurance industry rarely manages to present a united front. But several trade groups say they have forged an alliance with the goal of at least getting the limits of potential losses in an attack defined. 
"If the industry splits," said Joseph Annotti, a spokesman for the National Association of Independent Insurers, "the chances increase of something bad getting enacted."

HEADLINE: Rate Reduction Expected, but How Big? 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
After nine interest rate cuts this year, the Federal Reserve may be preparing to temper its campaign to revive the economy, analysts said today.
 The Fed is all but certain to cut its benchmark federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks for a 10th time when it meets on Tuesday. But economists and investors are divided over whether the central bank will cut the rate by half a percentage point, as it has done on seven of nine occasions this year, or hold the reduction to a quarter of a percentage point. 
 The rate now stands at 2.5 percent, its lowest level since the early 1960's and four percentage points lower than where it was at the beginning of the year. 
Whichever choice it makes, the Fed faces a series of tricky trade-offs. It is under pressure to bolster consumer confidence heading into the holiday shopping season, support stock prices at a time when Wall Street is still getting its legs back and be seen as responding aggressively to the surge in unemployment last month.
With interest rates on mortgages and other long-term borrowing having fallen last week, economists said more cuts in the Fed's short-term rates would help lock in the lower long-term rates set in the bond market, helping the economy substantially.
At the same time, Fed officials are clearly concerned about overdoing their rate cuts. Failing to be patient about giving this year's rate cuts time to work could lead to the economy overheating next year.
And continuing to cut rates in coming months -- especially in half-point increments -- could leave the United States approaching the bind that is bedeviling Japan, where official interest rates are close to zero, leaving Japan's central bank severely constrained in its ability to fight a continuing recession.
As a result, some economists said, the Fed is likely to hold a rate cut to a quarter point on Tuesday. Those economists who are forecasting a half-point cut said it might well be the last of that magnitude, with any further cuts likely limited to a quarter point.
Diane C. Swonk, chief economist at Bank One in Chicago, said the Fed is likely to have a vigorous debate on Tuesday, but to come down on the side of a quarter-point cut.
"There are those at the Fed who are going to be less willing to ease further despite market expectations for additional easing," she said. "There will be those who want to appear awake at the wheel and keep investor confidence buoyed. It nets out to something a little more conservative than the markets are actually expecting."
The Fed and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, try to avoid the impression that they are responding to any single economic indicator or even to one month's data. But the news last week that the unemployment rate shot up in October by half a percentage point, to 5.4 percent, plus a raft of other gloomy statistics have clearly put pressure on Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues to be responsive to the mounting evidence that the economy continues to deteriorate.
In another sign of spreading trouble, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported today that its its index of business activity outside of the manufacturing sector fell to 40.6 in October from 50.2 in September, a much steeper downturn that economists had anticipated. 
The figures suggested that the service sector had joined manufacturing in suffering through a deep retreat following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
At the same time, the Fed is always concerned about getting into big pendulumlike swings in policy. Should the central bank ease too much this year and ignite inflation pressures next year, it would be forced to reverse course and begin raising rates.
Economists seem relatively evenly divided about whether the Fed will choose to cut rates on Tuesday by half a point or a quarter of a point.
Kurt Karl, the chief United States economist at Swiss Re, the insurance company, said he thinks a half-point is more likely. But the Fed will soon have to start signaling that it will limit any further rate reductions to a quarter point, he said.
"They have to bring sentiment around from these bigger cuts to smaller cuts," Mr. Karl said. Continuing to cut rates aggressively in coming months, he said, might please investors "but not do much for the economy in the short run and do some harm at the end of next year."
Wayne M. Ayers, chief economist at FleetBoston Financial, said the Fed would probably limit its rate cut on Tuesday to a quarter point because of the likelihood that Congress and the Bush administration will ultimately agree on a fiscal stimulus package of new tax cuts and government spending that would give the economy a boost next year.
Mr. Ayers said the Fed might keep cutting rates for some time to push the federal funds rate down to around 1.5 percent, where it would be roughly equal to Mr. Greenspan's favored measure of inflation, the core personal consumption deflator.
When inflation and the federal funds rate are equal, the so-called real interest rate is zero, meaning that banks are essentially able to borrow money for nothing. The Fed only tends to push rates that low when it is acting aggressively to bring the economy out of recession. By other measures, including the Consumer Price Index, the real rate is already at zero or below.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE UNEMPLOYED; 
Attacks Hit Low-Pay Jobs The Hardest

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON and EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The terrorists who attacked the World Trade Center may have been trying to crush American capitalism and its masters of the universe on Wall Street. But the economic impact of the attack is felling a very different group of people: cooks, cabdrivers, sales clerks and seamstresses.
 Workers in traditionally low-wage industries, like restaurants and hotels, retailing and transportation, have been hit hard in the fallout from Sept. 11, according to a new analysis from the New York State Department of Labor. 
 And a report released yesterday by the labor-backed Fiscal Policy Institute forecasts that almost 80,000 people will have lost their jobs by the end of the year and that 60 percent of these positions paid an average of $23,000 a year. That is far below the citywide average salary of roughly $58,000. 
"The spillover effects hit the retail and service industries very hard in New York City," said James Parrott, the chief economist for the institute. "And those tend to be lower-wage jobs."
The sudden decline in these jobs marks a sea change in the economy since Sept. 11. Earlier this year, while the job market was softening, the losses were concentrated among white-collar workers like dot-com programmers, stockbrokers and advertising executives.
Now, they are concentrated among people like Kim Daily. A single mother of two, Ms. Daily worked her way up from a $6-an-hour-job picking up room-service trays to a $15-an-hour job stocking minibars at the World Trade Center Marriott.
When the hotel was destroyed on Sept. 11, so was her job. And she has not been able to find another one.
It is not for lack of trying; she stood in line for four hours outside a city-sponsored job fair but never even made it in the door. She has been talking to her union, but the only position available so far was so tip-dependent that she worried it would not cover her $700-a-month rent. A job bank had only a few hotel positions, and none paid anywhere near the $25,000 she earned at the Marriott last year.
"I don't want to go for less money," she said.
The changed job market raises huge challenges for the city at a time when hundreds of thousands of families have moved off the welfare rolls. The most successful of these former welfare recipients, as well as many newcomers to this country, found jobs at hotels and restaurants, as cleaners at office buildings and as messengers in Lower Manhattan.
"Now that the economy has exploded along with the World Trade Center, their prospects of staying in the world of work have diminished," said David R. Jones, president of the Community Service Society of New York, which has been helping workers who lost their jobs after Sept. 11.
His group is recommending a government-financed jobs program, he said. "Otherwise, we'll have people sitting on stoops, getting a little check and doing nothing," he said.
How many New Yorkers are unemployed is unclear. In a government survey taken in the week of Sept. 11, in which anyone who worked at all was counted as employed, 223,100 people in New York City were looking for work (after adjustments for seasonal factors). That was an increase of almost 20,000 people in a month. The unemployment rate hit 6.3 percent. 
The October survey will not be released for several weeks, but its results are included in federal figures, released Friday, that showed a surge in national unemployment, which rose by half a percentage point, to 5.4 percent. Unemployment insurance covers only about a third of unemployed workers, but the number of people applying for benefits in the city has soared. In the last month, an average of 12,745 people a week has applied; a year ago, that figure was 5,616.
A special program, Disaster Unemployment Assistance, is supposed to help those who are not eligible for unemployment insurance (usually because they worked part time or were self-employed). But only 2,350 people are now getting those benefits.
Almost 25,000 people told the New York State Department of Labor that they lost their jobs because of the trade center disaster. An analysis of the first 22,000 of those claims found that about 16 percent worked at bars and restaurants, 14 percent worked at hotels and 5 percent worked in air transportation. Only 4 percent worked at Wall Street brokerage firms (many of which simply relocated workers to Midtown or New Jersey).
The largest group of people -- 21 percent -- worked in a category called business services. Many of them were temporary workers, like Lisa Mendes, a single mother who lost her job as an accounting clerk on Sept. 12. In years past, when one temporary job ended, she could pick and choose among the offerings at the agencies. Now, "there's just nothing there," she said. "It's scary."
Ms. Mendes is typical of the unemployed in another way -- she lives in Brooklyn. The Labor Department analysis found that almost 26 percent of those who said they were jobless because of the twin towers collapse live in Brooklyn; 24 percent live in Queens, and 12 percent live in the Bronx. Just 18 percent live in Manhattan.
But Ms. Mendes, who is from Jamaica, is luckier than many of the unemployed because she speaks English and can use a computer. The Consortium for Worker Education, which runs a special program for people unemployed because of the disaster (and has already counseled more than 3,200 of them) has 5,000 jobs in its special job bank.
"Most of them are back-office jobs, data entry, word processing, administrative assistants," said Saul Rosen, associate executive director of the group.
Hotel and restaurant employment has been devastated by the destruction of the trade center and the steep drop in tourism that followed. Most restaurants are not unionized, but Local 100 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union, which represents about 6,000 restaurant workers, says that 10 percent of its membership lost jobs immediately after Sept. 11. About 200 of those 600 have since found work, but not necessarily restaurant work.
John Haynes has a short-term job at the Immigrant Workers Assistance Alliance, helping undocumented workers. Until Sept. 11, he cooked meals on the 106th floor of the World Trade Center for the 250 employees of Windows on the World. He said he earned $488.80 a week before taxes, or about $25,400 a year, and he lives in public housing in the Bronx.
He does not think he will be able to go back into restaurant work, he says. "They are not hiring right now," he said. 'So I'm going to go for job training, either in computers or photo imaging."
The tourist and travel drought has hit many businesses in Queens, according to a new report by the Center for an Urban Future, a public policy group. Airline workers, freight forwarders, truckers and limousine drivers are all hurting.
Listen to Greg Buttle, who operates valet parking lots at the three major New York area airports: You park at these lots and workers will shuttle you to and from the terminal for about $13 a day plus tax. (They will also wash your car, change the oil, rotate or replace the tires, even pick up your dry cleaning.) Before, he normally had more than 150 cars in the lots; now, there are about 50, he said.
Mr. Buttle said he employed 45 people before Sept. 11; now he employs 30. "I tried to make sure that the part-timers who have come in most recently are the first ones to go," he said. "But some of our employees have worked for us for eight or nine years."
For more evidence of the spillover effect, look at Chinatown. Business has plunged at many of the more than 200 sewing shops below Houston Street and at least 20 went out of business in October, said May Chen, a vice president of Unite, the garment workers' union. At least a thousand of her 10,000 members have lost their jobs as stores and clothing companies have canceled orders. Others are working reduced hours.
Their job prospects are not good. "Because of the language barrier, sewing is about the only skill they have," said Susan Cowell, another union official.
Unite also represents workers at commercial laundries; because of the declines at many restaurants, about 600 of these workers have also been laid off.
With the public's attention riveted to the sad stories of the dead and the heroism of the rescuers, some workers fear that their plights will be ignored.
"No one wants to hear our stories," said Asmat M. Ali, a former captain at Windows on the World. "About a busboy or the dishwasher making $250 a week and raising three kids in an apartment in the Bronx or Brooklyn. But 80 percent of the people who worked in the World Trade Center fell in that category."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: AIRLINE SECURITY; 
F.B.I. Says Man Carried Knives Past Screeners

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
A Nepalese man was indicted today on a federal charge of trying to carry weapons onto an airplane, after the authorities said airline workers caught him boarding a flight to Omaha this weekend with several knives, a stun gun and a can of pepper spray.
 Eight employees of a private security company have been suspended for failing to detect the weapons in the man's carry-on bags at an earlier security checkpoint, although they did find two other knives in his pockets. 
 Norman Y. Mineta, secretary of transportation, called the incident at O'Hare International Airport a "failure of dramatic dimensions," and threatened to levy a "substantial fine" against the carrier that hired the security company, United Airlines. United, in turn, said it had hired an auditor to monitor the private companies that handle screening of luggage and passengers, and stationed United managers at all security checkpoints at airports across the country. 
The security company, Argenbright, issued a new policy today requiring an immediate search of carry-on bags for anyone caught with suspicious items, a measure it said went beyond federal regulations. 
"Customers should know and feel comforted in the fact that there are many levels of security at the airport," said a United spokeswoman, Susana A. Leyva. "There are many cross-checks and many backup procedures in place. No weapon was ever carried on board."
But Monique Bond, a spokeswoman for the Chicago Department of Aviation, said the suspension, rather than dismissal, of the Argenbright employees was "unacceptable."
"Since we don't have control over the company or the workers, there's nothing more we can do," Ms. Bond said. "The issue needs to be addressed and it clearly is not being addressed."
The man, Subash Bahadur Gurung, 27, was arrested by the F.B.I. on Sunday evening at the airport while retrieving his luggage; he had been released by the Chicago Police Department the previous night.
The authorities do not suspect any connection with the Sept. 11 attacks. Officials said Mr. Gurung, who was headed to Omaha to visit a friend, is unemployed and itinerant and in the United States illegally. Now being held without bond, Mr. Gurung faces up to 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine on the weapons charge.
"The investigation does not seem to reveal any illicit, nefarious, suspicious reason for his trip," said Randall Samborn, a spokesman for the United States attorney's office here. But the case is the latest to raise questions about airport security.
An affidavit filed today said Mr. Gurung was stripped of two knives at a security checkpoint on Saturday at about 5:30 p.m., yet arrived at his gate with weapons.
At Gate C-5, the affidavit says, United workers doing a spot search looked into Mr. Gurung's duffel bag, fanny pack and a white plastic shopping bag, finding seven folding knives with blades up to four inches, along with a stun gun and a small container labeled tear gas/pepper spray.
In an interview with a television station here, Mr. Gurung said he had meant to put the knives, which he said he carried for his protection, in his checked baggage.
"It was all a mistake," he said. "What the police are doing is the right thing."
The authorities said Mr. Gurung had recently lived in two apartments in the Rogers Park neighborhood on the North Side of Chicago. The superintendent at one of the buildings said Mr. Gurung and his brother moved out in October 2000 after about a year, but returned last Thursday to ask about a vacancy.
"He didn't seem crazy or weird, just quiet," said the superintendent, Adam Colfax.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE CHARITIES; 
DEBATE OVER RULES FOR VICTIMS FUND

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARSTOW and DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Six weeks after Congress created an unlimited fund to compensate the victims of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, the federal government is still wrestling with an emotionally charged question that could reduce payments to victims' families by hundreds of thousands of dollars and affect how more than $1 billion in charitable donations is spent.
 The question is: Should awards from the fund be reduced by the amount of charity a victim's family accepts? 
 For some taxpayer watchdog groups, and some powerful Congressional leaders, the answer is a resounding yes. The point of the federal fund, they say, is to make victims' families financially whole, not to enrich them at the expense of American taxpayers, millions of whom have already made donations.
But for victims' rights groups, and other powerful Congressional leaders, the answer is an equally resounding no. 
Americans, they say, pledged donations to help victims, not the government's balance sheet. And if fund awards are reduced by the amount of charity that is accepted, what incentive will Americans have to provide charity to future victims of terrorism?
The September 11th Victims Compensation Fund, included in a bill to bail out the airlines, is without precedent in the level of government compensation offered to victims of crime. Families of those killed or injured are entitled to collect awards for a range of losses, like future wages, and pain and suffering. There is no cap on awards and no need to prove blame. Final decisions on awards are required within 120 days. The trade-off is that those who make claims waive their right to sue to collect potentially huge punitive damages. 
Yet, at a time when grieving families are scrambling to pay bills and navigate a maze of public and private aid, the unresolved question of how the federal fund will treat charitable income is complicating, and even slowing, the distribution of donations.
For the families, the uncertainty poses practical concerns: will accepting donations now reduce how much they collect from the fund later? Do they have to keep painstaking records of every charitable penny they receive?
"In my humble opinion, I don't believe that people who gave money donated with that intention," said Elliott Scheinberg, whose wife, Angela, died in the attack on the World Trade Center.
For charities, there are different problems. If charitable donations will be used, in effect, to subsidize government awards to those eligible for the fund, should more of that charity be directed instead toward those not eligible -- those who lost their jobs or homes, or suffered severe mental trauma?
"In my view, it is essential to understand how the fund will help families in order for us to figure out how we should help victims," said Joshua Gotbaum, chief executive of the September 11th Fund, the second-largest charity, with more than $320 million in pledges.
The question of how to treat charitable donations, he said, is of fundamental importance -- so important that it was the only topic he declined to address during a lengthy recent interview. "There are powerful issues strongly felt on both sides," he said cautiously, explaining that he intended to take the matter to his board.
The extreme fragility of the issue is also reflected in the shifting positions of New York's senators, Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Initially, both senators said that as a matter of fairness -- and pragmatism, given the expected concern about the fund's price tag -- families that had received substantial charitable aid should not get the same amount from the fund as families that receive little from charities. 
"The issue should be that everyone should be made whole," Mr. Schumer said last week.
Mrs. Clinton has proposed that while modest amounts of charity might be ignored, awards could be decreased for those who accepted charity above a certain threshold. "I could agree to a cap," she said several weeks ago.
They have since backed off that position, aides said, in part because sentiment in Washington appears to be shifting toward those who oppose reducing awards to reflect charitable donations received. Mrs. Clinton has now joined Tom Daschle, the Senate majority leader, and Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, in asking that victim awards be made without regard to how much a family had collected in donations.
Within weeks, the question will be resolved by Attorney General John Ashcroft, who is charged with writing the regulations that will govern the fund.
The law clearly requires that fund awards, which could easily exceed $1 million, must be reduced by any collateral sources of compensation received by the families. But while the law specifies life insurance and pension benefits as collateral sources, it makes no mention of charity.
During negotiations with Democratic leaders, three powerful Republicans -- Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas and Representative Roy Blunt of Missouri -- objected strongly to the fund's creation, questioning its cost and warning of potential abuse. Mr. Blunt, for one, has argued that at the very least the fund should be structured to protect taxpayers from "double dipping" by families seeking to be reimbursed for expenses already covered by charities.
"If families are concerned about maximizing their potential dollars, they can always go to court," Mr. Blunt, the chief deputy whip, said.
Whether awards from the fund are reduced to reflect the charitable gifts families receive will be an important factor in its ultimate cost to American taxpayers, budget analysts said. Early estimates by the Congressional Budget Office put the fund's potential price tag at $11 billion, but the budget office has not made that estimate official yet, in part because of the uncertainty surrounding the role of charity, legislative analysts said.
Justice Department officials are clearly aware that this is a difficult issue. For weeks, Mr. Ashcroft's aides have been quietly soliciting opinions from a range of parties, including victims' rights groups, leading Democrats on Capitol Hill, officials in New York City and companies that lost employees in the attacks.
But the officials have not clearly indicated where they stand. In fact, some who have been consulted came away with opposite impressions of the department's inclinations. One person who was consulted recently quoted a senior official as saying, "Well, there appears to be a consensus inside Justice that charitable contributions should not be considered a collateral source."
Yet Bob Monetti, a victims' advocate whose son was killed in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland in 1988, said that the officials he met seemed to favor reducing awards by the amount of charity that victims' families collected. "They're certainly inclined to say that if somebody pays your funeral expenses, nobody else will, including them," he said.
The Justice Department has until Dec. 21 to draft rules for the fund. On Friday, its struggle with the issue surfaced in a statement seeking public comment on how the fund should operate.
The statement said that while the department appreciated the strong policy reasons for making awards without regard to what a family had accepted in charity, it also invited public comment on whether the law indeed permitted it to do so. Comments, which must be submitted by Nov. 26, can be sent by e-mail to victimcomp.comments@usdoj.gov.
The department also asked for comment on other issues, many of which reflect a concern over how to balance the competing demands for speed and fairness. The more important questions focus on how to define and verify eligibility, how to calculate economic and noneconomic losses and how to determine which relative will be entitled to submit a claim as the "personal representative" of a victim. The department asks how the fund should respond when there are disputes among relatives over filing a claim.
Also unresolved is whom Mr. Ashcroft will choose as the special master to oversee the fund. The master will hold immense power over the finances of thousands of families, interpreting and enforcing the fund's rules and deciding final awards, without any appeal.
Ever since Magna Carta, no king has ever had the power that this master has, said Aaron J. Broder, a New York trial lawyer who said he believed many families would be better served by filing lawsuits.
The department's statement on Friday said that Mr. Ashcroft was interviewing "highly credentialed" candidates for the post. Among those mentioned is Kenneth R. Feinberg, a former chief of staff for Senator Edward M. Kennedy and the court-appointed mediator for several high-profile disputes, including claims involving Agent Orange.
Mr. Feinberg's supporters include Mr. Kennedy, Mr. Schumer and Senator Orrin Hatch. But he has run into opposition from the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, which is lobbying for the appointment of Robert C. Zampano, a retired federal judge from Connecticut.
In a recent interview, Judge Zampano confirmed his interest in the post. "I think we all have to make a contribution," he said.
But so far, Mr. Ashcroft's aides have not tipped their hand, although they have promised to consult with leaders in Congress before making a choice, and have emphasized that their choice will be someone who can command strong bipartisan support.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: ASIAN ALLY; 
U.S. and India Map Path To Military Cooperation; More Arms Sales Are Seen

BYLINE:  By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld told India's defense minister, George Fernandes, today that the United States is committed to building closer military ties between their two countries, and the two men discussed possible sales of American military equipment to India.
 Mr. Rumsfeld's quick visit here at the end of four-day tour of five nations seemed meant to reassure India that the intense American partnership with Pakistan, India's archrival, will not come at India's expense, and to remind India that it has a long-term interest in staying on America's good side. 
 India is an ally of the United States in the global campaign against terrorism. But expanding military cooperation between the two, the world's most populous democracies, is also part of a broader American strategy, predating the Sept. 11 attacks, to deepen relations with India on issues that include trade, antiterrorism and scientific cooperation. 
At a joint news conference today, Mr. Rumsfeld said his aim was "to strengthen the military-to-military and defense ties between our two countries, which I think are so important."
Mr. Fernandes, who has been testy and skeptical in his recent comments about the United States, was full of warm words, declaring himself "very happy with the discussions."
The two men -- Mr. Fernandes, the aging socialist in sandals and a crumpled kurta pajama, and Mr. Rumsfeld, the aging cold warrior in a pressed gray suit -- made an odd couple, but both said they wanted what Mr. Fernandes called "a relationship of mutual support and cooperation."
Mr. Fernandes has in the past expressed serious doubts about America's resolve to help India fight terrorism on its own soil and the effectiveness of the American bombing of Afghanistan.
Attorney General John Ashcroft has recommended that two Pakistan-based Islamic militant groups active in an anti-India insurgency, Lashkar-e-Toiba and Jaish-iMuhammad, be put on Washington's list of terrorist organizations. 
India had long sought this step and officials here welcomed the move. Lashkar, in particular, is one of the most dangerous groups operating in Kashmir, a land that both India and Pakistan claim, often sending suicide bombers to attack Indian security forces there.
Mr. Rumsfeld said antiterrorism would not stop with Afghanistan, and "we will be pursuing terrorist networks wherever we find them." 
When asked what he thought of the American military strategy, Mr. Fernandes, known as an undiplomatic maverick, said tactfully, "I think it's the military men who decide the military tactics. One should accept what is happening now."
Mr. Rumsfeld himself said he believes that the bombing campaign is getting more effective by the day now that the Americans have personnel on the ground helping them identify targets for the bombs. 
Asked if the Afghan war could last for years, Mr. Rumsfeld said: "Do I think Afghanistan will take years? No, I don't. I think it is something that is being very aggressively addressed at the present time. How long it will take, one can't guess."
Mr. Fernandes's temperate remarks signaled that India's pique about the American alliance with Pakistan, which India regards as the prime sponsor of terrorism against India, may be balanced by India's desire for a strategic relationship with the United States.
The mere fact that the American secretary of defense called on India was a measure of how dramatically United States policies have changed in recent months. After India conducted nuclear tests in May 1998, the United States imposed economic and military sanctions that derailed earlier efforts by the Clinton administration to bring the two nations closer together. No American defense secretary had come to India since January 1995. 
Mr. Rumsfeld and Mr. Fernandes also discussed India's need for military supplies, including General Electric engines for its light combat aircraft.
By early next month, Indian and American military officials are to begin to meet as a Defense Policy Group to discuss ways that the two militaries can cooperate. Douglas J. Feith, undersecretary of defense for policy, will lead the American side.
The members of the group will consider increased training of officers in each others' academies and joint military exercises. And in another indication of American interest, Adm. Dennis C. Blair, commander in chief of the Pacific region, will soon be coming to New Delhi.
American officials hope India's interest in a broader relationship, after decades when India was a leader of nonaligned nations and close to the Soviet Union and then Russia, will give India an extra incentive to act with restraint when it comes to Pakistan.
American officials have worried that the conflict between India and Pakistan, nuclear-armed enemies, could flare into war if there were a major terrorist attack on India by an Islamic militant group based in Pakistan. President Bush asked the two countries to "stand down" last month after intense fighting broke out in Kashmir.
Mr. Rumsfeld today made no mention of the desire for military restraint, nor did he need to. That point has been made clearly at the highest levels, including during Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's visit to New Delhi three weeks ago.
Even as senior Indian officials, including Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, have continued making bellicose remarks almost daily about Pakistan's sponsorship of Islamic militants in Kashmir, they have also said just as frequently that they have no plans to initiate military attacks across the line that divides Kashmir between India and Pakistan -- at least not for now.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld in New Delhi yesterday with Defense Minister George Fernandes. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Shares Rise on Expectations That Fed Will Cut a Rate

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday in a broad rally led by technology issues as investors followed a familiar pattern of showing optimism just before a regular meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers.
 Investors expect the Fed to reduce the federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks by a half-percentage point, to 2 percent, when they meet today, according to trading in futures contracts on the rate. Some economists are expecting a smaller quarter-point decrease. 
 Traders have had ample opportunity to detect the pattern. The Fed has reduced rates nine times this year, with six of those cuts coming at regularly scheduled meetings. Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst for Jefferies & Company, described yesterday's market movement as the routine "day-before ramp-up." 
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index gained 47.92 points, or 2.7 percent, to 1,793.65. Technology shares also helped lift the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index by 15.64 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,102.84.
The Dow Jones industrial average was held to a slightly smaller gain, climbing 117.49 points, or 1.3 percent, to 9,441.03. Twenty-four of the 30 Dow stocks rose, but by smaller percentages than the stocks of some technology companies.
The only thing that should seem more familiar to investors, Mr. Hogan said, is anticipation of what he called "the day-after sell-off" -- the likelihood that stocks would retreat after the Fed makes its decision on interest rates.
Optimism about the Fed was not the only factor driving the market yesterday.
Many mutual funds end their fiscal years in October, and the managers of those funds sell many of their losing bets at the end of October and begin a round of fresh buying in November. This can contribute to what analysts call a liquidity-driven market, or one affected by the new investment of free cash.
"The portfolio managers have had such a tough year," said Ned Collins, a trader at Daiwa Securities America. "Every one of them is so terrified to miss a 5 or 10 percent uptick."
Adding to that effect, potentially, the Fed reported last week that the amount of money available in currency, traveler's checks, deposit accounts and money-market funds increased by $110 billion in September. It is difficult to know whether individual investors are putting new money into the market, but recent increases in the savings rate cast doubt on that possibility.
"The names that are really moving aren't moving because fundamentals have improved," said Brett Gallagher, vice president of Julius Baer Investment Management. "Investors seem to be very willing to look beyond the current quarter and next quarter and into the new year."
The blue-chip stocks that benefited from the day's optimism included General Motors, up $1.53, to $43.78; Home Depot, up $1.23, to $41.55; and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, up $2.30, to $110.50.
The biggest and most concentrated gains were in the technology sector. Microsoft rose $1.87, to $63.27, though the proposed settlement of its antitrust case in the United States was still in doubt and prosecutors in Europe indicated that they were still pursuing an antitrust case. Siebel Systems jumped $3.52, to $20.81; Intel gained 68 cents, to $26.96; and Oracle rose 51 cents, to $14.96.
Cisco Systems reported after the market closed that its profit excluding one-time items and revenue fell, but not as much as analysts had expected. The stock rose 64 cents, to $17.90, in anticipation of the report, then surged to $18.57 after hours.
P.G.& E. said its quarterly earnings tripled, to $771 million, as energy costs fell at its bankrupt Northern California utility, Pacific Gas and Electric, and its stock rose 43 cents, to $18.36. 
Still, investors seemed focused on the progress of the war against terrorism, and the gains in the stock market seemed to reflect bets that the government's efforts to stimulate the economy, with rate cuts and a package of tax breaks and spending, would bolster the economy.
"We've dismissed the economic data points, we've dismissed the corporate profits, we know they're lousy," said Joseph V. Battipaglia, chairman of investment policy for Gruntal & Company.
Even with the war on terrorism as an ever-looming wild card, analysts are still frustrated by the same factors that frustrated them before September -- "the real lack of any quality earnings that we've seen so far and real lack of any visibility to tell us when the economy's going to bottom," Mr. Collins said.
"I'm still a skeptic," he added, "but, boy, would I love to be wrong."

HEADLINE: Global Slump Is Blurring Line At Bank Units for Junk Bonds 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
To cope better with an increasing number of companies whose investment-grade debts have been reduced to junk status, J. P. Morgan Chase said today that it would combine certain parts of its European corporate bond operations.
 European high-grade trading and research will be rolled into one unit with high-yield trading and research, the bank said. Sales and syndication will still be handled separately. 
 High grade refers to companies with the best credit ratings, while high yield refers to those with poor credit ratings, whose bonds are known as junk bonds.
Investment banks have tended to segregate the two types of bonds because they attract different investors and require different analyses. But with a global economic slowdown making lending risks harder to quantify, banks have been experimenting with different approaches. Some Merrill Lynch credit analysts in the United States now cover both investment-grade and junk bonds. And Salomon Smith Barney is looking at ways to integrate the two more closely, a spokesman said.
Standard & Poor's is forecasting that companies with investment-grade debt will be unable to repay about $100 billion in loans in 2001, more than double the amount defaulted on last year and the highest rate since the agency began tracking the figure in the 1920's.
So far this year, Moody's Investors Service has downgraded the credit ratings of 49 companies to junk from investment grade, including the Dole Food Company, Hasbro and AMR, the American Airlines parent.
Tim Frost, J. P. Morgan Chase's head of European credit trading, said he expected the number of downgrades to rise. "With the cold winds of recession blowing through the world economy," he said, "there likely will be other companies falling on hard times."
The junk bond market in Europe is newer than that in the United States. But it is growing rapidly as the debt of former rising stars -- like Marconi, a British telecommunications equipment maker -- is reduced to junk status. For that reason, Mr. Frost said, he will still need to hire analysts and traders, even after combining the high-grade and high-yield operations, a restructuring that, for now, is limited to Europe.
Typically, companies with strong cash flows that analysts considered likely to repay loans were granted investment-grade status and able to borrow at close to current interest rates. The junk bond market, pioneered in the 1980's by Drexel Burnham Lambert's Michael R. Milken, affords companies with shakier credit profiles a way to raise money by paying higher returns to investors willing to assume higher risks.
Chris Francis, global head of credit research for Merrill Lynch, said the blurring line between investment-grade and junk bonds had led his firm to require some credit analysts to cover both.
"We are going into a more challenging environment for corporate credit," Mr. Francis said. "There is nothing to suggest that this trend has finished."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
The Mayor Was There For the Yanks

BYLINE:  By GEORGE VECSEY 

DATELINE: PHOENIX 

 BODY:
HE has had worse duties. The smile on the face of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani told everybody he knew the difference between a funeral and a losing clubhouse.
 This was late Sunday night. It had drizzled in Phoenix and Mariano Rivera had lost the seventh game of the World Series, which was even more shocking. 
 The mayor displayed the same state of grace that has emanated from him since the awful events of Sept. 11. After staring down prostate cancer, he experienced the World Trade Center falling down on his constituents and his friends and very nearly on him.
So the Yankees lost a seventh game.
"They gave us a great October," the mayor kept saying.
Now it was November and the Yankees had inexplicably faltered in the final inning of one of the great World Series anybody has witnessed. Giuliani knew it was no crime to lose to a team with two stalwarts like Curt Schilling and Randy Johnson.
There was a celebration going on in the middle of the field as a new baseball city celebrated its first world championship. The Yankees, of course, have 26.
"I like their team," the mayor said. "You could see why they got to the World Series."
The mayor's time clock was probably somewhere over Kansas. He had flown to Phoenix for Game 6 on Saturday night, sitting with Senator John McCain of Arizona, a kindred spirit.
"I appreciate the way we were treated," the mayor said. "And if you have to lose, it's better to lose to a city like this. These people sent us search-and-rescue crews." 
When the team of his heart could not clinch the World Series on Saturday, the mayor had flown back to make sure his city was functioning during the marathon, always the most joyous day of the year.
Then he got on a plane to Phoenix for Game 7, joining a group of family members of some of the victims of the disaster. He has ministered to people since Sept. 11, and if he wanted to be a surrogate fan, with access to good seats, he more than earned it. 
"This was a great World Series, like we had when I was younger," he was saying. "The Yankees against the Braves. The Yankees against the Dodgers. It seemed like they always went seven games. We got spoiled."
"I kept thinking we'd do it," he added. "Even with runners on base, I thought Mo would get a double play. Baseball is a game of inches."
He also praised Steve Finley's acrobatic catch in right-center field. This was fan talk, but the mayor was also seeing a much bigger picture.
"Let's keep the focus on what it meant to our October," he kept saying. "It was great for our economy, great for our spirit. It brought people and money into the city.
"I'm not that disappointed. The Yankees did everything they could. They were a symbol. They never gave up. They were out of it, and they came back. They are still champions."
He even saw some value in losing the seventh game of an epic World Series.
"It gives the city a sense of reality, what you can accomplish," he said. "This is a city that just got hit with the worst attack in the history of our country, but the people hung in there."
The players were dressing and heading for the bus that would take them into a winter of roster changes.
By now the mayor's aides were trying to rush him toward the charter back home. Today is Election Day. The new mayor must be confident enough to allow Rudolph Giuliani to help in the recovery of the city. But for now, the mayor still has the power to authorize a parade.
There had been speculation whether it was appropriate to stage a traditional ticker-tape parade for the Yankees. "Whatever they want," the mayor said. "I'll be talking to them tomorrow. Most teams don't want to celebrate if they finish second, but I'll do whatever they want."
The mayor spotted Rivera, carrying his overnight bag toward the doorway. He stepped closer and whispered things in Rivera's ear.
"You did great," was all one eavesdropper could hear.
Rivera, a stable man with a religious core, is not about to grieve all winter for a few pitches that got away. He smiled gracefully and moved out into the night. The mayor stayed a few more minutes, despite his watchful aides. These were his Yankees, and their clubhouse was a reassuring place for a fan who has been to too many funerals.
