HEADLINE: FURIOUS LOBBYING IS SET OFF BY BILL ON MENTAL HEALTH 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
A plan newly passed by the Senate to broaden health insurance coverage for mental illness has touched off an intense lobbying campaign on Capitol Hill as advocates for the mentally ill try to eliminate restrictions on care.
 The goal of the legislation is what the advocates describe as parity in insurance: the elimination of widespread limits on treatment for various forms of mental illness. 
 The measure, approved by the Senate last week and now headed for a conference with the House, would outlaw disparities in coverage between mental and physical illness under all group health plans sponsored by employers with more than 50 employees.
"All too often insurance discriminates against illnesses of the brain," said Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, who offered the proposal with Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota. 
Employers, insurance companies and some health maintenance organizations are lobbying against the proposal, saying it would drive up costs. 
"Health care inflation is back, and it's surging out of control," even without the proposed new requirement, said Karen M. Ignagni, president of the American Association of Health Plans, which represents H.M.O.'s.
Supporters and opponents of "mental health parity" say the lobbying is intense because the proposal stands a greater chance of enactment now than at any other time in the last decade. The drive for parity has gained momentum with the discovery that many mental illnesses have a biological basis and can be treated with drugs.
At present, people who are treated for mental illnesses like schizophrenia or depression often face higher co-payments and deductibles than they would have to pay if they were being treated for physical ailments, like diabetes or cancer. Likewise, many insurance plans cover fewer visits to a doctor, and fewer days of hospital care, when patients are treated for mental illness.
The Senate proposal was adopted by voice vote as an amendment to a bill providing money to the Department of Labor and the Department of Health and Human Services for the current fiscal year.
Mr. Domenici, who has a daughter with schizophrenia, and Mr. Wellstone, whose brother has severe mental illness, have been tenacious advocates, lining up 65 senators as co-sponsors of their proposal. The two authors have also worked with lobbyists from groups like the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, the National Mental Health Association, the American Psychiatric Association and the American Medical Association.
After meeting with advocates for the mentally ill, Mr. Domenici sounded confident. "We're on our way now," he said in an interview. "There's a real opportunity to change the entire landscape with reference to mental illness and to put more money into research, more money into facilities. If there's insurance coverage, there's going to be a lot of assets following these sick people around, just as there have been over time huge amounts of resources for other diseases because insurance companies covered them."
Nearly three dozen states and the federal government have experimented with various types of parity for their own employees, and they say the costs have not been significant, with premiums typically rising less than 1 percent.
Benefits for employees of private companies are regulated by a 1974 federal law, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, or Erisa. The Erisa Industry Committee, a coalition of large employers, has told Congress that the Domenici-Wellstone proposal would "lead to the misuse and overuse of mental health benefits." Moreover, it says, "many employers are likely to comply with the parity mandate by reducing coverage for other medical and surgical benefits, rather than by increasing coverage for mental health benefits."
The House recently passed legislation to extend a 1996 law that provided a very limited form of mental health parity. That law, which expired on Sept. 30, said health plans could not set more restrictive annual or lifetime dollar limits on mental health care than they set for the treatment of physical illnesses.
The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, estimated last year that 14 percent of employers were not complying with the 1996 law. Most of those companies, by their own account, had lifetime limits of $100,000 or less on mental health benefits and set higher ceilings for medical and surgical benefits. 
In addition, many health plans did what they were free to do under the 1996 law, setting higher co-payments and deductibles, and lower limits on outpatient visits and days of hospital care, for mental illness.
In a study on the new Senate legislation, the Congressional Budget Office reported these findings:
*Health insurance premiums would rise an average of 0.9 percent as a result of the bill.
*The bill would impose a mandate costing the private sector $23 billion over five years.
*The federal government would lose $2.2 billion of revenue in the next five years, and a total of $5.4 billion from 2002 to 2011, because workers would receive less of their compensation in taxable wages and more in tax-free fringe benefits.
Advocates for the mentally ill said they believed that the costs could be lower, based on the experience of states with mental-health-parity laws. The Senate bill specifically allows employers and health plans to use managed care techniques to help control costs.
Further, Senator Wellstone said broader coverage of mental health care would save money in the long run, by increasing the productivity of workers, reducing their absenteeism and lowering the level of crime committed by people with mental illness.
Ms. Ignagni, the lobbyist for H.M.O.'s, said, "We believe in the importance of mental health benefits, but we oppose the Senate bill because it would interfere with the ability of employers to design and customize health benefits for their employees."
Senator Debbie Stabenow, however, said there was no reason for insurers to discriminate against people with mental problems.
"Mental illness is as physical as any disease that is now covered by our insurance system," said Ms. Stabenow, Democrat of Michigan. "If you are a manic-depressive, that means you have chemicals in your brain that are off balance."

HEADLINE: Local Elections to Test the Nation's Mood 

BYLINE:  By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

 BODY:
In the first broad test of the nation's political mood since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, voters will go to the polls today to elect governors and legislatures in New Jersey and Virginia and mayors in a dozen or so major cities, including New York, Detroit, Houston, Seattle and Miami.
 The campaigning has been all over the election spectrum, with some contests focusing mainly on local issues like traffic congestion and property taxes, some on corruption and some on personalities. 
 But a subtext in many campaigns, and the main text in a few, has been the deteriorating economy and the need for strong security and strong leaders in the attacks' aftermath.
It was not clear heading into today's balloting how the economic, security and leadership issues would play out, whether they might end up being the deciding issues and a harbinger of the 2002 Congressional elections or end up as minor factors. For that matter, because so many issues were at play, there seemed to be a good possibility that hardly any voting trends would emerge. 
The governor's races in Virginia and New Jersey are partisan affairs, so they will provide bragging rights. But many of the mayoral contests are nonpartisan, and clear victories will be harder to claim.
Final polls in the governors' races give the edge to the Democrats. In Virginia, Mark R. Warner, a millionaire businessman, is running ahead of Mark L. Earley, a former attorney general. In New Jersey, James E. McGreevey, mayor of Woodbridge, was favored over Bret D. Schundler, a former mayor of Jersey City, in a race that wound down with a focus on terrorism.
In both contests, the Democratic candidates have outspent their Republican opponents, and in both states Republican ranks have been somewhat divided.
Democrats in New Jersey hold out more hope for gains in the Legislature than their counterparts in Virginia, one of the most Republican states in the nation.
The Virginia governor's race has been notable for the inroads Mr. Warner has made in Republican ranks by portraying himself as a conservative, despite Mr. Earley's bid to portray him as just another tax-and-spend liberal Democrat. Mr. Warner has courted conservative constituencies ranging from stock-car fans to gun owners, and since Sept. 11, he has sought out groups of police officers and other public safety officials, as has Mr. Earley.
Mr. Earley's biggest struggle has been to energize his base. There have been defections, in part out of frustration with top Republican leaders, among them Gov. James S. Gilmore III. Those leaders have spent much of the campaign squabbling over next year's budget.
Mr. Earley has also been sorely disappointed by a decision by President Bush, hugely popular in Virginia, to forgo campaigning there. 
Among the mayors' races, most attention has been focused on New York, where Michael R. Bloomberg, a billionaire Republican businessman, is running against Mark Green, a veteran of numerous Democratic campaigns. But several other big-city races merit watching, even if the political implications do not seem as great or the issues as pressing.
In Houston, the nation's fourth-largest city, Mayor Lee P. Brown is seeking a third two-year term and for a change is all but ignoring vexatious problems with traffic gridlock, air pollution and unbridled growth. Instead, he contends that what Houston most needs is an experienced mayor who knows how to lead and knows how to keep a city secure.
"Now is not the time for on-the-job-training in the mayor's office," Mr. Brown asserted, taking a dig at his two challengers in the nonpartisan contest, Orlando Sanchez and Chris Bell, City Council members who lack his 40 years in public service. Mr. Brown started as police rookie, rose to command the police departments of New York, Atlanta and Houston, then was drug czar in the Clinton administration before becoming Houston mayor in 1997.
Mr. Sanchez and Mr. Bell agree that leadership and security are a priority, but they contend that Mr. Brown has been inept.
Recent polls have Mr. Brown out front -- but not far enough to avoid a runoff, probably with Mr. Sanchez.
In Atlanta, a city with its fair share of budget, city services and safety problems, the big issue in the mayor's race is the scandal-plagued administration of Mayor Bill Campbell.
Mr. Campbell has not been charged with any crime but some of his associates have. The candidates seeking to succeed him -- Gloria Bromell-Tinubu, a former city councilwoman, Shirley Clarke Franklin, a former mayoral aide, and Robb Pitts, the City Council president -- are trying to outdo one another with boasts of ethical purity.
The contest, which is nonpartisan, looks tight. There could be a runoff.
In Detroit, where the contest also is nonpartisan and too close to call, the big issue is how to get the economy moving. The candidates are Gil Hill, the City Council president; and Kwame Kilpatrick, the minority leader of the Michigan House.
In Cincinnati, where there has been racial tension recently, Mayor Charles Luken, who is white, faces a strong challenge from a political newcomer, Courtis Fuller, who is black. Mr. Fuller is a former television news anchor, as is Mr. Luken.
In Seattle, a close, nonpartisan race for mayor between Greg Nickels, a county councilman, and Mark Sidran, the city attorney, focuses on what residents call the Seattle way.
As Mr. Nickels sees the "way," Seattle is at its best when it is governed by "inclusion." As Mr. Sidran sees it, inclusion is fine, but sometimes the only "way" to get things done is by confrontation.
In Miami, nine challengers are running against Mayor Joe Carollo, who was arrested on a domestic abuse charge that was later dropped. The race has focused on services, taxes and municipal scandals.

HEADLINE: General Musharraf's Visit 

 BODY:
Less than two months have passed since Pakistan's ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, shocked his country's military establishment and infuriated radical Islamic groups by disowning the Taliban and allying with the United States. Now he feels confident enough to travel to New York this week to speak at the United Nations, visit the World Trade Center site and meet with President Bush. 
 Americans have to hope General Musharraf's confidence is justified. Should his nationalist and fundamentalist enemies back home prevail, it will be immeasurably harder for Washington to defeat the Taliban and oust Osama bin Laden's terrorist network from Afghanistan. Even more important, Pakistan, with its 140 million people and more than a score of nuclear weapons, could fall into dangerous and unpredictable hands. 
 No Muslim political leader has risked as much for the United States as General Musharraf, and Washington has been right to reward him generously. Yet America's new embrace of Pakistan needs to be cautious, recognizing that many serious issues remain unaddressed. Islamabad has still not severed its ties to terrorist groups fighting Indian rule in Kashmir, its commitment to restraining future weapons development is uncertain and General Musharraf's own promises of restoring democracy are hedged with ambiguities.
Mr. Bush's challenge is to find ways of supporting President Musharraf and helping him at home by channeling substantial development aid to Pakistan's impoverished people while encouraging further policy changes. The United States should also make clear that it will not repeat its mistake of the early 1990's and disengage itself from Pakistan's problems after American military objectives in Afghanistan are achieved. 
It makes sense for the United States to invest in the political and economic stability of Pakistan. It is also right to bolster General Musharraf's diplomatic prestige. The changes he has been engineering since Sept. 11 go well beyond allowing Washington to use Pakistani airspace and bases. If he succeeds in disentangling its military intelligence services from the Taliban, Al Qaeda and Kashmiri terrorism and limits foreign funding of violent Islamic extremist groups, Pakistan's chances for democratic development would be much improved. Mr. Bush should press him to persevere and promise to help him and his country if he does.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Despite a downturn and the terror attacks, Cisco manages a quarter-to-quarter sales increase.

BYLINE:  By Chris Gaither 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO 

 BODY:
THE steep year-long slide of Cisco Systems has apparently ended. For the first time this calendar year, Cisco's revenue increased from one quarter to the next, surpassing its own projections of flat-to-slightly-weaker sales.
 Officially, the company posted a loss yesterday in its first fiscal quarter, as sales fell 32 percent from a year ago, but the results exceeded Wall Street's expectations. 
 John T. Chambers, Cisco's president and chief executive, predicted similar results in the current quarter. "We remain cautiously optimistic about the quarter and a flat-to-low single-digit growth" in revenue, he said, adding, "It would not surprise us to see orders vary on either side of these projections." 
Suffering from belt-tightening at telecommunications providers and networking companies, Cisco, which sells Internet routers and switches to those companies and others, said it lost $268 million, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter. The results contrasted sharply with the corresponding period last year, when Cisco earned $798 million, or 11 cents a share.
Sales were $4.4 billion, compared with $6.5 billion in the first quarter last year. But revenue improved from $4.3 billion in the fourth quarter, a 3 percent increase.
Excluding special items like acquisition costs and an $858 million investment write-down, Cisco reported a profit of $332 million, or 4 cents a share, compared with $1.4 billion, or 18 cents a share, last year. Using that method, common among companies but not accepted by standard accounting practices, analysts had expected a profit of 2 cents a share. 
Cisco's shares have more than doubled in the last month, and in regular trading before the company reported results, the stock gained 64 cents, to $17.90. In after-hours trading, shares rose 90 cents, to $18.80.
In a conference call with analysts, Mr. Chambers said Cisco's book-to-bill ratio was better than 1 during the quarter, meaning the company took in more orders for products than it shipped -- a sign of a growing market. Orders grew in Japan, South America, Canada and Europe, but declined in Asia and the United States, the sources of 58 percent of Cisco's bookings in the quarter.
The federal government was the only sector in the United States that placed more orders than during the previous quarter.
The first-quarter results would have been stronger if not for the fallout from the terrorist attacks, Mr. Chambers said. Before Sept. 11, the United States had been showing relatively strong signs of improvement, he said, leaving him prepared to forecast single-digit growth for the current quarter. Instead, he estimated the attacks took 5 percent from the company's revenue during the first quarter and predicted they would take another 5 percent from the current quarter. 
"The U.S. economy continues to show weakness, and the events of Sept. 11 have magnified the economic uncertainty," Mr. Chambers said. The attacks came at the midway point of Cisco's quarter. Mr. Chambers said orders had been flowing smoothly in the June-August period, and then suffered a "modest disruption" after the attacks.
Cisco rose to glory in the 1990's, briefly becoming the world's most valuable company. But the bursting of the Internet bubble and subsequent slowdown in capital spending by service providers took a heavy toll on Cisco. It posted its first quarterly loss in May and took a $2.2 billion charge.
Revenue in its services division improved over the previous year, to $792 million from $608 million, but sales of networking products declined sharply, to $3.66 billion from $5.91 billion. 
Analysts praised Cisco's handling of its internal operations to contend with a weakening business environment. "What I would point out is the dichotomy between their ability to manage their internals -- which was absolutely first rate -- versus the exogenous factors that even Cisco can't control," said Tad LaFountain, a managing director with the investment bank Needham & Company. 
Paul Sagawa of Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, one of the first analysts to predict a slowdown in technology investments, said Cisco performed better than he had predicted during several months of great economic uncertainty.
But he questioned whether that would continue. "It may be difficult for them to sustain this level of sequential increase for the next few quarters," Mr. Sagawa said.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
U.S. and Some States Split on Microsoft, Risking New Delay

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON with STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
The 18 states involved in the Microsoft antitrust case appeared headed for a sharp split today, with one group of attorneys general planning to sign onto the proposed settlement between the software giant and the Bush administration and another group preparing to challenge it, saying it leaves loopholes that would undermine provisions intended to promote competition. 
 After three days of intensive deliberations, only one state attorney general, Thomas F. Reilly of Massachusetts, officially announced his position. He said Massachusetts would seek to block the deal, concluding that it "may prove to be more harmful than helpful to competition and consumers." 
 Officials of other states skeptical of the agreement, which included Connecticut and California, spent the afternoon in a late-stage effort to persuade Microsoft and the Justice Department to reopen the proposed settlement to eliminate a variety of ambiguities and provisions that the states viewed as too lenient, lawyers involved in the negotiations said.
The attorney general of Illinois, Jim Ryan, suggested he would support the agreement, while the attorney general of New York, Eliot L. Spitzer, postponed a planned announcement of his endorsement after his efforts to strike a separate deal with Microsoft collapsed, the lawyers said. 
The failure of the Justice Department to gain the endorsement of all 18 states throws the proposed consent decree into question and creates a situation that antitrust experts said is without legal precedent. At the least, the disapproval by some states is likely to delay the resolution of the case for many months.
Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly of United States District Court in Washington has instructed the parties to outline their positions at a hearing here on Tuesday morning. She has suggested that she may conduct parallel proceedings to consider both the merits of the proposed consent decree and the objections raised by officials of some of the states. Her original schedule suggested that she would not decide what to do before late next spring at the earliest.
Career officials at the Justice Department who have spent years working on the antitrust suit were described today by the lawyers involved in the case as feeling deeply dissatisfied and betrayed by the proposed consent decree, which was negotiated and approved by political appointees of President Bush. 
Timothy Bresnahan, a Stanford University professor who was chief economist for the Justice Department's antitrust division in the Clinton administration, said, "This settlement amounts to the government taking a dive." Like some other people, Mr. Bresnahan criticized the settlement as very limited in its ambitions and backward-looking. The provisions, he said, would be useful mainly for the particular competitive circumstances of the case, which focused on the early commercialization of the Internet in the second half of the 1990's.
But Assistant Attorney General Charles A. James, the new head of the antitrust division, who led the Microsoft negotiations for the Bush administration, made clear last Friday that the terms of the deal were no longer negotiable. By early this evening, he appeared not to have changed his view that this was the best settlement the government could obtain.
Massachusetts became the first state to formally reject the proposed agreement and was expected to be joined by Connecticut, California and Wisconsin, people involved in the negotiations said. Lawyers from other states -- including Maryland, Michigan, Ohio and Iowa -- declined to comment, saying they would issue their decisions on Tuesday.
But the strongest criticism today came from Mr. Reilly of Massachusetts. "There's no question in my mind that Microsoft will use this agreement to crush competition," he said, "and they would have the imprimatur of the U.S. government to do it." He said that the Justice Department's news release describing the agreement as a substantial victory for consumers and competition "is not reflected by this agreement."
"They may think they nailed this down, but they didn't," Mr. Reilly said. He asserted that the states' study of the proposed settlement found flaws that made his decision to oppose it "a no-brainer," particularly in light of "Microsoft's repeated history of violating court orders and rules."
Officials of other states disagreed, and found the consent decree a positive step toward resolving the case.
Mr. Ryan, who is facing a tough Republican gubernatorial primary battle in Illinois, said he was likely to support the deal. "I am inclined to sign on," he said. "I am pleased that the Microsoft case appears headed for resolution and that Illinois consumers will have gained a freer and more competitive marketplace as a result."
Today's decision shifts the fragile federal-state alliance in a remarkable way. Some states and Washington, which had worked more or less together for the last three years, will now become adversaries in the remedy phase of the proceedings. 
Microsoft now has a warm new relationship with the Justice Department. Together, they will defend the proposed deal from the criticism of some states, other technology companies and consumer groups.
For both the dissenting states and the Justice Department, the procedural framework of the case has legal and political pitfalls. If the judge ultimately agrees with the states and toughens the consent decree, it would prove embarrassing for the Justice Department, whose senior officials have hailed the deal as a tough, landmark agreement in the face of a barrage of criticism.
But if the dissenters fail to obtain any major modifications to the deal, they would look foolish, particularly as they go about spending millions of dollars more from state treasuries that no longer enjoy surpluses.
The proposed settlement, according to some industry executives and experts who are advising the states, leans too much toward Microsoft in its details, phrasing and general approach. 
In the requirement that Microsoft disclose technical information, one of these people said, the document is riddled with exceptions that seem to give Microsoft continuing control. For example, he said, the release of technical information is set in motion during the beta, or test, phase of Windows system development, but that may be too late to ensure competition.
"I would prefer that it simply embrace the principle that competitors will get equal treatment with the Microsoft developers making software products that run on Windows," the person said. "The decree should say outside firms will be treated equally instead of giving Microsoft a head start."
Another provision of the settlement says Microsoft can refuse to disclose technical information if a company does not meet reasonable, objective standards established by Microsoft for qualifying as a viable business. That provision, an industry executive said, could be a loophole for Microsoft to keep information from a start-up with no track record, but whose technology could challenge one of Microsoft's products.
Still another provision, according to an expert advising the states, could be interpreted as protecting Microsoft's advantage in new markets by stipulating that Microsoft does not have to share technical information if doing so might "compromise the security" of its products. Specifically, the security exception applies to Microsoft's technology in digital rights management and online identification.
These are crucial technologies in the emerging markets for online media and Internet commerce, where Microsoft, not yet dominant, has many rivals.
"It appears that Microsoft has carved out exemptions to protect itself in the fields it deems important for its future," an industry executive said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS; 
Treasuries Increase as Nonmanufacturing Business Slumps

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after a survey showed that nonmanufacturing business slumped in October more than forecast, bolstering expectations that the Federal Reserve will cut the benchmark lending rate half a percentage point at its policy meeting today.
 Ten-year notes have gained in seven of the last nine sessions, as signs of a worsening economic slowdown have prompted investors to increase their Fed rate-cut forecasts to a half-point from a quarter-point. 
 The decline in the survey, the National Association of Purchasing Management's nonmanufacturing index, added to the evidence that the economy has fallen into a recession. 
"The weak economic data we've seen should push the Fed over the top," said Michael Cloherty, government bond strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. He forecast a half-point cut in the overnight interbank rate, known as federal funds, to a 40-year low of 2 percent.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 16/32 , to a price of 105 19/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.29 percent from 4.35 percent on Friday. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 1 19/32 , to 108 3/32 . The bond's yield fell to 4.85 percent from 4.95 percent on Friday.
On Friday, 15 of the 24 economists surveyed at institutions that trade directly with the Fed forecast a half-point cut at today's meeting. A month ago, none of the primary dealer economists surveyed expected more than a quarter-point cut. Forty-seven of 84 economists polled in another Bloomberg survey also expected a half-point cut.
"Investors can expect a sub-2 percent Fed funds rate to be a feature of financial markets through 2002," said Rory Robertson, interest-rate strategist at Macquarie Equities. "The 10-year Treasury note is not as expensive as many perceive."
The gain in bonds followed Friday's tumble and a surge on Wednesday and Thursday, after the government said it would stop selling them.
"People who missed the rally of last week" are buying 30-year bonds, said Jim Claire, director of bond trading at the Evergreen Investment Management Company in Charlotte, N.C., which has $250 billion in stocks and bonds under management.

HEADLINE: Swissair Makes Deal With E.D.S. 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
The beleaguered Swissair Group said today that it had agreed to sell its ticketing and reservations unit, Atraxis, to Electronic Data Systems as it begins shedding its profitable subsidiaries.
 E.D.S., the American computer services company, must still receive regulatory approval to acquire Atraxis, which has 1,400 employees and specializes in airline reservations, airport management and air transport information services. 
 Terms of the sale were not disclosed.
The Atraxis Group is one of three Swissair subsidiaries that have been struggling with their finances recently because they have not been paid by the parent company. The information technology service, which serves 60 airlines and 40 airports around the world, had $400 million in revenue last year. But the booking company, based in Zurich, had become mired in the continuing financial difficulties of its parent group, Swissair, which filed for protection from creditors last month after piling up more than $10 billion in debt as its strategy to expand by taking stakes in regional European carriers failed. 
Its wobbly finances were pushed over the edge by the slump in international travel that followed the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States. Switzerland's government, banks and leading industries patched together a $2.5 billion rescue plan that still faces challenges.
A big challenge came last week when the Swiss government announced that it would refuse to release the first installment of its cash assistance to Swissair without financial guarantees for the continued running of Atraxis as well as Swissair's ground handling company, Swissport, and its maintenance firm, SR Technics.
The refusal to provide cash to keep Swissair's long-haul flights running threatened a second grounding of the fleet. Swissair was grounded for two days last month when it ran out of money and the government-industry package was negotiated. The cash crunch also threatened the effort to merge Swissair's long-haul operations with its former regional subsidiary, Crossair, to create a new, slimmed-down national airline.
In a bit of brinkmanship, the Swiss government last week set a deadline for the regional government authorities -- especially in Zurich, where Swissair's hub is located -- and the banks to kick in more cash to make up the subsidiaries' shortfall. Atraxis received $21 million to keep it running until the end of the month.
Its sale had been touch and go with Lufthansa of Germany and I.B.M. pulling out of the bidding, leaving E.D.S. to scoop up the ticketing service.
SR Technics received a $61.3 million loan to keep it running, and bidders are negotiating for the baggage and freight handler Swissport.
The government bailout package still faces challenges from disgruntled employees, however, who are demanding that officials provide a benefits package that would provide assistance beyond the unemployment benefits they would normally be entitled to receive. Over the weekend, the Swiss president, Moritz Leuenberger, rejected such assistance. 
Indicating the continuing political sensitivity of the Swissair debacle, Mr. Leuenberger also said that the government planned an inquiry into the airline's collapse. The investigation, which may take up to a year, is expected to pinpoint blame in the debacle, and perhaps make former Swissair officials liable for at least some damages.
The Belgian airline Sabena, which is partly owned by Swissair, also said today that it would be suspending flights on Wednesday. There was no announcement on how long the suspension would last.
According to Reuters, trade unions reported that management had told them on Friday that since no new investors had been found, there was a big chance that the Sabena holding company would be put into liquidation this week.
Burdened by its own debts, Swissair reneged on its pledges to provide Sabena with financing. It took a 49.5 percent stake in the carrier as part of its expansion plan.

HEADLINE: Terror Follows Immigrants to America 

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN 

 BODY:
Immigrants who came to America to escape strife-torn nations and start businesses in the homeland of entrepreneurship are suddenly facing some of the same fears they had fled. They came here from the Middle East, from the former Soviet bloc, from Africa, from Latin America. They left so they would never again have to worry about governments regulating their every move or bombs exploding in the streets or mustard missiles slamming into their homes.
 And that is precisely what has made the last two months so painful for so many of them: it is as if terror has followed them around the world. 
 In 1979, after the shah was ousted and Islamic militants seized American hostages, Jeniette Melamed fled Iran for the United States. Ms. Melamed, then the 20-year-old daughter of a Tehran tailor, objected to the new regime's harsh religious rhetoric and its curbs on freedom and yearned for a country that would let her pursue her entrepreneurial instincts. Even more, she longed for a stable and free society in which to live.
She got both. Arriving in New York with little money and even less English, she moved to Los Angeles and became a hostess at an International House of Pancakes, working her way through school. In 1982, she and her new husband, Hamid, moved back to New York and she opened a beauty salon with four employees on Fourth Avenue. The business has since grown into a day spa on East 13th Street with 25 employees, most of them recent immigrants. "I could not have had this business in Iran," she said.
Like untold millions of other Americans, Ms. Melamed, 43, has also discovered the serenity of suburbia. She lives in a three-bedroom home on a tree-lined street in Brookfield, N.Y., with Hamid, a grocer and owner of a Middle Eastern restaurant in Roslyn, and her two children, aged 14 and 10. She drives a Mercedes and the family takes an annual vacation in February, usually in Puerto Rico.
For more than two decades, Ms. Melamed could not read about the warfare and political upheavals of the Middle East without shuddering -- and thanking God that she had escaped it all, even though she says she still loves and misses her homeland.
Then came Sept. 11 -- and suddenly she brushed up against the horror that she thought she had left behind forever. She was on the Long Island Rail Road commuting to work when she heard about the planes that hit the World Trade Center; she arrived at her shop in time to see the second building collapse. She sent her staff home and waited to make sure they were safe before she left. Since then, she has been gripped by crying jags and smoke-filled nightmares.
"For many years I told my kids: 'This is the best country. We are free. We are wonderful; anyone can be president. In the United States, if you're not lazy, you'll never go hungry.' "
"Now, though, it's tough," Ms. Melamed said. "I'm afraid for my kids, for their futures. It's not fair. They took the flavor out of New York."
Her sister, Rosa Melamed, 46, who like Jeniette, uses her maiden name, has made the same emotional journey. She moved to New York in 1988 with her husband and young daughter after Iraqi missiles shattered her country. "America was the house of hope, the land of promise," she said.
Then, for a few minutes on Sept. 11, she thought she was back home in Iran. "Everyone was going crazy and I said, 'Don't cry, it's normal,' " she recalled. "Then I realized for me it was normal, it was normal in Iran, but for everyone else it wasn't."
John Ivanac experienced a similar role reversal. Mr. Ivanac made his way to the United States in 1966 at 26 to escape the communism and economic stagnation of his native Croatia, then part of communist-ruled Yugoslavia. Ten years ago, Mr. Ivanac was frantically telephoning his relatives in Croatia during the war with Serbia, not knowing if the calls would get through or even if anyone was alive to pick them up.
But on Sept. 11, the calls flooded in the opposite direction from his relatives to his two Midtown Manhattan restaurants, Villa Berulia and Trio.
"For three weeks, I've been so depressed," Mr. Ivanac said. The attacks on the World Trade Center, he said, "affected me more than the war in Croatia.
"I knew there was a war there, and when there is a war, whether you like it or not, someone's going to die," he added. "But this wasn't a war; this was a regular working day." Since then, he said, his business is down 30 percent.
Some visitors from troubled foreign lands are even wondering if it would be safer to go back home. Wahila Alam, a 28-year-old Pakistani physician, came to New York a year ago to work as an H.I.V.-treatment project researcher with Doctors of the World, a humanitarian organization that deploys medical professionals both here and abroad.
When she arrived, Dr. Alam thought she had left behind the fears and uncertainties endemic in countries like Pakistan that are in perpetual political turmoil. But for eight hours on Sept. 11, she was unable to locate her husband, who worked as a transportation engineer three blocks from the trade center.
"I was terrified," she said. "When I found out he was safe I thanked God, but afterward you're scared. What's next? Is it safe to be here? Is it really worth staying here?"
She has decided to do so. And other long-time immigrants who have taken American citizenship say they are not plagued by such doubts and trumpet their patriotism.
"This is by far the greatest country in the world," said George Feldenkreis, the chairman and chief executive of Perry Ellis International, the Miami-based maker of men's clothing. Mr. Feldenkreis, a Cuban Jew, came to Florida in February 1961, two months before the Bay of Pigs invasion. He remembers a world where bombs exploded in Havana restaurants, friends were arrested for speaking out against the government and soldiers gripped machine guns while standing guard. And that was the country his parents had chosen as a haven after they fled persecution in the Ukraine.
"The Americans have been very lucky that we have been able to have a very free country with unlimited movement," he said. "The U.S. is one of the few countries in the world that has never been touched. We are all very concerned that our way of life will be changed forever. But I've lived through situations in life and I tell my son, 'This too shall pass. We'll get used to it.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jeniette Melamed, left, owner of a day spa on East 13th Street in Manhattan, and her sister, Rosa Melamed, who works with her, fled Iran at different times for America. (Aaron Lee Fineman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Japanese Drug Makers' Profits Are Strong 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Japanese pharmaceutical companies, long derided overseas as copycat drug makers, are booking better-than-expected profits this fiscal year, providing one of the few highlights in an otherwise bleak earnings landscape.
 The country's largest pharmaceutical company, Takeda Chemical Industries, said today that its net income jumped 45 percent in the six months ended Sept. 30. The results, which beat the company's estimates by 17 percent, were helped by strong sales of two drugs that fight high blood pressure and ulcers. 
 In a rare display of confidence in Japan's weakened market, Takeda, whose best-selling product is Blopress, a drug that helps reduce blood pressure, raised its full-year profit forecast nearly 8 percent to 232 billion yen ($1.9 billion) for the year ending March 2002. 
Takeda expects domestic sales of Blopress to increase 50 percent in the full year and sales of Takepron, which treats ulcers, to gain 70 percent from a year earlier, Yuzuru Takagi, a Takeda corporate planning official, told Bloomberg News.
The brighter outlook contrasts with the stream of bad news from the country's electronics companies, steel makers and banks, which are cutting thousands of jobs and shutting factories.
Takeda and other drug makers, on the other hand, are benefiting from greater deregulation of Japan's $20 billion prescription drug market, a series of well-received products and, statistically, the fastest-aging population in the world. They are also shedding their image as copiers of drugs developed overseas.
"In the past five years, we've seen an emergence of a handful of Japanese companies developing some world-class research," said Jean-Pascal Rolandez, a strategist at BNP Paribas Securities in Tokyo.
The Sankyo Company, one of Japan's largest pharmaceutical businesses, will also probably beat its first-half earnings estimates when it reports on Nov. 14. The company's best-selling drug, Mevalotin, combats cholesterol and was helped when Takeda had to pull its anticholesterol offering, Baycol, off the shelves in August.
The Yamanouchi Pharmaceutical Company, another of the industry's biggest players, raised its half-year profit forecast 17 percent on Oct. 25.
Takeda's growth is more striking because it overcame several setbacks in recent months. The company, based in Osaka, recalled not only Baycol, which is made by Bayer, but also Calan, which fights strokes.
Takeda also ran afoul of the United States Justice Department, which accused TAP Pharmaceutical Products, a joint venture of Takeda and Abbott Laboratories of Abbott Park, Ill., of defrauding the Medicare and Medicaid system. TAP Pharmaceutical settled the case by paying a record $875 million in fines.
Regardless, pharmaceutical companies are benefiting as the Japanese people spend more on medicine. On average, each person pays 235,800 yen ($1,940) a year for medicine, doctor visits and other care, 42 percent more than a decade ago. Nearly 8 percent of that money is spent on medicine, two-and-a-half times the level a decade ago.
Spending on medicine has increased even as prices have declined. The government has loosened the rules that govern the sale of prescription drugs, making it easier for retailers to sell generic varieties. The Health, Labor and Welfare Ministry, which sets base prices for drugs every two years, will probably cut minimum targets again next year to reduce the burden on the debt-laden national health care system.
The cuts, however, will not severely hurt profit margins at Japanese drug makers because sales increases will continue to outpace the price declines. The government is careful to trim prices only gradually so as not to undercut the domestic manufacturers, analysts said.
Investors, too, do not appear concerned about the probable decline in drug prices. Shares in drug companies have gained 10.6 percent since the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States, which increased fears of a recession in Japan. The benchmark Nikkei 225 Index has gained just 3.3 percent over the same period.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
A Cross of Dollars

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
When Franklin Roosevelt took the United States off the gold standard in 1933, his budget director was aghast. "This is the end of Western civilization!" he declared. In fact, the real threat to civilization was the Depression and its political consequences, and one shudders to think what might have happened if Roosevelt hadn't defied monetary orthodoxy.
 Unfortunately, that old-time economic religion, with its narrow-minded insistence on monetary rectitude at the expense of every other consideration, has had a revival in recent years, thanks largely to the promotional efforts of right-wing think tanks. And that ideology, more than anything else, is responsible for Argentina's looming catastrophe. 
 As little as three years ago Argentina's "currency board" monetary system was the subject of extravagant praise in publications like Forbes and The Wall Street Journal, and economists at the Cato Institute established lucrative consulting practices advising other countries to mimic Argentina's approach. 
Why this enthusiasm on the right? Basically, the currency board -- introduced in 1991 to reassure investors -- returned the country to the gold standard, except that greenbacks took the place of ingots. To prevent future inflation, the system rigidly pegged the value of the peso at one dollar, and left very little discretion in monetary policy.
So what went wrong? You might think, given all the talk of debt default, that the problem was government profligacy. But Argentina's budget deficit has ranged between 1 and 3 percent of G.D.P., not bad for a depressed economy, and its government debt is only about half of G.D.P., better than many European countries. By the numbers, Argentina's fiscal picture looks better than America's did a decade ago.
The real problem with Argentina isn't fiscal, it's economic. The country is now in its fourth year of grinding recession. But the rigidity of its monetary system, designed to protect against inflation, precludes any of the actions that countries normally take to fight deflation, such as cutting interest rates or letting the currency depreciate. Instead, Argentina has gone through wave after wave of fiscal austerity, each time with the promise that the latest round of wage and job cuts would restore confidence and produce economic recovery. But austerity has not brought recovery. On the contrary, it has worsened the recession, increased social tension and further reduced confidence.
The natural answer is to remove the straitjacket: let the peso float, and do what is necessary to save the economy. That's what Britain did in 1931 and again in 1992, both times to its advantage; even Brazil, forced off its currency peg in 1999, found that floating its currency greatly improved its economic position. 
Admittedly, the fact that much private debt in Argentina is indexed to the dollar means that a peso devaluation might create financial problems. But as Ricardo Haussman, former chief economist of the Inter-American Development Bank (and a strong advocate of sound money), has pointed out, there is an answer: Simply issue a decree canceling the indexation. It's a radical solution, but the situation is desperate, and there is precedent: it's more or less what Roosevelt did in 1933. And some investment bankers have privately supported such a plan for months. 
But since last spring conservative economists in the U.S. have been urging Argentina to preserve its dollar peg and default on its debt instead. And that's what's happening. 
I've written before about an apparent double standard for economic policy in the third world, but this is truly bizarre. Advanced countries often devalue their currencies -- but Argentina is being told that it can't. On the other hand, advanced countries never default on their debt -- but Argentina is being told that it must. And this even though Argentina isn't heavily in debt by normal standards, and default -- which won't let Argentina cut interest rates, won't make its goods more competitive and won't end the need for draconian fiscal austerity -- will do nothing to end the economic crisis. 
It's hard to believe that Argentina will sacrifice not just its economy but its credit rating on the altar of a discredited monetary theology. But as you read this, Argentine officials are crucifying their long-suffering nation on a cross of dollars. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
Politics and Curriculum: How History Is Taught

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein 

 BODY:
IN 1954, my eighth-grade history teacher in Queens said we could not use the term "Civil War" but must adopt a textbook phrase, "War Between the States."
 Her instruction was not really about history, but about the controversies of her own day. By saying that the war a century earlier had mostly concerned states' rights, teachers and textbooks minimized the role of slavery and dampened support for a nascent civil rights struggle. 
 Today's texts again call it the Civil War. 
I was reminded of this by recent Asian protests over how schools in Japan teach about World War II. Koreans, for instance, have denounced a new Japanese text that says Japanese troops "advanced on," rather than "invaded," the Asian mainland. The book also ignores the "comfort women," Koreans used as sex slaves by Japanese soldiers.
This, too, is not only about history. It reflects debates about Japan's current policy toward Asia.
The interplay of politics and curriculum is the subject of "Censoring History" (M. E. Sharpe, 2000), edited by Laura Hein and Mark Selden. The book recalls a slogan from Orwell's "1984": "Who controls the past controls the future." That is true not only of totalitarians; every nation tries to shape the future when it teaches history.
In Germany, war crimes in World War II are acknowledged more forthrightly than in Japan, partly because German policy now favors European unity. Remorse for aggression and genocide was needed to win the confidence of former victims.
But German texts give little attention to how the country's big businesses participated in forced labor and extermination policies. Many of those companies are still important, and so it is not surprising that the curriculum papers over their wartime roles. In contrast, corporate collaboration with the Nazis was emphasized in East German texts before reunification.
Curriculum controversies have also flared elsewhere. A decade ago, when a Mideast peace seemed more feasible, Israeli texts described the many Palestinians who were forced from their homes in the 1948 war. Now that peace prospects have receded, books focus on the Palestinians, also numerous, who left voluntarily.
Asia provides several examples of the interplay.
After Japan's surrender in 1945, officers of the American occupation force and Japanese democratic leaders blamed the schools there, saying they had inculcated blind obedience. Early postwar texts encouraged the questioning of authority in general and the emperor in particular -- even 19th-century peasant rebellions got attention -- and did not mince words about Japanese aggression. 
But when the cold war took hold, occupation leaders wanted Japan to remilitarize against the Soviet Union. Criticism of wartime policy was muted as textbooks aimed to stir patriotism.
The pendulum swung back in the 1970's. Books again mentioned World War II atrocities, like Japan's massacre of civilians in the Chinese city of Nanjing. This textbook shift occurred at a time when Japan wanted other Asians to feel less threatened by Japanese economic leadership.
The protests this year about Japanese aggression and use of comfort women in World War II stem from a new text by Nobukatsu Fujioka. Mr. Fujioka, leader of a conservative group, was angered by what he deemed slights to Japanese honor -- for example, the United States' blocking Japan from leading a bailout of East Asian nations in the 1997 currency crisis. He aimed to write a text that instilled national pride. 
In South Korea today, students learn that World War II began in 1895, when Japan invaded their country. Leaders hoping to discourage future Japanese influence want to portray the war as a reflection of continuing Japanese imperialism.
But Korean texts gloss over collaboration by the nation's elite with Japanese colonial authorities in the first half of the 20th century. Telling that story could tarnish some leaders' present legitimacy. For similar reasons, historians in France also argue about what children should learn of their country's collaboration with the Nazis.
American texts once described slaves as content with their lot, and slave masters as benevolent. Books today describe both the inhumanity of American slavery and the genocide practiced against Indians.
But many textbooks still tiptoe around causes and conduct of the Vietnam War, to avoid stirring up political divisions dating from that era. For example, many historians say President Lyndon B. Johnson escalated the war for fear of domestic political accusations that he had lost a nation to communism, not only for national security reasons. Most texts don't discuss that. 
Arguments about textbooks only partly concern what is true. From the many facts to teach, we often select those that support adult goals. Because a democracy must argue about goals, we also argue about how to teach history. The fights will not end, and should not.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
E-mail won't soon replace regular mail in the direct marketer's reach for new customers.

BYLINE:  By Bernard Stamler 

 BODY:
PITY the poor direct marketer.
 The generally sour economy is one problem. And the continuing crisis in the nation's mail system is another, making people wary of opening unsolicited or strange-looking letters. 
 Unfortunately, those letters are the lifeblood of many a direct marketer's customer-acquisition campaign. As a result, an industry that was already hurting before Sept. 11 is in deepening trouble. 
In response, some in the industry have been holding back on their mailings, at least temporarily. At the suggestion of the Direct Marketing Association, which held its 84th annual convention last week in Chicago, others have announced plans to alter their mail packaging to make it appear less threatening -- by using windowed envelopes, for example, and including clear return addresses. Still others wonder whether they should, at last, turn from regular mail to e-mail as a means to obtain new customers.
The answer is probably not, at least not yet.
"I don't see people switching to e-mail," said H. Robert Wientzen, the chief executive of the Direct Marketing Association. "I tell people that it's coming, but nothing is as ubiquitous as the regular mail. It's still the most effective medium we have."
Mr. Wientzen's comment reflects the consensus among direct marketers. E-mail has its advantages -- incredibly low costs, for one, since it requires no postage or paper or printing to pay for. And e-mail works well for retaining and marketing to existing customers who have given permission to be reached electronically (logically enough, this is called permission e-mail).
But e-mail remains relatively ineffective as a way to generate new sales leads, which are traditionally garnered from mass mailings to consumers whose names appear on mailing lists that marketers rent from list brokers or other sources.
Why doesn't cold e-mail work? Many people dislike direct mail of any kind, routinely discarding it unopened. But an even greater percentage of recipients seem to loathe its Internet equivalent, disparagingly called spam. These consumers routinely delete unsolicited messages without even reading them. Add to that a relative paucity of available e-mail address lists, containing far fewer names than do traditional mailing lists.
As a result, e-mail acquisition mailings yield relatively low response rates compared with regular mail and can actually cost much more for each lead generated.
Jim Nail, online marketing and advertising analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., says e-mail lists are often priced unrealistically high. "People who own e-mail lists have this delusion that their lists are worth $100 to $150" for 1,000 names, he said. "They should be charging $30 to $40."
Rates vary, of course, both online and off, depending on a number of variables like the nature and cost of the product to be promoted. Sellers of higher-priced products are able to pay far more to acquire customers than vendors of cheaper wares can justify. Still, list costs are higher for e-mail than for regular mail across the board, according to Jared Blank, an analyst for Jupiter Media Metrix. Though market realities have lately pushed rates downward, they "are still too high," he said.
In a recent report, Jupiter found that although the average cost of renting an e-mail list has declined to $125 for 1,000 names from $200 last year, the response rate was such that the total cost of acquiring one customer through e-mail rose to $125 from $114.
That is much more than the average industrywide cost through ordinary mail -- $66 a customer last year, according to Jupiter, including production and postage as well as the cost of renting the mailing list, which averaged $110 for 1,000 names.
The trend is directly traceable to jaded consumers who delete unsolicited e-mail messages with more dispatch now than before, Mr. Blank said, a trend that most people say will only accelerate.
So, beyond the obvious -- better lists at lower rates -- what can the industry do to make e-mail marketing work better?
Some believe that the answer is to transform acquisition e-mail into permission e-mail. In a technical sense this is already happening: when consumers agree to receive e-mail from one company, they are often agreeing to accept it from others who may rent a list with their names on it as well. That does not mean, though, that consumers will read what they get, since e-mail from unfamiliar companies still looks like spam in the in box, with or without permission.
Better to get direct permission from people who are not yet customers. To do that, marketers have to "incentivize them," said Jonathan Jackson, senior analyst for online marketing at eMarketer Inc. That means giving them something they want, he said, and advertising it in banners, in other Internet ads and even in print ads with a company's Internet address prominently displayed. Prospects will then presumably go to the site and opt in to receive e-mail.
According to Gideon Sasson, executive vice president of the active trader group at Charles Schwab Inc., the technique works. His company does "a bunch of things" to generate leads, including buying lists, but also "introducing offers to prospects" on its Web site. To entice noncustomers who view the site, Schwab also offers a number of features, including a daily e-mail summary sent to customers that tells them exactly what happened to their stocks that day.
"People love it," he said of the feature, called My Closing Summary. And it gets them in as customers, ready to receive more e-mail from Schwab.
Which, of course, is exactly the point.

HEADLINE: Text of Federal Reserve's Statement 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve after its monetary policy-making panel announced that it had decided to reduce interest rates:
 The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to lower its target for the federal funds rate by 50 basis points to 2 percent. 
In a related action, the board of governors approved a 50 basis point reduction in the discount rate to 1.5 percent. 
 Heightened uncertainty and concerns about a deterioration in business conditions both here and abroad are damping economic activity. For the foreseeable future, then, the committee continues to believe that, against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness.
Although the necessary reallocation of resources to enhance security may restrain advances in productivity for a time, the long-term prospects for productivity growth and the economy remain favorable and should become evident once the unusual forces restraining demand abate.
In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved the request submitted by the board of directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond.

HEADLINE: Nyon Journal; 
Sky Falls In on the Swiss: Tranquillity Is a Victim

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: NYON, Switzerland, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Switzerland's image is that of an orderly country, smooth as its fabled chocolate, whose trains run as precisely as its watches and where crime does not exist, companies are profitable, and even the president takes public transport to work.
 But all that has been battered during the last six weeks by a string of crises unlike any in recent Swiss memory. 
 In late September, the tranquillity and security for which Switzerland is famed were shattered when a disgruntled gunman walked into the regional parliament in a wealthy area not far from Zurich and shot dead 14 local officials.
Days later, the indecorous collapse of the national airline, Swissair, scarred Switzerland's reputation for efficiency and reliability. 
Next, on Oct. 24, Switzerland's engineering marvel, the St. Gotthard Tunnel linking northern and southern Europe through the Alps, turned into an inferno, killing 11 people when two trucks collided.
Now, bowing to the necessity and cost of heightened security, Switzerland has agreed to allow the prestigious gathering of world economic leaders held at the ski resort of Davos every year for 32 years to be moved to New York. 
The forum and its elite agents of global capitalism had come under siege in recent years by unruly hoards of antiglobalization protesters. Now, on top of all their other setbacks, the Swiss have been left to wonder whether Davos man is now extinct. 
"I feel very insecure now," said Cornelia Mayinger, a psychologist who works on integrating immigrants near Zurich. "A lot of things have happened and I'm asking myself, 'What will it be next week?' "
Coming in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks in America, which sent shudders around the globe, the cumulative effect of these discete disasters has been akin to an Alpine avalanche. 
There is a sense of gathering, swelling catastrophe, a "rude awakening," as Christof Wamister wrote in the daily Basel newspaper Basler Zeitung, for a country that always prided itself on being an exemplary, special place.
"These things have never happened here, not in my lifetime," said Annelies Klarer, 67, who runs a sewing shop on a side street of this old Roman town. 
The rapid collapse of the country's 70-year-old airline -- "it's something close to my age" -- staggered everyone, she said.
The bankruptcy, the slayings in the affluent town of Zug near Zurich and even the collapse of the tunnel stunned the country in part because they were inflicted by the Swiss on themselves, not by outsiders.
"The Swiss can't blame someone else," Mrs. Mayinger said. "But we believe we are very special, and that makes it very difficult to change." 
Unease stems too from the creeping realization that hard as the go-it-alone Swiss have tried, the outside world has intruded. 
Far from being an island, Switzerland's population of 7.2 million is today 20 percent foreign-born. Once mostly laborers, these people are today more likely to be professional workers drawn by the booming economy of recent years, employed on better terms and exercising a greater influence on society. 
Though the Swiss are virtually alone among Europeans in refusing to join the European Union, they have anyway become more and more dependent on foreign markets. Those tighter economic ties have also circumscribed their choices. 
The multibillion dollar bailout of Swissair by the government had to be drawn up with an eye on possible objections from the European Union, which frowns on government subsidies to airlines and could have deprived Swissair of vital landing rights.
At the same time, Switzerland's sacrosanct banking secrecy has once again come under increased scrutiny, this time not as a haven for dictators' money but as a possible cover for terrorists. 
Britain's treasury secretary, Gordon Brown, caused a furor here after Sept. 11 by labeling Switzerland a "weak link" in the drive to ferret out terrorist funds. 
Profitable as it is, government officials strenuously defend bank secrecy, but surveys suggest that the public is far less wedded to a practice that often seems to bring unwanted attention. 
As for the killings in Zug, they punctured national pride and practice, being carried out by a Swiss and with a type of gun issued to all men here, so that they can be prepared if called upon to defend the country.
The action was also seen as an assault on Switzerland's traditionally open, participatory democracy -- the mixture of referendums and accessible government devised to keep the country's three cultures and four languages bound together.
Within days of the killings, checkpoints sprang up at federal and cantonal office buildings, and officials, barely guarded normally, got more protection -- even against their will. 
Then, on the day of national mourning for Zug's victims, Swissair ran out of cash.
The airline was grounded for two days with scenes -- repeatedly broadcast on television -- of 40,000 passengers stranded without food or beds. Known nationally as Switzerland's ambassador to the world, Swissair had been more than a giant national enterprise.
"It's part of our blood," said Daniel Haener of the Swiss Foreign Ministry. "When I was a small boy, I didn't know what it was to be Swiss, but I knew what Swissair was." 
The quick succession of blows to the national psyche have prompted an outpouring of letters to the Geneva-based daily Le Temps and left Swiss to wonder whether their country is, after all, like anywhere else. 
"There's a fragility now," said a journalist there, Joelle Kuntz. "People are worried that some of these things that happened in America could happen here."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Technology Shares Lead Gains After Fed Cuts Rates

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks ended sharply higher yesterday after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates a half a percentage point and hinted it might cut more to bolster the sagging economy.
 "The Fed is clearly on our side and will remain so until we've seen concrete evidence of a turn in economic activity," said Ned Riley, chief investment strategist at State Street Global Advisers, referring to Wall Street's initial reaction. 
 The Fed cut its federal funds rate -- a benchmark for short-term interest rates -- for the 10th time so far this year to 2 percent, its lowest level in 40 years. Lower rates reduce borrowing costs for businesses and consumers, pumping up spending. 
Major market indexes at first seesawed the unchanged mark after the Fed's announcement, but steadily racked up gains as investors put aside worries about an increasingly grim economic environment and, instead, focused on hopes the Fed's aggressive easing could ignite a recovery next year.
"Nothing's happened so far, and they've cut a lot, so that's bothering some people," said Henry Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed, which oversees $35 billion.
"On the other hand," he added, "another 50 basis points can't be construed as not a constructive development for economic activity."
Technology stocks, bolstered early in the day by an upbeat outlook from the technology bellwether Cisco Systems, led the climb. Its shares rose 57 cents, to $18.47. The Nasdaq composite index rose 41.43 points, or 2.3 percent, to close at 1,835.08.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 150.09 points, or 1.6 percent, to 9,591.12, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 16.02 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,118.86. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
(By Bloomberg News)
Treasury bond prices rose after the Federal Reserve cut the benchmark lending rate by a half-percentage point and signaled it may lower it again to reverse an economic slowdown.
The Fed's rate reduction, the 10th this year, to 2 percent, added to a two-year-old rally in Treasuries that has pushed the yield on benchmark two-year notes to a 43-year low. The Fed said it is concerned the economic slump is deepening, which prompted investors to buy more Treasuries on the expectation of another cut in the overnight interbank rate next month.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 9/32 , to a price of 105 28/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, declined to 4.26 percent from 4.29 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 1/32 , to 108 4/32 . The bond's yield was unchanged at 4.85 percent.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Lifetime Caring for Father Leaves 2 Brothers Little for Themselves

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
Bill and Jeff Collins have just a little more than nothing in their four-room apartment in Rego Park, Queens.
 In the bedroom they share are two mattresses that rest on the wooden floor. In the living room are two metal chairs, a fan, a television hooked up to a rabbit ears antenna, and an empty hook where a picture used to hang. 
 The brothers, 48-year-old twins, threw out most of their furniture in May when they thought they were going to be evicted. They have since gotten help with the rent that they owed. 
"We thought we weren't going to be here anymore," Jeff said, shrugging his shoulders. "So what did we need it for?"
Their living room is devoid of creature comforts, but it's the kitchen where their poverty is most visible. In the refrigerator is a Tupperware container filled with tap water and a carton of soy milk. The cupboard has plates and bowls but no food, while the shelf underneath has only a dozen letters and bills, a plastic bag of Cheerios and a toothbrush.
Their mother died when the brothers were 8. They lived with their father, David, virtually all their lives. 
David Collins, a retired taxi driver, had Parkinson's disease, diabetes and congestive heart disease and died in May 2000. Because of his health problems and a compulsive gambling habit, he never had any savings, his sons said, and depended on them for financial support and personal care. 
"We had to help him take his insulin," Jeff said. "We had to cook his meals. Late in life we had to bathe him. He couldn't do it by himself."
Far from being liberated when their father died, the brothers were afraid to face the world at large without his guidance.
But Jeff had $8,000 in the bank from jobs he held before his father became severely ill, and the two began to look for work. After a year, the money had been exhausted on food and their $866-a-month rent.
"The rent has to be paid," Bill said. "You have to pay or get out and be homeless."
When they told their landlord about their financial problems, he gave them a list of charities that could help. "There must have been 25 of them," Bill said. "We called and called. Some of them gave us some other numbers to call."
Eventually they called Karen Norden, a social worker with the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services. Ms. Norden paid two months of their rent to tide them over as they looked for work, and told them about the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty, which has been helping them with their rent since then.
Both agencies are beneficiaries of UJA-Federation of New York, one of the seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The two brothers are searching for work. In the meantime, they survive on the money Bill earns picking up pieces of paper at parks in Forest Hills, Queens, for the city's Welfare Employment Program for $137 a month.
The brothers have a folder filled with job applications and rejection letters. They estimate that in the past few months they have applied for about 100 jobs. They have applied to be file clerks, mail handlers and janitors, so far without success.
Perhaps it is a slowing economy that keeps them out of work, or their limited work experience. The two worked as temporary file clerks in Queens for Chase Manhattan Bank for two years before the company merged with Chemical Bank in 1996 and they were laid off. Before that, they worked for a home health aide service in Queens, Jeff as a file clerk and Bill as a data-entry operator. 
But they never fully pursued careers, because they wanted to fulfill their father's request that they care for him. 
He told them that they would never be successful at anything, they said, and that has given them a low sense of self-esteem. "The dilemma is that they're too honest and good for the world that we live in," said their social worker from the council, Chana Rogalsky. "They were never taught to promote themselves."
Ms. Rogalsky has helped them get a grant that has paid for their rent since May, has helped them apply for jobs, and is searching for a way they can attend a vocational school, though they do not have enough money to pay for tuition.
Bill wants to become a bus driver, but does not have enough money to take a licensing class. Jeff wants to learn more about computers and get a job where he can work in an office.
Those are the ideals, anyway. "We would like to have a career in a way," Bill started to say before he was interrupted by his brother, who said, "We'd just like to a have a job right now."
