HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE MAIL; 
Postal Service Is Expected To Ask U.S. For Bailout

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA with CLAUDIA DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
So many Americans have shied away from mailboxes and post offices since anthrax appeared that the volume of mail handled by the United States Postal Service has dropped about 10 percent, costing at least $500 million in lost revenues and pushing the battered postal system to the brink of financial crisis, officials said yesterday. 
 Tomorrow, the Postal Service is expected to ask Congress for a bailout, similar to the one given to the airline industry, to cover the billions of dollars postal authorities say it will cost to make the mails safe. 
 The diminishing volume of mail could not have come at a worse time for the postal system. Despite rate increases in January and July, the Postal Service closed the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 with a $1.65 billion shortfall, and it expects to lose at least an additional $1.35 billion this year. 
The financial situation was so bad that even before the first anthrax-laced letter was postmarked, postal authorities had filed a request to increase the cost of a first-class stamp again, this time by 3 cents, to 37 cents. Now adding to the postal system's current woes, authorities say, will be the billions of dollars it will cost to buy the new equipment needed to sanitize incoming mail against the anthrax bacteria and to protect postal workers who may come into contact with anthrax or other biohazards. 
At a meeting of the postal board of governors yesterday, the postmaster general, John E. Potter, called the weeks since the terrorist attacks on Washington and New York "one of the most difficult and sad times in postal history." 
Two postal employees died after contracting anthrax, three have been hospitalized and more than 16,000 have been put on medication as a precaution. 
Independent sources estimate that the total cost of reacting to the anthrax emergency and the terrorist attacks could be $8 billion. Postal authorities have not yet named a figure, but Mr. Potter has said that if a Congressional bailout does not cover the cost of responding to the anthrax attacks it might be necessary for the Postal Service to raise postal rates even higher than previously planned to make up any shortfall. 
The Postal Service has already received $175 million in federal assistance to buy 4.8 million respirator masks, 88 million pairs of industrial-grade plastic gloves and other quick-fix safety enhancements for its 800,000 employees. And yesterday, postal authorities said they had reached a $24 million deal in which Ion Beam Applications of Chicago would sanitize mail at Ion's Bridgeport, N.J., operation for three months starting this week or next.
The decline in mail volume since early October follows a similar dip in the weeks immediately after Sept. 11, when the airlines -- which carry some of the nation's mail -- were grounded and business came to a temporary halt.
The drain on postal revenues -- totaling about $800 million in the entire period since Sept. 11 -- extends a corrosive cycle that the Postal Service has been fighting for more than 20 years. As alternatives like FedEx, fax machines and the broad range of Internet services have emerged to steal away some of the first-class mail that is most profitable, the Postal Service has tried to cover lost revenues by continually raising rates.
Yet, each rate increase provides more incentive for businesses to switch to some other method of communicating with customers -- causing further decline in first-class volume and laying the groundwork for even more rate increases.
"The Postal Service is in a literal free fall at this point," said Dan Moll, deputy staff director of the House Committee on Government Reform, which has overseen the Postal Service since a reorganization at the beginning of the current session of Congress.
Concern is widespread in Washington that the Postal Service is headed toward a fiscal breakdown. The 1969 law that established it as a self-supporting corporation owned by the federal government imposed a $15 billion debt ceiling. Given current trends, Mr. Moll said, "the Postal Service could reach that debt limit sometime in the second or third quarter of 2002."
Despite new electronic technology and the Internet, an expansive range of American businesses remains dependent on the postal system to solicit orders and collect payments. Some, like banks and utility companies, already have tried to reduce their reliance on the Postal Service. For example, the Potomac Electric Power Company, which serves 700,000 customers in the Washington area, said that nearly 12,000 customers paid their October bills electronically, an increase of more than 30 percent over the previous month.
For other businesses that continue to rely more heavily on the Postal Service, like catalog companies and magazine publishers, the prospect of higher rates or an overburdened Postal Service that cannot maintain standards of service, is worrisome.
"The mail service is our lifeblood," said Nina B. Link, president of the Magazine Publishers of America, which represents the largest magazines in the United States. The publishers mail about 90 percent of their magazines -- roughly 850 million issues a month -- at a cost of nearly $200 million in postage.
The publishers want a Congressional bailout to ensure the safety of the mails, but they oppose the request for a 9 percent rate that was filed Sept. 11. "There needs to be a government appropriation that deals with the safety and financial issues of the Postal Service," Ms. Link said. "It cannot come on the backs of the mailing community."
Robert E. McLean, executive director of the Mailers Council, the largest organization representing companies that rely on the mail, predicts that the total cost to the postal system of responding to anthrax could be as high as $8 billion, "depending on how long it takes to find the person responsible."
Mr. McLean said his group supported a congressionally funded rescue. But critics say the entire structure of the Postal Service and its continuing links to government need to be examined before a bailout or future rate hikes are approved.
"The temptation is way too high for the Postal Service to unload its systemic fiscal problems on the backs of taxpayers," said Rick Marquette, executive director of PostalWatch, a citizens' group that monitors the postal system. Mr. Marquette said it might be time to privatize the system and allow other companies to fully compete in delivering the daily mail. 
"A quick bailout is not going to fix the systemic problems," Mr. Marquette said. "The Postal Service needs to get its financial act together." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: William Charleston gathers bills at Potomac Electric Power, which has been thinking about billing online since the recent anthrax scares. (Linda Spillers for The New York Times)(pg. But, while the inflation-adjusted postal rate for first-class mail has not risen since the mid-1970's, the amount of first-class mail, both in volume terms and as a percentage of the postal service's revenue, has eroded. That has caused the Postal Service to run deficits in recent years and pushed the service closer to a total debt of $15 billion, the legal limit. HEADLINE: Philadelphia Inquirer Editor Is Forced Out 

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
Robert J. Rosenthal, the editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, was forced out of his job yesterday in an abrupt culmination of months of tensions brought on by disagreements with executives of its corporate parent, Knight Ridder, over the newspaper's journalistic and strategic ambitions.
 The move came after 18 months of cutbacks, buyouts and steep circulation declines at The Inquirer. Mr. Rosenthal resisted pressures to make coverage more consistently local at the expense of regional, national and international coverage. 
 Bob Hall, the publisher of The Inquirer, told a stunned and grim meeting of the news staff yesterday that Mr. Rosenthal was being replaced by Walker Lundy. Mr. Lundy is a respected longtime Knight-Ridder employee who for the last 11 years set the tone for both aggressive reporting and reader-friendly feature coverage at The St. Paul Pioneer Press. 
Mr. Lundy led The Pioneer Press, which has a daily circulation of 195,000, to a 2000 Pulitzer prize for articles revealing academic cheating by members of the University of Minnesota basketball team. The articles led to the suspension of four players just before a major tournament and enraged many readers. 
The sudden change of editors in Philadelphia marks the second time this year that a top executive at a Knight Ridder newspaper left in the midst of budget-driven disputes. It also marks a major transition in the life of a newspaper that three decades ago set itself a journalistic mission of covering the city, the region, the country and the world with as much depth and breadth as any newspaper in the country. 
In recent years, the newspaper struggled financially, and its parent company was increasingly eager to satisfy investor demands and bolster its stock price. Its sweeping and expensive journalistic vision, first articulated by The Inquirer's best-known former editor, Eugene L. Roberts Jr., became a source of perpetual friction. Similar frictions led to the resignation of Jay T. Harris, the publisher of The San Jose Mercury News earlier this year.
Over the last decade, the Philadelphia region's population and job growth has stagnated while strong suburban competitors cut into The Inquirer's circulation, advertising base and profitability. 
The Inquirer's daily and Sunday circulation declined more than 8 percent in the six months ending Sept. 30, compared with the similar period a year earlier. In the last five years, as The Inquirer's daily and Sunday circulation dropped nearly 15 percent, smaller competitors like The Bucks County Courier Times and The Delaware County Times lost little if any circulation in their wealthy and growing suburbs.
Asked what differences had led to Mr. Rosenthal's departure, Mr. Hall, the publisher, said yesterday, "If you had to summarize it, it would be the commitment to local and regional and the speed with which we were getting there." He added: "It sort of evolved. I can't overemphasize that Rosey's an incredible journalist. But it was time."
Reporters and editors at The Inquirer said yesterday that Mr. Rosenthal had been reluctant to divert resources from major regional, metropolitan or national beats to local suburban coverage.
Mr. Lundy, who was introduced to the newsroom yesterday morning, said in an interview yesterday that he needed to learn more about the staff and the region before setting priorities. But, he added, "The goal here is to continue to do the kind of journalism that the paper did first under Gene," and "also figure out some ways to address the circulation issues and ways to make even more people want to read The Inquirer. I don't think it's an either-or issue."
Mr. Lundy will be the first editor not promoted from within The Inquirer newsroom since Mr. Roberts took over the newspaper in 1972. The newspaper won 17 Pulitzer Prizes during Mr. Roberts's 18-year tenure.
After announcing his departure at 10 o'clock yesterday morning to the top editors, Mr. Rosenthal spent the rest of the morning writing notes to reporters and editors, and being hugged by his colleagues. As he walked out at lunchtime, the entire newsroom stood and applauded him.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Rosenthal said of his staff: "Pound for pound I'd match them against anybody. We've gone through a tremendous amount of upheaval, but the people who remained I'm extraordinarily proud of."
Asked about the mood in the newsroom yesterday, Gail Shister, the television critic, said, "It's like Dresden after the bombing." She added, "Rosey represented, in some ways, what was great about the Inquirer, because he is a total news guy."
The newsroom was rocked earlier this year when, during buyouts to satisfy the corporate goals of 10-percent cutbacks, the managing editor, William Ward, suddenly resigned. As of September, 2001, the news staff included the equivalent of 514 full-time journalists, down about 100 from January 2000, the peak of the dot-com economic boom.

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 On the Front Lines

GAINS ON THE GROUND -- Northern Alliance officials said that they had captured three districts near the strategic city of Mazar-i-Sharif. The officials said that United States military advisers helped plan and coordinate the assaults. A1

RACING AGAINST TIME -- Relief workers based in Pakistan are feverishly loading sack upon sack of wheat and other desperately needed food supplies onto trucks bound for Afghanistan. The vehicles will travel 350 miles of the world's worst roads, over the Khyber Pass, in an effort to get food to millions of hungry Afghans before winter makes the route impassable. B1

MEETINGS WITH REBEL -- Hamid Karzai, the Afghan exile who has emerged as the Bush administration's main hope for forging a southern alliance against the Taliban, was taken from Afghanistan by American forces on Sunday, brought to Pakistan for talks and returned to Afghanistan on Monday, senior Pentagon officials said. B3

The Coalition

EUROPEAN ALLIES -- After ignoring European offers of military help against the Taliban and Al Qaeda terrorist network for several weeks, the Bush administration is taking steps toward expanding the role of coalition partners. A1

GERMANY'S TROOPS -- Germany announced that it will mobilize up to 3,900 specialized troops to support the war against the Taliban in Afghanistan. Chancellor Gerhard Schroder would not say where or when the troops would be used, and there was no indication that they would be sent into combat. B4

Security and Terrorism

A WARNING IS REVERSED -- The F.B.I. lifted a warning issued last week that terrorists might be planning to destroy bridges along the West Coast and said that its investigation showed that the threat was "not credible." B5

MONITORING AIRPORTS -- The F.A.A. has increased monitoring of security at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago after a man was allowed to pass through a United Airlines security station carrying weapons, including a stun gun. B5

SEAPORT SECURITY -- In Portland, Maine, and other seaports around the nation, fears about vulnerability to terrorist attack have increased. But unlike airports, which have received massive federal attention since Sept. 11, seaports' concerns have gone mostly unnoticed. B5

The Anthrax Crisis

A STRUGGLING INVESTIGATION -- A senior counterterrorism official for the F.B.I. told senators that a month into its bioterrorism investigation, the agency still cannot answer such basic questions as how many laboratories in the country handle the anthrax bacteria. A1

THE SENATE OFFICES -- A plan to fumigate the entire Hart Senate Office Building with a powerful gas to kill anthrax bacteria has been abandoned over safety concerns. B6

HOSPITAL REOPENS -- Seeking to reassure jittery employees and attract patients after a seven-day closure, the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital reopened and was declared free of the anthrax bacteria that killed an employee last week. B6

INQUIRY IN NEW YORK -- Investigators said they believed that Kathy T. Nguyen, a hospital worker from the Bronx who died of inhalation anthrax on Oct. 31, did not leave New York City in the weeks leading up to her puzzling death. B6

ANTHRAX AND ABORTION CLINICS -- The rest of the country is just now experiencing what abortion clinics already know about anthrax scares. Clinics have been at the receiving end of at least four separate waves of mailed anthrax threats since 1989. B7

Ripples From Sept. 11

POSTAL SERVICE CRISIS -- The volume of mail handled by the United States Postal Service has dropped by about 10 percent, costing at least $500 million in lost revenues and pushing the battered postal system to the brink of financial crisis, postal officials said. The Postal Service is expected to ask Congress for a bailout on Thursday. B1

CRITICISM OF RED CROSS -- Members of a House oversight committee criticized the American Red Cross over the agency's recent decision to withhold more than $200 million in charitable donations from the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks. B1

HEADLINE: Fed Reduces Short-Term Rates to Lowest Level Since 1961 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Struggling to reverse the slide in the American economy, the Federal Reserve cut its key short-term interest rate today for the 10th time this year, aggressively pushing it down to a level not seen since early in the presidency of John F. Kennedy.
 No one doubted that the Fed's policy makers, gathered here for one of their periodic meetings, would cut interest rates again. The only question was by how much. 
 The choice to cut by half a percentage point rather than a quarter-point -- lowering the rate to 2 percent -- reflected what some analysts described as a determination on the part of the Fed to start the economy growing again in case another shock causes more economic damage.
"They see an economy clearly in recession, and they decided that it makes sense to act aggressively now to get things going as quickly as possible," said Peter Hooper, chief domestic economist for Deutsche Bank North America. "We are not out of the woods yet in this war on terrorism." 
The Fed, in a brief statement, said that it had lowered rates once again because "heightened uncertainty and concerns about a deterioration in business conditions both here and abroad are damping economic activity."
Some analysts described the reference to deterioration abroad as an attempt to encourage the European Central Bank and the Bank of England to also cut rates when they meet on Thursday. Both have been reluctant to act as strongly as the Fed to counter a potential global recession.
The Fed's policy makers reduced the so-called federal funds rate, the interest rate that financial institutions charge each other for overnight loans. That lending rate, in turn, influences the borrowing cost for commercial loans and for a variety of consumer loans, including home equity lines and car loans. Mortgage rates, which respond closely to long-term borrowing costs set by traders in the government bond market, are less affected by the Fed actions.
With little fear of reviving inflation, the Fed's overriding goal this year has been to encourage people and business to borrow and spend more. But in a weakening economy suffering from layoffs, excess capacity and dwindling consumer confidence, the Fed has been only partly successful. With the future uncertain, businesses have curbed their investments despite the cheap credit and Americans have become more cautious spenders..
Still, the economy would have been even worse off without the Fed rate cuts. The housing market has remained generally healthy and mortgage refinancing has given households extra cash for spending and paying off high-interest debt. The stock market has also stopped nose diving and today stock prices surged after the Fed's mid-afternoon announcement.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which had been down before the mid-afternoon announcement, rose 150.09 points, while the Nasdaq advanced 41.43 points.
"The objective here is growth, growth, growth, as soon as possible, and everything else is out the window," said Ian Shepherdson, chief domestic economist at High Frequency Economics. Like many others on Wall Street, he expects the Fed to cut the Federal funds rate again by the end of the year, to 1.5 percent.
But there was a hint of resistance on the Fed's policy-making committee, which is made up of the seven governors based in Washington and bank presidents from each of the Fed's 12 regional districts. Five of the regional presidents, in rotating groups, vote at the meetings, which are held eight times a year. In the discussion today, some apparently held out for only a quarter-point cut.
The hint of this discord came in the announcement that the Fed had also cut its largely symbolic discount rate, which is the interest that the Fed charges banks on the rare occasions when they borrow directly from the Fed. In making the announcement that the discount rate would also fall by half a percentage point, to 1.5 percent, the Fed disclosed that only one of the 12 regional banks, the Bank of Richmond, had requested a half-point cut. The standard practice is for most of the Fed's 12 regional banks to endorse a discount rate cut.
The fact that only one signed on suggested to some analysts that the presidents of other banks argued at the meeting today for a smaller cut in both the Federal funds rate and the discount rate -- but finally went along with Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, in voting for the larger amount.
"It raises the possibility that some of the policy makers preferred to slow down the rate cuts, and Greenspan felt the risks were too great," said James Glassman, chief domestic economist for J. P. Morgan Chase. The vote tally will not be published until mid-December.
The half-point cut today matched in size the two other Fed cuts since Sept. 11.
But several competing arguments are now being advanced by Wall Street economists for slowing the rate-cutting process. One is that the Fed should leave more room for future cuts, in the event that the recession now under way worsens. Another is that the Fed should take into account the stimulus that is coming from tax cuts and stepped-up government spending.
And while inflation is not a problem now, bond traders might become nervous about a rising inflation rate from too much stimulus and push up long-term rates to help protect themselves against its consequences.
"They are using up their monetary medicine too fast," said Ethan Harris, a Lehman Brothers economist. 
But since Friday, when the Labor Department announced the largest job loss for a single month in more than two decades, other analysts have encouraged the Fed to remain aggressive in cutting rates. The job numbers and a contraction in the economy in the third quarter overcame resistance to a half-point cut, they said.
Few of the years since the Depression have been as eventful for the Fed as 2001. The fed funds rate is now at its lowest level since September 1961 -- an era when neither inflation nor interest rates ever got very high. The rate has come down by 4.5 percentage points since Jan. 1 -- mostly in half-point increments.
That is out of character for Mr. Greenspan, whose preference during his 14 years as Fed chairman has been for cautious quarter-point adjustments up or down.
The problem is that this recession is different than others since World War II. In the past, the Fed has usually brought on recessions by a deliberate campaign to raise interest rates to counteract inflation from too much demand. Once inflation has been tamed, lowering rates has typically revived the economy within a relatively short time.
This time, however, business provoked the downturn by sharply cutting back on investment once it became clear that companies had poured too much money into new technology and building capacity to meet a level of demand that failed to materialize. The sell-off in the stock market only added to the alarm.
"People will no doubt refinance mortgages like crazy and that will lower debt burdens and put more cash in households' pockets," Joel L. Naroff, an economic consultant, advised his clients after today's rate cut. "But having more cash in your pocket and spending it are two different issues and that is the crux of the problem."

HEADLINE: The Next Governor of New Jersey 

 BODY:
James McGreevey, who came close to pulling off an upset victory in the New Jersey governor's race four years ago, won the job easily last night. The state reconfirmed its reputation as a place that likes its Republicans moderate, something Mr. 
McGreevey's opponent, Bret Schundler, was not.
 Although New Jersey lost hundreds of its citizens when the World Trade Center was attacked, the issues that concerned voters were apparently not related to terrorism so much as a desire to see the next governor fix nuts-and-bolts problems like high property taxes and expensive auto insurance. The challenge for Mr. McGreevey is that there is no easy way to relieve either. Property taxes are used mainly for school funding, and the state cannot afford to take much more of the education burden without raising taxes itself. 
 The polls made it clear that voters are counting on Mr. McGreevey to look after the state's economy and employment. We hope he does that with an economic development plan in which New Jersey and New York City can cooperate, not compete. 
Mr. McGreevey enjoyed a clear lead throughout the race, which allowed him to refrain from making many extremely ambitious promises. He did, however, vow to make all his appointments on merit, and voters will be watching to make sure he follows through. New Jersey has seen too much of the ineptitude associated with the privatization of such programs as auto emissions testing and E-ZPass. One way Mr. McGreevey can declare war on cronyism is by taking a strong stand behind campaign finance reform for state legislative races.

HEADLINE: THE 2001 ELECTIONS: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
Trenton Democrats Are Out of Doghouse

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Nearly a decade after they were cast into exile for foisting a politically disastrous tax increase on an unsuspecting public, New Jersey Democrats finally completed their escape from the doghouse of state politics today.
 Buoyed by James E. McGreevey's comfortable margin of victory in the governor's race, Democrats wrested control of the Assembly from the Republicans, and achieved at least a 20-20 split in the State Senate. The new balance of power in Trenton will give Democrats the predominant role in setting the state's agenda for the first time since 1993. 
 Mr. McGreevey's win was so decisive that party leaders were quick to cast the victory as a mandate, and on Monday, Terry McAuliffe, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, was already proclaiming that the opinion polls were a "referendum on the Republicans' stale ideas." 
But many nonpartisan political analysts say the election results were less an indictment of Republican rule than a return to political equilibrium in New Jersey, a state that generally leans slightly Democratic.
"Most New Jersey voters no longer remember that it was Jim Florio and the Democrats who pushed the tax increase, but after 10 years of prosperity, people still have their two cars and their three television sets," said Gerald M. Pomper, a professor of political science at Rutgers University. "And after eight years of Republicans in power, I think it was natural for people to want to give the Democrats a chance again."
That return of the political pendulum was nudged along by a newly redrawn map of legislative districts that favored Democratic candidates, and the implosion of the state Republican Party after Christie Whitman stepped down as governor this year to join the Bush administration.
When New Jersey's tax revolt began to gather steam in 1991, it was hard to envision the day when the state's volatile electorate might be willing to forgive.
The revolt began in 1990, when the newly inaugurated governor, Jim Florio, rammed a $2.8 billion tax increase through the Legislature at a time when Democrats controlled both houses. Antitax groups and talk radio hosts harnessed the widespread public anger.
In 1991, the voters' wrath boiled over into an electoral disaster for Democrats, who lost control of both houses of the Legislature. In 1993, Mr. Florio himself was defeated by Mrs. Whitman, beginning an eight-year period of total Republican control in the State House. 
Mr. McGreevey's Republican opponent, Bret D. Schundler, tried to rekindle that anger during this fall's campaign, reminding voters that his opponent had voted for the tax increase and warning that Mr. McGreevey would "be worse than Jim Florio." But time appeared to have taken the sting from those words, and some polls showed that even many of Mr. Schundler's supporters expected a tax increase regardless of who won.
As an advocate of looser gun control laws and an opponent of abortion rights, Mr. Schundler was anathema to the moderates who have long made up New Jersey's Republican establishment. The party offered Mr. Schundler little financial support; it was already weakened by Mrs. Whitman's departure and Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco's abrupt withdrawal from the race after questions were raised about several of his business deals. 
And despite eight years of solid growth in the state's economy, Republicans did not solve its most enduring problems: school financing, suburban sprawl, high property taxes and the nation's most expensive auto insurance rates.
"I don't think there was much affection for Governor Whitman or the Republicans," said Prof. James W. Hughes, dean of the Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers. "There was no mourning or celebration or anything really. She was just gone. And Schundler came from a conservative wing of the party that even New Jersey Republicans never fully embraced."
Now that Democrats have returned to power, however, they inherit a daunting set of political challenges. After years of unparalleled prosperity, statistics from the State Labor Department show that the economic slowdown has cost New Jersey 27,000 jobs this year. Republicans increased the state debt in the past eight years, leaving the administration little room for new borrowing should tax revenues decline. 
The Sept. 11 terror attack and the high cost of increased security are also likely to drain the state budget, forcing the incoming administration to choose among tax increases, borrowing and deep cuts in services. 
"In some ways, the Democrats might be better off if the Republicans control at least one house of the Legislature," said David P. Rebovich, a political science professor at Rider University. "That way, if there are tax increases, they can share the blame and everyone walks the plank together."
But after 10 years as political outcasts, Democrats have vowed not to repeat the mistakes of 1990. While Mr. McGreevey would not join Mr. Schundler in pledging not to raise taxes, he made it clear that he would consider it only as a last resort.
Likewise, Assemblyman Joseph J. Roberts Jr., the state Democratic chairman, managed to discuss the subject at length this week without ever uttering the dreaded T-word. 
"I have absolutely no expectations that under any circumstances will Jim McGreevey have to take any such steps," he said. "The lesson of 10 years ago is that if, at some point in the future, there is a need to take those measures, it would be done only after every other alternative had been exhausted and if people were overwhelmingly in favor of it."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE SEAPORTS; 
On the Dock, Holes in the Security Net Are Gaping

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 3 

 BODY:
The big cargo ships and ships with truck-size containers pull up to docks where no one inspects their contents. Brown tankers from the Middle East steam into the bay, slide under a drawbridge that bisects the Fore River and tie up by terminals, tanks and a pipeline that carries the oil that heats Montreal.
 In warmer weather, cruise ships like the QE2 and the Royal Empress with up to 3,000 tourists park at piers on busy Commercial Street, right next to Portland's lively downtown. 
 For Portland's officials, the scene, at least before Sept. 11, was a point of pride, the sign of a strong economy and a proud maritime heritage. Now it evokes fear and uncertainty. The unscrutinized containers, the bridge, the oil tanks, the dormant but still-radioactive nuclear power plant 20 miles north of the harbor -- all form a volatile mix in a time of terrorism. 
The usual barrier is chain-link fence. "It keeps out the honest people," said Paul D. Merrill, owner of a cargo terminal. "That's what it comes down to." The Port of Portland, Police Chief Michael Chitwood said, "is a tinderbox." 
Remote as it seems on the northeastern ear of the nation, Portland is not particularly exceptional among the nation's 361 seaports. The ports of New York and New Jersey, Miami, Long Beach, Calif., and Los Angeles are much bigger and busier. Yet like most ports, the one here is near a population center and it is packed with bridges, power plants, and combustible and hazardous materials.
All that makes ports among the country's greatest points of vulnerability. 
Even so, no national plan exists to thwart attacks against them, to respond if one happens or to organize a community afterward. No federal agency regulates seaports the way the Federal Aviation Administration manages airports. They are managed locally, often by the private businesses that use them. All are overseen by a patchwork of agencies, already stretched thin, some monitoring hundreds of ships a day. 
Compared with the attention being given to airline security, security at the ports has gone largely unnoticed, even though they handle 95 percent of the cargo that enters from places other than Canada and Mexico. A bill to tighten port security has passed a Senate committee. The full Senate could vote on the bill within two weeks, but the debate has yet to begin in the House of Representatives. 
"People in Congress don't have any idea it's a problem," said Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, who is chairman of the Commerce Committee and co-sponsor of the bill with Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida. "I've got folks who don't have ports in their states. It's hard to get it in front of their heads." 
Port officials are aware of various threats, like using a tanker or fuel-loaded cruise liner as a bomb, secreting weapons and explosives in containers, hijacking a ship and ramming it into a nuclear plant on the shores of a river, or infesting a cargo of grain or seeds with a biological weapon. 
Given the potential dangers, the security measures in place are far from adequate.
"We're looking for needles in a haystack," said Dean Boyd, a spokesman for the United States Customs Service. "And the haystack has doubled." International trade has doubled since 1995 while the number of people to handle inspections has remained roughly constant, he said.
The Coast Guard patrols coasts and harbors but little of the land or the cargo. It checks out ships coming in from the open sea but has no way of thoroughly searching everything that comes by.
The Customs Service says it can inspect only 2 percent of the 600,000 cargo containers that enter seaports each a day on more than 500 ships. Of the 2 percent, many are not inspected until they reach their final destination, sometimes on the opposite coast, where they travel unguarded by rail, barge and truck.
Last year, a government commission on crime and security at seaports found similar weaknesses. The commission surveyed 12 major ports including those of New York and New Jersey, Miami, Los Angeles, New Orleans and Charleston.
While withholding their identities for security reasons, the report found that only three of the ports tightly controlled access from the land and that access from the water was completely unprotected at nine of them. 
The report also emphasized the hazards posed by materials unloaded from ships. "The influx of goods through U.S. ports provides a venue for the introduction of a host of transnational threats into the nation's infrastructures," the report said. 
A tangled chain of authority further compromised security, the commission said, a point echoed by the authorities in Portland. 
"No one's in charge," said Jeffrey W. Monroe, director of transportation for the city. "There's no central guidance." 
And ports have a strong economic incentive to limit control. With the taxes that cruise ships, tankers and other businesses pay, ports are the lifeblood of their communities. Port authorities' principal constituencies are private industry and economic development offices, whose mission is growth, not security. "They win if they move more cargo," Senator Hollings said.
In Portland, the seaport has been a boon, generating millions of dollars a year in revenues. Mr. Monroe said that in the past year the bulk cargo business grew 10 percent, passenger traffic and oil imports both rose by 20 percent. But the stalling economy and now the cost of heightened security have wiped out nearly all that the seaport and airport contribute to the city budget.
In Congress, the Hollings-Graham legislation would help cities meet some of the cost of securing their ports. It would give the Coast Guard regulatory control over ports, require background checks of waterfront workers and provide for 1,500 new Customs agents. 
Before the September attacks, the seaport industry's principal lobby, the American Association of Port Authorities, fought the legislation, arguing that it would impose one-size-fits-all security systems for all seaports. 
Though the group now supports many provisions of the bill, it still has questions over the matter of who controls security. Meanwhile, ports have taken their own steps to improve security. In Florida, Gov. Jeb Bush announced he would deploy the National Guard to oversee four of the state's busiest ports. In California, Gov. Gray Davis tightened security around bridges. 
In Portland, officials and businesses have taken similar steps. Minutes before the drawbridge opens for a tanker, police officers arrive to monitor both sides of the bridge. Fences are being repaired and installed. 
At the city's International Marine Terminal, where from May to October the Scotia Prince carries 170,000 passengers on 11-hour cruises between Portland and Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, visitors used to roam freely around the pier. Now only passengers are allowed there, and then only after they and their baggage are cleared by metal detectors and bomb dogs. The pilings below the pier are now illuminated at night.
For its part, the Coast Guard now focuses primarily on harbor security. It requires vessels weighing more than 300 tons to notify the port 96 hours before arrival. The big ships also must fax crew lists, said Lt. Cmdr. Wyman W. Briggs, executive officer of the guard's facilities in Portland. The crews of fishing boats must carry picture ID's.
For all this, much tighter seaport security may prove impossible. Seaports cannot be secured like airport, said Brian Nutter, administrator for the Maine Port Authority in Augusta. "You can't fence off the whole state of Maine," Mr. Nutter said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
10th Fed Rate Cut This Year Raises Hopes for a Recovery

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve cut interest rates again yesterday, pushing down short-term rates as far this year as it has usually done before the economy comes out of a recession. Stock market investors now seem to believe a recovery will begin by the middle of next year.
 Despite some hesitation after the announcement of the half-point reduction, share prices ended the day with a solid rally -- making it the most enthusiastic reaction of the year for any of the cuts that have come at regularly scheduled meetings of the central bank's policy making Federal Open Market Committee. 
 The cut leaves the rate on overnight loans between banks at 2 percent, the lowest since 1961. 
The three major market averages, the Dow Jones industrial average, the Standard & Poor's 500 and the Nasdaq composite index, ended the day up 1.5 percent or more. They had been mixed to down after the first five expected moves this year, but rose, albeit not as strongly as yesterday, after the last move, on Oct. 2.
Lower interest rates are expected to stimulate the economy by making it less expensive for individuals and businesses to borrow money. One rate the Fed directly controls is now down more than two-thirds from where it began the year. That is about the same amount as rates fell before recent recessions ended.
In part, yesterday's market advance reflected more mystery than usual surrounding the Fed meeting. While all Fed forecasters expected a cut, they were split between factions that expected a quarter-point cut -- or 25 basis points -- and those that expected the cut to be twice as much.
"It means that the Fed is nervous about the economy," said William C. Dudley, the chief United States economist of Goldman, Sachs, after the Fed announced the bigger move. "I think there was probably a big debate about 25 or 50."
A possible sign of dissent in the Fed was the fact that only one of the 12 Fed regional banks, the one based in Richmond, Va., had asked for a half-point reduction in the discount rate, the interest on loans by the Fed to banks. On Oct. 2, eight of the 12 banks had requested cuts.
Under the Fed's rules, the Open Market Committee has complete discretion over the federal funds rate, the rate at which banks lend to each other overnight. But moves in the discount rate must be initiated by regional banks.
If there was substantial dissent, and that will only become clear when minutes of yesterday's meeting are released, that may make a large cut at the next meeting, on Dec. 11, less likely. Many economists expect a quarter-point cut at that meeting.
The Fed's only comment yesterday was a terse statement notable largely for two changes from its October statement. It mentioned that business is weak overseas and that increased security spending "may restrain advances in productivity for a time."
While neither point had been made before in the Fed's announcements of rate cuts, both were widely understood by investors and did not seem to bother traders. The stock market has rallied since it hit bottom on Sept. 21, a week after trading resumed following the Sept. 11 attacks, and those rising prices appear to have both reflected and reinforced hopes for an economic recovery.
Since those bottoms, the Dow and S.& P. 500 are up about 16 percent, while the Nasdaq index has leaped 29 percent.
With yesterday's cut, the federal funds rate has fallen from a cyclical peak of 6.5 percent to 2 percent. While previous recessions have often started when rates were far higher -- and therefore had more percentage points to fall, one way to compare cuts is by the percentage decline.
Comparing that to past recessions is a bit tricky, because the Fed did not always use the federal funds rate as a target, and it tended to be more volatile. But Robert J. Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company, noted that this decline is generally in line with those of the past.
In the recessions that ended in 1970, 1975 and 1991, the declines from the peak monthly average of the federal funds rate to the low monthly average ranged from 64 percent to 70 percent, he said. The two exceptions were the mini-recession of 1980 and the longer one that ended in 1983, when the declines were 49 percent and 55 percent, respectively.
The Fed has now cut rates 10 times this year -- seven at regularly scheduled meetings and three between meetings. The first two surprise moves, in January and April, produced market surges that faded within weeks or months. The third, on Sept. 17, came the day the market reopened after the attacks, and may have limited the falls that day.
This recession -- assuming as most economists do that one has begun -- differs from previous downturns in several ways. Normally recessions begin with weakness in the housing and auto sectors, as higher interest rates lead to depressed sales. But this time it was the industrial economy that went first, and consumer spending held up surprisingly well for most of this year.
The Fed's aggressive cuts in rates have helped to support housing, which has only recently begun to weaken, and car sales are now strong -- although that is widely viewed as stemming from aggressive price cutting by automakers, which are losing money despite the strong sales.
Paradoxically, the strength of demand in those two sectors makes it less likely that they will be able to lead the recovery when it arrives, since there appears to be little pent-up demand. But, Mr. Dudley at Goldman, Sachs said, there are other areas that are likely to provide stimulus, starting with the effect of lower energy prices and additional production by companies after they finish reducing inventories that had been too large when the slowdown began. And, he added, there is the delayed, but still expected, fiscal stimulus package from Washington.
For now, anyway, the stock market seems to be confident that the economy will revive. And while yesterday's decision by the Fed to go for a bigger cut may be evidence of greater concern about economic weakness, investors believe it simply makes the eventual recovery that much more certain.

ALCOA TO BUY 8 PERCENT OF ALUMINUM CORP. OF CHINA

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Alcoa, the world's biggest aluminum maker, said yesterday that it would buy 8 percent of the Aluminum Corporation of China, the country's largest producer of the metal, to expand in China's growing economy while the United States economy slumps. The Chinese state-controlled company plans to offer a total of a 30 percent stake and raise about $350 million, the International Financing Review said yesterday, citing an unidentified banker. The shares, which will be sold starting Nov. 19, will trade in London and New York.

SONIC SHARES DROP 19 PERCENT ON PROFIT WARNING

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Shares of the Sonic Corporation, which owns the largest chain of drive-restaurants in the United States, fell as much as 19 percent yesterday after it said its fiscal first-quarter earnings would be at the lower end of analysts' estimates. Sonic shares fell $5.52, to $29.73, in early afternoon trading of 1.49 million, seven times the three-month daily average. 
The stock, which traded as low as $28.45, reached a 52-week high yesterday of $35.25. It ended the day down $4.28, to $30.97. Profit in the quarter ending Nov. 30 will be at the lower end of the range of 33 to 36 cents a share because of worsening consumer confidence and economic conditions, the Oklahoma City-based company said. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call was 35 cents.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Back to Business: Baseball Votes to Drop 2 Teams

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: ROSEMONT, Ill., Nov. 6 

 BODY:
In a move that Commissioner Allan H. (Bud) Selig said was necessary for economic reasons, Major League Baseball owners voted overwhelmingly today to eliminate two of their 30 teams before next season. The two teams are to be determined, Selig said, but the strong feeling among team executives was that they would be the Montreal Expos and the Minnesota Twins.
 "No modern American sport has done this," Selig said at a news conference after the 28-2 vote. But, he said, the step was necessary as a significant way of dealing with the game's economic problems. 
 "It makes no sense for major league baseball to be in markets that generate insufficient local revenues to justify the investment in the franchise," Selig said. "The teams to be contracted have a long record of failing to generate enough revenues to operate a viable major league franchise." 
This will be the first time since the formation of the major leagues as they exist today that teams will be eliminated. The National League dropped four teams after the 1899 season, going from 12 to 8, but the American League did not come into existence until 1901.
With their action, the owners, in trying to solve one problem, created another one. Their unilateral decision, without consultation with the players' union, promises to make negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement more difficult than they were already going to be.
Donald M. Fehr, the executive director of the players' union, called the vote "most imprudent and unfortunate," adding in a statement: "Over this last season, and, especially, over the last several weeks, we have been reminded, vividly, of the special place baseball holds in America. This makes it all the more unfortunate that the clubs would choose this moment to dash the hopes of so many of its fans."
Commenting briefly on labor, Selig announced that the owners would not lock out the players nor would he impose a signing freeze "at the present time." The labor contract expires at midnight Wednesday.
By not identifying the teams that will be eliminated, Selig left off-season plans for some teams under a cloud. Free agents can begin signing new deals in two weeks, but they will not want to commit to a team that might not exist on April 1. Fans, too, will be reluctant to commit to buying season tickets without knowing if they will have a use for them.
The commissioner declined to say how many teams were candidates for elimination, but there appeared to be five, with the Montreal Expos and the Minnesota Twins the overwhelming favorites to be terminated before spring training next February. Those teams were the two "no" votes, but each owner had his reason for voting that way. Jeffrey H. Loria, the Expos' owner, had said that he would not vote for eliminating his own team, and Carl R. Pohlad, the Twins' owner, presumably wanted to be able to say that he voted against contraction.
Selig did not indicate how much baseball would pay the owners of the teams that were dropped, but it is expected to be from $125 million to $200 million. The commissioner did not provide details on how the process of contraction would be carried out, nor did he give a date for when the procedure would be completed.
The Expos, who joined the N.L. as an expansion team in 1969, are an obvious candidate. Interest in baseball in Montreal has waned considerably in recent years, and Loria had quietly hoped to be able to move the team, possibly to northern Virginia.
But Selig ruled out relocation for the moment "because there exists no prospective market that meets the desired requirements for fielding a stable, competitive and economically viable franchise for next season."
The Twins are next on the list because Pohlad has wanted to get out of baseball, and the money he would receive from Major League Baseball would almost certainly be more than he could get from the sale of the team. 
In addition, Selig and Pohlad have been close over the years, and some people in baseball believe Selig will present contraction as a going-away gift to Pohlad, who has been a strong and loyal supporter.
The other three teams that could be considered are the two Florida teams, the Florida Marlins and the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, and the Oakland Athletics.
The Marlins and the Devil Rays are struggling to hold their fans but seem to be fighting a losing battle. Baseball would very likely face a stiffer legal challenge from the state of Florida than from Montreal, where no fight would be expected, and Minnesota, where the Twins have only a year left on their Metrodome lease.
A high-ranking baseball official confirmed that Loria, if he loses the Expos, would buy the Marlins, whose owner, John Henry, hopes to buy the Anaheim Angels, whom the Walt Disney Company wants to sell.
The Athletics at one time seemed to be as obvious a candidate for contraction as the Expos, but they have developed a highly attractive team and are taking steps to hold on to their good young players. Selig said many owners, possibly a majority, favored the elimination of four teams, but he said two would be the number for now. One owner said the Yankees and the Mets were among the teams that proposed four be eliminated. 
The owners acted without consulting the players association. Baseball officials maintain that they do not have to negotiate contraction, only the effects of contraction, meaning what happens with the players from the two teams. 
"We consider this action to be inconsistent with the law, our contract, and perhaps, most important, the long-term welfare of the sport," Fehr said. "This is the worst manner in which to begin the process of negotiating a new collective bargaining agreement. We had hoped that we were in a new era, one which would see a much better relationship between players and owners. Today's announcement is a severe blow to such hopes." 
Selig said his office would complete negotiations with the teams to be contracted and begin negotiating with the union on the effects of the action, including dispersal of the players from the contracted teams.
But when negotiations for a new labor agreement begin, the owners will seek major concessions from the union on economic issues, and the union will most likely be less willing to consider the changes the owners say they need. Interleague play could be a casualty of contraction. The union has yet to approve interleague play for next season and now may very well reject its continuation.
By eliminating two financially ailing teams, the owners will have two fewer teams to subsidize through their revenue-sharing plan and two fewer teams with which to share national revenue, such as television, licensing and Internet money. 
Furthermore, they will be able to divide playing talent among fewer teams, although that idea never seemed to intrigue them when they were expanding and taking in hundreds of millions of dollars from new franchises.
The elimination of two teams, assuming they are the Expos and the Twins, would leave the N.L. with 15 teams and the A.L. with 13. One N.L. team, very likely the Pittsburgh Pirates, would have to move from the Central to the East to replace the Expos. To maintain an even number of teams in each league, one N.L. team would have to move to the A.L.
Baseball officials have talked in the past about moving the Arizona Diamondbacks from the N.L. to the A.L., but the Diamondbacks have objected. Now that they have the added stature of being the World Series champions, the Diamondbacks could be even more difficult to dislodge.

HEADLINE: Man in the News; 
Flexibility in Victory; James Edward McGreevey

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
He has been introducing himself to the New Jersey public for six straight years, but James Edward McGreevey has never really gotten past hello.
 In his 1997 campaign for governor, Mr. McGreevey told the voters that Christie Whitman was an out-of-touch aristocrat who had failed to lower property taxes, auto insurance rates and the state's debt. He lost by only 1 percent. 
 This year, Mr. McGreevey told the voters that Bret D. Schundler was an out-of-step extremist who wanted to undermine the public schools, curtail abortion rights and let people carry concealed weapons. He won handily by recent New Jersey standards.
Yet in all this time on the campaign trail, Mr. McGreevey, 44, has revealed precious little of himself. He coasted to victory this year without having made a single ambitious promise, offering instead only modest remedies for core middle-class concerns.
Those omissions, his advisers say, could prove enormous advantages as he prepares to take office as New Jersey's 51st governor. He will need all the flexibility he can muster in a state now facing an estimated $1.5 billion budget shortfall, a stalled economy and the daunting challenges to the public safety, health and mood that have arisen since Sept. 11.
What New Jerseyans do know about Mr. McGreevey is that he has worked toward this moment his entire adult life, and probably much longer than that. His second-grade classmates at St. Joseph elementary school in Carteret say they were sure he would run for governor someday.
New Jerseyans also know that he is a perpetual student and an inexhaustible worker. He was a notorious grind in college and graduate school, packing his semesters and summers with extra courses. When he lost to Mrs. Whitman, he embarked on a grueling course of self-instruction in the people, places and public policies of the Garden State, walking and talking through its major cities and countless hamlets. He led seminars on the mind-numbing but important arcana of land use and municipal functions as president of the state's Conference of Mayors.
"For the last four years, no one has studied more about this state and learned more about its people than Jim McGreevey," said Robert Sommer, a Democratic lobbyist and fund-raiser for Mr. McGreevey. "And I can't imagine anybody being more fully prepared to take over in such an incredibly difficult time."
He is also undeterred in defeat, magnanimous in victory, and adept at making friends of his adversaries no matter how their clashes end, supporters say. These are characteristics that could prove valuable in facing fiscal crises or other threats.
Mr. McGreevey did that in Woodbridge, where he was elected mayor in 1991, but had to win over Republicans who controlled the Township Council. More recently, even though Democrats hold every seat on the Council, he continued to reappoint one of his loudest and harshest Republican critics to a prominent position on the township's Library Board.
Last year, when Senator Robert G. Torricelli suddenly tried to hijack the Democratic nomination for governor that Mr. McGreevey had believed was his, Mr. McGreevey refused to say a critical word about the foe who had been his friend, even after he had dealt Mr. Torricelli's coup attempt a crushing blow.
"Politically, he's always been able to turn the other cheek, because he looks forward," said Gary Taffet, Mr. McGreevey's campaign manager and probable chief of staff. "He's not personally vindictive. It's just not his nature."
Mr. McGreevey's thick skin and consensus-building style could help him work with lawmakers in both parties better than any governor since Thomas H. Kean, said State Senator John Lynch, a political patron and adviser to Mr. McGreevey.
"It isn't so much that he wants peace as that he sees the benefits of building a team, of trying to make people feel more comfortable with his leadership," he said. "And he's right. It works."
James Edward McGreevey was born in Jersey City, the state's Democratic power center throughout much of the last century, on Aug. 6, 1957. He was named for an uncle who had died in the battle of Iwo Jima. His parents, Veronica and Jack McGreevey, a nurse and a trucking company salesman, raised their three children in Carteret, on a close-knit block with many other Jersey City natives.
Except for kindergarten, Mr. McGreevey was educated at two parochial schools: St. Joseph elementary school in Carteret, and St. Joseph High School in Metuchen. He spent three semesters at Catholic University in Washington before transferring to Columbia University, where he majored in political science and graduated in 1978. He received a law degree from Georgetown in 1981 and a master's in education from Harvard in 1982.
He entered politics immediately after returning from Cambridge, spending a year as a Middlesex County assistant prosecutor and two years as a lawyer for the Democrats who controlled the State Assembly. He was named executive director of the State Parole Board by Governor Kean in 1985, at 27. Two years later, he became a lobbyist for Merck & Company, the pharmaceutical manufacturer in Rahway.
Mr. McGreevey was elected to the Assembly from Woodbridge in 1989, but served only one term. In 1991, he was stripped of the nomination to his seat by Joseph DeMarino, the local Democratic leader. In return, Mr. McGreevey successfully challenged Mr. DeMarino's re-election as mayor of Woodbridge. He was re-elected easily in 1995 and 1999. He also served one term in the State Senate, from 1994 to 1997.
He has a 9-year-old daughter, Morag (Gaelic for Mary), who lives with her mother, Karen J. Schutz, in Vancouver, British Columbia. He and Ms. Schutz were married in 1991 and divorced in 1997. 
Mr. McGreevey was married on Oct. 7, 2000, to Dina Matos, an executive at Columbus Hospital in Newark, who turned 35 on Monday. Mrs. McGreevey is seven months pregnant; Mr. McGreevey joked along the campaign trail that their child was due just in time for his inauguration.
But Mrs. McGreevey went into early labor last weekend and has been hospitalized since Saturday. Her husband was at her side almost constantly until delivering his acceptance speech tonight.
While Mr. McGreevey's modest agenda leaves him room to move, it also may allow skeptics to question whether he is up to the job he has finally won. But those who know him best say Mr. McGreevey has often been misjudged in the past -- by Mr. Torricelli, by rivals in Woodbridge, by Mr. Schundler -- and it would be a mistake to do it again.
"So many people over the years have underestimated him," Mr. Lynch said. "Maybe that changes tomorrow. But I suspect that there are a lot of people who suspect that he's not as deep as he is, that he hasn't grown as much as he has, and that he's not as talented as he is."

HEADLINE: THE 2001 ELECTIONS: CONNECTICUT; 
Latino Mayor for Hartford; New Haven Incumbent Wins

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Hartford voters made history today by electing the city's first Latino mayor, while New Haven's longtime mayor, a fellow Democrat, won his race for a fifth term.
 In Waterbury, the endorsed Democrat, State Representative Michael J. Jarjura, won, according to unofficial results. He and two other candidates were competing to succeed Mayor Philip A. Giordano, who is serving the remainder of his term from prison, while he faces charges that he raped two girls. 
 In Hartford, Eddie A. Perez, the endorsed Democrat, defeated former City Councilman Robert F. Ludgin, a Democrat who petitioned to be on the ballot, by a vote of more than 4 to 1. 
At 9:30 last night, several supporters carried Mr. Perez on their shoulders into a victory celebration at Troutbrook Brewery, a Hartford bar. A band played salsa music and supporters chanted "Viva Eddie."
"It feels good to say Senor Alcalde," Mr. Perez said, as he addressed supporters who were calling him "Mr. Mayor."
Mr. Perez, 43, who moved to Hartford from his native Puerto Rico at age 14, made history not only in Hartford but also in New England, where he will be the first Hispanic mayor of a state capital. He is the president of a neighborhood group, Southside Institutions Neighborhood Alliance, and campaigned on a promise to build and renovate schools in a city where failing schools led to a state takeover of the Board of Education in 1997.
The job, however, is largely ceremonial because of Hartford's "weak mayor" form of government, which Mr. Perez's predecessor, Mike Peters, failed to change in a referendum last year.
Mr. Perez's supporters have said that they will push for another vote.
New Haven's mayor, John DeStefano Jr., a Democrat, won by a vote of nearly 3 to 1 over Joel Schiavone, a Republican real estate developer, according to unofficial results.
Two cornerstones of Mr. DeStefano's campaign were increasing home ownership and universal preschool for children.
Julio Gonzalez, the mayor's campaign chairman, said Mr. DiStefano, 46, promised to build more housing downtown and spur economic development there and at the harbor.
In Waterbury, Mr. Jarjura, 40, a lawyer and vice president of a family produce company who has served 10 years in the State Legislature, won with about 39 percent of the vote, according to unofficial results. He was challenged by Larry DePillo, 52, a Democrat who petitioned to be on the ballot, and Dennis Odle, 49, a Republican.
The new mayor will inherit the reins of a city whose finances and administration are under state control for the next four years in an effort to tackle a $50 million deficit.
Mr. Jarjura wanted to "restore dignity to city government," said his campaign manager, Garrett Casey.
Mr. Jarjura also vowed to seek a review of all city services and all nonincome-producing properties in an attempt to ease the burden of a 30 percent property tax increase imposed by the state oversight board, Mr. Casey said.
Elections were held in all but seven of the state's 169 towns, with races for mayor or first selectman in 132 towns. Problems with some voting machines complicated the balloting in two southeastern Connecticut towns. In New London, for a few minutes after the polls opened, voters were in some cases unable to choose candidates from more than one party because the machines had been prepared incorrectly. All votes cast during those few minutes will be counted in the regular tally, but a record of the number of votes cast will be retained as evidence should someone challenge the results.
In Waterford, all the pointers on four machines at two different polling places pointed to blank spaces from 6 a.m. until 9 a.m.
Officials said 225 people voted on these machines, and their votes would not be counted but kept aside for a record.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eddie A. Perez, who will be the first Latino mayor in Hartford's history, was carried on his supporters' shoulders during a victory celebration last night. Mr. Perez, the endorsed Democrat, won by a 4-to-1 ratio. (Patrick Raycraft/The Hartford Courant via The Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
In Suburbia, Vouchers Sink Schundler's Campaign

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: PLAINSBORO, N.J. 

 BODY:
IT almost seemed that in his run for New Jersey governor, Bret D. Schundler forgot he needed the suburban vote. New Jersey, the most suburban state, with the nation's highest annual income, $54,226 per household. In no other major industrial state do cities count so little, says James Hughes, a Rutgers public policy expert. Only 10 percent of New Jersey people live in its six biggest cities (compared to New York State, where 60 percent do.)
 So what did Mr. Schundler pick for a cornerstone of his campaign? A $1 billion school voucher/tax credit program that would provide public financing for mainly city children to attend private and parochial schools. Forget whether this is a violation of the separation of church and state. It was suicide for a New Jersey Republican. Vouchers have no appeal to suburban Republicans. Suburbanites have terrific public schools and pay high taxes for them. They're going to vote for a man who wants them to pay more taxes so that poor city kids can attend private school? 
 Yesterday, voters here miles from Mr. Schundler's headquarters at the Princeton Marriott were unanimous. "We moved to Plainsboro for the public schools," said Matt Poulter, a Merrill Lynch worker who voted for the Republican Christie Whitman two times, but for the Democrat James E. McGreevey yesterday. "Why give private schools our money?"
"If you want to send your kids to private school, pay for it yourself," said Shelley Marini, a professional service manager who voted for McGreevey. Even Republicans voting for Schundler, like Pat Luther, wife of the local Republican chairman, seemed miffed. "I never understood the voucher thing," she said. "We pay high property taxes for good public schools." 
Several years ago, I interviewed Mr. Schundler about vouchers. The Jersey City mayor seemed miffed that Governor Whitman hadn't passed a voucher plan in the Republican-controlled Legislature, and he was sure it was just a matter of time. He could not see that Governor Whitman, of Somerset County, was the quintessential soccer mom; that the Republican Senate leader at the time, Donald T. DiFrancesco of Scotch Plains, was a suburban soccer dad; and that mom and dad were never going to make a voucher plan for the Jersey City whiz kid.
Why didn't Mr. Schundler take the easy way out and drop it? He is an intellectual, a man who believes in ideas, making him a political rarity. At Harvard, he could be painfully intense whatever his cause was -- human rights or his Christian beliefs. In the 1980's, when he was still a Democrat, he wasn't a pragmatic Mondale Democrat; he was a Gary Hart Democrat. In the 1990's, when he took a stand against abortion, he didn't say he personally opposed it, but believed in a woman's right to choose; to Mr. Schundler, abortion was murder, and not even rape justified murder.
He often says school choice is today's civil rights issue. And yesterday, this conservative Republican suffered the same fate as those liberals from the 1970's who tried to use government to help promote racial integration through methods like school busing. At the Marriott, he sounded like a 70's liberal. As reporters asked if he was bracing for a loss, he seemed genuinely humble when he said: "A good life isn't about getting to someplace any way. A good life is doing anything you can to make the world a better place." 
THE main thing he did offer suburbanites -- a plan to ban tolls on the Garden State Parkway -- was not believable. "Cut the tolls?" said Mrs. Luther, a Republican. "Not with the way the economy is going." Or as David Koricki, 19, voting for the first time (and for Mr. McGreevey), said, "Not going to happen." After Sept. 11, Mr. Schundler's plans seemed even more out of step to suburbanites who would be happy to hold onto what they had. "Suburbanites are just hoping for the status quo," Mr. Hughes said.
Mr. McGreevey didn't feel pressure to come up with an ambitious education plan to help inner-city children; he just had to be Not Bret Schundler. At the end of their fifth debate, the two candidates made silly comparisons about which had done more to fight crime; Mr. Schundler of urban Jersey City or Mr. McGreevey of suburban Woodbridge. And Mr. Schundler let go one of his snide comments: "You're the mayor of Mayberry and you couldn't keep it safe."
Replied Mr. McGreevey, "I consider Mayberry a compliment." Every week, Andy and Aunt Bea and Opie had more than enough worries just with what was happening on Main Street, and because Mr. McGreevey was riveted on that one basic idea, he beat the idea man last night.
