HEADLINE: THE 2001 ELECTIONS: GOVERNOR; 
Democrat Vows to Alter Way 'Business Is Done in Trenton'

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Wednesday, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
James E. McGreevey, the Democratic mayor of Woodbridge, easily won election Tuesday as New Jersey's 51st governor, defeating a fiery conservative Republican, Bret D. Schundler, who never gained the support of his party's moderate establishment.
 With 98 percent of the vote counted, Mr. McGreevey had 56 percent of the vote to Mr. Schundler's 42 percent, a landslide by recent standards: the last two governor's races were decided by margins of one percentage point or less. 
 Mr. McGreevey's victory came as a Democrat, Mark R. Warner, won the governor's post in Virginia, loosening the iron grip that Republicans have had on top offices in that state. Page A19. 
The entire New Jersey Legislature was up for re-election Tuesday as well, and Mr. McGreevey's coattails were lengthy enough for his party to recapture control of at least one house of the Legislature for the first time since 1991.
Democrats won control of the General Assembly, but the results of key races in the State Senate indicated that the upper house could be evenly divided for the first time in modern New Jersey history.
Indeed, Mr. McGreevey, in an exultant victory speech at 10:16 p.m., vowed that his administration would cross party lines to "change the way business is done in Trenton."
"The government that we build will be a government of Republicans, independents and, yes, Democrats -- a government for all the people," he shouted to a mobbed hotel ballroom in East Brunswick. "A government that is accountable to you, and only to you."
Mr. McGreevey, whose pregnant wife, Dina, remained hospitalized for pre-term labor, vowed to "work day and night, with the full fiber of my being, with every measure of my strength," to tackle soaring property taxes, failing public schools, vanishing open space and official corruption and mismanagement.
"Now let's get to work!" he cried.
Mr. McGreevey took the stage even before Mr. Schundler had wrapped up an extraordinary, rambling 23-minute concession speech, in which he acknowledged his defeat almost in passing -- and attributed it mainly to a lack of campaign money -- before issuing a warning that sounded like a demand for a rematch in four years.
"He has said he is committed to not raising taxes," Mr. Schundler said in one of several challenges he laid down before Mr. McGreevey. "We're going to hold him to that."
The finger-pointing in defeat started early this morning. And in a sign of how ugly the battle could soon get for control of the Republican Party, Bill Pascoe, Mr. Schundler's voluble campaign manager, assailed the acting governor, Donald T. DiFrancesco, for having undercut Mr. Schundler repeatedly since withdrawing from the primary last April.
"I think he's cut a deal, a long time ago, to sabotage the Republican gubernatorial campaign," Mr. Pascoe said.
Mr. DiFrancesco could not be reached early this morning to comment.
Mr. McGreevey, 44, nearly unseated Gov. Christie Whitman in 1997, then barely took a breath before resuming what would prove a six-year battle for the job. This time around, he enjoyed the overwhelming support of women, blacks, Democrats, independents, and poor and middle-class voters, according to a survey of voters leaving polling places.
Exit interviews with 1,718 voters found that taxes and the state's economy were foremost on people's minds. Those who said they were concerned about the economy tended to vote for Mr. McGreevey, while those who worried more about taxes tended to favor Mr. Schundler.
But education was the next most important issue cited by voters, who appeared to accept Mr. McGreevey's argument that Mr. Schundler's school choice proposals would threaten public schools: 70 percent of those concerned most about education said they voted for Mr. McGreevey.
If the result of the governor's race proved anticlimactic, it came at the end of what may well have been the most unpredictable political year in New Jersey history.
Mr. McGreevey, who fended off a surprise challenge last summer from another Democrat, United States Senator Robert G. Torricelli, had no rivals within his party when the year began.
But Mr. Schundler entered the Republican primary as a dark horse, a social conservative in a staunchly moderate state, who had never held a state office and who was unloved by the elite in his own party.
But Mr. Schundler's opponents proceeded to self-destruct in dramatic fashion. Mr. DiFrancesco, the president of the State Senate, was the early favorite to clinch the Republican nomination. But his ascension to the office as acting governor, following Mrs. Whitman's departure for Washington, subjected him to a new level of scrutiny. After an avalanche of reports about his past business dealings and allegations of ethical lapses, he withdrew from the race.
The Republican Party's moderate wing was still unwilling to embrace Mr. Schundler; instead, it drafted Bob Franks, a former congressman who had lost a close race for the United States Senate the previous November, and extended the primary by three weeks to give Mr. Franks extra time to raise money.
But Mr. Franks's hastily plotted campaign strategy proved catastrophically wrongheaded: he ran to the left of Mr. Schundler, painting him as an extremist on social issues. Mr. Franks seemed to succeed only in angering the party's right wing, however, and conservatives came out in force to give Mr. Schundler a 14-point margin of victory.
Mr. Schundler, for his part, had run a nearly perfect primary, even his detractors conceded. But in hindsight it appeared he had pushed so hard for conservatives' support that he found it hard to get back to the crucial political middle in the fall.
His flawless touch seemed to have deserted him soon after the June 26 primary, when Mr. Schundler tried to take the issues of abortion and guns off the table in the campaign. He stumbled badly in each case, digging himself a deeper hole. And he learned the hard way -- through devastating public opinion polls -- that supporting tighter firearms restrictions has become a prerequisite for statewide officeseekers.
Mr. McGreevey, meanwhile, quickly developed an effective, three-pronged campaign mantra to depict Mr. Schundler as an extremist. Mr. McGreevey said his opponent opposed abortion even in cases of rape and incest; favored a law making it easier for people to get permits to carry concealed weapons; and would drain the public schools of nearly $600 million. And to the welcome surprise of Mr. McGreevey's campaign aides, Mr. Schundler's heated efforts to rebut these charges -- in news conferences, television advertisements and debates -- often succeeded only in focusing greater public attention on them.
Mr. Schundler's challenges seemed to multiply by the hour. Mr. McGreevey and the Democratic Party built up a huge financial advantage, and Mr. Schundler never succeeded in plugging into the Republican fund-raising machine that had amply underwritten Mrs. Whitman and Mr. DiFrancesco for years.
Worse, while Mr. McGreevey had the entire Democratic Party rallying him on, Mr. Schundler faced a constant campaign of sabotage by Mr. DiFrancesco. The acting governor never hid his disdain for Mr. Schundler, whom he blamed for the news reports that had driven him to quit the race.
So as Mr. Schundler tried to cobble together a platform of popular pocketbook issues that would appeal to suburbanites, such as a vow to remove the tolls from the Garden State Parkway, Mr. DiFrancesco used the power of his office to denigrate Mr. Schundler's proposals as "intellectually dishonest."
Mr. Schundler also continued to hurt himself. His hopes of victory rested on winning over the blue-collar Democrats and independents in the broad middle of the New Jersey electorate. But he antagonized union members when it was reported that he favored laws that would curtail the rights of labor organizers.
Still, Mr. Schundler began the homestretch of the campaign after Labor Day assured that he would have the active support of President Bush and members of his cabinet; after all, an upset victory for a conservative in New Jersey would be viewed as a mighty validation for the new administration. And a surprise court ruling in New Jersey made it possible for Republicans in Washington to spend millions on TV commercials for Mr. Schundler without violating the state's campaign finance law.
Mr. Schundler, hoping to woo Jewish voters, then departed for a short trip to Israel. He was there on Sept. 11, when the hijacked airplanes struck their targets.
The terrorist attacks staggered both candidates. But it locked in, for several weeks, a sizable McGreevey lead in the polls. And it was Mr. McGreevey, cautious as ever, who benefited once politics resumed.
While Mr. McGreevey refrained from campaigning, Mr. Schundler, eager to demonstrate the leadership qualities he believed voters would seek in a time of crisis, sought out reporters to describe his many ideas for ways to improve New Jersey's defenses against terrorism and its readiness for emergencies. But he also spoke critically of some emergency workers who responded on Sept. 11, triggering criticism from members of both parties.
The episode, after which Mr. Schundler increasingly attacked the news media, struck even his own advisers as a turning point.
Mr. McGreevey, meanwhile, bathed in the adulation of every major police, fire and labor union, whose endorsements Mr. Schundler was left to dismiss as the tainted products of special interests.
But while Mr. Schundler was pouring forth with proposals for tax and toll cuts, a complicated overhaul of the public education system, and other ambitious measures, Mr. McGreevey said little that was specific and less that was controversial.
His reticence on the subject of taxes gave Mr. Schundler a huge opening, which he exploited during their televised debates. He pledged not to raise taxes, and lampooned Mr. McGreevey as the second coming of Jim Florio, the one-term governor who raised taxes by $2.8 billion in 1990.
In the final weeks of the campaign, Mr. Schundler finally seemed to have hit upon a resonant message: taxes, taxes, taxes. 
For Mr. Schundler, however, the most poignant effect of the Sept. 11 attacks may have been an indirect one. His friend in the White House, President Bush, saw his favorability ratings rise to historic levels. But Mr. Bush was busy prosecuting a war, securing the nation's defenses and rallying its morale. The promised trip to New Jersey to aid Mr. Schundler's campaign would never come to pass.

HEADLINE: British Chain Reports 20% Profit Surge 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Radical changes at Marks & Spencer, once a stalwart of British retailing, seemed to be paying off today when the company announced a 20 percent surge in six-month profit.
 Bucking a general economic slowdown, which has been worsened by the Sept. 11 attacks in New York and Washington, the company said net income in the six months to the end of September rose to $:144.2 million ($210 million), compared with $:120 million in the comparable period last year. 
 The rise, within analysts' expectations, was the biggest in four years, despite evidence that British shoppers are growing reluctant to spend as economic growth falters. But analysts and the company's management remained cautious that the good news after three years of gloom could all too easily evaporate if shoppers stayed away from Marks & Spencer during the critical Christmas shopping period. 
The improvements so far, said Luc Vandevelde, the chief executive, were "not representative for us to talk about recovery." He added, "We will have to wait until after Christmas."
The possible stirrings of a turnaround are the latest twist in a three-year story during which the company -- once an investor's favorite because of steady growth in profits that hit $:1 billion in 1997 -- has wrestled with setbacks as many younger female shoppers turned away from its lackluster, midprice clothes in favor of zippier offerings from rivals like Next and Matalan.
The chain, once a byword for British Main Street quality, dropped its home-grown management, turned away from relatively pricey British suppliers and, this year, reversed an ambitious overseas expansion program. It sold off stores in France, Spain and other parts of Europe while seeking to pull out of units in the United States, including Kings Supermarkets and the Brooks Brothers retail clothing chain.
Mr. Vandevelde said today that the Sept. 11 attacks had derailed the Brooks Brothers sale. "We were waiting for final confirmation of the bid. Then we had to stop and restart the process again," he said, without going into detail. But the company said that, despite the delay, it would proceed with plans to hand back some $:2 billion ($2.9 billion) at today's prices to shareholders next March. The share price rose today by as much as 7.9 percent, to 325 pence, the highest since January 2000. Hopes of a recovery have pushed the company's stock up by 60 percent this year. It ranks among the top performers on the London stock market.
Apart from revamping, the company has also been casting about for a new, less stodgy image. It hired George Davies, who founded its rival Next, to create a new women's wear range called Per Una, but those clothes began entering stores only two days before the end of the half-year reporting period.
As it struggles for a new identity, Marks & Spencer is also experimenting with food-only stores to wring profit from its high-end packaged foods and sandwiches. It said today that it would open 20 more Simply Food convenience stores.
Analysts questioned, however, whether the growth spurt could be sustained in a year-end quarter of unseasonably warm weather that may have hit October sales and undermined the company's ability to sustain its resurgence. The figures made "pretty confused reading," ABN Amro said in a research note, while the company is heading for a period of higher costs from refurbishing 100 of its 310 British stores.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Judge to Hear From 9 States On Microsoft

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON with STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
A federal district judge said today that she would hold a pair of separate but related proceedings early next year to consider the proposed antitrust settlement between the Bush administration and Microsoft and to hear arguments by a group of states that officially broke ranks with the federal government in search of tougher penalties.
 The order by Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly of United States District Court in Washington followed the announcement this afternoon that nine states involved in the case, led by New York, Illinois, Michigan and Ohio, had decided to join the Bush administration's settlement after it was slightly revised in negotiations that concluded at about 3:30 this morning. 
 The other states that agreed to the settlement are Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, North Carolina and Wisconsin. These nine supporting states will recoup their legal costs from Microsoft. 
Nine other states and the District of Columbia declined to sign the agreement. Officials from some of the states were still considering whether to join with the Justice Department. But lawyers involved in the case said they expected that a core group would challenge the proposed consent decree for failing to address the concerns of two federal courts that found Microsoft had abused its monopoly position in the software market. The dissenting states say the proposed settlement has too many loopholes and does not do enough to promote competition in the industry. 
The states that refused to sign included many that are home to Microsoft's biggest rivals and others in the technology industry that have complained about Microsoft's aggressive market tactics, including California, Massachusetts and Utah. The others that did not sign were Connecticut, Florida, Iowa, Kansas, Minnesota and West Virginia.
The decision by some of the states to dissent complicates, and could ultimately delay, the implementation of the proposed settlement decree. If those states prevail, however, it could lead to more restrictions imposed on Microsoft.
At a brief hearing this afternoon, Judge Kollar-Kotelly denied a request by Microsoft that she stop the dissenting states' proceedings until after she issued her ruling on the proposed consent decree. Microsoft's legal maneuver was an attempt to diminish the legal prospects of the opposing states. Those states have said that central elements of the agreement -- greater disclosure of software code, nondiscrimination against rivals and computer makers, and limits on the ability of Microsoft to leverage its monopoly in the server markets -- have overly broad exceptions that would make the proposed settlement largely ineffective.
Under the scheduling order issued today, Judge Kollar-Kotelly will be receiving a competitive analysis of the proposed settlement and a wide range of comments about the deal from supporters and critics over the next three months. All the evidence in that proceeding is expected to be submitted by the end of February, which is shortly before the judge will begin hearings on the remedies proposed by those states that have dissented. The states not backing the agreement have been ordered to file their list of proposed remedies next month.
Both the Justice Department and Microsoft applauded the states that decided to join in the agreement.
"The fact that so many states have joined the federal government in supporting this agreement is a very significant positive step toward resolving these issues once and for all," said Bill Gates, the co-founder and chairman of Microsoft. "While this decree will place significant restrictions on our business, we believe this is a fair and reasonable settlement that will be good for consumers, good for the high-tech industry and good for the economy."
Charles A. James, the assistant attorney general in charge of the antitrust division, said that "the Justice Department and the states that have settled have done the heavy lifting here."
"Our settlement is now the base line," Mr. James said. "Consumers in Massachusetts and California will get the benefit of this settlement. If they can get more, that's for them to determine. At the end of the day, the resolution set before the court today will be the resolution of the Microsoft antitrust litigation."
Mr. James dismissed criticism by some of Microsoft's competitors that the consent decree was the product of a back-room deal involving heavy political pressure from Microsoft and other administration officials outside of the Justice Department.
"There was no political influence whatsoever involved in this process," he said in an interview this afternoon. "This was an antitrust decision. We did a lot of good things. Even the states which have not signed on have not said we did anything improper. There is no intrigue here." 
Other officials said the consent decree was the product of a more narrow reading by the Bush administration than by Microsoft's critics as the parties considered last June's decision by the United States Court of Appeals here. That opinion, which overturned a lower court's order to break up Microsoft, found a variety of antitrust violations and ordered the case returned to the district court to consider appropriate remedy.
The eight late-night changes to the proposed consent decree would broaden the disclosures Microsoft must make to rivals about the operation of its powerful software for data-serving machines. By adding the phrase "or the Internet" to one section, lawyers for the states explicitly required Microsoft to reveal technical details about servers other than those used only for office networks. Experts said that change could expand the settlement to cover Microsoft's future business strategies of providing Internet services.
Much of the criticism of the Justice Department settlement and the efforts of some states to tighten the language has been prompted by skepticism that Microsoft will voluntarily live up to its terms. Indeed, the current antitrust suit against Microsoft grew out of allegations that the company had violated a consent decree it signed with the Justice Department in 1994.
For that reason, some experts believe that the sanctions against Microsoft, regardless of their precise final form, will prove highly regulatory, insuring that the three-person technical committee overseeing compliance will be busy. 
"Does anybody really trust Microsoft to comply?" said David Farber, a computer science professor at the University of Pennsylvania, who testified in the trial as an expert witness on the government's behalf. "There are going to endless marches to that three-person technical committee."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tom Miller, left, the Iowa attorney general; Charles A. James, center, an assistant United States attorney general; and Richard Blumenthal, the Connecticut attorney general, at a news conference yesterday. (Carol T. Powers for The New York Times)(pg. C4)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED -- AN OVERVIEW: NOV. 6, 2001; 
More Troops, More Accusations, More Economic Stimulus

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
 Naturally, the Bush administration has wanted international support for its war on terrorism, but only up to a point. British troops aside, the idea of foreign armies joining the actual fighting in Afghanistan has hardly thrilled the Pentagon, where the feeling is that more players mean more back-seat drivers. So Washington has for the most part ignored offers of help. Until now.

BUILDING THE MILITARY STAKES -- With European countries practically banging on the door, the United States took steps, however reluctantly, to expand the coalition's armed might. In Europe, public support for the war has weakened, and government leaders there sense that with a piece of the military action, their peoples will have a greater stake in seeing this campaign through to the end. France, Italy and Germany all want to send troops -- a significant development in particular for the Germans, who have not deployed soldiers beyond Europe since World War II.
 One possible leading role that NATO seeks for itself is delivering food to Afghanistan as winter nears. That task could prove vital. Despite American air drops of food packages, as many as six million Afghans are said to be on the brink of starvation, after two decades of war and four years of drought. The United Nations World Food Program is already trying to help. Its trucks are carrying about 250 million pounds of wheat across the Khyber Pass between Pakistan and Afghanistan. But they must travel some of the worst highways in the world, with drivers keeping one eye out for American bombs and the other for holes the size of refrigerators.
To encourage continued political support, President Bush spoke by satellite television to an antiterrorism conference of former Soviet bloc countries in Europe. In a sense, he was preaching to the choir when he compared Al Qaeda terrorists to the "fascists and totalitarians" of the mid-20th century. They had "the same mad, global ambitions," he said. 
For the first time, the president himself accused Al Qaeda's leader, Osama bin Laden, of seeking to acquire chemical, biological and nuclear weapons. But other officials said there was no new evidence that Mr. bin Laden had in fact gotten his hands on weapons of mass destruction.

MAKING THE MILITARY MOVES -- On the ground in Afghanistan, the anti-Taliban Northern Alliance gave signs of finally going on the attack. Its commanders said their forces had captured three districts not far from Mazar-i-Sharif, a Taliban-held city at an important crossroad. Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said he could not verify the claims. But if they prove true, it would be the biggest breakthrough to date for the Americans' proxy ground forces. They did it, alliance leaders said, with help from some 15 American advisers who organized troops and helped plan the attacks.
Back home, there was more than the usual assortment of good news and bad news.
The Postal Service said the anthrax scare had reduced the volume of mail by about 10 percent, for a revenue loss of at least $500 million. A bit of offsetting good news was that no new anthrax cases have been reported since Friday. And the Federal Bureau of Investigation in effect said "never mind" about that threat to bridges on the West Coast. It is "not deemed credible" any more, the bureau said.
That was fine. But then the F.B.I.'s senior official for counterterrorism told a Senate hearing that investigators remained clueless about the source of the anthrax that has killed 4 Americans and sickened 14 others. Not only that, the agency could not even say how many laboratories in this country handle the anthrax bacteria. Senators, as might be imagined, were not amused.

MASSAGING THE ECONOMY -- The economy, weakening rapidly since Sept. 11, got a boost when the Federal Reserve cut its most important short-term interest rate for the 10th time this year -- to 2 percent, a level not seen in 40 years. Some analysts saw that as auguring an economic turnaround, perhaps by the middle of 2002.
Among the places hit hard financially was New York City, where voters chose a new mayor to lead their recovery. The race was close: the Democrat Mark Green, the city's public advocate, vs. the Republican Michael R. Bloomberg, a self-made billionaire. The winner has a tough act to follow. Rudolph W. Giuliani's stewardship since Sept. 11 has given him virtually a walk-on-water reputation in New York and around the country.
 CLYDE HABERMAN

HEADLINE: Seeking City Money, Lincoln Center Submits Its Renovation Plans 

BYLINE:  By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
After months of argument, Lincoln Center's powerful performing arts organizations agreed this week to send City Hall a redevelopment plan of nearly $1.2 billion, which does not include a proposed separate on-campus home for the New York City Opera but sets aside $240 million for a new opera house elsewhere if a site can be found.
 The plan also omits a hotly disputed glass-enclosed galleria connecting public spaces that the architect Frank Gehry had been commissioned to develop. 
 The consensus, reached at a meeting on Monday afternoon, was an effort to set aside lingering differences and secure a $24 million payment that had been pledged by the city, participants said. They said that even as the parties shook hands on the submission to the city, elements of the package were still in dispute and could change in the coming months and years. 
Any member organization can still veto the plan.
The payment would be the first installment of a 10-year commitment of $240 million made by the departing administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani before the events of Sept. 11 toward a sweeping redevelopment program originally estimated at $1.5 billion. The mayor's office said that Mr. Giuliani still believed that the Lincoln Center project and other plans central to the city's status as a cultural capital "should be encouraged." 
The bulk of the money -- the biggest single item is the reconstruction of Avery Fisher Hall -- would have to be raised privately.
Marshall Rose, the departing chairman of the redevelopment project, said that the 11 members of a Lincoln Center constituent committee, made up of organizations like the New York Philharmonic, the Metropolitan Opera, the New York City Ballet and the City Opera, "unanimously agreed" to submit the preliminary plan to the city by the end of the week. He declined to discuss its contents until it was presented to the mayor. 
Participants cautioned, however, that elements of the final plan were far from settled in this fiercely divisive year, which included the recent resignation of Mr. Rose as redevelopment chairman. Monday was his last meeting. 
According to a confidential executive summary distributed to members and obtained by The New York Times, the plan lays out spending for a host of projects from the extensive redesign of Avery Fisher Hall, to new auditoriums for film, expanded catering facilities and a greening of Damrosch Park on the campus's southwest corner. 
Some of the expenditures may still fall out in the face of economics if they are determined to be more wish-list than vital. 
According to the summary, the preliminary master plan rules out a new home for the City Opera in Damrosch Park or elsewhere on the Lincoln Center campus but allocates $240 million for a 2,200-seat opera house if a site can be found someplace else. If the City Opera stays put, the plan calls for spending up to $87 million at the New York State Theater, which is shared with the New York City Ballet, to improve its operatic acoustics.
The plan also kills the proposed $100 million Gehry glass galleria. But it budgets about $150 million for the enhancement of other public spaces, including landscaping of Damrosch Park and a new centerpiece fountain in the plaza.
The proposals to build a new City Opera house in Damrosch Park, and the galleria, which would have connected various public spaces and would have vaulted over the Metropolitan Opera House, had been adamantly opposed by the Met and its general manager, Joseph Volpe, who was backed by Beverly Sills, Lincoln Center's chairwoman.
Although parts of Lincoln Center have been renovated and patched up many times over 40 years, officials saw the need in 1999 for a far more sweeping effort to modernize old halls with the latest technology and correct spatial compromises in the original design.
The plans for changes in the five and a half acres of outdoor space are what proved the most contentious. But most of the spending involves individual projects of the member groups within their existing buildings and is therefore of limited concern to their Lincoln Center neighbors.
The New York Philharmonic, for example, is down for the most expensive item, a $326 million total rebuilding of Avery Fisher Hall, whose acoustics have proved troublesome from Day 1. 
The new hall would have 2,400 seats, 338 fewer than now, to improve the sound, and there would be high-tech enclosed viewing booths, more backstage space and donor and food-service amenities. 
Another major allocation is $179 million for an expansion of the lobby and backstage areas at the Metropolitan Opera House. But Mr. Volpe has said in the past that the Met has not made a decision on proceeding with a project of that size and the fund-raising it would entail. 
The plan also sets aside $10.5 million for an expansion of the Film Society of Lincoln Center's quarters in the Samuel B. and David Rose Building on 65th Street, which includes the Walter Reade Theater. The society would get a new 150-seat theater to continue runs of films that prove unexpectedly popular -- a so-called "rollover house" -- and a screening room with up to 100 seats, along with a new marquee on the street.
The Rose building, completed in 1992 for $180 million, is itself down for $15 million in improvements, including new lighting and utilities in the Kaplan Penthouse, where Lincoln Center often entertains guests.
The plan also allocates $69 million to Alice Tully Hall for lobby expansion and refurbishment; $58 million to the Vivian Beaumont and Mitzi E. Newhouse theaters for redesign of entrances and lobbies; and $26 million to the Juilliard School for stage, classroom and office enhancements.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE CALIFORNIA ALERT; 
F.B.I. Lifts the Warning About West Coast Bridges

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
The Federal Bureau of Investigation today lifted a warning issued last week that terrorists might be planning to destroy bridges on the West Coast and said its investigation showed that the threat was "not credible."
 The announcement should ease some of the tension felt up and down the West Coast after Gov. Gray Davis of California made the warning public over the wishes of federal officials. 
 F.B.I. and Justice Department officials said a separate, nationwide alert of possibly imminent terrorist attacks remained in place, at least for a few more days. They said the broad warning, issued on Oct. 29, was prompted by intercepts of telephone conversations in which members of Osama bin Laden's terrorist network spoke urgently of an upcoming attack against American targets. 
The officials said the nationwide alert was still in effect even though the original time frame -- Oct. 29 through this Monday -- had expired, and even though there was no substantial new evidence this week of plans for a terrorist strike.
In a brief statement, the F.B.I. said today that it had issued the warning about West Coast bridges based on "uncorroborated information indicating the possibility of additional terrorist attacks targeting suspension bridges" from Nov. 2 to Nov. 7. But a subsequent investigation "has determined that the threat to suspension bridges is not deemed credible."
Law enforcement officials said the original tip about the bridges had come into the Customs Service from a source who had sometimes proved credible in the past.
On the basis of the tip, they said, the F.B.I. issued an advisory to law enforcement officials in six Western states last Wednesday night. "Reportedly, unspecified groups are targeting suspension bridges on the West Coast," the advisory said.
But officials said a feverish investigation over the last week had determined that the source was mistaken, and that there was no special threat to West Coast bridges.
Federal and state law enforcement officials have criticized the decision by Governor Davis to make the warning public at a news conference on Thursday in which he described the threat as "credible." 
F.B.I. and Justice Department officials have said that they never intended the warning to be made public because it was unsubstantiated -- far less credible, they said, than the information that led to the nationwide warning on Oct. 29 -- but that they provided it to state officials to enable them to beef up security around bridges. The governors of the two other Pacific Coast states, Gary Locke of Washington and John Kitzhaber of Oregon, also received the F.B.I. warning. But they did not make it public.
Governor Davis's announcement startled Californians, dominated local newspaper and television coverage and led some commuters to find alternate ways of getting to work. Traffic on the state's two most famous bridges -- the Golden Gate and the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge -- fell by about 3 percent during some rush-hour periods last week. Some commuters left their cars behind and took ferries across the bay.
Governor Davis defended his announcement again Monday night, saying: "My No. 1 job is to keep Californians safe. I'm going to err on the side of caution." 
But within minutes of the F.B.I.'s announcement withdrawing the threat, California lawmakers were accusing the governor of seizing the national spotlight at the expense of frightening the public and scaring tourists away from a state that has been seriously affected economically since Sept. 11.
"If you have credible evidence that there is going to be an attack, you have a duty to disclose it," said Dave Cox, head of the Republican caucus in the State Assembly. "But if it couldn't be corroborated, then in fact it's a publicity stunt that is disingenuous with the public."
Worried that the public will become desensitized to future threats, California Republicans called for a new system for handling warnings about potential attacks, so that residents will not assume their elected officials are simply "crying wolf," as Bill Jones, the California secretary of state, put it.
"We need to leave this to the professionals: the F.B.I., the attorney general," said Mr. Jones, who announced his intention to run against Governor Davis last March. "This whole experienced has not increased the public's confidence."
Despite the lifting of the threat, officials said that security on California bridges will remain at its current high level. National Guard troops, Coast Guard helicopters and extra California Highway Patrol officers are on duty.
"We will remain in our present state for the time being," said Mary Currie, a spokeswoman for the Golden Gate Bridge authority. The authority also plans to keep its current schedule of running two extra cross-bay ferries through Wednesday evening.
The most visible, and to many commuters, unsettling, reminder of security on the bridges, National Guard troops carrying M-16 rifles, wearing camouflage uniforms, and riding in Humvees, will remain for now, said Lt. Col. Terry Knight, a spokesman. 
"We're in place until further notice," Colonel Knight said. "We've been talking about bridges and infrastructures and roads and waterways since Sept. 11. So we'll keep the Guard in place for a little while longer."
The furor in California over the warning was more evidence of the challenges faced by the Bush administration in deciding how much intelligence information to release about potential terrorist threats after the Sept. 11 hijackings.
The administration has been criticized for its two nationwide public warnings -- on Oct. 11 and Oct. 29 -- of possibly imminent terrorist strikes.
In issuing the warning last week, Attorney General John Ashcroft said the threat of another large terrorist attack was "credible," but he acknowledged that the intelligence leading to the warning "does not contain specific information as to the type of attack or specific targets."
Many state and local law enforcement officials said such unspecific warnings served little purpose, since they had remained on high alert since Sept. 11, and tended to create panic in communities that were already under intense strain.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: ECONOMIC LEGISLATION; 
Amid Stimulus Wrangling, a Call for the President to Step In

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Congressional Republicans stepped up attacks on Senate Democrats over economic stimulus legislation today, while Democrats argued that it was time for President Bush to get directly involved to avoid a partisan breakdown.
 Democrats said they would push their $67 billion bill, which emphasizes temporary unemployment and health insurance benefits and short-term tax breaks, through the Finance Committee on Thursday. But as Senator John B. Breaux, a moderate Democrat from Louisiana, observed, neither party has the votes to pass a bill. 
 Republicans argued that Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and the chairman of the Finance Committee, should meet with Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, to work out a compromise with the $89 billion plan Mr. Grassley has put forward. Mr. Grassley, whose plan would speed up tax cuts passed earlier this year, told reporters that he and Mr. Baucus had worked well together on Mr. Bush's tax-cut proposal last spring. 
"If the kids in the Senate get out of the way and leave it to us professionals that know how to do this, we'll get the job done," Mr. Grassley said. 
Mr. Baucus said the Republicans were just trying to force Democrats to compromise twice, once in the Senate and then again with House Republicans, who passed a $110 billion bill nearly two weeks ago that was even more heavily tilted toward tax cuts for corporations and higher-income people than the Grassley bill.
"This is the time for the president to exercise presidential leadership and step in," Mr. Baucus said. Without such help, he said, "it's going to be partisan and unproductive."
The White House has said it would not get involved until after a Senate bill was passed and the measure went to a House-Senate conference.
The skirmishing began early in the day, when Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas and the House majority leader, said that Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota and the Senate majority leader, did not act as though the economy was a "front-burner issue."
Then, after it appeared that the Democrats had the votes in the Finance Committee to bring a bill to the floor, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the minority leader, accused them of "pursuing a totally partisan bill." Mr. Lott threatened to delay the bill with amendments and, if necessary, a filibuster.
In addition to its tax cuts and insurance provisions, the Senate Democratic economic plan also includes $20 billion in spending for additional measures to promote homeland defense, including bioterrorism and food safety defenses, and improved security at airports and federal establishments. But at a meeting today with Congressional leaders, President Bush said he was adamantly opposed to any spending for domestic security beyond the $40 billion in emergency appropriations approved by Congress in September.
Even Republicans on the House Appropriations Committee, including the chairman, Representative C. W. Bill Young of Florida, have sought additional spending. But the president would not discuss such proposals today, said Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the ranking Democrat on the committee.
Mr. Daschle contended that Democrats had been the ones who reached out to discuss compromise, and he joined Mr. Baucus in appealing for administration involvement.
If that does not happen and Republicans filibuster, he said, Democrats will not back down.
"Our desire is to stay on this legislation until we succeed," Mr. Daschle said. "If it takes additional days or weeks of effort, we're going to do that."
Asked if he might extend the Senate schedule, which usually requires senators to be in town only from Tuesday through Thursday, to five days a week, Mr. Daschle replied, "We might even work six days a week."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 8, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about disputes in the Senate over economic legislation referred incorrectly in some copies to the home state of the majority leader, Tom Daschle. It is South Dakota, not Iowa.

HEADLINE: While Congress Argues, the Fed Acts 

 BODY:
Yesterday the Federal Reserve cut interest rates for the 10th time this year in its campaign to revive the sluggish economy. The federal funds rate now stands at 2 percent, a 40-year low. The Fed offered no sign that it had reached the end of the rate cuts, yet there are powerful arguments against too many further reductions. Congress can save Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, some much-needed maneuvering room by taking over the job of supplying economic stimulus as soon as possible. 
 In the absence of a stimulus package, the markets have counted on Mr. Greenspan's rate cuts for succor. But the Fed cannot act solely as an economic engine. It must also guard against deflation today and high inflation in the future. Some prices are falling, which is normal in a recession. A wider decline in prices could stall a recovery by forcing more employers to shrink paychecks. The Fed has to leave some room between the federal funds rate and zero, in case a sudden flood of liquidity is needed to combat deflation. 
 There is also the danger of inflation. Though that looks remote now, inflation could be hard to restrain next year if the Fed goes too far. In several previous recessions, the Fed's last interest-rate cut was greeted by a jump in prices. The effects of rate cuts take six months or longer to percolate through the economy. At some point the Fed should sit back and wait to assess the effect of its moves.
Congress could take some of the pressure off Mr. Greenspan by drafting a reasonable stimulus package. Even in these extraordinary economic times, politics-as-usual has gotten in the way. Republicans fought hard to squeeze their plan, loaded with corporate bonuses that will do little to stimulate growth, through the House. Senate Democrats want extra spending, which the House is resisting.
The two parties' leaders met yesterday but failed to resolve their differences. For the moment, they should focus on the ideas they share: rebate checks for low-income tax filers, extended unemployment benefits and tax breaks linked directly to business investment. That would help to build consumers' confidence in the economy, and in their elected representatives.

HEADLINE: Mayor-Elect Michael Bloomberg 

 BODY:
In electing Michael Bloomberg mayor yesterday, New Yorkers were clearly hoping the man whom Rudolph Giuliani endorsed would turn out to be the kind of leader Mr. Giuliani has been during the weeks since Sept. 11. The choice of Mr. Bloomberg, a political novice, over Public Advocate Mark Green is in many ways a gamble, a leap into the unknown. But every resident of New York and every American who cares about the city will root for him to succeed. 
 The terror attack and its aftermath have overshadowed and befogged the campaign, and it seemed appropriate that when most New Yorkers went to bed last night, it was still impossible to predict who would be the victor. Mr. Green, who led the polls by double digits only a few weeks ago, suffered from the defection of many Latino voters who were angry at the defeat of Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer in the Democratic runoff. He was also overwhelmed by money. Mr. Bloomberg invested what is believed to be over $50 million into a campaign in which voters came to know him almost exclusively through his carefully tailored TV ads. 
 It was Mr. Bloomberg's identification with Mayor Giuliani that was his most powerful weapon. New Yorkers are still traumatized by loss. They know that soaring unemployment and gaping budget holes are inevitable. They know that further danger from terrorists is possible. They need a mayor who can restore the ambitious optimism that is the core of the city's character, and over the past two weeks more and more voters began taking Mr. Giuliani's word that Michael Bloomberg was the man who could do that.
He faces an unenviable challenge. He will now have to manage a greatly reduced budget, woo business interests to invest in Manhattan and take care of the needs of the victims of a staggering economy -- all at the same time. Mr. Bloomberg has said that one of his first actions will be to contact the city's union leaders, whose help he will desperately need. Those leaders had good reason to expect, only a few months ago, that their members would soon receive large and much-deserved raises. Mr. Bloomberg, whose own employees are not unionized, has had little experience in large labor negotiations. But his first impulse, to reach out and begin talking, was a wise one.
He must begin work immediately on preparing the budget that will be due within a few weeks of his inauguration, wrestling with shrinking revenues and expanding need for services. He must also become intensely involved in the rebuilding of Manhattan's downtown financial center. 
Finally, Mr. Bloomberg will have to contend with the big shadow thrown by Mr. Giuliani, who now occupies near-legendary status. Mr. Giuliani is moving on, but he is not likely to go away. The next mayor will never be able to match the strong, paternal image that Mr. Giuliani presented, and he should not try. He will have to rise to this moment differently, using his own voice in his own way to rally the city, manage it and keep it safe and financially sound.

HEADLINE: In a Turnaround, Virginia Elects a Democratic Governor 

BYLINE:  By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Mark R. Warner, a Democrat who campaigned like a Republican, easily won the Virginia governor's race today, loosening the grip that Republicans have had on most top offices in the state for almost a decade.
 Mr. Warner, a multimillionaire venture capitalist who outspent and outmaneuvered his Republican opponent, former Attorney General Mark L. Earley, led by 52 percent to 47 percent with 99 percent of precincts reporting. 
 The victory gave Democrats some bragging rights. But the Republicans held on to the office of attorney general, and in legislative elections they increased their numbers in the House of Delegates to almost two-thirds of seats, from slightly more than one-half. So it was unclear whether the Warner victory meant the Republican wave that has been sweeping across Virginia in recent years had been stopped, just as it was unclear whether there were any national implications in the victory. 
In his victory speech, Mr. Warner said that Virginians "want a new government and I'm here to accept the challenge."
But aware of the results from the state House of Delegates races, Mr. Warner said he was looking forward to "working cooperatively with the General Assembly."
Mr. Earley, in congratulating his opponent, called on Virginians to "move forward as one people." He said he was proud of his effort to extend a Republican record in Virginia "that history will recognize as a golden era."
Virginia law limits governors to a single term, so the incumbent, James S. Gilmore III, who also serves as national Republican chairman, could not seek re-election. Mr. Gilmore had urged Republicans nationwide to contribute to Mr. Earley's campaign, and they responded by providing $3 million of the $10 million his campaign spent.
To the very last day of campaigning, Mr. Earley held out hope that President Bush, a hugely popular figure in Virginia, would drop down into the state for a final whirlwind day of campaigning with him. It never happened. Mr. Bush sent word that in the midst of a national crisis over terrorism, there was no time or place for partisan presidential campaigning.
Mr. Warner, 46, who ran unsuccessfully for the United States Senate five years ago, has been a moderate-to-liberal Democrat for most of his political life. But this year , he ran as a "Virginia conservative," hardly ever mentioning that he was a Democrat. He spent about $20 million, including $5 million of his own money.
Mr. Earley, a 47-year-old conservative with close ties to the Christian right, tried to paint Mr. Warner as just another tax-and-spend Democratic liberal. And for a while he appeared to be making headway, especially after Mr. Warner said he saw no reason not to raise taxes to pay for better roads as long as the increases were approved by citizen referendums. But in the end Mr. Early could never fully close the gap of 10 points or so that Mr. Warner opened up in the earliest days of the campaign.
Voters were already somewhat sour on Republicans at the start of the campaign, mainly because Governor Gilmore and the leaders of the Republican-controlled General Assembly were caught up in a bitter intra-party fight over how to draw up and finance the state budget.
Mr. Warner was able to exploit that division and dissatisfaction by promising that such feuding would never occur on his watch and by promising that a Warner administration would be as reliably conservative, especially in a time of economic hardship, as any ever seen in the state.
To burnish his conservative credentials, he made dozens of trips to heavily Republican areas, began showing up at stock car races and country music shows and courting the National Rifle Association and talking up gun rights.
A number of the state's normally Republican business leaders very publicly endorsed Mr. Warner, as did a former Republican governor, Linwood Holton. Most embarrassing of all for Mr. Earley, the dissidents formed a group called Virginians for Warner.
The last Democrat elected governor of Virginia was L. Douglas Wilder, in 1989. Since he left office in early 1994, not only have Republicans held the office but they also won control of the state legislature.

HEADLINE: THE 2001 ELECTIONS: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
An Election In a Shadow

BYLINE:  By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
It was a mayoral election unlike any other, following a mayoralty unlike any other. Rising above the campaign's many extraordinary developments, from the race-tinted schism within the Democratic Party to the voters' acceptance of an expensive candidacy by a wealthy political neophyte, was the specter of the man who went before.
 He is a daunting figure, so celebrated he is known everywhere by his first name alone: Rudy. Rudolph W. Giuliani practically willed a drop in crime, gloried in a surging economy, alienated minorities, struggled through public moments of personal drama -- and seared himself into the collective memory of a metropolis. 
 But just when the city seemed ready to trust itself without him, the terrorist attack of Sept. 11 blew a deadly hole through Lower Manhattan. And Mr. Giuliani's reassuring calm in great crisis transformed him into a civic saint, his strengths magnified, his weaknesses forgotten. 
These dynamics set the stage for yesterday's critical event in city history, leaving these central questions:
Will the new mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, wither in the considerable shadow cast by Mr. Giuliani? Or will he figure out a way to lead, to manage, to be judged on his own terms?
The question of leadership ended up looming over all other issues in the campaign, making otherwise well-qualified candidates appear diminished. "The election changed on Sept. 11, and suddenly the No. 1 issue became leadership," said Ross Sandler, the director of the Center for New York City Law at New York Law School. "We suddenly saw how critical a single leader was in a time of crisis."
The times of crisis that lie ahead will certainly provide a thorough test of Mr. Bloomberg's ability to lead. The problems that faced the city before the attack on the World Trade Center are now intermingled with the breathtaking challenges created by the terrorist attack that destroyed the World Trade Center: the problem-plagued school system; the anthrax scare; the lack of affordable housing; the delicate cleanup and rebuilding of the city's devastated financial center.
Mr. Bloomberg may well find himself dealing in the morning with the complications of a deficit in the city's $40 billion budget, and in the afternoon with the needs of a constituency still traumatized by the terrorist attack. All the while, there will be the ghost of Mr. Giuliani by his side, available for constant comparison.
Indeed, it was Mr. Giuliani's endorsement less than two weeks ago that gave Mr. Bloomberg, the Republican candidate, a well-timed boost over his Democratic opponent, Mark Green, who during the campaign had the gall to suggest that he would have handled things even better than the man called Rudy. It was as though Mr. Bloomberg had been named star pupil, and Mr. Green commanded to wash his mouth out with soap.
But some see the potential for Mr. Giuliani's successor to overcome that ghost, to out-Rudy Rudy. Elliott Sclar, a professor of urban planning at Columbia University, said that coalition building among the city's ethnic groups and grass-roots organizations -- never one of Mr. Giuliani's strengths -- was essential in addressing a budget deficit that could reach $5 billion by 2003.
"With a shrinking pie," he said, "everyone is going to have to sign onto the fairness of what happens."
Mr. Sclar also said that the next mayor should also see himself as the leader of a much larger region. Mr. Giuliani reveled in contentious quarrels with the elected leaders of New Jersey and New York State, he said. "But the mayor of New York can catalyze the concerns of regional development," he said.
It is a vital concern, Mr. Sclar said, given that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey owns the World Trade Center site, whose redevelopment is one of the new mayor's foremost concerns. "Remember that old song?" he asked. " 'How Do You Get Them Back to Lower Manhattan Once They've Seen Hoboken?' "
These challenges will unfold against backdrops that may seem familiar -- from City Hall to Gracie Mansion -- but that in truth have been transformed by term limits and the travails of the recent mayoral campaign. When he assumes office on Jan. 1, Mr. Bloomberg will quickly be reminded why his new job is often called the second-most difficult in the world. Beyond the immediate deadlines prescribed by the City Charter -- offices to fill, budget reports to make -- he will find that he is not the only freshman at the learning institution of City Hall. 
Thanks to term limits, two-thirds of the City Council membership will be new, all wondering whom to back for the powerful position of speaker. The veteran at that job, Peter F. Vallone, will be gone, and with him the ability to deliver Council majorities on votes dear to the mayor's heart.
"Will it mean more freelancers?" asked Jerry Skurnik, a political consultant. "Will it mean more of a role for Democratic county leaders? Those are the interesting questions."
But there seems no end to the interesting questions raised by this campaign. For example, what does yesterday's election say about that city monolith, the Democratic Party?
With the notable exceptions of Fiorello H. LaGuardia, John V. Lindsay and Mr. Giuliani, the surest way to become mayor of New York was to win the Democratic nomination. But by the end of yesterday's contest, it appeared that another New York political truism had been proven false. 
The city remains 5-to-1 Democratic by registration, and its voters seem as likely as ever to vote Democratic when choosing whom to send to the White House or to Congress. But when the election centers on the control of City Hall, the city's Democrats are clearly finding it easier to vote for Republicans than their parents did -- assuming, of course, that their parents lived and voted in this demographic kaleidoscope of a city.
"This is the third straight election where partisanship hasn't meant very much," said David Axelrod, the Democratic consultant who worked for Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Democrat who lost the nomination to Mr. Green. "One thing is clear: whatever the outcome is, a large number of Democrats are going to vote on another line."
Mr. Axelrod's prediction certainly proved to be prescient late last night. In a predominantly Democratic city, a Republican candidate with no prior public service had blown the city's Democratic establishment away. Mr. Bloomberg's victory means at least three successive terms of a Republican City Hall.
Political analysts say that Mr. Green played it safe and smug for a dangerously long time. But they also say that the Democratic Party -- the party of Tammany, of unions, of minorities -- buckled under interfamilial squabbles that were colored by, of all things, race. 
The efforts by some Green supporters to torpedo Mr. Ferrer's hopes of becoming the city's first Puerto Rican mayor by linking him to the Rev. Al Sharpton marked the final moments of the Democratic primary in late September. Resentment over the gambit, which Mr. Green adamantly disavowed, clearly still lingers.
Also eating into Mr. Green's once-substantial lead were the truckloads of money that Mr. Bloomberg dumped into in his own campaign -- well in excess of $50 million, according to some estimates. 
Beyond the resonance of Mr. Bloomberg's television commercials, his victory indicates a city where voters no longer dismiss a candidacy based at least in part on a candidate's wealth, as many of them did in the losing mayoral and gubernatorial campaigns of Ronald S. Lauder and Lewis E. Lehrman. In doing so, the voters of New York join a national trend, seen in New Jersey and California, among other states, of becoming inured to the unlimited use of personal fortunes to finance political campaigns.
In different times and circumstances, the next billionaire novice may not fare so well, and the Democratic Party may heal its wounds. But at this moment in the city's history, it seems that party affiliations matter less, and leadership abilities matter more. Mr. Bloomberg will be charged with the responsibility of nursing a wounded city back to health, and for that honor, has said he will decline the $195,000-a-year salary.

HEADLINE: THE 2001 ELECTIONS: MAYOR; 
BLOOMBERG EDGES GREEN IN RACE FOR MAYOR; McGREEVEY IS AN EASY WINNER IN NEW JERSEY

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Michael Rubens Bloomberg, a self-made billionaire who set out at the age of 59 to finance a new career in politics, was elected the 108th mayor of New York City yesterday, as voters turned to him to lead a city apprehensive about the loss of a popular mayor and anxious about a future clouded by threats of terrorism and economic turmoil.
 Mr. Bloomberg achieved the unlikely goal of being elected mayor of New York in his first outing in politics. It came after he spent what is likely to be far more than $50 million of his own money to defeat Mark Green, the public advocate and Democratic candidate. Along the way, Mr. Bloomberg set a modern-day record for campaign spending in New York City, in a way that raised questions about the effectiveness of the city's strict campaign finance law. 
 Mr. Bloomberg's victory marked the first time in the history of New York that two Republicans have been elected consecutively to City Hall. It means that in a city where Democrats outnumber Republicans by five to one, the Republican Party is now poised to control City Hall for at least three terms in a row. 
And it left the city's once-dominant Democratic Party divided and dispirited, and facing the reality that winning the Democratic Party line is no longer the equivalent of winning citywide office. Even before the numbers were counted, Democrats were squabbling about who was to blame for Mr. Green's losing a contest that had once seemed in hand.
Mr. Green conceded in a speech to supporters at 12:25 this morning, congratulating his opponent but also leaving little doubt about why he thought he was not delivering a victory speech.
"When a campaign adviser last month told me that no candidate in America had ever won an election being outspent by $45 million, I thought we'd beat the odds," he told the subdued crowd. "We did good. Michael Bloomberg did a lot better, and I congratulate him and we all should."
Mr. Green quieted the boos that rose from the crowd and said: "I ask this city to support him as he begins the hard work and hard choices ahead. And let's face it: No American city has suffered a murderous attack and a municipal crisis as we have suffered." 
Mr. Bloomberg, with Mr. Giuliani at his back and deep circles under his eyes reflecting the all-nighter of campaigning he had pulled before Election Day, declared victory at 12:56 a.m. today.
"New York is alive and well and open for business!" he said. "We are clearly going to have enormous problems, but I know we are up to the task. We can do it.
"Tonight is not about Republicans and Democrats, it's about New Yorkers," Mr. Bloomberg continued. At that, Mr. Giuliani, who was picking confetti off Mr. Bloomberg's shoulder, raised a chant of "U.S.A." that was picked up by the crowd.
The mayor-elect concluded by saying: "The easy part is done. Now comes the hard part."
With 97 percent of the election districts reporting unofficial returns, Mr. Bloomberg had about 30,000 more machine votes than Mr. Green, according to a City Board of Elections official, Douglas A. Kellner, a Manhattan Democrat. Absentee and paper ballots had not been counted. 
The election marked the end of a contest held in a city still reeling from the attack on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, and jumpy over continued episodes of anthrax infections and fear of another terrorist assault. This atmosphere at first imposed a somber air on the politicking, but by the end, the race became as much of a street fight as any contest New York had seen in a generation.
The tense, tight and expensive race went down to the very last minute. Advertisements for Mr. Bloomberg, featuring a testimonial from Mr. Giuliani, were still on the airwaves as voters returned home from work last night. And former President Bill Clinton, at the behest of Mr. Green, conducted telephone interviews with black radio stations throughout the afternoon, encouraging listeners to vote for Mr. Green.
Mr. Green, who is not exactly new to this -- this was his 11th election night as a candidate since he first ran for Congress 21 years ago and far from the first time he has lost -- asserted that he was not fazed by the razor-tight denouement. 
"I cut off my nerve endings as a young man," he said earlier last evening. "Otherwise, you can't do this line of work. Since I can't affect it any more, since I've done everything humanly possible to explain my record and vision to the jury of voters, I'm satisfied with whatever the verdict is."
The campaign ended with a burst of spending by Mr. Bloomberg and a flood of harsh attacks by Mr. Green that some Republicans suggested last night had backfired.
In the final days of the campaign, Mr. Bloomberg, the founder of Bloomberg L.P., was ubiquitous: on television and radio, in mailboxes, on Web sites. Mr. Bloomberg even mailed videotapes, in which he appealed for votes, to households across New York.
Mr. Bloomberg chose not to participate in the system, in which candidates are provided public matching funds in exchange for agreeing to limits on donations. Mr. Green, however, did participate, a decision that several Democrats said yesterday proved to be a mistake as Mr. Bloomberg overwhelmed Mr. Green in spending.
And in a survey of voters leaving the polls yesterday, New Yorkers said they did not object to the notion that Mr. Bloomberg was using his personal fortune to win the election: more than half said they were not concerned by it, notwithstanding Mr. Green's efforts to make it an issue.
Mr. Green, after initially ignoring most of Mr. Bloomberg's criticisms, responded in the final weekend with a series of attacks and advertisements that were unusually harsh, even by New York City standards, including one in which he reprised the details of a sexual harassment suit filed against Mr. Bloomberg by a female employee of his company.
Mr. Bloomberg settled the suit out of court, and denied the charges. He denounced Mr. Green for the attacks in the final days, but there were indications that they had taken a toll. Voters who said they had made up their mind in the final three days of the campaign supported Mr. Green; voters who said they had made up their mind in the last week said they had backed Mr. Bloomberg.
By contrast, there were signs last night that strife among black and Hispanic Democratic leaders over the way Mr. Green had run his primary campaign against Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, had diminished Mr. Green's performance among traditionally Democratic voters. 
Mr. Ferrer disappeared from the campaign trail in the final days before the election, and the Rev. Al Sharpton declined to support Mr. Green, citing the efforts by some Green aides to use mailings and phone calls aimed at Jewish voters to highlight Mr. Sharpton's backing of Mr. Ferrer. Mr. Sharpton called those efforts racist; Mr. Green denied any knowledge of them.
The survey found that Latino voters were evenly divided between Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Green. And Mr. Bloomberg appeared to be winning about one-quarter of the black votes, a number that Mr. Sharpton noted was unusually high for a Republican candidate in New York.
And 4 in 10 of the voters who said they had supported Mr. Ferrer in the Democratic primary said they had voted for Mr. Bloomberg. He made a concerted effort to appeal to Mr. Ferrer's supporters, repeatedly chastising Mr. Green for his tactics.
Several of Mr. Green's supporters expressed bitterness at the absence of Mr. Ferrer from the campaign trail, as well as the decision by Roberto Ramirez, the chairman of the Bronx Democrats and one of Mr. Ferrer's closest friends, not to put his organization behind the Green candidacy. In signs that the finger-pointing had already begun, they suggested that Mr. Ramirez and Mr. Ferrer deserved a significant amount of the blame for the loss.
The contest also offered a measure of the extent to which Mr. Giuliani, the two-term Republican mayor who was prohibited by term limits from running again, could designate his successor. The mayor endorsed Mr. Bloomberg, appeared in a series of television advertisements for him, and turned out once more last night in time for the evening news.
Mr. Giuliani remains an extremely popular figure in New York, according to a survey of voters leaving the polls, and about one-quarter said they had been influenced by his recommendation that they vote for Mr. Bloomberg. (Though that influence was offset by some voters, particularly black New Yorkers, who said the endorsement made them less likely to vote for Mr. Bloomberg.)
Mr. Bloomberg did best among those New Yorkers who described the economy and jobs as the top issues facing New York's next mayor. Mr. Green did best among voters who said the second most important issue was education.
Although Democrats said they were confident about the outcome of the race, some were beginning last night to offer what could be taken as a post-mortem discussion, at least, of why Mr. Green had not done as well as he had expected.
"New York Democrats have been challenged this year, facing a Republican opponent who spent $60 million to defeat our candidate," said Judith Hope, the chairwoman of the State Democratic Party. "We'll become a stronger party because of these challenges."

How the Polls Were Conducted
The Election Day polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting stations throughout New York City and New Jersey yesterday. Questionnaires in New York City were available in English or Spanish.
The poll was conducted by Edison Media Research of Somerville, N.J.
The results are based on 1,608 voters in New York City and 1,718 voters in New Jersey, located in 40 randomly selected districts in each place. 
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results should differ by no more than plus or minus three percentage points from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all voters who turned out in New York City or New Jersey yesterday. 
Results based on smaller subgroups have a larger potential sampling error. 
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion on Election Day, such as the reluctance of some voters to take time to fill out the questionnaire, may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE DISSIDENT; 
U.S. Plucks Rebel Figure From Afghan Redoubt for 'Consultations,' Then Returns Him

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ with STEVEN LEE MYERS

DATELINE: QUETTA, Pakistan, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Hamid Karzai, the Afghan exile who has emerged as the Bush administration's main hope for forging a southern alliance against the Taliban, was plucked from Afghanistan by American forces early Monday, brought to Pakistan and then ferried back across the border, senior Pentagon officials said today.
 The operation showed considerable coordination between Mr. Karzai and the Bush administration, which has been criticized for lacking a strategy in the south, where the Taliban are strongest. Until now, the administration has concentrated its political and military support on more organized opposition forces in northern Afghanistan. 
 Mr. Karzai, who secretly entered Afghanistan several weeks ago to organize opposition to the Taliban in their southern stronghold, survived a battle with the Taliban in the district of Derawat in Uruzgan Province last Thursday. A senior American military officer said today that Mr. Karzai, the head of a well-known Afghan family, had asked to be taken out of the mountainous region when it be came clear that Taliban forces were closing in on his position.
"If we had done nothing, he would have died," the officer said.
At the Pentagon today, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said Mr. Karzai had been spirited out with "a small number of his senior supporters and fighters" so that he could conduct "consultations."
Mr. Rumsfeld played down the operation to remove Mr. Karzai, which involved American Special Operations forces, saying "it was not an extraction in the sense of a military campaign."
Mr. Karzai apparently met with American officials and some of his own supporters in northern Pakistan before being taken back to his redoubt. Mr. Rumsfeld described the extraction of Mr. Karzai and the apparent sharing of information as a "very sensible arrangement."
Mr. Rumsfeld said the United States had provided Mr. Karzai with ammunition and food, but what else the administration has provided Mr. Karzai, who is considered more of a politician than a military strategist or commander, was not clear. The secretary suggested over the week end that Washington was poised to place American advisers with him, but the senior Pentagon officials said advisers were not accompanying Mr. Karzai, though he remained in close contact with American officials.
In the family home in this border town, word of American cooperation infuriated Mr. Karzai's family, who said they feared that the American embrace would severely damage his efforts inside Afghanistan.
"Does he want people to think he is an American agent?" said Ahmed Karzai, a younger brother, during an interview today. Ahmed has become the chief conduit between Hamid Karzai and the outside world, giving interviews to foreign journalists about news from his brother, who calls in by satellite phone. 
Ahmed also serves as a line to other anti-Taliban commanders who live here and appear to be waiting for the right moment to join Mr. Karzai.
Since the battle last Thursday, the Taliban have been denouncing Mr. Karzai as a tool of the United States and have insisted that they captured and then executed several of his sup porters. "The moderates who oppose the Taliban are not happy with this," said another brother, Shah Wali. "The Taliban are now calling him an American agent. What should we fight against: Taliban propaganda or Rumsfeld propaganda?"
Both Ahmed Karzai and Shah Wali denied today -- despite news reports to the contrary -- that Mr. Karzai had left Afghanistan. They appeared concerned by the notion that he had left Afghanistan, a move that would be interpreted as one of weakness by the Pashtun, the largest ethnic group in Afghanistan. Mr. Karzai, and most of the Taliban, are Pashtun.
On Monday, Ahmed Karzai said he had spoken to Hamid twice by satel lite phone and was told by his brother that he was still in the region of Derawat. Today, Ahmed Karzai said his brother had phoned to say he was well and continuing his "political work" inside Afghanistan.
Mr. Karzai is regarded warmly in Washington, in part because he has long seen Osama bin Laden as a serious threat. After the battle last Thursday, Mr. Karzai told Ahmed by satellite telephone that most at tackers were Arabs and Pakistanis.
On Monday night, one of Mr. Karzai's supporters, a man in his 20's who returned to Quetta from the battlefield in southern Afghanistan, stressed that Arabs and Pakistanis had led the Taliban charge against Mr. Karzai.
The supporter, who had driven for more than a day from Mr. Karzai's hideout, said Mr. Karzai fielded about 200 fighters against the Taliban's 700s. Although the numbers could not be independently verified, it appeared that Mr. Karzai was out gunned and outmaneuvered until help came from American war planes.
The supporter, who came to the Karzai home Monday night, said the fighting stopped when "the planes came." One of Mr. Karzai's anti-Taliban allies in Quetta, Yusef Pashtun, said Mr. Karzai had told him by telephone that the Taliban attack against him last Thursday was "highly professional."
Although Mr. Rumsfeld and other officials declined to discuss the "consultations" Mr. Karzai held, they suggested he had valuable intelligence that could be useful in the American campaign, now entering its second month.
Mr. Karzai is a leader of the Populzai clan, which is strongest in the Taliban heartland around Kandahar, Uruzgan, Helmand and Ghor Provinces. Mr. Karzai is asking the people in those areas to choose between their clan and the Taliban.
Because economic conditions had deteriorated and the Taliban had be come so unpopular, Mr. Karzai was confident that the people would choose clan over the religious rulers, Ahmed said.

Rebel's Nephew Is Executed
(By The New York Times), JABUL-US-SIRAJ, Afghanistan, Nov. 6 -- Taliban forces executed the 20-year-old nephew of the Pashtun dissident Abdul Haq on Monday night, family members reported to day. The young man, Izetulla, was captured with Mr. Haq late last month during a failed expedition to organize Pashtun resistance to the Taliban government inside Afghanistan. Mr. Haq was hanged within hours of his capture. 
"He was killed last night in Kabul," said Haji Kadir, Mr. Haq's brother and a leader in the opposition Northern Alliance, said in an interview today. "They shot him."
Mr. Kadir said he learned of his nephew's death this morning. Mr. Kadir said that Izetulla was the son of a third brother in the family, Haji Den, who served as education minister in the government that briefly ruled Afghanistan in the early 1990's before the country disintegrated into civil war.
