HEADLINE: Man in the News; 
Finding a New Mission; Michael Rubens Bloomberg

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

 BODY:
Michael Rubens Bloomberg, among the wealthiest people in New York City, has been a man in search of a mission beyond making money. With yesterday's come-from-behind victory in the mayoral race, he seems to have found it.
 Mr. Bloomberg had made it well known in recent years that he was looking for a major life change. Friends and associates say he talked mostly about four jobs that would tempt him away from Bloomberg L.P., the financial information and communications company that he founded in 1981 and that, according to Forbes magazine, made him the sixth richest New Yorker, with an estimated worth of $4 billion. 
 The jobs were president of the United States, secretary general of the United Nations, president of the World Bank and mayor of New York City.
"He is absolutely driven by the need and desire to make a difference, which has nothing to do with money," said Dr. Alfred Sommer, who, as dean of the Bloomberg School of Public Health at Johns Hopkins University, had spent many evenings over dinner with Mr. Bloomberg discussing his future.
Dr. Sommer had urged Mr. Bloomberg to consider a new career championing public health causes around the world, particularly since Mr. Bloomberg donated tens of millions of dollars to the Johns Hopkins public health school (it was renamed earlier this year in acknowledgment of those donations). But Mr. Bloomberg, who received an engineering degree from Johns Hopkins and an M.B.A. from Harvard, said it was not a good match with his background.
In the end, several of Mr. Bloomberg's associates said, Mr. Bloomberg was motivated to run for mayor by two factors. First, he accepted that he had no chance of landing the White House or United Nations job (at least not anytime soon) and he regarded the World Bank position as a long shot because another affluent New Yorker, James D. Wolfensohn, holds it. 
Second, and perhaps more important, he was inspired by the success of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in lowering crime rates and turning around the city's tarnished image.
"He genuinely admires the difference that Giuliani made," Dr. Sommer said. "When he looked around, how he could make a difference, and knowing his own skill set, the mayor's job was the obvious thing."
Many friends cautioned Mr. Bloomberg against making his first foray into public life, suggesting that he might not take well to the intense media scrutiny of a mayoral campaign. Mr. Bloomberg did engage in heated exchanges with reporters over some of their questions and even his campaign staff bristled at his occasional slip.
But more often than not, Mr. Bloomberg seemed to enjoy the attention of being a candidate and he often spoke in awe about the big and diverse city he discovered on the campaign trail.
"It's been a great experience," Mr. Bloomberg said on his last day of campaigning. "No matter how many people you know, you get a chance to meet more people. I think this is not a job for anybody that doesn't like people."
Mr. Bloomberg moved to New York in 1966 after graduating from Harvard to take a job for $9,000 a year at Salomon Brothers. In his autobiography, "Bloomberg by Bloomberg," he describes his first duties for the firm as counting billions of dollars of actual bond and stock certificates, stripped down to his underwear, in a sweltering bank vault. Only an occasional six-pack of beer made it tolerable.
Before long, Mr. Bloomberg was promoted to the equities desk, where he started his career trading stocks. He would spend 15 years at Salomon Brothers, learning all there was to learn about the financial industry and becoming addicted to the good life in New York. "I didn't love Wall Street just for the money, I also loved it for the lifestyle it provided," he wrote in his book.
In 1973, Mr. Bloomberg became a partner. But by 1979, Mr. Bloomberg's star was no longer rising at Salomon and he was pushed off to what was then considered the sidelines. His last job at the firm was running its information systems department -- his introduction to computers -- and by 1981 he was fired. "I had stirred the pot, lost the battle, and was paying the price," Mr. Bloomberg recalled.
But Mr. Bloomberg left Salomon with a $10 million handshake, money he quickly invested in starting a company with a few friends from Salomon in a one-room office on Madison Avenue.
Using the knowledge of computers and Wall Street gleaned at Salomon, Mr. Bloomberg named the company Innovative Market Systems and specialized in providing detailed financial information to the financial services industry on custom-made computers. The company would later be renamed Bloomberg L.P. and the computer terminals would become known simply as Bloomberg boxes.
Today, Bloomberg L.P. employs 8,000 people and does business in 126 countries, having expanded into radio, television, magazines and a news service. Mr. Bloomberg is still the majority owner, but in preparation for his run for mayor, he handed over the day-to-day operations of the company to Lex Fenwick, who formerly ran its European operations.
Though not particularly well-known to the general public, Mr. Bloomberg became a regular fixture in New York's society circles during his years at Bloomberg L.P. and he served on various boards, including those at Lincoln Center and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. 
He wrote in his book that one of the reasons his marriage to Susan Brown fell apart was, "I like to go out and party." They divorced in 1993. He is still friendly with his former wife, though, who, along with her boyfriend, was a volunteer for his campaign. The older of his two daughters, Emma, also volunteered, as did his sister and his mother, who is 92.
Mr. Bloomberg was born in the Boston suburb of Medford, Mass., on Feb. 14, 1942. His father, William, was an accountant at a local dairy. He died while Mr. Bloomberg was at Harvard. His mother, Charlotte, was a housewife and still lives in his childhood home. He says he calls her every morning before work.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Bloomberg's supporters erupted in joy last night when news came that Mark Green had conceded the election. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TURF; 
Miami Beach Buyers Chill Out

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

DATELINE: MIAMI BEACH 

 BODY:
AT the north end of Ocean Drive, the Art Deco axis of South Florida's night life, the Breez restaurant sits empty. It's a bar without drinkers, a restaurant without diners. It laid off its star chef five weeks ago. "We do a lot of cleaning," said Gabriel Fernandez, the 25-year-old bartender, wiping the sinuous aluminum bar.
 A nearby parking lot contains just two cars. One has a "For Sale" sign on the windshield. The other belongs to the attendant. 
 Farther down the beachfront strip, sidewalk hawkers offer two-for-one pina coladas and rum punches, thrusting menus into the hands of passers-by. At the Delano, Ian Schrager's oceanfront hotel, the icy chic of the corridors is undisturbed by human visitation: the long white marble sushi bar is empty. The Zen-like dining room has only a few patrons. 
For the last decade, Miami Beach has welcomed fashion photographers, interior designers and a fabulous fraternity of club hoppers -- all of whom coexisted with an older population in Bermuda shorts and knee-high black socks. As a photograph, and as a happening, it worked. But this fall the scene has evaporated. The jets are half empty, and many of the hotels are struggling to stay alive.
After seven years of ever-ascending prices, Miami Beach's overheated real estate market is finally cooling down. "Everybody -- buyers and renters -- is cautious right now," Zaino Mizani, a real estate agent with Majestic Properties, a company that both sells and develops condominiums, said Tuesday. "It's hard to convince people to buy. If they have to come here because of job relocation, they'd rather rent and hold on to the cash and see what happens." 
Some developers are making deals, not only for condos but for rentals. This week at the Waverly, a new rental project that is only 60 percent full, the landlords are offering between one and two months' free rent; two-bedrooms go for $2,235. 
The city's market is starting to bloat with listings of high-priced houses and half-built condominium developments, according to figures gathered by the local real estate agents association. 
Before Sept. 11, there were 540 condominium apartments on the market. This week, there were 1,497 -- almost triple the number. Before the attacks in New York, there were 73 houses in Miami Beach on the market. Now, there are 260. 
Bruce Singer, the president of the Miami Beach Chamber of Commerce, said he worries about a glut of new condominiums in tall towers that are still on the drawing boards, or just starting to rise. "It's not an opportune time," he said.
Mayor Neisen O. Kasdin is uneasy, too. "New hotel development, office construction and retail were already slowing," he said. Until Sept. 11, residential real estate was "continuing very strong." Now, he is awaiting the sales figures. "There is a good deal of concern," he said. "There's no candy-coating it; tourism has been hit bad after 9/ 11." Last weekend's cancellation of the Art Basel Miami Beach show, a result of fears of terrorism and anthrax, left Miamians reeling, the mayor said.
In an oceanfront area of mid-1990's condominium towers, the first of what was to have been twin projects has been built. "We've heard the second has been delayed," Mr. Mizani said. He gestured to a sign there proclaiming the Continuum development: "Never Before, Never Again." "That may be true," he said, with a wry smile. (The developer said there was no date set for groundbreaking on the second tower.)
At the Green Diamond tower on Collins Avenue, near the famous Fontainebleau Hotel, condominiums are selling for $350,000 to $800,000, around 20 percent to 30 percent less than similar ones at its twin next door, the Blue Diamond, which opened for business first. At the Yacht Club at Portofino, a 38-story, 220-unit condominium, there are 63 apartments for sale; 20 came on the market after Sept. 11. At the corner of Second Street and Collins Avenue is Ocean Place, a much smaller development. It is almost finished, but it appears that workers have walked off the job, leaving unfinished plasterwork and lighting fixtures hanging from their cords. 
Of the 17 properties shown on a recent tour of houses for sale, 10 had come on the market after Sept. 11.
Five of the rest had been reduced significantly. The price of one town house condominium had been reduced three times: from $425,000 to $380,000 to $365,000 to $349,000. A 1924 villa on Hibiscus Island had already been reduced from $3.5 million to $3.29 million on Oct. 4. The next day, it was reduced again, to $2.95 million. The stucco had been troweled -- and retroweled -- on a classic Mediterranean-style movie star mansion that desperately needed renovation, but the bones were there: a double-height living room with a stone fireplace, overlooking a swimming pool and an 80-foot waterfront. A white yacht was moored out front -- blocking most of the view. 
At another open house, for Villa Palma, a $3.4-million house with a marble fountain and a tennis court, the broker handed out fliers. "Owner very motivated and has reduced price yet again," they said.
Samuel Spencer Blum, a real estate lawyer here, said he has seen "a definite decrease" in new contracts. Mr. Blum blamed the lull on the national economy and on the terrorist attacks in New York. (Almost unmentioned here are the anthrax attacks in Boca Raton.) "If they're afraid to buy a toaster," Mr. Blum said, "they're going to be afraid to buy a second home."
In the Coral Gables section of Miami, he said, "three contracts have fallen through in the last week; nothing's wrong with the house -- people kept getting cold feet."
Nevertheless, some brokers are far from pessimistic. Jerry Grabill, chairman of the Realtor Association of Greater Miami and the Beaches, said the market "hasn't changed very much: I expected it to go down the tubes, but it seems to be stable." 
Alan Jacobson, president of Wimbish-Riteway Realtors, who deals in the most expensive properties in Miami Beach, said business is fine. "We have 13 signed contracts over $1 million since Sept. 11," he said. "That's below our average, but it's not a reflection of a down market."
In general, Mr. Jacobson said, "what has happened is, the supply of properties starts to exceed demand, and the prices come down. Those people who were waiting to put their house on the market are no longer waiting." He predicted that "real estate will remain stable in South Florida as it always has been." 
"Buyers who believe they can get a steal in this market are wrong," he said.
Mr. Jacobson is right about customers not getting a steal. In fact, Michael Y. Cannon, a real estate appraiser, said prices do not appear to be affected. "But the jury is still out," he conceded. He said data on the real estate market would not be fully digested until December. One sign of a softening, Mr. Cannon said, was the increasing number of classified advertisements in local newspapers placed by owners of unfinished condominiums trying to unload their investments. But overall, he said he disagreed with "the pundits" who predict sharp price declines.
Even if there are no steals, most buyers here expect a reduction, or at least more bargaining room, said Mr. Mizani of Majestic Properties. 
Jason Bryan, manager of Johnny Rockets restaurant in the Coconut Grove section of Miami, was out looking for a two-bedroom bargain rental two weeks ago. "There's lots of selection, and a lot more room to negotiate a price," he said. "We see a lot that have been reduced." (Miami's Multiple Listing Service shows 1,069 rentals available in Miami Beach; of those, 469 came on since Sept. 11.)
Mr. Bryan passed the Johnny Rockets on Ocean Drive. There were two people sitting at tables on the sidewalk. Inside, there was no one. "Last year, it would have been packed," he said. At the cafe at Gloria Estefan's Cardozo Hotel, there were 13 people sitting along the wraparound porch.
Again, no one was inside. 
But the people here say they hope that when the weather up North turns cold, the tourists will remember Miami Beach.
"Oh, honey, of course Sept. 11 affects our economy," said Mitchell Wolfson Jr., the founder of the Wolfsonian Museum. "But Miami Beach has the capacity to reinvent itself," Mr. Wolfson concluded. "The city has done it before."

HEADLINE: Technology That Aims To Do Good 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ZIPERN 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif. 

 BODY:
SILICON VALLEY is not generally known for a pervasive sense of charity. Last year Paulina Borsook, a longtime technology journalist, found a large and sympathetic audience with her book "Cyberselfish: A Critical Romp Through the Terribly Libertarian Culture of High Tech," which attacked the technology world for showing "a lack of human connection and a discomfort with the core of what many of us consider it means to be human."
 So an awards benefit in the heart of Silicon Valley to celebrate "Technology Benefiting Humanity" might seem incongruous. But on Nov. 1 the Tech Museum of Innovation, a three-year-old science and technology museum in downtown San Jose, held just such an event -- with a keynote speech by former President Gerald R. Ford -- to honor technology specialists who "improve the quality of life around the globe." 
 The museum, known informally as The Tech, brings a Silicon Valley spin to the notion of a public science institute. The Tech's financial backers may have made their money on silicon, but the technology that betters the human race, they argue, is much broader in scope. 
More than 1,000 people from around the world attended the evening's black-tie fund-raiser and banquet as two enormous screens projected short videos about work by 25 finalists for the museum's Technology Benefiting Humanity Awards.
The judges, assembled by Santa Clara University's Center for Science, Technology and Society, reviewed more than 390 applications from 50 countries. Awards carrying $50,000 stipends were given in five categories: health, education, environment, economic development and equality. 
"This means we can make a whole lot more limbs for a whole lot more people," said Dr. Chaz M. Holder, who received the equality award for a system of socketless prosthetic limbs that weigh and cost less than versions commonly used. Mr. Holder, himself a triple amputee after a car accident 20 years ago, said that some 25 million people in the developing world who need artificial limbs never get them because they can cost upwards of $20,000. Over the last two years his company, CZBioMed, based in Fayetteville, N.C., has fit 400 prosthetic limbs on patients in Sierra Leone and Vietnam.
The health award went to Joseph DeRisi, a professor of biochemistry at the University of California at San Francisco, who is working to identify the genes likely to be essential to the survival of the parasite that causes malaria. 
The South Africa-based Freeplay Foundation won the education award. More than 150,000 wind-up and solar-powered radios have been furnished by Freeplay for use in development, disaster relief and education initiatives, mostly in Africa.
Fabio de Oliveira Rosa, the president of Ideaas, a Brazilian organization, received the economic development award for developing low-cost rural electrification systems. The environment award went to Dr. Betsy Dresser, director of the Audubon Nature Institute's Center for Research of Endangered Species in New Orleans, for innovative applications of technology to preserve biodiversity.
Peter Giles, president of the Tech Museum, said that the idea for the awards was inspired by a policy group's report on economic development and technological change. Applied Materials, already a benefactor of the Tech Museum, signed on as a sponsor, and individual awards were backed by Nasdaq, Knight Ridder, Credit Suisse First Boston, Intel and J. P. Morgan Chase.
The report, an annual "State of the Future" analysis by the Millennium Project of the American Council for the United Nations University, suggested that the most effective way to encourage progress in fields without obvious market potential was through incentives like prize money as well as peer recognition.
Jerome C. Glenn, co-director of the Millennium Project and an author of the report, argues that Silicon Valley's kind of entrepreneurial know-how and small-group collaboration should be applied in tackling problems of the developing world. "These winners will become attractors around which energy can flow," he said of the award recipients.
Mr. Glenn said that the terrorist attacks helped crystallize the awards' purpose.
"You can't have two billion people living with disease, poverty, war, conflict and terrorism and survive like that for very long," he said. "We have to ask how we can use technological innovation to create a more serious global partnership between the rich and the poor."

HEADLINE: For Antiquers, An Anxious Season 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
THE Winter Antiques Show in January, the most prestigious annual antiques event in the country, has been locked out of the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 67th Street -- its home for 48 years -- by National Guard operations there. The show will be staged instead at the Hilton New York on the Avenue of the Americas at 53rd Street.
 "I'm aware of the three magic words -- location, location, location," said Arie L. Kopelman, president of Chanel U.S.A. and chairman of the show committee, anticipating sales nervousness about the absence of the armory's well-heeled foot traffic. "The good news is that there's a show." 
 The military occupation of two East Side armories and the city's occupation of the West Side piers has forced the cancellation of much of the antiques fall and winter exhibition schedule. According to dealers and organizers, the disruption has cost them tens of millions of dollars in revenue. 
The Winter Antiques Show's homelessness is the glittering tip of the iceberg of events since Sept. 11 that have also changed the antiques market's direction generally and produced uneasy thinking about New York as the collectors' capital. 
Compounding a cooling economy, the impact is registering at all levels, from the fine-furniture sales in October at the auction houses, where only the best sold well, to the 26th Street flea markets, where panicked sellers are bringing out their best pieces to keep buyers interested. 
The exclusion from the armories has already necessitated the cancellation of the International Art and Design Fair in September and the International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show in October. Anna Haughton, an organizer of both events, said that they represented a loss as high as $75 million in sales for dealers. If venues for large shows are still unavailable by spring, organizers said, the outlook could deepen from dark to pitch black.
"They do 20 to 70 percent of yearly business at these shows," Ms. Haughton, who is based in London, said of dealers. "Globally, New York is the center of the market. If the fairs are not up and running quickly, the market will fragment and start to move away. And it will never come back."
For now, Leanne Stella, the president of Stella Show Management, was optimistic about keeping her shows in New York, despite the cancellation of three out of four fall events, including the Triple Pier Antiques Show, which was to have taken place this weekend and next, with 1,200 dealers participating at Piers 88, 90 and 92, now also unavailable to exhibitors indefinitely.
"I've lost my exposure to New York," said Carol Lehman, manager of Stevens Antiques, a shop in Frazer, Pa., who was scheduled to exhibit at the piers. "We only do the shows in New York to give us presence there, for decorators."
Ms. Stella said that the loss of revenue to her company would be "several hundred thousand dollars -- it's easily 50 percent of our business." She estimated the loss to dealers bounced from the piers at more than $24 million, based on previous shows. Hardest hit are those without shops.
"They are really frightened of being crippled by the loss of the show," she said. "It's devastating to them." 
Though uncalculated, the cancellation of the fall antiques events undoubtedly affected the revenues of other convention services, like hotels and restaurants. 
Ms. Stella added that if her spring show, to be held in March, was not possible at the three piers, it would force the issue of removing the event from New York City. "Connecticut or northern New Jersey or upstate -- you have to go where there's already interest in antiques," she said. Yesterday, Ms. Stella was trying to organize an impromptu fair of 200 dealers from the canceled piers show, which would take place in Somerset, N.J., on Dec. 1 and 2.
Genevieve Ward, an associate editor at Antiques and the Arts Weekly, a trade journal in Newtown, Conn., said that she was seeing organizers' restiveness to relocate shows, though not the biggest-ticket events like the Winter Antiques Show.
"Show managers are looking to branch out into suburban locations," she said. "Civic centers, convention centers in Westchester. There are a lot of shows outside of New York, held as benefits for local museums; shows in Boston and Philadelphia, still on the go. All the New York collectors go to Boston and Philadelphia anyway."
But even local relocation has proved tricky. Stella Show Management moved its Gramercy Park Modern show, scheduled at the armory on Lexington Avenue at 26th Street, to Madison Square Garden, notifying participants a short week before its opening on Oct. 6. Ten dealers dropped out, a wary and weary reaction to added logistical problems, security issues and a lack of confidence that buyers would appear. Attendance dropped by 15 percent from the previous year, Ms. Stella said. The organizers' costs rose by $50,000, or 25 percent, because of the move.
"I didn't have a good feeling about it," said Chris Kennedy, a Massachusetts dealer who canceled, uncertain that it would draw a crowd, or spenders. "For me, a furniture dealer, I'll walk a small table down to the curb for a customer, but you could no longer exit by the nearest door. The load in, the load out -- everything was compounded by security."
Mr. Kennedy, the owner of e-modern in Springfield who has exhibited for 15 years on the New York show circuit, confirmed an atmosphere of caution among buyers and sellers in the last month, mentioned at every tier of the antiques market.
"I don't think this foreshadows a depression movement -- to get liquid quickly by selling what you have cheaply," he said. "But you retrench, buying more carefully so you have a cushion, so you can reduce a price to make a sale."
The modern design collecting community's flagship event, Modernism, which opened today, was relocated from the Seventh Regiment Armory to the Hasbro toy showroom at 32 West 23rd Street (www .sanfordsmith.com). 
The show also shrank, from 72 exhibitors to 55, because of lack of space and cancellations. The move cost its organizers, Sanford L. Smith & Associates, $75,000 on top of the usual costs, Mr. Smith said.
In its own relocation scramble, the Winter Antiques Show (www.winterantiquesshow .com) also looked into vacant retail space on West 57th Street and at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.
The imperative to move threatened to turn one of the city's more elegant tailgate parties, with six-figure merchandise sold from the richly decorated dealers' booths inside the Upper East Side 19th-century landmark, with its Tiffany interiors, into what dealers feared would be more akin to selling old furniture out of the back of a truck. The Winter Antiques Show benefits the East Side Settlement House in the Bronx; it raised more than $1 million last year.
David A. Schorsch, a dealer from Woodbury, Conn., exhibiting for the first time, said he was not concerned by the change in venue. "Obviously when you're in the business of retail, you like the idea of folks on Park Avenue wandering in," he said. "But we have to keep our eye on the ball -- the country's at war. For antiques dealers to deal with inconvenience seems reasonable to me, in the larger scheme of things."
John Levitties, the owner of the John Alexander gallery in Philadelphia, a specialist in English Arts and Crafts exhibiting at Modernism, said: "Everyone's rolling with the punches this year. For us, it's not the income of the show. The juxtaposition of different styles and booths at a show like this introduces people clearly to what we do."
Mr. Levitties said that his business had been quiet after the World Trade Center attack and stronger since the last week of September. "There's been no noticeable negotiation about prices," he said. "But people are somewhat slower to make decisions."
Storefronts and galleries, though a source of steadier business, cannot provide the lively anticipation and competition among collectors that major shows can, said several dealers.
"Shows generate excitement," said Leigh Keno, a prominent American antiques dealer with a shop in New York, who will be at the Hilton with the Winter Antiques Show. 
Mr. Keno said that September's tragedy, the subsequent disruptions and a lingering question over larger values in the light of current circumstances -- both economic and social -- had affected people's approach to buying. "Major items are still selling," he said. "But items that are 5 or 6 on a scale of 10? People are just waiting."
Lou Marotta, a dealer at 243 East 60th Street, on a block of antiques shops that cater to decorators rather than to collectors, was not so sanguine.
"Before Sept. 11, business was better than ever," he said, despite a slowing economy. "Then, no one walked in for three weeks. Since the fourth week, business has been unreliable. People buying things and then changing their minds -- waffling. People are asking for discounts, more than ever. It makes me realize how fragile this business is. All my money is put back into inventory, to keep it fresh. How many months can I go, and pay the rent?"
Mr. Marotta concluded: "I've really thought it through. In four months, I would be doing something else to earn money, like interior design. In six months, I would be out of business."
Mr. Keno, speaking on Monday upon his return from the Ellis Memorial Antique Show in Boston and smaller weekend auctions in the Northeast, said that he saw no evidence of buyers trying to drive unusually hard bargains.
But of the big collections coming up for sale in New York at the Americana auctions that typically coincide with the week in January of the Winter Antiques Show, Mr. Keno cautioned auction houses that great expectations might well be untimely and unwise.
"The key in these sales is going to be conservative estimates," he said. "I don't think buyers are as tolerant right now of aggressive estimates."
In fact, though Sotheby's and Christie's both reported stronger than anticipated attendance and sales results at October's decorative arts auctions, the buy-in rate -- the number of lots that the house buys because bidding is not satisfactorily high -- was nearly double last year's at certain sales. At Sotheby's English furniture auction on Oct. 19, the buy-in was 21 percent, up from 12 percent the year before.
"Some people think, 'Great, we're going to get a bargain,' " Peter Lang, the director of the English furniture department, said, adding that there were bargains to be had, but not on the best pieces.
On Sunday at the flea market on the Avenue of the Americas at 26th Street, a thinner than usual crowd was rummaging as hard as ever, moving like truffle pigs through the piles of dainty discarded silver and disco-era lighting.
Jim Oliveira, who has a vintage-glass business with Sara Blumberg, his partner, said that the flea market itself was improving.
"It was drying up as a source," he explained. "A lot of dealers who set up shops in a better economy are returning."
Mr. Oliveira mentioned a 1920's Italian vase he purchased recently.
"There's more stuff coming out than I have seen in years, things that disappear from the market in a boom," he said. 
"It's a rare vase; I haven't seen anything like this in eight or nine years," he said. Mr. Oliveira has several customers for it.
"The hard-core buy, when they see pieces like that," he said.

HEADLINE: To Promote Democracy 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While richer nations must certainly be prodded to increase foreign aid to developing nations (Economic Scene, Nov. 1), a concerted effort should be made to see that the money we are sending abroad is used wisely. 
 Since 1999, the United States has spent $1.4 billion on "democracy promotion," yet there is very little in the way of cogent analysis about the impact of these grants. 
Foreign grantees and the American nongovernmental organizations that work with them often make a good case for continued financing. With little attendant scrutiny from the media, scholars and independent good-governance organizations, however, precious resources can be squandered year after year. 
 Americans must take an interest in these daunting and often dangerous initiatives.

JEFF BALLINGER
Cambridge, Mass., Nov. 1, 2001

The writer is a research associate at the Kennedy School, Harvard.

HEADLINE: The Caprice of Coffee 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: MONTENEGRO, Colombia 

 BODY:
For generations, coffee paid for everything here: the paving of roads, the electrification of remote hamlets, the building of schools. Growers, flush with cash from producing beans that were widely considered the best in the world, built elegant haciendas and sent their children to top universities.
 But now, the price of raw coffee has plunged worldwide, and many growers are planting other crops, trying to become more efficient or going out of business. 
 The situation has been especially acute for farmers in Colombia, who are loath to scrimp on the production of their premium, smooth-tasting beans but who must modernize and cut expenses to compete with countries where coffee is grown at a fraction of Colombia's production costs.
"Coffee has given us comforts, a good income and stability, but today we worry that coffee, at today's prices, is just not worth it," said Fernando Gallego, who has a 61-acre farm here. "I still have some coffee plantations, but next year, I imagine I am going to sell some of my land." 
Coffee growers across the world are suffering as an oversupply of coffee has caused the price of a pound of beans to sink to its lowest level in 30 years.
 The price dropped to 45.19 cents in New York on Wednesday, down from 95 cents in December 1999. 
Nowhere has the bust been more devastating than in Latin America, which produces 60 percent of the world's coffee and where some economies are heavily dependent on coffee exports.
"The prices have deteriorated to the point that for a majority of countries, not to mention all of them, the actual prices are not covering production costs," said Jorge Cardenas, president of the National Federation of Coffee Growers of Colombia, which represents 570,000 coffee farms.
And nowhere are farmers more frustrated than in places like Colombia, where the care lavished on the beans -- care that made the product distinctive -- makes production particularly expensive.
The reason for the oversupply and the price slump is simple: The 60 coffee-growing countries around the globe are producing too much. In the year ended Sept. 30, they churned out 115 million 132-pound bags, while world consumption reached only 108 million, according to the Association of Coffee Producing Countries, which is based in London.
Much of the glut has come from a surge in production in Vietnam, where coffee is cheap because of labor costs and subsidies. Once a minor player, Vietnam has surpassed Colombia as the world's second-largest coffee producer. Production there rose from a million bags in the late 1980's to 13 million in the last year -- a million more than Colombia. Brazil, the No. 1 grower, is also increasing production at low cost because its farms are highly mechanized.
Conditions will probably get worse, analysts say, pointing to the recent failure of a plan by the coffee growers group to have its 28 member countries hold back on exports and thus stabilize prices.
The turmoil in the industry has been catastrophic for many Latin American coffee farmers. Some from the eastern highlands of Mexico have embarked on perilous journeys across the desert in search of work in the United States. Subsistence farmers in Central America are losing their livelihood, and itinerant pickers have resorted to begging. Farmers elsewhere, from Venezuela to Peru, are trying to sell land or switch to more lucrative crops.
And then there is Colombia, which has been economically, psychologically and emotionally tied to coffee like no other country.
Half a century ago, Colombian coffee commanded $5 or more a pound in today's dollars and made up 80 percent of the country's exports. Colombia's economy has diversified in the last 20 years, but coffee is still the No. 2 export, following oil, and it accounted for about 9 percent of total exports last year.
The benefits were greatest here in Quindio, a province of 575,000 people in the mountainous heart of coffee growing country, a region where rainfall, soil composition and altitude are said to be perfect for coffee cultivation.
In the mid-1990's, at least 35 percent of Quindio's workers were directly employed in the coffee industry. And through the National Federation of Coffee Growers, the de facto government in this region, coffee revenues have financed public works projects like telephone lines, the salaries of agricultural technicians and the building of aqueducts -- services often absent from Colombia's many strife-torn regions.
"We never had guerrilla groups because the level of life here was very good," said Pedro Nel Salazar, director of the National Coffee Park, a former farm turned theme park in Montenegro. "But it was not the state that came here. It was the Federation of Coffee Growers."
Now, though, the signs of economic disarray are everywhere as the bean grown in Colombia, arabica, one of two main species in the world (the other, less expensive bean, is robusta), has slumped.
 It dropped from $1.23 a pound in December 1999 to 67.50 cents on Wednesday. 
The effect on the nation's economy has been immediate, with coffee exports falling to $1.2 billion last year from $2.4 billion in 1997, when a recession began taking hold.
Three million to 4 million of Colombia's 40 million people have traditionally been hired for the twice-a-year harvests. Now, hundreds of thousands are losing their jobs, as farmers scale back their operations.
"We cannot take out credit for our farms, and we have had to reduce the work force," said Oliverio Castellanos, who helps run several family farms. "You feel hopeless because producing is almost not worth it."
Shaken by the crisis, the government of President Andres Pastrana announced a $150 million rescue package in September, although most farmers here think the bailout will fall far short.
The National Federation of Coffee Growers has had to drastically scale back its largesse. Allocations to regional committees are just 30 percent of what they were in the 1980's. Globally, the most visible cost-cutting has been in the budget for advertising, which for 40 years has featured Juan Valdez and his burro, Madison Avenue creations that helped sell Colombian coffee.
Those most likely to weather the tumbling prices are the larger farmers, who can more easily cut costs and increase efficiency. But the vast majority of Colombia's farms have only about 10 acres, said Eduardo Uribe, a coffee expert at Los Andes University in Bogota.
If farmers want to stay in business, they must focus on organic coffees and other specially produced brands likely to command a superpremium price, said Richard P. Peregoy, an international business expert at the University of Dallas Graduate School of Management in Irving, Tex. "Things are going to go down, down, down unless they find a niche market," he said.
Coffee growers agree but say the prospects of making such a switch are grim.
"That is what they say, but the reality is different," Mr. Gallego, the farmer, said. "We do not have the capital for that, to bring out the specialty or organic coffees."
So he and most other farmers are squeezing in other crops, like plantains, between their coffee bushes to increase revenue. Hugo Tabares, who, like many farmers living in haciendas, is trying to rent out rooms to weekend visitors.
"We have to act and try to find another way to make money," Mr. Tabares said. "And we try to keep costs as low as possible."
He added, "We just want to do what we can to keep our farms."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
The decline of the Muslim Middle East, and the roots of resentment, can be traced to Islamic inheritance law.

BYLINE:  By Virginia Postrel; Virginia Postrel is the editor at large of Reason Magazine and the author of "The Future and Its Enemies." E-mail: vpostrel@reason.com.

 BODY:
UNTIL the late Middle Ages, the Muslim Middle East was at least as economically developed as Europe. Then, beginning with the rise of the great Italian traders in the 14th century, Europeans pulled ahead, while the Islamic world gradually declined. By the 19th century, European economic influence had translated into political domination of the Middle East. The Islamic world has never fully recovered, and that disparity feeds resentment today.
 What happened? The puzzle is vexing not only because Muslim traders had been so successful in earlier eras but because they remained successful in trade with other regions, like India and East Africa. They were not bad at business; to the contrary, they were good at it. 
 This is the sort of big-picture question that interests economists who study "institutions" -- the laws, regulations and norms that provide the underpinnings for economic life. After the work of the Nobel laureate Douglass C. North, these scholars recognize that development does not take place in a vacuum. The institutions that work well for certain types of economic activity may not work as well for others. Discovering new and better institutions is as important as discovering new technologies or business practices. And that trial-and-error process can take time.
Since 1997, Timur Kuran, an economist at the University of Southern California, has been investigating the connection between institutions and the economic decline of the Muslim Middle East. In a paper, "The Islamic Commercial Crisis: Institutional Roots of the Delay in the Middle East's Economic Modernization," he proposes an answer: Islamic partnership law and inheritance law interacted to keep Middle Eastern enterprises small, never allowing the development of corporate forms. (A version of the paper can be downloaded at papers.ssrn.com/abstract_id=276377.)
In the Middle Ages, both Islamic and European law required that a partnership dissolve if one partner died or was incapacitated. That tended to limit the size of such arrangements. The typical partnership would be, say, two financial backers and one trader who brought merchandise to or from a distant locale. The more people involved, the more likely the partnership would have to dissolve in the middle of a venture.
In Europe, the consequences of a partner's death could be limited. Inheritance law often allowed a person to designate heirs. So a particular son might inherit the partnership share. The partnership would still have to dissolve technically, but it could be immediately reconstituted. Even in places where inheritance law was more rigid, heirs were generally limited to the nuclear family, keeping down the number of claimants and, therefore, the potential for disrupting partnerships. As a result, European partnerships were able to expand over time, allowing more ambitious, better-financed ventures.
Under Islamic law, by contrast, inheritance was prescribed in rigid detail, with all sorts of family members -- uncles, cousins, siblings, parents, and so on -- getting pieces of the estate. There was no way to limit a stake to a single heir. These prescriptions were rooted in the Koran, which meant they were virtually impossible to alter. The fragmentation produced by inheritance law, combined with the strictures of partnership law, kept Middle Eastern enterprises small. That, in turn, limited the pressure to evolve new economic forms.
"Why did you get the joint stock corporation and the modern corporation in Europe?" Professor Kuran asked. "Because as these partnerships expanded, they created problems that had to be resolved by putting pressure on the legal system to recognize new institutions." For instance, partners who wanted to pull out and sell their shares needed a financially graceful way to do so, leading to transferable shares and stock exchanges.
"As these problems arise, the legal system responds," Professor Kuran said. "The same thing doesn't happen in the Islamic world because the partnerships don't grow."
That difference did not matter for a long time, because the small partnerships were still extremely successful, and most of their trade was with Africa or Asia. Only in the 18th century, when trade with Europe became a big part of Middle Eastern commerce, did the difference between the systems become important.
At that point, Christians and Jews in Islamic countries also suddenly had a business advantage. As religious minorities, they had been able to choose whether to do business under Islamic law or, with mutual consent, under some other law. Although their own religions also provided laws and courts, they generally relied on Islamic law.
When Europeans started dominating Middle Eastern trade, however, they brought European courts with them. That gave Middle Eastern religious minorities a new option: to use European law. "So," Professor Kuran said, "a local Christian in Istanbul suddenly gets the idea he could start running his business under French law and take his disputes to the French court in the city, and to have his contracts notarized by a French notary, effectively moving under French law. This happens on a very large scale."
Since European institutions had evolved to better suit the scale of modern businesses, in which thousands of people may be involved as investors and employees, Christians and Jews using those laws began to prosper in comparison to their Muslim neighbors. Only in the 19th century did Middle Eastern governments begin adopting secular commercial laws that allowed Muslim-owned enterprises to grow.
Today, Professor Kuran says, Islamic inheritance law poses no problems to large-scale endeavors. The estate simply divides up the securities among the heirs, and the business goes on undisturbed. Secular corporate law lets religious inheritance law work in a modern economy.
"I'm not talking about blanket condemnation of Islamic law," he said emphatically. "That is patently false. I don't believe it and I don't argue it." Rather, he views the situation as an unintended consequence of institutions that were suited for the times in which they developed.
"When the inheritance law was put into place, the early Muslims in the seventh century were not thinking about the consequences for commerce with Europe 1,000 years later," he said. They were addressing inequities in their own day, including the problems of daughters left with no inheritance. "But in the process," he said, "they created another problem 1,000 years down the road."

HEADLINE: Novartis Plans Drug Discount For Elderly 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Novartis A.G. of Switzerland said yesterday that it would offer cards to low-income elderly Americans to provide discounts of 25 percent or more on the company's brand-name drugs.
 Novartis said the discounts would take effect in January. Those eligible will be people who are 65 or older and have incomes of $26,000 or less for single people and $35,000 for couples. 
 The offer follows a similar announcement early last month by the British company GlaxoSmithKline. A number of pharmaceutical companies are seeking to burnish their reputations in hopes of deflecting pressure in Congress for measures that could increase the government's influence on drug prices. Other drug companies are cutting prices on anthrax drugs and offering to produce smallpox vaccines.
"The pressure on the industry has eased, due to the war and bioterrorism," said Dr. Daniel Vasella, chief executive of Novartis. "It's a good time to be proactive instead of defensive."
The discount drug card program, he said, is a partial step toward reducing the burden of drug costs for 10 million low-income people who do not have insurance that covers drugs. 
That group is faced with some of the world's highest drug prices. Reflecting the buying power of the purchaser, the same drugs cost less to United States government agencies, managed care buyers and, to a lesser degree, people who get discounts through mail-order pharmacies and discount drug cards like ones offered through the retiree organization AARP. 
"We are trying to make a contribution to easing some of the divides" between wealthy and poor Americans, Dr. Vasella said.
Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of Health and Human Services, said Novartis was "offering an innovative solution" to make prescription drugs "more accessible to those seniors who cannot afford them." 
"Moving forward," Mr. Thompson said, "it will be necessary for the administration, Congress and the private sector to work together to formulate a more comprehensive solution." 
Consumer advocates and industry analysts said the drug company cards would have little effect. "Only a tiny, tiny portion of the elderly population is likely to avail themselves of such a card," said Ron Pollack, executive director of Families USA, an advocacy group in Washington. 
It is unclear how many people already use Novartis drugs. Novartis products accounted for almost one in four recommendations by doctors to patients over 65 in the last 12 months, according to IMS Health, which collects data about pharmaceutical sales. But Mr. Pollack said only one Novartis product, Miacalcin Nasal Spray for osteoporosis, was among the top 50 drugs used by the elderly in a Families USA survey last year. 
GlaxoSmithKline has only recently begun to send sales people to tell doctors about its drug card program, said David Stout, president of the company's United States unit. He said 3,000 callers to the company had requested applications after a "brief, modest advertising campaign."

HEADLINE: U.S. Figures Show Rate of Productivity Gained in Third Quarter 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
Productivity in the third quarter rose at the fastest pace in more than a year as companies relied on fewer workers to produce goods and services, government figures showed today.
 Productivity, a measure of how much employees produce for every hour worked, increased at a faster-than-expected 2.7 percent annual rate from July through September, compared with a 2.2 percent pace in the previous three months, Labor Department figures showed. Analysts had expected a 2 percent rate of increase in the quarter, when the economy shrank for the first time since 1993. 
 Worker hours fell at a 3.6 percent annual rate in the third quarter, more than at any time since 1991 as companies cut almost 250,000 jobs to save money in an economic slowdown. At the same time, companies installed new systems to improve efficiency.
"The relatively strong rise in productivity attests to firms' desperate efforts to remain price competitive and protect battered profit margins by aggressively cutting back on their work force," said Jade Zelnik, chief economist at Greenwich Capital Markets Inc.
The increase was the largest since a 6.3 percent surge in the second quarter last year, just before the economy started to slow. The third-quarter pace compares with productivity increases that averaged 2.5 percent a year from 1996 to 2000, when the economy grew at an average rate of 4.1 percent.
Unit labor costs, or the amount paid for each unit of production, rose at a 1.8 percent rate in the third quarter, the slowest pace in a year. That compares with a 2.6 percent rate of increase in the second quarter.
In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said that consumer borrowing rose by $3.2 billion in September after a $6.1 billion jump in August and a $2.1 billion decline in July. Even with September's unexpected increase, borrowing has averaged a $1.6 billion increase the past four months, after rising an average $11.8 billion in the first five months of the year.
That is a further sign consumers have cut back their spending. The Commerce Department also reported sales by wholesalers fell more than inventories in September.
Sales declined 1.3 percent, the largest drop since March, after a 0.5 percent increase in August, the Commerce Department said. Inventories fell 0.1 percent, after falling 0.2 percent in August. The decline was the fourth in a row, the longest stretch since March-June 1991, when the country was emerging from a recession.
Productivity lowers the cost of doing business and enables the economy to grow faster than once thought possible without igniting inflation.

HEADLINE: Pakistanis Urge U.S. to Suspend TextileTariffs 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
A two-thirds decline in business from United States companies is forcing apparel and textile concerns in Pakistan to lay off thousands of people and could soon close numerous factories, according to a report released yesterday by a Pakistani trade group. The Pakistani government had previously estimated the decline in orders at closer to 40 percent. 
 The Pakistan Textile and Apparel Group, a coalition of Pakistani clothing manufacturers and buyers for United States companies, issued the report as part of its campaign to encourage the United States to suspend tariffs on their goods. The domestic textile industry bitterly opposes such a move, arguing that the removal of tariffs would cause further job losses in an industry already suffering. 
 Textiles and apparel manufacturing is a crucial industry in Pakistan, as it employs roughly 60 percent of the industrial work force. The United States, which imported $1.9 billion of the industry's goods last year, is Pakistan's biggest customer. Since the United States took its war on terrorism into the region, many American companies, including American Eagle Outfitters and Perry Ellis, have stopped ordering goods.
Rising unemployment in Pakistan could pose political problems for the United States since the nation is a key ally in the effort to rid Afghanistan of Osama bin Laden and his allies.
"Unfortunately, millions of Pakistani workers risk losing their jobs, destabilizing the economy and potentially the entire government, because of the collateral effects of the military activity in neighboring Afghanistan," said Senator Jon Kyl, a Republican from Arizona who supports some trade concessions for Pakistan.
Although the production and shipment of Pakistan products, like yarn and knit polo shirts, continue uninterrupted, many American companies have not placed new orders out of fear that escalating hostilities could interfere with getting the products to market on time. Some companies have also decided to move business because of rising insurance and freight costs.
Reliable statistics on orders in Pakistan are difficult to get because big retailers often buy through third parties. The report released by the Pakistan Textile and Apparel Group is based on a survey earlier this week of 14 big apparel factories in Lahore, Karachi and Faisalabad. Pakistan has 350 factories that make textiles and apparel, according to the group, though many are smaller than the ones surveyed.
The survey showed a 64 percent reduction in orders for clothes that would be made from December through February. Employment in the 14 factories dropped 32 percent, from more than 16,000 a year ago to about 11,000 this week. 
The same group had previously estimated that 18,000 workers had been let go throughout the industry. A New York spokeswoman for the group said the survey suggested that that number had certainly risen, but she did not have a revised nationwide figure.
The group is publicizing the losses to press its case for a suspension of United States tariffs on Pakistani imports, which average 17.5 percent on top of the cost of the orders. 
"Pakistan desperately needs tariff relief for our industry to survive," said Aleema Khan, another spokeswoman for the group, who owns a business in Lahore and represents a number of United States companies that import textiles from Pakistan.
The Bush administration has asked Congress to pass legislation that would allow it to cut tariffs, but the domestic textile industry and its allies in Congress are expected to fight it.
The domestic industry has lost 90,000 jobs in the last 18 months to foreign concerns, according to its Washington lobbying arm, the American Textile Manufacturers Institute.
Ms. Kahn said that Pakistan was not competing with the United States for jobs but was losing business to other nations like Bangladesh, China and Vietnam.
"Giving Pakistan the relief we are seeking will not harm the U.S. textile industry," she said. "It will not create additional business. It will only help bring back the business we had before."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Trade Group Predicts Turnaround in Chip Sales Next Year

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 7 

 BODY:
The trade association for the semiconductor industry predicted today that the sharpest ever decline in chip sales would turn around next year with 6 percent growth, followed by a full-blown recovery in 2003.
 The forecast by the Semiconductor Industry Association, which represents most chip makers, was more optimistic than several other predictions by independent research firms, which believe the market will grow only slightly at best and shrink 7 percent at worst. 
 The semiconductor association, which is based here, said chip revenue this year would fall 31 percent, to $141 billion, after a record surge in sales pushed the industry up 37 percent in 2000, to $204 billion. The 31-percent decline would nearly double the decline in 1985, the sharpest drop on record, when the market fell 17 percent. 
The association predicted that demand would remain weak in the first half of next year but pick up substantially in the last six months, pushing the market to $150 billion, a 6 percent increase over 2001.
The momentum will carry into 2003 and 2004 with 21 percent growth for each year, the association said.
The recovery is expected in every region of the world. The forecast called for 4 percent growth in the Americas, which slumped 43 percent this year, and 1 percent growth in Europe, which declined 29 percent this year. Asia, which declined 23 percent this year, is expected to lead the surge with 14 percent growth.
The sales of computer chips, the computer brains in everything from personal computers to cell phones to automobiles, are widely seen as a sign of the technology industry's health. While manufacturers of memory chips and networking processors continue to suffer through a terrible slump, chip makers for PC's and wireless devices have seen signs of improvement in recent months, though revenue has lagged because of price wars.
George Scalise, the trade association's president, said makers of PC and wireless chips have largely cleared out their excess inventory and are beginning to see increases in orders. He said his forecasters believed early evidence that consumers would spend about as much money this holiday season as last. More electronics sold means more chips sold.
"We've been through these cycles before, and we know this too shall pass," Mr. Scalise said. "The industry will continue to grow as it has in the past."
But Wall Street analysts and independent research firms varied in their hopes for the extent of the upturn. Several agreed that 2003 would improve dramatically over 2002, by as much as 25 percent. But they questioned whether the industry could improve enough in the second half of next year to offset an expected slow first six months.
"It's very hard to see anything better than flat in '02, because you're starting in a very deep hole," said Mark Edelstone, an analyst with Morgan Stanley.
The International Data Corporation, based in Framingham, Mass., has predicted the chip industry would decline by 7 percent in 2002, the first ever consecutive years of shrinking sales. Mario Morales, a senior vice president in the company's semiconductor group, said the number of chips sold would improve, but their average selling prices have decreased so sharply that chip makers would have trouble surpassing their sales, even compared with such a dreary year as this.
"The major impact is really the price erosion we've witnessed over the last couple of quarters, in not only the PC-related markets but also the wireless and network equipment markets," Mr. Morales said.
IC Insights, a research firm based in Scottsdale, Ariz., predicted a 1 percent increase next year. But the company's president, Bill McClean, acknowledged that companies and consumers could take very little prodding to cut back spending on electronics even further.
"If the U.S. economy proves stubborn to interest rate reductions, and people don't feel comfortable spending for one reason or another, we could easily see single-digit negative growth rates next year," he said.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Optimistic Outlook"After a decrease in global semiconductor sales for 2001, the Semiconductor Industry Association forecasts a recovery in sales through 2004. Graph shows forecast from 1990-2004. (Sources: Semiconductor Industry Association; World Semiconductor Trade Statistics)

HEADLINE: Global-Warming Talks Gain With Accord on Compliance 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: MARRAKESH, Morocco, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
Government ministers from around the world moved a step closer today to bringing a treaty to combat global warming into force after their officials reached agreement on a crucial sticking point. 
 Ministers were upbeat as they addressed the United Nations talks here to define the terms of the pact that will commit industrialized nations by 2012 to cut their emissions of heat-trapping gases by an average 5 percent below where they stood in 1990. 
 Many were encouraged by a breakthrough in lower-level talks late Tuesday that put in place a system to ensure that countries comply with their pollution targets -- previously seen as a stumbling block that could have sunk the treaty. 
"The progress made thus far is solid and encouraging," the Iranian environment minister, Massoumeh Ebtekar, told the session on behalf of the group of developing countries known as the G77. "The agreement reached last night is indeed a very good outcome," she said.
Whether countries that emit more greenhouse gases than allowed under the so-called Kyoto Protocol of 1997 would face binding sanctions had been a thorny question at recent similar forums, but many delegates said it now seemed settled. 
Environmental groups that had accused Japan, Russia, Canada and Australia of trying to elude a binding sanctions system welcomed the agreement. "Countries now know if they miss their targets there will be consequences," said Jennifer Morgan of the World Wildlife Fund.
Ministers had agreed on the outline of a compliance system at a meeting in Bonn, Germany, in July, but squabbling in Marrakesh over the legal fine print had cast the deal into doubt.
Emphasizing the importance of a climate change treaty, Secretary General Kofi Annan said the Kyoto proposals, which were rejected by the United States in March, were "a victory for multilateralism."
"Indeed, joining forces against global threats to human society and the planet has never been more important," he said in a message read to the conference by an envoy.
The United States faced a barrage of criticism when it pulled out of the treaty saying the Kyoto pollution-cutting requirements for developed countries but not poorer ones would hurt the American economy.
The American under secretary of state for global affairs, Paula J. Dobriansky, gave no hint that Washington would return to the treaty, which President Bush had described as "fatally flawed."
"Our collective long-term objective must be to create a truly global approach that stitches together actions by all countries into a tapestry of national and international cooperation," she told the conference.

HEADLINE: Holiday Air Travel Is Expected to Be Off Sharply 

BYLINE:  By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
Air travel this holiday season is expected to be off sharply, deepening the gloom for airlines that have been desperately cutting fares to try to put more people into airplane seats during what is traditionally the busiest travel period of the year.
 With almost daily reports of new airport security slip-ups, and with repeated and vague government warnings of further terrorist attacks, Americans are showing less interest in venturing far from home over the Thanksgiving holiday, surveys and experts say. For the entire fourth quarter, air travel is projected to be at least 25 percent below last year's levels, according to the Travel Industry Association of America. 
 Estimates scheduled for release today by the AAA automobile club project a 5.9 percent decline from a year ago in the number of Americans planning to make Thanksgiving weekend trips of more than 100 miles from home. Last year, the AAA said that a record 36.8 million Americans made such trips. 
"It looks like the overall number of travelers will decrease, but a greater percentage will be going by car," said Mantill Williams, a spokesman for the AAA. Part of that may be because gasoline prices this year are averaging about 32 cents a gallon lower than last year, he said.
Travel industry officials attribute the likely drop in air travel to both the weakening economy, which has discouraged longer trips, and post-Sept. 11 fears. But the fears are not particularly of becoming a victim of terrorism.
"We find that the much bigger factor is fear of being stranded," said Betsy O'Rourke, the marketing director of the Travel Industry Association of America, which regularly polls travelers. "The feeling is, 'I don't want to get caught too far away from home right now,' " she said.
The apprehension stems mainly from fresh memories of an air system that came to a halt, stranding tens of thousands of travelers on Sept. 11, she said.
"Literally everybody has a story," Ms. O'Rourke said. "They know somebody who was stranded somewhere, or didn't get on a flight."
Domestic airlines, facing losses this year expected to exceed $5 billion industrywide, had hoped that deep, but selective, discount fares could lure Americans back to flying over the holidays. But airline executives have been telling analysts that the strategy has not worked, and that they may abandon fare-cutting soon.
"In my discussions with airline C.E.O.'s, they are saying that any pricing stimulus they have attempted in the last three to five weeks has produced nothing," said Michael Dyment, a partner at Andersen, the financial consulting firm. 
Instead, he said, discounting has simply damaged the airlines' financial performance, because business travelers who would be flying regardless of the fare are paying less. The National Business Travel Association projected this week that the average fares paid by business travelers, which had been rising at near double-digit rates in recent years, would increase only about 3 percent in 2002.
The picture still could improve, of course, if fare sales prompt Americans to make last-minute holiday travel plans; not just airlines, but hotels, restaurants and related businesses are still hoping they will.
In the meantime, airlines are trying to assure customers that airports are not as chaotic and inconvenient as many suppose. Northwest Airlines, for example, said this week that it had streamlined boarding procedures, even with tighter security, and now advises that travelers arrive at the airport 90 minutes before flight time, instead of the two hours that had been recommended.
Additionally, the F.A.A. said yesterday that it was hiring and training several hundred temporary security workers to augment its force of about 850 airport security agents, about half of whom are deployed at check-in areas. Rebecca Trexler, a spokeswoman for the agency, said the new employees should be on duty before Thanksgiving.
Robert L. Crandall, the retired chief executive of American Airlines, said that this year's holiday travel numbers ought not be given much weight as a measure of the long-term health of the airline business.
"It's still too close to Sept. 11," he said. "There are no indicators in the short term that have any prognosticating value for the long term. We're all in a state of crisis, and what happens this Thanksgiving or Christmas, I don't think has anything to do with what's going to happen in 2002 and the years beyond that."
Ms. O'Rourke, the travel trade group executive, said that she saw "more good news than bad news" in poll data, for example, showing that the number of Americans who now say they are afraid to get on an airplane is about 7 percent, virtually unchanged from before Sept. 11. 
For those who are traveling by car, train, bus or on shorter flights, she added, bargains abound as hotels and other destinations have begun promoting packages to entice Thanksgiving travelers who want to stay closer to home.
Some hotel companies say those tactics are paying off.
"Locations that are dependent on airlines to deliver their customers are having a difficult time, but locations where they get a lot of driving traffic are actually doing quite well," said Bruce Wolff, the senior vice president for global sales at Marriott International.

HEADLINE: Police and the Economy 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The report that overtime earnings as a result of the World Trade Center attack will lead to a record number of police retirements (front page, Nov. 2) could be turned into a blessing by the new mayor. In the 1990's the size of the Police Department was greatly increased, and crime decreased. 
 But crime decreased everywhere in the 1990's, even where the number of police officers stayed the same. Although politicians and the police took credit, the crime drop was probably due mostly to the Supreme Court. Twelve years after the court decided that abortion was legal, crime started dropping and kept dropping for a decade. 
 Crime has leveled off. But the economic boom is over, and the city is left with a police department that is bloated and wasteful, as can be seen from the daily activity records of individual officers. A wave of resignations might be perfect for a city that needs to re-examine its expenditures.

ROBERT PANZARELLA
New York, Nov. 5, 2001

The writer is a professor of police science, John Jay College of Criminal Justice, CUNY.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Johnnie Cochran to Head Business Zone 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Johnnie L. Cochran Jr., the lawyer who gained national prominence by successfully defending O. J. Simpson against murder charges, has been named chairman of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, the economic development organization that has been administering $250 million in federal, state and city funds in Harlem, Washington Heights and Inwood.
 Mr. Cochran, 63, was the choice of United States Representative Charles B. Rangel, the powerful Harlem Democrat, to succeed the current chairman, Richard D. Parsons, the vice chairman of AOL Time Warner. The zone's governing board approved the nomination Oct. 22. Mr. Rangel described Mr. Cochran in a statement as "visionary when it comes to community and economic empowerment." 
 Mr. Cochran, whose recent clients have included Sean Combs, the rap mogul, and Abner Louima, who was tortured by the police, is a popular figure in Harlem, and his involvement in the empowerment zone may help allay concerns in the neighborhood that the program has done more to help big developers and national retailers than small businesses. Mr. Rangel has often been at odds with city and state representatives who have veto power, along with him, over how the empowerment zone money is spent.
But critics of Mr. Cochran's selection said they wondered if he had the time to devote to the empowerment zone. In recent years, he has built the nation's largest plaintiffs' law practice, with 10 offices around the country and more than 100 lawyers. His appointment takes effect early next year, he said.
Mr. Cochran said he would be his own man. "If you know anything about me," he said, "you know I'm pretty independent. I very often speak up and fight the status quo."
Mr. Cochran has also not endeared himself to those who were appalled by the racial overtones of the Simpson defense and who disapprove of his close relationship with the Rev. Al Sharpton. But Jim Capel, Mr. Rangel's chief of staff, said Mr. Cochran had "one persona in terms of being a lawyer and another in terms of being chairman of the board," and would be able to keep these roles separate.
Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington, the city's representative on the empowerment zone board, refused yesterday to discuss Mr. Cochran's new position. State officials did not return a call requesting comment.
Mr. Cochran said yesterday that he spends about half of his time in New York, where he has an apartment on West 57th Street. He still votes in Los Angeles, where he was raised. His parents moved there from Shreveport, La., when he was 6. Acknowledging that he is something of an outsider, he said, "Maybe because of that I bring a fresh approach."
He said he planned to get very involved in the empowerment zone, despite his busy schedule. "My mother had a saying," he said. " 'If you want to get something done, give it to a busy person.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. will head a $250 million development group. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE LEGISLATION; 
House Committee Approves Measure to Aid Insurance Industry in Terrorist Attacks

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
Congress edged closer to aiding the insurance industry tonight when a House committee voted to promise insurers billions of dollars in loans in the event of any large terrorist attacks next year.
 The measure, approved by a voice vote of the Finance Services Committee, would generally provide loans to the industry to cover 90 percent of terrorism costs greater than $1 billion. For attacks causing more than $20 billion in losses, the bill would impose a special assessment on insurance policyholders to help defray the costs. House Republicans said they had decided to adopt a one-year measure now and advance a longer-term plan next year. 
 Democrats on the committee failed in efforts to raise the amount of money the insurance industry would have to pay before the government offered any assistance. The Democrats said tonight that they would continue trying to raise this amount in the full House. A measure being prepared in the Senate would offer assistance only after the insurance industry paid the first $10 billion in claims from any terrorist attack next year.
The bill the committee approved this evening would protect smaller insurers that face big claims and would give the industry tax breaks to encourage it to build up reserves for terrorism coverage. It also protects the insurers from punitive damages in any lawsuits arising from terrorist attacks.
Bush administration officials and industry executives say that to avert an economic crisis Congress must adopt the legislation before adjourning shortly.
The world's leading reinsurance companies, which provide insurance to primary insurers, have said they intend to stop covering losses from terrorist attacks as 70 percent of insurance contracts come up for renewal at the end of the year. Without adequate coverage, banks and other lenders say they will stop providing credit for major construction projects and corporate equipment purchases. 
Though a consensus has emerged in Congress that quick action must be taken, there is wide disagreement about the details. Although competing measures provide different kinds of federal relief, they all take the first step of putting the federal government into a new supervisory role over the insurance industry. 
The House legislation sidestepped some lawmakers' concern about a Senate plan endorsed by the Bush administration. That proposal would rely on the federal treasury to bear the costs of any large-scale attack. 
"Unlike other approaches that have been suggested by the Senate and the administration, the bill that I and 30 other bipartisan members introduced is clearly a backstop, not a bailout," said Representative Michael G. Oxley, the Ohio Republican who heads the House Financial Services Committee. "We are providing a helping hand-up, by creating immediate federal assistance in the aftermath of another terrorist attack, but not a hand-out, by demanding that every dollar of American taxpayer assistance ultimately be repaid."
But Democrats and industry experts say the House plan will not do enough to keep insurance premium rates down in the same way the Senate plan might. Some lawmakers were also critical of the tax breaks that the House bill would give the industry.
"While the proposal purports to recover money from industry, it also provides the industry with a long-term subsidy which could well exceed what it pays," said Representative John J. LaFalce of New York, the ranking Democrat on the Financial Services Committee. He said the proposal "could actually impede the re-emergence of the private market" for terrorism insurance.
Prospects remain uncertain for the completion of a bill before Congress adjourns. The Senate measure has stalled over a jurisdictional squabble among three committees.
The Senate bill, being prepared by senior Democrats and Republicans on the Senate banking committee, would require the industry to pay for $10 billion in insurance claims before the government intervened. The government would pay 90 percent of losses that exceeded $10 billion.
But the legislation has been bogged down in a dispute over its limitations on the civil liability of insurers. Senator Ernest F. Hollings, the South Carolina Democrat who heads the Commerce Committee, has indicated his interest in possibly introducing a rival measure.
None of the measures under consideration would provide money for any losses from the attacks of Sept. 11. Experts estimate those attacks could cost the industry more than $40 billion.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At the House Finance Services Committee session yesterday: the ranking Democrat, Representative John J. LaFalce of New York, left, and the committee chairman, Michael G. Oxley, Republican of Ohio. (Carol T. Powers for The New York Times)

 INTERNATIONAL A3-13

Taiwan Moves to Build Commercial Links to China
Taiwan lifted longtime restrictions on direct investment in China, bowing to the reality of living next door to a fast-rising political and economic power. But some analysts worry that the move will make Taiwan overly dependent on China and threaten its political independence. Others say it will accelerate the commercial integration of Taiwan and China. A3

The Concorde Flies Again
The world's only supersonic airliner resumed passenger service with an Air France flight from Paris to New York followed by a British Airways flight from London. The planes have been modified since a Concorde crashed outside Paris 15 months ago. A12

Spanish Judge Is Slain
A judge was shot dead as he left home near Bilbao, in northern Spain, in the first fatal attack linked to the Basque separatist group E.T.A. since the Sept. 11 terror attacks in the United States. Officials speculated that the shooting was a response to the arrest of two people suspected of planting a car bomb in Madrid that injured 95 people on Tuesday. A8

Greek Elite Is Accused
Tensions between Greece and the United States increased after Thomas Niles, a former American ambassador to Athens, asserted that there were links between Greece's political elite and the Revolutionary Organization 17 November, a terror group held responsible for a series of assassinations of Americans and others. A9

German Response to Sept. 11
The German cabinet adopted plans for major changes in security and immigration laws and approved the deployment of up to 3,900 troops for up to a year to support the American-led war in Afghanistan. A12

Government ministers from around the world meeting in Morocco were encouraged by a breakthrough in lower-level talks that put in place a system to ensure that countries comply with their pollution targets -- an issue that has been a stumbling block. A5
