Oregon Sues U.S. to Keep Its Assisted-Suicide Law
Oregon's attorney general, joined by four patients, went to court seeking a stay of a Justice Department order authorizing federal drug agents to take action against any doctor who prescribes lethal drugs for terminally ill patients wishing to end their lives under provisions of Oregon's assisted-suicide law. A14

$5 Billion Valdez Penalty Voided
A federal appeals court in San Francisco struck the $5.3 billion in punitive damages assessed for the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska in 1989, the worst in the nation's history. The court agreed with Exxon Mobil that the award was excessive, and it ordered a judge to reduce it. A14

The Supreme Court heard arguments on just what it means when the Americans With Disabilities Act defines a disability as an impairment that "substantially limits" someone from engaging in one or more "major life activities." A18

Unofficial results indicate that Shirley Clarke Franklin has become the first woman to be elected mayor of Atlanta and the first black woman to lead a major Southern city. A24

President Bush asked Senate leaders to pass a slimmed-down version of his plan to give federal money to religious charities, saying all charities were hard-pressed to provide relief to victims of the Sept. 11 terror attack while helping the needy. A17

HEADLINE: No Joy in Mudville, as Twins Are Near Striking Out 

BYLINE:  By JOHN W. FOUNTAIN 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
There is no epitaph for baseball here yet. But if there was any handwriting on the wall for Minnesota Twins fans on the day after Major League Baseball owners voted to cut the 30 professional teams by two, it read: Baseball is dead.
 While the owners may not decide for several weeks which of the financially weakest teams will die, the Twins, along with the Montreal Expos, are on the short lists of most baseball experts. And so on a somber day across the Twin Cities, the fans mourned. 
 Some reminisced, while others cursed or huffed. Still others choked up as they recalled fond memories of the days that eventually turned into years of watching baseball while eating a hot dog, sipping on a Coke and cracking peanuts at the old ballpark.
"This is something I'm really struggling with," said Tom Montbriand, a sales representative for a local sign company who was inside the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome, which the Twins have called home for the last two decades, on business this afternoon.
"Growing up in a family of five boys and a sports-crazed dad, we really loved the Minnesota teams. So it's not easy," he said of the potential demise of the Twins.
Mr. Montbriand has not missed a Twins home opener since 1966. He grew up just three blocks from Metropolitan Stadium, where the team played for 20 years after moving from Washington in 1961. He started going to games with his father at age 5, Mr. Montbriand said. He is 41 now with children of his own: a son Joshua, 6, and a daughter, Taylor, 7.
"I'd like them to enjoy a lot of things that I was able to enjoy when I was a young child going to a game with my dad," Mr. Montbriand said. "They'll be missing out on that."
There seemed few, if any, people here who were holding onto any thread of hope, most considering it a done deal that the Twins are one of the two teams headed for extinction, although the Oakland Athletics and both Florida teams -- the Marlins in Miami and the Devil Rays in St. Petersburg -- are other possible candidates.
Commissioner Bud Selig said that elimination of two of the 30 major league teams was necessary for economic reasons. Contraction will mean two fewer teams for owners to subsidize through their revenue-sharing plan as well as two fewer teams to share national television revenue.
In the case of the Twins, the owner, Carl H. Pohlad, has wanted to get out of baseball for some time, and would probably get more money from Major League Baseball than he would from selling the team to someone else. The Twins have had a difficult time filling the Metrodome in recent years, although attendance picked up this year when the team made a strong, but ultimately unsuccessful, run for the division title. They last won the World Series 10 years ago.
Most fans echoed Mr. Montbriand's sentiments.
"With everything that's gone on over the last few months, the way our world has changed, there's been definitely no guarantees for anything," said Steve Oslund, 32, a maintenance worker at the Metrodome, who added that he worried about being able to keep his job if the Twins disappear.
"I feel sorry for a lot of people I know that are going to be out of work, good people that have got families and everything," he said. "I'm a little sad." 
"It's going to be painful for us, but yet, for the team it's going to be hard," added Mr. Oslund, sitting inside the stadium, which has undergone its seasonal metamorphosis from baseball stadium to football field for the Minnesota Vikings.
"Bud Selig says it's not going to be a sad day. I don't know what the hell he's thinking," Mr. Oslund said. 
Co-worker Darrell Nomeland, piped in. 
"You know what he's thinking: 'All right you guys, come on and give us a hundred-million dollars or we're going to shut you down,' " Mr. Nomeland said. "Those guys don't care about baseball. It's the bottom line." 
"It's the almighty dollar," Mr. Oslund said. "That's what it's all about."
For fans here, there was plenty to be said today about the death of baseball, of an end to warm summer evenings under the glow of stadium lights, the smell of beer wafting through the stadium, the cry of "hot dogs," "peanuts" or "Cracker Jack." At restaurants and bars and on the airwaves, the idea that the Twins may be history has begun settling in like winter cold.
At the Dome Souvenir Shop, a family-run business near the Metrodome, the owner, Ray Crump, mourned the team's expected demise. Mr. Crump, 65, has followed the Twins for decades, dating to the days when he earned 50 cents a game as a batboy for the team when they were the Washington Senators and later as equipment manager for the team when it moved in to Minnesota, and Mr. Crump moved with it.
"It's a sad day. I have one guy in particular who has been coming to my store since 1986, and he's come to every Sunday game since 1986 and all he does is live for baseball," Mr. Crump said. 
So does Mr. Crump, who also runs a fluorescent-lighted establishment adjacent to his souvenir shop named, "The Original Baseball Hall of Fame Museum of Minnesota." It is a long narrow room filled with glass-encased World Series bats, baseballs and Twins memorabilia that on game days draws fans in droves.
"I'm going to miss it," Mr. Crump said, sounding resigned. "It's my life."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tom Montbriand, in the home of the Minnesota Twins, talked about the team's future. (Craig Lassig for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 2001 ELECTIONS: THE GOVERNOR-ELECT; 
McGreevey Warns of Tough Fiscal Future in New Jersey

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Nov. 7 

 BODY:
Governor-elect James E. McGreevey exulted today in his victory over Bret D. Schundler and thanked voters for their support at his first post-election news conference. But he also issued a stark warning about the tough fiscal situation that he and the newly elected state legislators will face when they take office.
 "Santa isn't coming to the State Legislature with Christmas tree lists this year," he said. "We need to cut back. We need to be fiscally responsible. We need to live within our means." 
 Mr. McGreevey looked pale and had dark rings under his eyes as he faced a bevy of microphones and television cameras in the council chambers at Town Hall here today. But if he was thoroughly exhausted, he was also downright giddy. "A nonpartial crowd," he joked, as supporters, campaign staff members and Woodbridge municipal employees loudly applauded his arrival. "Where were you guys four years ago?" 
Mr. McGreevey first ran for governor four years ago, losing to Gov. Christie Whitman. On the day after that election, a disappointed Mr. McGreevey vowed to run again. Today, he happily deflected questions about his transition plans and about the potential makeup of his cabinet. He cheerfully conveyed his "heartfelt gratitude" to voters. He smiled as he reported that his pregnant wife, Dina, who remains hospitalized with complications, "is doing incredibly well and the baby is healthy and all things are moving forward." And he laughed about his plans to invite his Irish relatives from around the world to a reunion at Drumthwacket, the governor's residence.
But he also fielded a barrage of questions that highlighted the tough challenges that lie ahead: a looming deficit of perhaps $1.5 billion, ballooning state debt, a stalled economy, ongoing terrorist threats, the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks, sky-high property taxes and auto insurance rates and a struggling public school system. Not to mention the perils of Trenton, a state capital filled with internecine rivalries, some of which have only been inflamed by the Democrats' return to power.
On the state's impending budget problems, Mr. McGreevey said again that he would not raise taxes. "I guess I'll answer this question for the 400th time," he said. "I am committed to having a government living within its means. And it will be necessary to make difficult decisions." Asked specifically about taxes, he replied, "Oh, I am ruling out a tax increase." And he promised a thorough review of state spending. 
"Yes, there will be cuts," he said. "And I am committed for New Jersey state government to being operated in a cost-effective, fiscally conservative and responsible manner, and we will have to make difficult decisions. But again, it's a 5,000-plus line item budget. It will be an agonizing reappraisal of what government should do and, perhaps more importantly, what government ought not be doing." 
Mr. McGreevey said that he had already been in touch with Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco and that he hoped for a good working relationship in the Republicans' final months after eight years of control. Mr. McGreevey said he would meet with Mr. DiFrancesco this week and would consult with him on many issues, including New Jersey's role in the cleanup and recovery from the attack on the World Trade Center and the state's claim to federal aid as part owner of the trade center. 
Mr. McGreevey also said that he hoped that Mr. DiFrancesco and the Republicans would not complete a deal for a new sports arena in Newark, so that he could do it. "Clearly my preference is to move forward on the arena subsequent to the inauguration," he said. "We need to ensure the sole exposure is to the bondholders, not to the taxpayers." And he repeated earlier criticisms that an arena deal by Republicans that failed this summer had been a "billion-dollar porkfest." 
But several Republican officials said, by contrast, that the best situation for Mr. McGreevey would be for the arena deal to be completed before he took office and that, in fact, his comments might have been intended to move the deal along.
Even before the arena issue resurfaces, Mr. McGreevey will be forced to confront a battle for the speaker's position in the soon-to-be Democrat-controlled State Assembly. 
"We need to achieve consensus," Mr. McGreevey said today, adding that he would become involved in the dispute only if legislators requested his involvement. His aides said he was in fact hoping to broker a deal to prevent a battle between the Democratic minority leader, Joseph V. Doria Jr. of Bayonne, and Joseph J. Roberts Jr. of Camden. Mr. McGreevey declined to say whom he preferred. "I would look forward to developing consensus with all of the members," he said.
At the outset of his news conference Mr. McGreevey said he would not answer questions about who would be appointed to his administration. "As to transition, we will be making announcements next week," he said. But the rumor mill, of course, was churning wildly among Democrats, and aides to Mr. McGreevey said some appointments were virtually certain. For example, Gary Taffet, Mr. McGreevey's longtime chief of staff in Woodbridge, is expected to have the same job at the State House, they said. 
In addition to the news conference, Mr. McGreevey met with his campaign staff members to thank them and spent much of his day at the hospital with his wife, aides said. 
Throughout today's news conference, Mr. McGreevey spoke of the gravity of his responsibilities as governor, particularly in relation to education issues and antiterrorism measures. "I appreciated the campaign and the excitement of last night," he said. But he also talked about "the seriousness of the mission at hand" and "the need to tackle serious security issues, working in concert with the Office of Emergency Management, working in concert with the Department of Health."
To voters, he said: "I will continue to work hard to earn your trust every day. I will work at this job with every ounce of energy and every fiber of my being."
Mr. McGreevey also said he had sought during the campaign to outline proposals without making too many promises. "I think we made very clear specific commitments, particularly regarding the quality of public education," he said. "Yet we were also steadfast to ensure that we did not commit financial resources to initiatives which could not be sustained, particularly during these economic times."
But even as he stressed the serious work ahead, Mr. McGreevey clearly could not suppress his giddiness over fulfilling a longtime dream and being elected New Jersey's 51st governor. Dressed in his familiar navy suit and red, white and blue tie, Mr. McGreevey also displayed his trademark self-deprecating humor as he described plans to move with his wife from their condo in Woodbridge to the executive mansion in Princeton.
"Dina and I will be moving to Drumthwacket," he said. "And we will be immeasurably lowering the lineage of Princeton and the Princeton community." He also said one of his dreams was to hold a reunion for his Irish relatives from all around the world at the mansion. As for neighbors, he said, "I can see them saying, 'There goes the neighborhood.' " 

How the Polls Were Conducted
The Election Day polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting stations throughout New York City and New Jersey on Tuesday. Questionnaires in New York City were available in English or Spanish.
The poll was conducted by Edison Media Research of Somerville, N.J.
The results are based on 1,608 voters in New York City and 1,718 voters in New Jersey, located in 40 randomly selected districts in each place. 
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results should differ by no more than plus or minus three percentage points from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all voters who turned out in New York City or New Jersey yesterday. 
Results based on smaller subgroups have a larger potential sampling error. 
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion on Election Day, such as the reluctance of some voters to take time to fill out the questionnaire, may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Head of Troubled New York Academy of Sciences Is Resigning in Policy Rift 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS OVERBYE 

 BODY:
The New York Academy of Sciences announced yesterday that its president and chief executive, Rodney W. Nichols, would leave at the end of the year. Mr. Nichols's efforts to reshape the academy, including closing its award-winning magazine The Sciences and putting its elegant headquarters on East 63rd Street up for sale, roiled the institution in recent months.
 In his letter of resignation, given to the board of governors last Thursday, Mr. Nichols, a physicist and former executive vice president at Rockefeller University, said that he had served for almost a decade and "I believe it is time for me to pursue new goals." In an interview he said he had been mulling over the move for a year for a variety of reasons, including the fear that the criticism and resentment he was encountering were hurting the academy. "I'm more of a distraction to the continuation of the process of renewal and modernization," he said. 
 The academy, founded in 1817, is the city's oldest scientific organization, including Thomas Jefferson and Charles Darwin as former members. It is known worldwide for its work on human rights for scientists in foreign countries, for its scholarly publications and for holding groundbreaking scientific conferences on subjects like AIDS and women in science.
Dr. Torsten N. Wiesel, a neurobiologist and former president of Rockefeller University who took over as chairman late in September, called Mr. Nichols's resignation a big surprise. "He has played a major role in helping the organization renew and modernize its mission of serving science, technology and society," Dr. Wiesel said in a statement.
Under Mr. Nichols the academy began projects like science education, technology and the economy, and pollution in New York Harbor, and took steps towards raising an endowment, which it has never had.
Others close to the academy, however, said that a rift had developed between Mr. Nichols and some board members over the purpose of the academy and its finances.
Mr. Nichols's critics said that he was turning the academy into a think tank, instead of a forum where scientists could meet and talk. "Scientists in the academy -- and the academy is for the scientists -- disagreed with him," said Dr. Fleur L. Strand, a former president of the academy and professor of biology at New York University.
The academy has been in trouble, all agree. In recent years its membership has declined from about 42,000 worldwide to about 28,000. It traditionally operated as a confederation of so-called sections organized along specialties like chemistry or anthropology. But this summer Mr. Nichols announced that the sections would be disbanded in favor of interdisciplinary forums.
The proposed sale of the mansion, which many agree the academy has outgrown, nevertheless struck a sour note with many academy members who regard it as a symbol.
Dr. Wiesel said it was unlikely that The Sciences, which had won seven National Magazine Awards, would be revived soon, calling its cancellation a fiscal decision. In searching for a replacement for Mr. Nichols, he said he wanted to keep in mind the needs of the New York area's scientists.
"It's important that they see this as a home for scientists," he said.

PERSON: David Rivel 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
From a Room With a View, Going to Bat for Parks

BYLINE:  By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
HOW often is it that a New Yorker gets a chance to work in a charming old building that looks like a medieval fortress, and from an office window, can hear sea lions barking for their chow three times a day?
 David Rivel is in this fanciful situation. He's the new executive director of the City Parks Foundation, a nonprofit group that raises money to restore neighborhood parks. He is found on a recent afternoon behind his tidy desk in the group's second-floor office in the Arsenal in Central Park, also the home of the New York City Parks and Recreation Department. It overlooks the Children's Zoo, hence the barking sea lions. 
 "Some people call them seals, but they're sea lions," he says knowledgeably, seemingly into the groove of his environs after one month on the job.
On the surface, Mr. Rivel, 40, is rather dry, a bit stiff -- not exactly your fanciful type. That is, until you get him talking about Jerry Lewis films -- his undergraduate thesis at Wesleyan University analyzed the comedian's directing career -- or razz him about his nom de parc, Sturgeon, bestowed by the parks commissioner, Henry J. Stern, in honor of Mr. Rivel's grandfather who founded the famous Murray's Sturgeon Shop on the Upper West Side. (Every park employee or park friend gets a moniker. "It's Henry's thing," Mr. Rivel says.)
He readily admits he is not a "parkie," one of those folks who can gab endlessly about wetlands and distinguish among tree species. "I don't know anything about that stuff."
But Mr. Stern, who created the foundation in 1989 while serving under Mayor Edward I. Koch, considers him a full-fledged member of the park family. Mr. Rivel was even presented with a little gold pin that says "Sturgeon" to wear on his jacket pocket. "He may not wear it for you; some of the new people are a little self-conscious," Mr. Stern says. The commissioner is also aware of Mr. Rivel's other strengths. "He's supposed to be a fund-raiser and a team player, so we look forward to working with him."
The other day, Mr. Rivel was pondering the task ahead of him now, after six years as president of the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music. He is credited with steering the music school from being near financial collapse to having an endowment of $1.5 million, a $300,000 scholarship fund and a $2.4 million renovation of its main building in Park Slope. He assumed the leadership there after a vice presidency at Lincoln Center.
Slightly built with a trim, graying beard, Mr. Rivel leans back, hands clasped behind his head. He has an almost scholarly air as he talks about the role of parks. For one thing, he sees them as healing places.
"Look at what happened after the tragedy of Sept. 11," he says. "Everyone went to the parks. I went to Union Square. Parks are those communal places where people can come together and share experiences. They've always been that way, but every once in a while something happens to make you realize that."
Mr. Rivel's office has few personal touches. He's kept the autographed posters left by his predecessor, Deborah Landau, of one the foundation's biggest programs, Central Park SummerStage, the music festival in the park's Rumsey Playfield.
He says his biggest challenge is getting a handle on all the programs under the auspices of the foundation, which has an annual budget of $15 million. They include one of the biggest youth tennis programs in the nation, as well as programs to help public schools grow gardens and to mobilize community groups to improve their parks.
As Mr. Rivel talks about the community mobilization initiative, started in 1995, you can tell his juices are flowing. "It grew out of the realization that wealthy parks will be just fine, and what do we do about other parks? We try to organize communities to support their parks so there's a built-in constituency."
Mr. Rivel, who grew up in Weston, Conn., describes himself as an old-fashioned liberal. His father owns a market research company, and his mother used to run a cooking store and school. He met his wife, Laura, in an antinuclear group in Chelsea in 1986. They bonded when they were arrested at a protest on Staten Island. She now runs a program for teenage parents and their children in Queens. The couple, who have a 12-year-old daughter, Hannah, live in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn.
On this windy, cool afternoon, Mr. Rivel decides to tool uptown through Central Park in a dark green van, passing joggers, a wedding party, swirling leaves on manicured lawns. He wants to meet some staff members for the first time in Marcus Garvey Park near 125th Street in Harlem.
THE leafy retreat is one of five major parks, including Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn and Crotona Park in the Bronx, that his group has intensified efforts to spruce up. "The foundation can play a role in making sure that every park looks like Central Park," he says.
The foundation now produces summer concerts in the Harlem park. It has contributed to the hiring of a gardener and bought computers for the recreation center. Soon, it hopes to fix the broken footpaths that wind all the way up to the park's watch tower.
There's a long way to go, but Mr. Rivel is optimistic. In the golden shadows of dusk, he is beaming, watching two uniformed schoolgirls cut a path through the park. "It's part of their community now. It's not the thing they walk around and avoid because it's a horrible place."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Parks are those communal places where people can come together and share experiences." DAVID RIVEL (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Baseball Is Now Waiting for the Sale of Two Teams

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
As intriguing as Major League Baseball's decision to eliminate two teams is, so are the ongoing negotiations for the sale of two other teams, one of them to an owner whose team is No. 1 on the contraction list.
 In fact, word circulating among baseball executives yesterday was that the primary reason Commissioner Bud Selig has declined to identify the teams to be eliminated is that he is waiting for the results of those negotiations for the sale of the Florida Marlins and the Anaheim Angels. 
 Jeffrey Loria, owner of the Montreal Expos, is negotiating to buy the Marlins from John Henry, and Henry is negotiating to buy the Angels from the Walt Disney Company. Selig denied yesterday that those talks are having any impact on his disclosure of the two teams he says will be eliminated before next season. 
"That's not true," Selig said. "It's not even close. Those are unrelated."
Selig said after the 28-2 vote at the owners meeting on Tuesday that the teams would not be identified until negotiations with them are completed. 
"We have so many details to work out," he said yesterday.
There was no further word from the Players Association on contraction yesterday. Given the angry reaction by Donald Fehr, its executive director, the union will certainly challenge the owners' plans through the grievance procedure. The union, if it chooses, can also try to block contraction by refusing to approve the new schedule that the owners would have to produce after eliminating two teams. 
Representatives of the union and the owners are scheduled to meet in Manhattan today. The owners maintain that they do not have to negotiate contraction with the union, but they acknowledge that they have to negotiate the effects of contraction, like the distribution of players to other teams.
The prevailing belief among baseball executives is that the Expos and the Minnesota Twins will be those teams. But the high-powered game of musical owners is just as intriguing as the idea that baseball will shed teams.
Loria, an international art dealer who lives in New York, would prefer to move the Expos, perhaps to northern Virginia, but Selig will not permit relocation now. Loria wants to remain in baseball, so his alternative is to buy another team. He would not talk about that alternative yesterday. "I have no comment on any of that," he said.
Henry, an investment entrepreneur who lives in South Florida, has been unsuccessful in his efforts to gain public funding for a new park for the Marlins and has said he cannot fund a stadium by himself while also maintaining a large-enough payroll to have a competitive team.
So he is trying to buy the Angels from Disney, which wants to sell. But two executives said yesterday that Disney is asking for more money than Henry has offered.
Efforts to reach Henry by telephone were unsuccessful. Tim Mead, an Angels spokesman, said Tony Tavares, the club's president, has acknowledged that Henry was interested in buying the Angels. He also quoted Tavares as saying that Disney would discuss the sale of the club with any owner who was involved in contraction as well as any other potential buyer.
The Angels, however, are proceeding with plans for the 2002 season as if Disney will still be the team's owner.
The delay in identifying the teams to be eliminated prompted speculation ascribing two different motives to the plan.
One theory has Selig trying to panic state legislatures in Minnesota and Florida into finding funding for new stadiums for the Twins and the Marlins. If the legislators think a team from their state could disappear, they might act quickly in reversing their opposition to using public money for new parks.
The other theory has Selig using contraction as a negotiating weapon. That idea has the commissioner threatening to eliminate 50 major league jobs but withdrawing the threat if the players make the kind of economic concessions the owners will seek in talks to replace the collective bargaining agreement that expired at midnight last night.
"This is not meant to do anything other than what we in the industry believe we have to do," Selig said in denying those alleged motives.
Asked if contraction was a negotiating ploy, the commissioner said: "It is not a negotiating ploy. I said before that I think this is something that has to do with the number of franchises that can't produce enough revenue to be competitive. There isn't anything in their past, present or future that indicates we can solve that problem."
Is it possible that Selig and the owners will change their minds and not eliminate the teams before the 2002 season? "We have every intention of doing it," Selig said.
Agents, meanwhile, began grumbling yesterday about the difficulty they will face in determining which teams to begin negotiating with for clients who are free agents. Those players can begin signing with new teams Nov. 20. 
"We have to move as expeditiously as possible," Selig said, acknowledging the need to complete contraction plans so that clubs and players can get on with their business.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: NOTEBOOKS; 
Man Indicted In Fake Threat Of Anthrax

BYLINE:  By JANE FRITSCH 

 BODY:
Nixon B. Saldanha of Bombay had had enough of New York and wanted to return to India. But he could not afford the plane fare, prosecutors said yesterday, so he tried to get himself deported.
 First, he called 911 about 10 days ago to complain that someone had thrown an envelope full of something at him, officials said. He had hoped to be arrested for filing a false report, they said, but the police never responded to the call. 
 On Friday, however, Mr. Saldanha, 30, who has been living in Jackson Heights, Queens, got plenty of attention when, investigators said, he told a member of the National Guard outside Grand Central Terminal that he had found two envelopes that appeared to contain anthrax.
Mr. Saldanha was indicted yesterday by a federal grand jury in Manhattan on charges that he made false statements to federal officials in connection with an anthrax hoax. If convicted, he could face up to 10 years in prison and a fine of $250,000 or more.
The incident occurred about 11 p.m. on Friday, after a National Guardsman had completed work at the site of the World Trade Center and was waiting near the terminal for a ride, according to the indictment. Mr. Saldanha approached him with two envelopes, one addressed to Tom Brokaw, the NBC News anchor, and the other addressed to "Editor, New York Post," investigators said.
Mr. Saldanha told the guardsman that he had found the envelopes on top of a nearby telephone booth, the indictment said. Concerned about the possibility of anthrax, the guardsman told Mr. Saldanha to put the envelopes on the ground, and contacted the Metropolitan Transportation Authority police.
The envelopes were removed by hazardous-material specialists and were sent to the City Department of Health for analysis.
Meanwhile, F.B.I. agents interviewed Mr. Saldanha. They said Mr. Saldanha told them that he had found the envelopes. Later, he told a different story to detectives from the Joint Terrorist Task Force, the indictment said.
He told the detectives that he had come to the United States in June 1999 on a visitor's visa. He had attended community college and worked, but had been unemployed since August and wanted to go home.
So, he told the detectives, in late October he decided to find a way to get arrested so that he would be deported. After his 911 call got no response, he downloaded copies of anthrax-tainted letters from a news organization's Web site, prepared similar letters, then sealed them in envelopes along with talcum powder, the indictment said.
Mr. Saldanha is to be brought before a magistrate in Federal District Court in Manhattan today. Investigators said his wish to be deported might be fulfilled -- after a stay in a federal prison. JANE FRITSCH

HEADLINE: 1,400 Layoffs Are Planned At Waterford Wedgwood 

BYLINE:  By BRIAN LAVERY 

DATELINE: DUBLIN, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
Waterford Wedgwood, the Irish luxury goods conglomerate, will cut 1,400 of its 10,000 jobs worldwide in response to slumping sales, which started falling from record highs in July and are now down 4.5 percent from last year.
 After additional restructuring of its retailing and manufacturing, the company said, the changes will add 43 million euros ($38 million) to company profits, for a charge of 60 million euros ($54 million). 
 Since Waterford Wedgwood's only chance to bolster sales figures lies in the coming holiday season, the company simultaneously increased its marketing budget 15 percent. 
It also unveiled a new advertising campaign that uses images of warmth and comfort for "a focus on family and friendship, what the Americans call 'cocooning,' " in line with post-Sept. 11 consumer trends, the chief executive, Redmond O'Donoghue said. New television ads will start immediately in the United States, where Waterford Wedgwood does 44 percent of its business.
"In spite of all of these events, gift giving will go on," he said. "People want to celebrate births, anniversaries, graduations, and we have the brands to help them do that."
September's terrorist attacks hurt luxury goods manufacturers in two ways because they curtailed tourist travel as well as regular consumer spending. Vacationers are the most reliable buyers of high-end products, even in regular department stores, Mr. O'Donoghue said. In Ireland, the second-biggest market for the Waterford brand of crystal, the number of tourists from the United States is expected to fall from a million in 2001 to half that number in 2002.
More than 1,100 of the company's layoffs will be at manufacturing operations in Britain, although 100 workers will lose their jobs at the company's flagship crystal plant in Waterford, Ireland. It will also close 40 of its British retail outlets, with the loss of 400 jobs.
Mr. O'Donoghue moved today from chief operating officer to group chief executive, a change that formalized his role overseeing the group's four component companies. A familiar name, Tony O'Reilly Jr., rose to chief executive of the Wedgwood ceramics division. Mr. O'Reilly's father is Sir Anthony O'Reilly, the Irish billionaire and media magnate, who holds a controlling interest in Waterford Wedgwood.
Mr. O'Donoghue took a bullish long-term view today, sticking to Waterford Wedgwood's commitment to double last year's record annual revenues by 2005. American sales have been hurt the most in recent months, but luxury goods are still selling well even in recession-hit areas like Japan, where Waterford Wedgwood licenses its brand.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Lose Momentum And Give Up Sharp Gains

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks slipped yesterday, eroding the previous session's sharp gains, as worries about the gloomy economic environment overshadowed hopes the Federal Reserve's rate cuts can help spur a rebound.
 "You get these fights with the bulls and the bears," said James Volk, co-director of institutional trading at D. A. Davidson & Company. "There are a number of people that are bullish about the economy turning around and there's another group that think there's no reason for this buoyancy in the market because it's still way, way premature." 
 The market initially built on Tuesday's rally when the Fed's 10th interest-rate cut this year sent stocks soaring to their highest levels in about two months. But momentum faded toward the end of yesterday's session.
"We had a big run up yesterday after the Fed announcement," said Peter Coolidge, senior equity trader at Brean Murray & Company. "The announcement was expected, but the run-up wasn't, so we're just giving up a little bit of ground on that."
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index, buffeted early in the session by disappointing results and a discouraging forecast from the wireless telecommunications company Qualcomm, finished with a gain of 2.45 points, or 0.1 percent, at 1,837.53.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 36.75 points, or 0.4 percent, to 9,554.37. At its session high of 9,644.12, the blue-chip index had erased all of its post-Sept. 11 losses.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.06 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,115.80.
Shares of Hewlett-Packard dragged on the Dow after the company and Compaq Computer stood firm on their plans for a $21 billion merger, even as pressure mounted from Hewlett and Packard family members to cancel the deal.
Hewlett shares slipped 63 cents, to $19.18. The stock gained more than 17 percent Tuesday after the founding Hewlett family, which has a stake of more than 5 percent in Hewlett-Packard, said it would vote against the deal. Compaq's stock sagged 51 cents, to $7.99. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday as investors speculated rising worker productivity will keep inflation in check, giving the Federal Reserve room to follow Tuesday's interest-rate cut with another in December.
"Productivity gains and lower labor costs indicate there's the possibility for growth, so we can keep lowering short-term interest rates without worrying about inflation," said James Cusser, who manages about $1 billion at Waddell & Reed in Overland Park, Kan. 
The 10-year Treasury note rose 19/32 , to a price of 106 17/32 .
The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.18 percent from 4.26 percent on Tuesday. The yield was the lowest it has been since Oct. 5, 1998.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 31/32 , to 109 5/32 . The bond's yield fell to 4.79 percent from 4.85 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Slow Lane to Kmart's Recovery; 
Consumers Turn Frugal and Many Suppliers Discontent

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
When Charles C. Conaway strode into Troy, Mich., 18 months ago to take over the sagging Kmart Corporation, he had big plans. Not only did he intend to revive Kmart, the nation's No. 2 discount chain, by attracting new customers with a wide array of useful, low-price goods, but he would also do it by September 2002. 
 Much has changed since then, but not according to plan. The company announced last week that Halloween sales fell from those last year, a disturbing development in any retailing business. Kmart executives also said that the prime fourth quarter, when Americans shop for the December holidays, was likely to be flat at best. 
 And on Tuesday, Moody's Investors Service said it was reviewing Kmart's credit rating for possible downgrading. 
Mr. Conaway says he remains confident that a turnaround is on track. "We're doing the right thing," he said. He acknowledges that the makeover, which he calls "a massive cultural as well as structural transformation," is still in progress, but says that many of the behind-the-scenes remedies that customers rarely see are already behind him.
Some of the company's problems seem beyond management's control. Nearly a year ago, the economy started to shrivel and consumers stopped spending so lavishly. The terrorist attacks nearly two months ago delivered a further economic blow. 
But several analysts and manufacturers say that Kmart still seems to lack a strong image that might draw consumers and is riven by problems years in the making. For one thing, while other discount merchants have picked up newly frugal customers, Kmart has been largely left in the cold. Analysts say that Mr. Conaway, despite his efforts, has not found the formula he needs to distinguish Kmart from its competitors. Moreover, in a possible indication that Kmart is going out of its way to conserve cash, many manufacturers who supply products to its 2,100 stores complain that they are having a hard time being paid. 
Kmart was in disarray before Mr. Conaway arrived from the drug retailer CVS, where he had been president and chief operating officer. His predecessor, Floyd Hall, recruited five years earlier on a similar mission, developed private brands for Kmart and introduced Super Kmart grocery stores. He stepped down in part because Martha Stewart, whose home furnishings line is a top seller for the company, complained that he was not committed enough to her products.
Running Kmart has long been one of the toughest jobs in retailing. Once one of the fastest-growing companies in the United States, it has been steadily losing ground for years to Wal-Mart, the nation's biggest retailer, while other chains, like Kohl's, have picked up steam.
Many things about Kmart were "broken," Mr. Conaway said -- from the supply chain, which is supposed to transfer products smoothly from manufacturer to warehouse to store shelves, to the computer systems intended to track sales and inventory. 
Beyond that, Kmart was suffering from an identity crisis. While its name may be embedded in the nation's consciousness -- with its BlueLight specials and its battle cry "Attention, Kmart shoppers" -- many shoppers have been unclear for years about just why they should go to Kmart.
Wal-Mart became the world's biggest retailer by efficiently delivering the lowest-priced goods in town; Target created an image as the place for the simultaneously price-conscious and fashionable. But at Kmart, shoppers complained that the products they most wanted were often out of stock. And prices, while low, were regularly undercut by Wal-Mart.
Against this backdrop, Mr. Conaway, a trim 41-year-old whom some analysts make fun of for his tendency toward malapropisms (in a conference call over the summer, he declared that "Kmart and Martha Stewart are inexplicably linked at the hip"), sought to carve out a space for Kmart.
Earlier this year, he zeroed in on mothers, saying Kmart would market itself as the retail destination that best met their families' needs. Brands that Kmart already sold, like Martha Stewart and Sesame Street, fit in neatly.
Mr. Conaway has signed additional exclusive agreements for apparel with Joe Boxer and Disney. The brand lineup, together with the convenience offered by the urban locations of many Kmart stores, he told analysts on Sept. 10, will provide "a tremendous sweet spot for us, by being the authority for Mom."
Not everyone agrees. "Wal-Mart and Target have already perfectly divvied up the market," said George Strachan, a Goldman, Sachs analyst, noting that among the top three discounters, Wal-Mart captures a majority of shoppers who earn $50,000 a year or less, and Target attracts most who earn more.
Mr. Conaway quickly committed the company to lower prices, with his "BlueLight Always" program. The price cutting began earlier this year with a few thousand products, and by last month it had widened to about 38,000 items, roughly a third of its total, the company said.
Mr. Conaway has also tried to improve customer service, tying compensation for store managers to how well their stores do on service. Mr. Conaway boasted not long ago that scores for service had barreled upward from just 40 percent satisfaction a year ago to about 60 percent today.
He has also invested in self-service cash registers that allow shoppers to scan their own purchases -- in the interest of improving their experience in the store. 
Kmart's overall financial performance has left room for improvement. Last fiscal year, including special charges, it had a net loss of $244 million on sales of slightly more than $37 billion. In the most recent four quarters, Kmart barely eked out a profit.
And while Mr. Conaway's promises are compelling, the results have yet to appear in hard numbers. Kmart's sales per square foot, a typical retailing gauge, lag behind those of both Wal-Mart and Target. J. C. Penney, another old-line retailer trying to turn itself around, is one of the few chains with a worse performance by that measure.
As Mr. Conaway's price cutting got under way, Wal-Mart executives moved quickly to lower prices, which stymied Mr. Conaway's effort to stand out. While Wal-Mart's sales have risen 5 to 6 percent this fall, Kmart's have been flat. 
Kmart is now so focused on the bottom line that it makes missteps with consumers, a manufacturing executive said.
"Take Halloween," he said -- "and all that candy. The day after Halloween, Wal-Mart will mark theirs down 75 percent. They don't want it there. It's like dead fish. And Target will have it for 50 to 75 percent off. At those two stores, it will be gone within a week. But at Kmart, it will be marked down 20 percent, and it will be straggling for God knows how long."
The disappointing sales in October -- which Mr. Conaway attributed to a nationwide mood of anxiety that put a damper on trick-or-treating as well as other spending -- were hardly good news. "They definitely are struggling," said Emme Kozloff, a retailing analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein.
Mr. Conaway said December would reveal much about his strategy. "You've really got to get through the holiday season to understand how long it's taking you to change consumer behavior and your own culture," he said. 
Another important indicator is inventory turnover, which shows how frequently the overall stock of goods moves from warehouse to customer. At Wal-Mart, the average for last year was 7.3 times, and at Target 6.3. At Kmart, it was 4.3. 
Rapid inventory turnover is essential because the longer products sit in stores, the more they cost the retailer, who as a rule has paid for them up front.
Some manufacturers, insisting on anonymity and noting that the deadline for Mr. Conaway's turnaround was just 10 months away, made a point of the company's tight cash practices. At the beginning of this year, one manufacturer was asked to "contribute" money back because Kmart's margins were not as high as expected. The executive in charge was incredulous, asking why his company should be responsible for Kmart's difficulties. The answer he received, he said, was blunt: "Well, in order for us to stay in business, everybody has to contribute." 
Mr. Conaway said he knew of no such conversations. But he said he had had one meeting with a supplier who said that he had not been paid on time. The problem, it turned out, was that Kmart had lengthened the period it had to pay him, "and he didn't realize it." 
The difficulty for many manufacturers is that Kmart is a major account, and none want to lose its business, particularly at a time when general economic conditions are deteriorating.
Mr. Conaway said Kmart was working to improve relations with suppliers, and wanted to eliminate the $200 million worth of "charge-backs," or fines for shipping delays and the like, that it posts annually. The company stopped charging manufacturers for most of the summer, and even collected an award for the effort.
But the charge-backs are now in full swing once again, and among manufacturers, resentment is growing over that, as well as other methods Kmart appears to be using to shore itself up.
The Moody's review will examine Kmart's ability to pay off money it owes.
A spokesman for Kmart, Jack Ferry, said: "To date we have made significant operational progress in transforming Kmart's business model. It takes time for the financial performance to be seen."
Several manufacturers said the company had fallen behind by a week or more in its payments for products already delivered. Such a delay may seem insignificant, but the amount of money flowing through a giant retailer quickly adds up. Kmart makes an estimated $70 million a day in payments to suppliers, according to Burt Flickinger, a retailing consultant; thus, a weeklong delay amounts to a half-billion-dollar interest-free loan. 
Kmart is not alone. "As the economy slows down, companies are more likely to stretch their cash by taking longer to pay their bills," said Robin Schauseil, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Managers. 
Mr. Conaway says Kmart is not short of cash, but adds that he still has plenty to do before the company is fixed. When he arrived, he said, "our prices were too high, our stores were too dirty, our lines were too long, and we were out of stock a lot. Those are huge liabilities that we are working on."

HEADLINE: No Strings, No Loyalists 

BYLINE:  By Andrew White; Andrew White is director of the Center for New York City Affairs at the Robert J. Milano Graduate School of Management and Urban Policy of New School University.

 BODY:
The New York City electorate has realigned itself once again. This time Latinos held the winning hand, and they played it for Michael Bloomberg. In an extraordinary swing that has implications for the future, nearly half the Latino voters pulled the lever for the winner in the mayor's race. This bloc was not necessarily pro-Bloomberg, but it expressed anger about Mark Green's failure to make sufficient amends with Latinos after his attacks on Fernando Ferrer in the Democratic primary runoff.
 Mr. Bloomberg has an electoral coalition representing two very different core constituencies. On the one hand are Giuliani Democrats -- white working-class and middle-class voters -- along with wealthier pro-business voters. On the other are mostly working-class Latinos and about 25 percent of the black vote. In the face of the emerging fiscal crisis, it may be very difficult to hold these groups together. 
 The last mayor to try to hold onto support from such a diverse coalition was David Dinkins, who spent four beleaguered years in City Hall at war with the surging crack epidemic, a brutal recession and all manner of consequent social disasters. Who now remembers that Mr. Dinkins tried hard to earn the support of the business establishment as the economy sagged? He eliminated thousands of jobs in city bureaucracies, cut funds for many social programs, promoted real estate development and found money for 6,000 new police officers.
As a result, he ultimately lost much of his coalition's activist and labor base. Today, purveyors of conventional wisdom remember Mr. Dinkins as weak on crime and a patsy for divisive ideologues. All of which says a lot for the powerful forces that shape public opinion, and perhaps more for the Dinkins administration's inability to sell anything resembling a vision to voters.
Rudy Giuliani's great achievement was being able to impart a vision to his policies. The public understood his intentions and goals: cut welfare, reduce crime, keep Manhattan's streets free of beggars and other signs of disorder. Michael Bloomberg will succeed as mayor only to the degree that he can communicate a similar clarity of purpose, even if he pursues a substantially different agenda.
And he will have to. We no longer live in the 1990's, when the reformation of welfare, crime policy and taxation were top priorities in cities nationwide. Today some level of fiscal conservatism is assumed in New York City, despite campaign rhetoric to the contrary. Even if Mr. Giuliani hadn't drilled this deeply into the civic discourse, the devastation from the Sept. 11 attacks and the decline in the city's revenue forecasts mean Mr. Bloomberg has to govern with severe budget cuts. 
Nor can he coast on Mr. Giuliani's basic reforms -- many of which are not fully implemented. Instead, he has to build on these reforms at a time of declining public resources. His interest in social welfare, expressed even at the height of an often nasty campaign, is different from the passions of the departing mayor. While Mr. Giuliani cut the welfare rolls, one in five city households still had income below the federal poverty line last year. With the coming recession, Mr. Bloomberg will have to ensure that more eligible people, including the working poor, receive food stamps and other federally funded supports that are available to the city. 
In child welfare and foster care, he will have to take promising bureaucratic reforms made by Nicholas Scoppetta, commissioner of the Administration for Children's Services, and push those reforms out into the neighborhoods to change the way basic services are delivered, without adding greatly to the cost.
In the Police Department, he will need to reduce the social costs of Mr. Giuliani's anticrime policies. There is widespread anger about the enormous numbers of young men in minority neighborhoods who are stopped by police and searched. He may have to re-examine the impact of arresting and detaining -- rather than ticketing, as was once standard policy -- thousands of young blacks and Latinos each year for low-level misdemeanors. He will also have to limit the costly practice of neighborhood street sweeps in order to pay for new antiterrorism security needs. 
Meanwhile, the unions await new contracts. Businesses await new tax abatements. Unemployment is on the rise, and the 16-acre site of the World Trade Center sits just blocks from City Hall. The new mayor will almost certainly find himself fighting with groups that are affected as the city department budgets are slashed and welfare rolls swell. Like Mr. Dinkins during the last recession, Mr. Bloomberg must balance the budget, or he could well face a fiscal takeover by the state-chartered Financial Control Board, which managed city finances after the fiscal wreck in the 1970's.
Like Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Bloomberg isn't beholden to the union bosses and machine politicos who helped to put Mr. Dinkins in office. He has a high degree of independence from interest groups in city government. The Republican Party is largely irrelevant in New York City anyway and had little to do with his election. The municipal unions mostly abdicated any active role in the general election. 
Mr. Bloomberg's lack of such attachments will work to his advantage. Many of the voters who chose him -- conservative and liberal whites, Latinos, a smaller constituency of blacks -- were seriously alienated by Mark Green and the Democrats. In this context, his lack of a public record may have helped him to win by default; four years from now, he won't have that advantage.
If Mr. Bloomberg wants a second term, he will have to reach out to these various constituencies. He certainly won't be able to count on a repeat performance of the Democratic Party's self-immolation along ethnic and racial lines. But that is an issue he will face in time. For now, in the wake of Sept. 11 and after a bitter campaign season, he would do well to bring to his new administration a dose of humility and inclusiveness. The challenge is to blend those qualities with the projection of competence and clarity of goals that a traumatized city needs.

HEADLINE: Court Overturns Jury Award In '89 Exxon Valdez Spill 

BYLINE:  By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
A federal appeals court ruled today that the $5.3 billion in punitive damages the Exxon Corporation was ordered to pay for the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill, the worst in the nation's history, was excessive, and told a judge to set a lower amount.
 The decision vacates the award a jury in Anchorage ordered Exxon to pay in 1994 to 33,000 commercial fishermen, Alaska Natives, property owners and others harmed when the Exxon Valdez ran aground and spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil into Alaska's Prince William Sound. 
 Exxon, which has since merged with Mobil to become the Exxon Mobil Corporation, had repeatedly appealed the jury award, arguing that it should not have to pay the punitive damages because it had already paid damages as ordered by Congress. A district court in Alaska rejected the company's appeal in 1995, and the United States Supreme Court rejected its request for a new trial last year. 
But today, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, ruling on oral arguments made in 1999, said that while punitive damages could be awarded for the spill, which devastated 3,000 square miles and severely damaged one of the world's most sensitive ecosystems, the $5.3 billion was excessive in light of recent Supreme Court rulings on damage awards. Under those rulings, Exxon Mobil might be ordered to pay up to about $1.6 billion, or less than one-third of the original award.
Exxon Mobil had no immediate reaction to the decision, a company spokeswoman said.
In Alaska, the organization representing the Prince William Sound fishermen affected by the spill said there was "shock and surprise" at the ruling.
"There's some disappointment around here," said Sue Aspelund, executive director of the Cordova District Fishermen United. "People's lives have been on hold a long time, since 1989, trying to get this thing resolved." 
Environmental groups said they were dismayed by the ruling.
"We feel that Exxon is getting let off the hook," said Gary Skulnik, a spokesman for Greenpeace. "They have committed environmental atrocities, and they are not being made to pay the price for it."
The Ninth Circuit panel, in what sounded like an effort to deflect such a reaction, wrote, "This is not a case about befouling the environment."
"The verdict in this case," it said, "was for damage to economic expectations for commercial fishermen."
The panel noted that the Supreme Court in 1996 set forth for the first time factors that should be considered in reviewing whether punitive damages were excessive, including the reprehensibility of the defendant's conduct, the ratio of the award to the harm inflicted on the plaintiff, and the difference between the award and the civil or criminal penalties in comparable cases.
Judge Andrew J. Kleinfeld, in writing the unanimous decision, noted that Exxon mitigated its reprehensibility by spending more than $2 billion to remove the oil from the water and adjacent shores, "and even from the individual birds and other wildlife dirtied by the oil." Exxon also "began settling with property owners, fishermen and others whose economic interests were harmed by the spill," Judge Kleinfeld wrote, spending $300 million on voluntary settlements "prior to any judgments being entered against it." 
Finally, he noted, the ratio of the $5.3 billion in punitive damages and the $287 million in compensatory damages the jury awarded was more than 17 to 1, a figure that would not get by the Supreme Court.
While the appeals panel did not set an amount for the Alaska district court to order, it noted that the Supreme Court set a ratio of about four to one in punitive awards to actual harm to the plaintiffs. The panel noted that the district court had determined the actual monetary damage to the plaintiffs as $288.7 million to $418.7 million, which would bring the punitive damages to, at most, about $1.65 billion.
The Exxon Valdez spill occurred shortly after midnight on March 24, 1989, when the tanker ran aground on a reef while trying to steer away from icy waters. The Anchorage jury found that the tanker's captain, Joseph Hazelwood, was reckless for leaving the bridge as the vessel neared the reef, which was shown on navigation charts. 
The jury also found recklessness by Exxon for allowing Mr. Hazelwood to be in charge of the ship when the company knew that he was an alcoholic, that he had begun drinking again and that he was drinking on board their ships.
The oil spill disrupted entire fishing communities, forcing shops to close, fishermen to declare bankruptcy and people to move from their hometowns. (While many people did receive settlements from Exxon, many others did not.) The spill also killed 250,000 birds and thousands of marine mammals, affecting 20 animal species. Ten years later, only two species, the bald eagle and the river otter, had fully recovered, while 10 had shown no significant recovery.
While public outrage over the spill forced President George Bush to abandon his drive to allow drilling in the coastal plain of Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, the plan has been renewed this year under the administration of his son.

HEADLINE: In America; 
Mark Green's Problem

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
It was a humiliating defeat. And if Mark Green is at all interested in understanding the real reason he is not the mayor-elect of New York at this critical moment in the city's history, he should do the thing he has always done best -- look in a mirror.
 To get a sense of how quickly and disastrously the Green campaign collapsed, consider that on Friday night the co-chairman of Miramax Films, Harvey Weinstein, served as chairman of a gala "Unity Dinner" for Mr. Green, which was attended by, among others, former President Bill Clinton and Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Charles Schumer. 
 Seventy-two hours later Mr. Weinstein endorsed Michael Bloomberg for mayor. That is bizarre by anyone's definition.
From Friday to Monday Mr. Weinstein had tried to broker a little real unity between Mr. Green and the Bronx borough president, Fernando Ferrer, who was defeated by Mr. Green in a bitter runoff election. 
But Mr. Green and his supporters were afraid of being perceived by white voters as caving in to Mr. Ferrer and his supporters (especially the Rev. Al Sharpton), so they aborted the attempted reconciliation. Mr. Weinstein was so angry he bolted to Bloomberg.
It seems always to be like that with Mr. Green. He infuriates people. He has a level of arrogance that is breathtaking, even for a politician. And his empathy gauge is almost always on empty.
Mr. Green never seemed to appreciate the depth of the anger of Mr. Ferrer's supporters in the aftermath of the runoff. When Mr. Green's own supporters were trying to forge links with the Ferrer camp, Mr. Green kept insisting that he didn't need the Ferrer people to win the election. He needed their support in order to govern successfully, he argued, but he could win the election without them.
Mr. Green's biggest problem was not that he made mistakes, but that he never learned from his mistakes. Almost from the beginning he seemed to take it for granted that he would be elected mayor. He seemed mesmerized by the polls, which almost always showed him winning. So he ran a Rose Garden campaign in the Democratic primary, and finished second, which shocked him. He went down and dirty against Mr. Ferrer in the runoff, which he won, but his tactics turned off Ferrer supporters by the thousands.
If he was chastened, he didn't show it. As the general election got under way, he went back to the Rose Garden. As late as two weeks ago, after a Bloomberg attack, Mr. Green coolly replied, "I don't really have to respond to him."
And when the question of debates came up, Mr. Green said of Mr. Bloomberg, "I'm not sure he's entitled to a debate, but I may give him one." They ended up debating twice. 
All kinds of reasons for Mr. Green's defeat are being tossed about. Certainly Mr. Bloomberg spent obscene sums of money. And lots of fingers are being pointed at the city's designated scapegoat, Al Sharpton. (In truth, Mr. Sharpton was treated shabbily by Mr. Green. The two men double-dated with their wives when that served Mr. Green's purposes. And then, when the campaign needed a demon, Mr. Sharpton was available for that role as well.)
But it wasn't Michael Bloomberg or Al Sharpton who loudly proclaimed that he would have done "as well or better" than Rudolph Giuliani in the aftermath of the trade center catastrophe. That was Mr. Green himself. And it was Mr. Green who, each time his lead shrank to near-zero, turned to the pettiest and nastiest tactics. The ad that he ran in which an announcer says, "Kill it! Kill it!" in a reference to a comment Mr. Bloomberg was alleged to have made to a pregnant employee was a grotesque embarrassment. 
The margin of Mr. Green's defeat was razor-thin, which tells me that if he had tempered his arrogance and demonstrated a modicum of leadership on the great issues of the day, he would have won.
Lee Miringoff, who directs the respected Marist College Poll, noted yesterday that voters -- concerned about terrorism and its effect on the city's economy and overall future -- brought "a higher level of seriousness" to this campaign than either of the candidates.
So the guy with all the money won. But it didn't have to be that way.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: MUSLIM ALLY; 
Musharraf Urges Bombing Halt for Ramadan

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE DALEY

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
The president of Pakistan, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, made another plea today for a stop to the American-led military strikes in Afghanistan during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan as he made his way to Europe and the United States.
 Speaking at Ataturk Airport in Istanbul during the second stopover of a six-day diplomatic shuttle that brought him to Paris this evening, General Musharraf said he would discuss a pause in the bombing with President Bush later in the week during his visit to the United States. 
 "One would certainly wish it would not go on during Ramadan because it will definitely have negative effects around the Islamic world," the general said.
But General Musharraf stopped short of categorically calling for a halt to the bombing during the holy days beginning later this month, and in a news conference with President Jacques Chirac of France the subject did not come up. 
The general is on his first trip outside of Pakistan since the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington and is scheduled to address the United Nations General Assembly on Saturday. 
At Elysee Palace here, General Musharraf and Mr. Chirac said their evening together would be spent over a "working dinner," discussing the difficulties Pakistan is facing and the economic aid it needs. 
"Pakistan has chosen to fight against terrorism," Mr. Chirac said. "France understands the difficulties involved in this courageous decision and wants to give it its support." 
Once given a cool reception in the West, General Musharraf has already won pledges of debt relief and the lifting of United States economic sanctions as part of a number of measures intended to prop up Pakistan's stalled economy in exchange for his support of the American-led antiterrorism coalition. 
But the six-day trip is another occasion for General Musharraf to enhance his stature in Pakistan by talking with world leaders as well as pursuing even more concrete promises of aid. 
General Musharraf made two stopovers in Iran and Turkey -- both predominantly Muslim countries -- before arriving in Paris. He is to meet with Prime Minister Lionel Jospin on Thursday before traveling on to London and New York.
Few details were made available about his stopover in Tehran, although a local news agency said that he met with the first vice president, Muhammad Reza Aref, on the crisis in Afghanistan. 
Iran disagrees with Pakistan and Turkey over the war in Afghanistan, with Tehran condemning the strikes against the Taliban. 
During a 40-minute stopover in Turkey, General Musharraf said news reports on civilian deaths in Afghanistan were exaggerated, though he did not offer his own assessment of the number killed. 
He dismissed accounts of divisions within Pakistan's military over his assistance to the United States, saying that Pakistan is a moderate Muslim country where a minority has given the world a false impression. 
"Pakistan has one of the strongest and best-disciplined armies in the world, which would follow only its leader," he said. "Just as there is no possibility of another coup in Turkey, there is none in Pakistan, either."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Jacques Chirac of France, center, met with Gen. Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's military ruler, at Elysee Palace in Paris yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: ECONOMIC LEGISLATION; 
Spending War With White House Focuses on Countering Terrorism

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
Democrats in Congress headed today toward a major confrontation with President Bush over tax and spending policy, vowing to defy his threat to veto legislation that provides additional money to counter terrorism in the United States.
 The Senate Republican leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, and the speaker of the House, J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, sided with the president, who told lawmakers on Tuesday that they should wait until next year to review whether more money was needed beyond the $40 billion Congress had already provided. The leaders put pressure on their colleagues, winning support from top Republicans on the House Appropriations Committee who had favored added spending. 
 But Democrats said they welcomed the coming confrontation with Mr. Bush as an opportunity to highlight differences between his domestic priorities and theirs. 
Democrats brushed aside Mr. Bush's threat to veto emergency spending that exceeded the $40 billion approved by both houses of Congress on Sept. 14, three days after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon and before the outbreak of anthrax threats and other security concerns. 
Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, said: "The $40 billion has all been spoken for. Additional money for homeland security and bioterrorism is urgently needed. If there's anything that is important to people right now, it's their personal safety and security and their economic safety and security."
On Thursday, the Senate Finance Committee is expected to approve a $67 billion package of tax cuts and new spending intended to stimulate the economy, which has been teetering for months on the edge of recession. 
Democrats plan to take the bill to the Senate floor next week after adding $10 billion to $20 billion -- to hire agents at the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Customs Service and the Border Patrol; to upgrade the public health system; to purchase smallpox vaccine and antibiotics, and to pay for new food safety and airport security measures. The money could also be used to increase security at nuclear power plants and to inspect ships arriving at American seaports. 
In addition to that spending, Democrats relished the opportunity to contrast their economic stimulus bill -- which provides jobless benefits and health insurance for the unemployed and immediate tax rebates for low-wage workers -- with a Republican bill passed by the House, which would cut taxes for many large corporations.
"The Democratic caucus sides with the people," said Senator Mark Dayton, Democrat of Minnesota. "The Republican caucus sides with the privileged, so they can give tax relief to millionaires and billionaires."
Senators of both parties predicted today that the economic stimulus bill would be approved by a party-line vote in the Finance Committee. Senator James M. Jeffords, independent of Vermont, said he planned to vote with the Democrats. To win his support, the Democrats agreed to pump $6 billion into agriculture programs, not normally viewed as a means of providing quick stimulus to the economy.
Mr. Lott said the proposals for new spending had proliferated so fast that "it's hard to keep up with all the different suggestions." He circulated a critique of the Democratic bill deriding it as a "special interest grab bag." In the end, Mr. Lott said, the president's veto threat will avert the need for a veto. "There won't have to be a veto" because Congress will rein in its impulse to spend more and more, Mr. Lott predicted.
Under one provision of the Senate Democratic bill, the government would help farmers by buying certain commodities that have been selling at low prices in the last two years. Crops eligible for this program include apples, asparagus, blueberries, cauliflower, cranberries, peaches, potatoes, pumpkins and watermelons.
Dick Armey of Texas, the House Republican leader, rallied to the president's side, saying: "This country is in the middle of a war. Now is not the time to provoke spending confrontations with our commander in chief."
The chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, C. W. Bill Young, Republican of Florida, had wanted to increase spending on antiterrorism programs. Today, under pressure from House Republican leaders, Mr. Young said he would support Mr. Bush's call to limit such spending to $40 billion. But he said other members of his committee would insist on additional money, and Mr. Young said he might not have the votes to block those efforts.
Mr. Hastert said Congress could always provide more money next year. "If there are new needs," Mr. Hastert said, "we would move legislation as soon as the need arises."
Despite Mr. Lott's prediction that no veto would be needed, the president's threat was somewhat risky. Many Republican lawmakers would like to vote for more money for popular antiterrorism efforts.
The administration supported the stimulus bill approved by the House, saying that corporate tax cuts would help avert further layoffs and would stimulate an economic recovery by encouraging companies to invest in new equipment and factories.
But Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said the House bill would provide a windfall to big companies. Specifically, he said, by retroactively repealing a provision of the tax code known as the alternative minimum tax, the bill would provide $1.4 billion to I.B.M., $1 billion to Ford, $833 million to General Motors and $671 million to General Electric. 
Moderates like Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, expressed despair at the resurgence of political infighting. 
"Two months after Sept. 11, one of the most cataclysmic events in our nation's history, we're dithering," Ms. Snowe said. "There does not seem to be any genuine good-faith interest in negotiating on a bipartisan basis."
The bill expected to emerge from the Finance Committee has several provisions to help New York, including tax credits for employers in Lower Manhattan and tax incentives for developers to rebuild the area devastated by the terrorist attacks. Aides to Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said that 10,000 companies with 300,000 employees would qualify for the tax credits. 
In the past, such tax credits were offered to employers to encourage the hiring of welfare recipients and low-wage workers. But Republicans said the Democratic bill included no such requirements. Thus, Mr. Lott's critique of the bill says it would provide companies with a $4,800 tax credit for each investment banker employed in Lower Manhattan.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senators Barbara Boxer of California and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, both Democrats, yesterday in a Senate gallery. (Carol T. Powers for The New York Times)(pg. B7)

HEADLINE: Bush Plan Would Revise Bill to Aid Charities 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
President Bush asked the Senate leadership today to pass a slimmed-down version of his plan to give federal money to religious charities, saying all charities were hard-pressed to provide disaster relief for the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks while helping the needy.
 These pressures from the war on terrorism helped persuade Mr. Bush to eliminate the most contentious parts of his religion-based initiative to win passage of the law before the end of the year. 
 In letters sent today to Senator Tom Daschle, the South Dakota Democrat who is the majority leader, and Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the minority leader, Mr. Bush said charities needed help immediately. 
"Although individual generosity is evident everywhere, thousands of our nation's charities, paradoxically, have been suffering," he wrote.
With the economy in a downward spiral, more people may seek help from charities. But at the same time many charities are finding it increasingly difficult to raise money for causes other than the care of victims from Sept. 11.
Mr. Bush said in his letter that such a bill should include incentives for donations to charities, equal treatment of community and religious charities and direct support to groups like those that help children with a parent in prison.
The House passed a broader measure this summer but it was stalled in the Senate. Mr. Daschle said he was unlikely to consider the House bill soon because of many so-called charitable-choice provisions that would allow religious groups receiving federal money to hire only members of their faith and to disregard antidiscrimination laws. 
Senator Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania, and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, will be the co-sponsors of a bill that would eliminate the most contentious provisions while providing equal treatment for the charities.
The House bill grants up to $13 billion in tax relief over 10 years. It allows people who do not itemize their taxes to deduct up to $25 in charitable contributions and allows noncorporate businesses like family restaurants to receive tax credits for food donations.
