HEADLINE: Essay; 
To the Crawford Summit

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
George Bush told Vladimir Putin last month that the 1972 ABM treaty was "outdated, antiquated and useless." Putin countered by telling Barbara Walters, in an interview ABC broadcast last night, that the treaty, which keeps the U.S. and Russia defenseless against nuclear attack, was "essential, effective and useful." 
 Then the Russian president added the crucial but: "But we have a negotiating platform from which we could reach agreements." 
 That platform was secretly nailed down on Oct. 21 in Shanghai: the useless-to-us, useful-to-them ABM treaty will be stretched to permit us to test -- in ways currently prohibited -- a defense against terrorist or rogue-state missiles. 
In return, the U.S. will agree at the president's Crawford, Tex., ranch next week to a Start treaty reducing each side's nuclear missiles to under 2,000, which is all the Russians can afford to maintain. Notes the Jamestown Foundation's Harry Kopp: "Start Plus meets ABM Minus." 
About the war in Afghanistan, Putin gave Walters this accurate assessment: "The United States is losing not in the military but in the information. It seems to me that on the information field, terrorists are acting more aggressively and more offensively. . . ."
The Russian leader ought to know; the ex-K.G.B. operative has long been a master of disinformation. He gained popularity among nationalists by blaming Chechen separatists for all terrorist acts in Russia. Now, in the onslaught of organized terrorism against the U.S., he volunteers to be what Russians call our partnyor in defeating it.
A politician who recently talked with him at length in Russian tells me "he's still K.G.B., but he no longer has to worry about the nationalists and militarists like Zhirinovsky and Lebed. The old Communists are dying off while the young reformers dwindle down, and he's grabbed control of the media so nobody can be heard criticizing him." 
With his popularity rating soaring to Bush-like heights, Putin has three geopolitical choices: (1) to align Russia with China against the West; (2) to romance Europe and try to draw it away from the U.S. superpower; or (3) to disappoint China and astound Europe by befriending the U.S. directly.
He started moving toward that America-first option by closing down his Cuban spy operation, abandoning the Cam Ranh Bay naval base in Vietnam and withdrawing objections to our dearly desired oil pipeline from the Caspian Sea through Turkey. Though he clings to his lucrative, dangerous nuclear buildup of Iran, he no longer glowers at our desire to admit the Baltic States into NATO. 
Then, after Sept. 11, Putin seized his opportunity to help the injured U.S. When he permitted our military presence on his southern flank in Uzbekistan and Tajikistan, his generals dared not object publicly. He could even offer us combat troops -- "in rescue operations, including on the territory of Afghanistan" -- secure in the knowledge that the last thing anti-Taliban Afghans would tolerate would be a Russian re-invasion. 
But the surest sign of Putin's strategy will be his willingness to bend the ABM treaty out of shape. Hu Jintao went to Moscow last week to argue that an American space shield would undercut China's nuclear threat to Taiwan; he was rebuffed. (Who's Hu? He's the Chinese leader likely to replace Jiang Zemin in two years, and Barbara should start going after him now.) 
European leaders, opposing our missile shield in what they hoped would be a worldwide gang-up against American hegemony, are agape. How could Putin bypass their toll bridge to integration with the West, they sputter, and make a private deal with the unilateralist Bush? 
Putin seeks an osobye otnosheniya -- "special relationship" -- with the U.S. for good reasons. China, bordering Russia's east, is a long-term strategic threat; the U.S. is not. Europe is not about to welcome an economic rival, but the U.S. has the money and savvy to exploit Russia's oil and gas resources, and holds the key to its entry into the World Trade Organization. 
We can hope that at the Crawford summit, Bush and Putin will cut the pious soul-searching and fulsome expressions of undying trust. America's national travail has enabled Putin to speed a rapprochement, but we should not forget that once up on its hind legs, the Russian bear will growl again.

HEADLINE: Focusing on the Losers 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
In a burst of candor and finger-pointing, a senior Republican official here departed from his colleagues' spin that they had frittered away the governorships in Virginia and New Jersey on Tuesday to Democrats who had more money and did not have to contend with divisive primaries.
 In fact, that official, Steve Schmidt, communications director for the National Republican Congressional Committee, said, the two losers, Mark L. Earley in Virginia and Bret D. Schundler in New Jersey, were at fault. 
 "We're glad the president did not campaign for these guys," Mr. Schmidt said in an interview. "No one wants to see him spend political capital on people who have run preposterously bad campaigns." 
It seems like a basic point: The best campaign wins. But that notion was often lost in the cross-fire today as Republicans and Democrats battled a public relations war over whether the elections of James E. McGreevey in New Jersey, Mark R. Warner in Virginia and Michael R. Bloomberg in New York City carried any national political consequences.
In the view of strategists in both parties, the outcome came down to the strengths -- and often the flaws -- of individual candidates. In Virginia, Mr. Earley found himself squabbling with other Republicans over the state budget and never found a way to counter Mr. Warner's conservative pitch. In New Jersey, Mr. Schundler struggled to become untethered from the conservatives who helped him win the nomination. And in New York, Mark Green, despite his decades in Democratic politics, could never manage to unite restive wings of the party behind him.
"The most important thing, even more than money, is the candidate," said Douglas Sosnik, a Clinton political director. "Mark Earley never gave people a reason to vote for him. It got so bad that he closed his campaign with an endorsement from the mayor of New York -- not traditionally the most effective way to get elected governor of Virginia. And Warner made himself an acceptable alternative, no small feat for a Democrat in Virginia."
The Democrats did not manage the sweep that their party chairman, Terence McAuliffe, had confidently predicted. Mr. McAuliffe was so eager to dwell on the positive that he declared, "Mark Green almost won!"
While almost is not good enough, the twin victories in New Jersey and Virginia gave Mr. McAuliffe the most encouraging political news since the Democrats took control of the Senate in June. The success in two states with quite different demographics may give the party a psychological lift and help with recruitment and fund-raising.
Now Mr. McAuliffe can lambast his Republican counterpart, Gov. James S. Gilmore III of Virginia, for not rescuing his own state.
"When the president is at 90 percent approval and they run an anti-tax message where the chairman of the party is the governor of the state and yet our Democratic candidate wins the governorship," Mr. McAuliffe said, "there's something fundamentally wrong with the Republican message."
But Mr. Bloomberg's upset victory in New York, where Democrats are registered five to one over Republicans, prevented the Democrats from making a potent case that there was any national tide for their party -- and took the edge off the expected but nonetheless stinging Republican defeats in New Jersey and Virginia.
And because President Bush did not campaign in any of the races, the Democrats cannot convincingly say that their victories were a referendum on his presidency, just as in New York Republicans cannot say the results had anything to do with the White House. In New Jersey, for example, exit polls found that foremost on the minds of voters were not the attacks on Sept. 11 but their state's ailing economy and high taxes.
Mr. Gilmore portrayed the Democratic victories for governor as "great personal triumphs" that had nothing to do with a national trend. He said the same even about New York, where Mr. Bloomberg benefited from the endorsement of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. "The New York win was spectacular," he said. "it says a lot about Rudy Giuliani -- as much as Mr. Bloomberg."
As was Mr. McAuliffe, Governor Gilmore was searching for the positive. Playing down the defeat of Mr. Earley in his state, Mr. Gilmore said, "We came very close in our lieutenant governor's race."
There were some similarities in the three big winning campaigns. From the start, all three vastly outspent their rivals. Perhaps guilty of hyperbole, Mark Mellman, Mr. Green's pollster, said of Mr. Bloomberg, "It was the largest concentrated spending on a political campaign in human history."
Mr. Bloomberg and the pair of Democratic victors were also successful in expanding their appeal beyond their parties' traditional voters. As Mr. Gilmore put it, "Mark Warner ran very much as a Republican" and "McGreevey was running as a no-tax fiscal conservative." And Mr. McAuliffe said Mr. Bloomberg "ran on a Democratic message."
The winners also benefited from candidates who were not widely liked in their own parties.
It was never a secret in their parties that the losing candidates were viewed as flawed. In an internal memorandum to Governor Gilmore after the results were in, Todd Reid, a party official, was unsparing in his criticism of Mr. Earley's campaign.
In one passage, he complained that Earley commercials were concentrated "on shows like 'Buffy the Vampire Slayer,' 'Xena: Warrior Princess' and 'Showtime at the Apollo' " and that "we were never able to make up for all those wasted ads run when no one was watching."
Some Republicans argued that the party was trying to make scapegoats of its candidates when it should consider its own role.
"If I were Gilmore, I'd be very, very embarrassed," Mickey Edwards, a former Republican congressman, said. "When you're the national chairman of the party and your state goes to the other party, to some extent it's got to be a referendum on you."
That may be the case. But many Republicans would clearly rather Mr. Gilmore take the blame than the person who made him chairman, President Bush.

HEADLINE: THE 2001 ELECTIONS: THE DEMOCRATS; 
It's Morning for the Democrats In the Suburbs of the Northeast

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
In New Jersey, Democrats claimed control of state government for the first time in nearly a decade. In Nassau County, Democrats wrested control of the county government for the first time since World War I. Even in Greenwich, Conn., a bastion of Republican politics, Democrats managed, in a stunning upset, to take control of local government for what the new top elected official believed was the first time ever.
 With the notable exception of New York City, where Democrat-turned-Republican Michael R. Bloomberg upset Mark Green, Tuesday was a very good day for Democrats throughout the New York region. 
 Helped by redistricting, buoyed by some poor performances by Republican incumbents and lifted by an influx of voters more amenable to core Democratic beliefs, Democrats showed that for the first time in many years, they were a suburban force to be reckoned with, even in Republican strongholds. 
At the same time, the victories reflected two newer political realities. One is that the Democratic Party, with its current taste for Clintonian centrism, has been solidifying its strength throughout the Northeast. The other is that the aging Republican machines in places like Nassau and Suffolk Counties have weakened so much that they can no longer be counted on to deliver victory after victory, automatically.
"I don't think there was an anti-Republican tide," said United States Representative Peter T. King, a Long Island Republican. "But I think the Democrats are getting an edge, and Democrats for the most part have been in the ascendancy in the Northeast."
At no time was the region's increasingly Democratic hue more evident than in the 2000 presidential election. States supporting Al Gore were shaded blue in the television coverage, while states supporting George W. Bush were in red. With the exception of New Hampshire, the Northeast was all blue.
The increasing appeal of the Democratic Party was also manifested last year by how well Hillary Rodham Clinton ran in traditionally Republican upstate New York in her Senate campaign. Next year, Gov. George E. Pataki is likely to face a formidable Democratic challenger.
In New Jersey, an increasingly fractured Republican Party has not yet decided who should challenge the state's embattled senior senator, Robert G. Torricelli. It might be former Gov. Thomas H. Kean. Or, if the powerful conservative wing of the party -- the same people who propelled Bret D. Schundler to an emphatic primary victory -- has its way, it might not.
Still, Democrats have been careful in assessing their long-term plans, especially with a slumping economy and government belt-tightening all but guaranteed.
"One thing I've learned from political activism is that you're only as good as your next election victory," said Robert P. Zimmerman, a Nassau County member of the Democratic National Committee. "But this is one great send-off to plan for your next victory."
In Nassau, where the county's financially troubled government was the dominant issue, Thomas R. Suozzi, the Democratic mayor of Glen Cove, trounced Bruce R. Bent, a Republican, for county executive. It was the first time a Democrat has led the county since 1970.
In the County Legislature, the Democrats retained the slim majority they won in 2000, their first majority since 1917. And in an upset, the Republican comptroller, Frederick E. Parola, lost a close race to his Democratic challenger, Howard S. Weitzman.
Even in solidly Republican Suffolk, there were dents in the party's armor. James M. Catterson Jr., the three-term district attorney, was soundly defeated by his Democratic rival, Thomas J. Spota III, a former prosecutor.
Republicans may have wanted to see the results as purely local events with little relation to national trends. To Democrats, though, the results in the downstate suburbs of New York mean that Governor Pataki will probably have to work harder to win the same voters in the 2002 gubernatorial election.
"I gather the governor used to rely on good old Nassau County," said Howard A. Scarrow, a political science professor at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. "Well, guess what? It's probably not much different than Westchester or New Jersey or the suburban counties."
In New Jersey, Democratic strategists were still giddy yesterday about the election of James E. McGreevey as governor, the party's new 44-to-36 majority in the State Assembly and the 20-20 tie in the State Senate. It was only eight years ago that the Democrats were crushed, at every level, by the Republicans, who tapped into voter discontent over the $2.8 billion tax increase under Gov. Jim Florio. 
Some Republicans said the losses reflected voter antipathy toward Mr. Schundler. Party leaders chose to take encouragement from smaller wins, citing victories in freeholders' races in Bergen, Cumberland and Passaic Counties.
"We're very disappointed," said State Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos, the state Republican Party chairman. "But I think there are some quieter successes around the state that hearten me, and that indicate that we have a strong farm team."
Democrats, though, said the results reflected years of grass-roots organizing, particularly in the suburbs. Some of those efforts, they added, were manifested in some historic breakthroughs in several local elections.
One traditional Republican area, Summit, elected two Democrats to its seven-member City Council. It was the first time that even one Democrat had won there since 1922, and it reflected the changing demographics of a city that has become more diverse with the arrival of baby-boom families from New York City who tend to be socially liberal, fiscally moderate and locally independent.
In Greenwich, Richard Bergstresser, a Democrat, defeated the incumbent Republican, Lolly H. Prince, to capture the top elected post, first selectman. It was the first time a Democrat had won that position in 18 years. Democrats also won the majority on the board of selectmen for the first time in four years, he said.
But Mr. Bergstresser said he could not recall when, if ever, Democrats had control of both the first selectman's job and the board. 
"Any time a Democrat can win in Greenwich, it's an upset," he said. "We've managed to awaken what we hope is a sleeping giant."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED -- AN OVERVIEW: NOV. 7, 2001; 
Pursuit of Terror Funds, Anthrax Victim on Tape, Partisan Sniping

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
 "Follow the money" is a tried and true maxim for investigators, and it works for President Bush, too. Repeatedly, he has made clear that one way to strike at Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden's terrorist network, is to cut off its cash flow. Now that effort has taken a new course.

UNUSUAL ALLIES IN CRACKDOWN -- With help from other countries, the United States went after two financial networks accused of not only supplying Al Qaeda with money but also helping it to move weapons and relay instructions to its terrorist cells. Their names are Al Barakaat and Al Taqwa, and yesterday a string of their offices were raided by law enforcement agents around the United States and in Europe. As important, perhaps even more so, the crackdown was joined by countries that normally have little appetite for this policing.
 For instance, the United Arab Emirates seized assets and records of Al Barakaat, which is based in Dubai. Liechtenstein, a center for international money-laundering, took measures against Al Taqwa. Also cooperating, senior officials said, was Saudi Arabia, the much-criticized homeland of 15 of the 19 airplane hijackers in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
Protests of innocence by the two financial networks failed to impress Washington. Al Barakaat was said to have slipped tens of millions of dollars a year to Mr. bin Laden's operation by skimming money off the top of routine transactions. Al Taqwa was described as sort of an E.F. Hutton for terrorists, offering investment advice.
Did the raids choke off Al Qaeda's entire money stream? Not likely, officials in Washington said. Still, Mr. Bush said, this latest action "blocks an important source of funds."

ELUSIVE LEAD ON ANTHRAX -- The president is intent on showing that the campaign against terrorism and Mr. bin Laden's Taliban protectors in Afghanistan is moving apace on several fronts. That has not always been an easy task, especially when his administration is forced to concede that it has no idea of the source of the anthrax that has killed or sickened 18 Americans. Still, there were encouraging words from Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security. With no new cases of the disease reported this week, Mr. Ridge said that he hoped "the anthrax has stopped permanently."
For a while it seemed possible that a new anthrax-bearing letter had come to light. A tape surfaced of a phone call to 911 made on Oct. 21 by one of the two Washington postal workers who died from inhalation anthrax, the worst kind. In that call, the worker, Thomas L. Morris Jr., talked about being near a colleague who handled a letter with powder in it. As it turned out, that powder tested negative, so there was nothing to point investigators in a eureka-prompting direction.
Even so, Mr. Morris's call for help, the night before he died, gave a glimpse of a man in distress. To a question from the 911 operator, he said he had no idea what happened to the suspect letter, or if its contents were indeed anthrax. "I was told it wasn't," he said, "but I have a tendency not to believe these people."

PARTIES SPAR ON ECONOMY -- In Washington, the bipartisan glow was fading. Democrats and Republicans have sparred over how to improve airport security and how to give CPR to a troubled economy. (More tax cuts for business, Republicans say. More money for unemployment and health benefits, Democrats reply.)
Now the two parties are hung up on how much to spend on anti-terrorism measures like hiring federal agents and improving the public health system. Soon after Sept. 11, both houses of Congress approved $40 billion in emergency spending. The Democrats now say that sum is not enough by a long shot, but the White House and its Republican allies on Capitol Hill are standing their ground. If the president makes good on a threat to veto any more money to counter terrorism, Democratic leaders say they are prepared to defy him.

PROGRESS BY NORTHERN ALLIANCE -- On the war front, the anti-Taliban Northern Alliance said it had captured another town, putting it closer to an assault on Mazar-i-Sharif, a city crucial to controlling northern Afghanistan. Should that city fall to the alliance, American forces would have an easier time moving into Afghanistan from bases in neighboring Uzbekistan.
One problem was that the rebels' claims of success could not be independently verified. Nonetheless, an alliance commander promised that Mazar-i-Sharif would be seized before the week is out. "God willing," he said. CLYDE HABERMAN

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
An Outsider Comes Inside To Run Things

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
ONCE again we have elected a mayor who proudly claims not to be a politician. This is a wonderful formula for lively news conferences, as we learned during Rudolph W. Giuliani's performances, and the city's political journalists are understandably ecstatic. 
 It's hard to know exactly what else Mr. Bloomberg's election means, because he has been vague about his plans. He didn't dwell on bureaucracies and budgets during the campaign, and after Sept. 11 that approach seemed to suit voters. 
 "Until Sept. 11, the compelling question in the campaign was how to carve up the city's $40 billion budget," said Mitchell Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University and an adviser to Mr. Bloomberg. "After Sept. 11 the question became: how do we keep the city's $400 billion private economy intact? Workers of all classes were worried, especially the ones dependent on entry-level jobs in hotels and restaurants."
The public-private dichotomy was evident in a survey of voters Tuesday that was commissioned by the City Journal, the quarterly of the Manhattan Institute, the conservative research group. People who reported working for private, for-profit companies preferred Mr. Bloomberg by a 15-point margin. Mr. Green won by 17-point margins among government employees and among workers for nonprofit groups, which often depend on public money. 
The closeness of the final result reflected the disproportionate turnout of the government and nonprofit workers. Although they're outnumbered in the city's workforce about three-to-one by employees of for-profit companies, on Tuesday they constituted nearly as large a share of the electorate (37 percent versus 41 percent) as the for-profit workers.
"Public employees turned out to choose their boss, and they wanted it to be Mark Green," said Myron Magnet, the editor of City Journal. "People outside the public sector preferred someone who had started his own company."
During the campaign, Mr. Bloomberg was faulted by some members of the business community for political naivete. Conservatives distrusted his background as a liberal Democrat. But two-thirds of conservatives ended up voting for him, according to the poll of voters. 
"Conservatives were reassured late in the campaign by Bloomberg's unequivocal promise not to raise taxes," Dr. Magnet said. "I was heartened that the first words out of his mouth after being elected were, 'New York is open for business.' Yes, he's a liberal on cultural matters, but he believes in fiscal prudence and business-friendliness, and that's what we need most now along with public safety. Half a Republican is better than none."
Dr. Moss, after knowing Mr. Bloomberg for nearly a decade and advising him in the campaign, predicts that he will surprise his critics. "We've had politicians and we've had prosecutors as mayors, but we haven't had a manager who cares about performance," Dr. Moss said. "Mike is not an ideologue. He's a doer. Democratic politicians here succeed by taking fewer and fewer risks as they climb the ladder -- any new idea threatens special interests. Bloomberg's basic career path has been to find a new way to do something. He is a risktaker who is going to change the culture of city government."
Mr. Bloomberg hasn't explained how he'll change the culture of workers who can't be fired, but he has at least shown that he looks at some problems differently. Before Sept. 11, he refused to join the Democrats promising more and more subsidized housing. He preferred to rely instead on private builders.
AFTER Sept. 11, he did not call for a grand new bureaucracy to rebuild downtown Manhattan. While Mr. Green was vowing to bring back the financial services industry, Mr. Bloomberg said that revival would depend mainly on private efforts and on new industries. He pooh-poohed the plans by Democrats to woo back the old businesses by offering tax credits. 
"Any company that makes a decision as to where they are going to be based on the tax rate is a company that won't be around very long," he said in an interview last week. "If you're down to that incremental margin you don't have a business." Mr. Bloomberg didn't pretend to know which industries would ultimately find it profitable to be downtown, so he didn't offer a master plan. Whatever you think of his restraint, it was radical by New York standards. Only a nonpolitician around here could imagine the city surviving without his guidance.

HEADLINE: THE 2001 ELECTIONS: THE TRANSITION; 
Giuliani Officials Aren't Promised Automatic Jobs

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg indicated yesterday that he would form his own team for a new administration, and not necessarily by retaining Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's top aides. 
 Mr. Bloomberg had long campaigned on the theme of carrying on the policies of the Giuliani administration, and many voters chose over him over Mark Green for that very reason. But in answer to repeated questions yesterday about which people Mr. Bloomberg would keep from Mr. Giuliani's team, the mayor-elect said that although he expected short-term help from the current administration, he would be reviewing his options. 
 This apparently also applies to the outgoing mayor, whom Mr. Bloomberg said he would consult when making appointments to the new commission to redevelop downtown. But he would not promise to name Mr. Giuliani to the panel. 
"The only one I've said publicly that I'd like to keep is the police commissioner, Bernie Kerik," Mr. Bloomberg said, adding that he had received a promise yesterday from Mr. Kerik that he would consider the job. 
"In terms of any other commissioner, I have not made any other firm decisions," Mr. Bloomberg said.
"I have thought a lot about it," he added, when asked if he had considered anyone else from Mr. Giuliani's roster. "Before you pick, you want to see who else is available." 
Other Giuliani appointees who might be asked to stay at least temporarily are Deputy Mayor Joseph J. Lhota and Transportation Commissioner Iris Weinshall, Bloomberg aides said. 
Whomever Mr. Bloomberg chooses to join him in what may well be one of the most arduous mayoralties in decades, it seems clear his administration will have a potpourri of political leanings and backgrounds. Mr. Bloomberg, whose nascent political career has left him owing little to traditional political allies, is expected to appoint people from the private sector as well as government and politics. Page D1. 
And just as his campaign drew advice from Ester Fuchs, a left-leaning professor of political science at Barnard, as well as from aides with the State Republican Party, Mr. Bloomberg's administration is expected to be diverse and occasionally incongruent, drawing advice from people ranging from the sitting mayor to Fernando Ferrer. 
"He is very smart, he is an independent thinker who owes nothing to anyone," said former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who crossed party lines to support a candidate who did the same to run. "Politics don't mean anything to him. I think he will look at all of Giuliani's people individually and take advice from Rudy, but he is his own man."
Mr. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would name his transition team in a few days, and that his administration would be put together behind closed doors. But yesterday, several people who worked closely with his campaign proffered a most-likely-to-succeed list. 
At the top is Patricia E. Harris, who oversees philanthropic operations at Bloomberg L.P. and was the first person he thanked on election night. Ms. Harris, who did not return calls yesterday, is expected to be offered a deputy mayoralty or a top commissionership. 
Kathleen Cudahy, a former top aide to the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, who quit to join Mr. Bloomberg's campaign as a senior policy aide, is also expected to join the new administration.
"She will play a major role because of her expertise with the City Council and also in economic development and a whole host of other issues," said Jonathan Capehart, another policy adviser to Mr. Bloomberg, who is weighing his own options. He is a former newspaper reporter, and says he cannot decide whether to return to that profession or stay on with Mr. Bloomberg, which he said would be a joy.
Others who are expected to play a role, Bloomberg people say, are Kevin Sheekey, who worked for Mr. Bloomberg as a lobbyist and political adviser at his company in Washington, and is being considered as a chief of staff or for a similar high-level role, if he can be convinced to leave Washington; William Cunningham, one of Mr. Bloomberg's senior strategists, whom many expect to play a senior role in the transition and the administration; and Vincent A. LaPadula, who worked in the Giuliani administration before joining the Bloomberg campaign.
"It is his decision to approach who he wants," said Mr. Cunningham, who, like others yesterday, insisted that they had not discussed future roles with the mayor-elect. "He knows where I am."
Mr. Bloomberg has also expressed an interest in finding a role for a former police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly. His campaign press secretary, Edward Skyler, is expected to lead the press operations, officials said.
Mr. Bloomberg, a lifelong Democrat who joined the Republican Party for the sole purpose of running for mayor, is said to have low tolerance for ideology, preferring pragmatic solution-oriented advice from people of all political persuasions that he turned to when running his media business. While Gov. George E. Pataki appeared yesterday at the joint news conference and stood beside him on election night, the governor and the mayor will probably vie for his attention. 
Further, many of Mr. Giuliani's commissioners, deputy mayors and other high-level staff people are exhausted. There has been nearly two months of seven-day weeks, endless funerals and nonstop meetings, all centering on a tragic event that left myriad municipal problems in its wake.
Even commissioners who are clearly not political, like Dr. Neal L. Cohen, the health commissioner, who has helped guide Mr. Giuliani through the anthrax crisis, could not say yesterday whether he really wanted to stay or not. One recent experience of Mr. Cohen's may explain the reluctance of many Giuliani officials: Just as he sat down to take a much-needed break over homemade ravioli that a neighbor had dropped off, his cellphone went off, and when he went to answer it, his dog chowed down his dinner. 
Mr. Bloomberg alluded to the idea that while he ran on ties to Mr. Giuliani's record and administration, he might not attempt to create a carbon copy of it, as was widely expected.
"I think that the problems change," he said yesterday. "The city changes, its population changes, its assets and resources change. We're going to go through a period where job retention is a very big problem. Rudy was blessed with basically a good economy after the first couple of years." 
Mr. Bloomberg also speculated yesterday that he would need Mr. Giuliani's help in the coming months, but would not commit himself to the offer of a specific role.
In terms of recommending to Governor Pataki that Mr. Giuliani head a new commission to rebuild downtown, Mr. Bloomberg said: "I certainly will talk to him about it. I can tell you this, I wouldn't be comfortable in us selecting anybody without his advice as to who should do it."

HEADLINE: The Vote, and the Post-Mortems 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "An Election in a Shadow: Attempting to Follow an Outsized Giuliani" (news analysis, front page, Nov. 7), you wonder whether Michael R. Bloomberg will "figure out a way to lead, to manage, to be judged on his own terms." 
 Mr. 
Bloomberg has vowed to build on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's successes, and to this end he might be compelled to continue most of the current administration's policies. 
 Yet for the last eight years the needs of low-income people have been largely ignored by Mr. Giuliani and his administration. This segment of the population has always been the most vulnerable to economic downturns, and this is even truer now. 
Mike Bloomberg has a golden opportunity to outshine Mr. Giuliani not only by building on his strengths but also by addressing his weaknesses.

ARTURO HALE
New York, Nov. 7, 2001

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 The Financial Front

WAR ON MONEY NETWORKS -- President Bush announced an international effort to destroy two financial networks that American officials said had long been suspected of funneling money to members of the Al Qaeda terrorist organization. The announcement came as law enforcement officials in the United States and Europe staged raids to disrupt their operations. A1

FIRM UNDER SCRUTINY -- A partner in one of the financial networks singled out by investigators said he was a victim of guilt by association. B8

Dangers in the Gulf

TRAINING TERRORISTS -- Two defectors from Iraqi intelligence said they had worked for several years at a secret Iraqi government camp that had trained terrorists since 1995. A1

ATTACK AT AIR BASE -- A gunman was shot and killed after he opened fire at American and Qatari troops guarding an air base in the Persian Gulf nation Qatar that was being used by American military aircraft. B2

Where the War Stands

SHIFT IN STRATEGY -- With its caves, tunnels and urban hiding places, Afghanistan has proved to be an especially difficult battlefield. Already, the United States military has been compelled to adapt its one-month-old military campaign. A1

REBELS ON THE ATTACK -- Forces opposed to the Taliban captured a town near Mazar-i-Sharif, a city regarded as a linchpin in the battle to control northern Afghanistan. B1

GROUND OPERATIONS -- Pentagon officials make no secret now that success in Afghanistan will depend on ground operations, a kind of combat that was fading from importance before Sept. 11. B6

IN CAVES AND TUNNELS -- An Afghan general said American bombs had been effective but only ground troops could destroy the Taliban's network of caves and tunnels. B6

SAILOR APPEARS LOST -- A sailor went overboard from the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk. If confirmed, his death would be the fourth American fatality in the Afghanistan war. B6

GERMANY TIGHTENING SECURITY -- Germany cabinet backed changes in security and immigration laws in response to the Sept. 11 attacks. A12

The Messages

TWO LEADERS UNITED -- President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain are becoming allies joined by war, national self-interest and what their aides say is a growing personal chemistry. B3

SPEAKING FOR BIN LADEN -- Osama bin Laden appeared to find a new avenue of propaganda: four boys said to be his sons, who were filmed brandishing weapons and speaking of the Afghans' support for the Taliban. B3

NEWS CONFERENCES CURBED -- Under pressure from the United States, Pakistan has asked the Taliban ambassador in its capital to stop using news conferences to attack the United States for bombing Afghanistan. B3

SEEKING A PAUSE IN BOMBING -- The president of Pakistan made another plea for a stop to the American-led military strikes in Afghanistan during the holy month of Ramadan. B3

Congress and Business

ECONOMIC SHOWDOWN -- Democrats in Congress headed toward a major confrontation with President Bush over tax and spending policy, vowing to defy his threat to veto legislation that provides more money to counter terrorism in the United States. B1

RADIO IN AFGHANISTAN -- The House voted to create Radio Free Afghanistan to beam American news and entertainment programs to Afghans in their local languages in an effort to combat Taliban propaganda. B7

HELP FOR INSURERS -- Congress edged closer to aiding the insurance industry when a House committee voted to promise insurers billions of dollars in loans in the event of any large terror attacks next year. B7

HIJACKING SUSPECT -- Prosecutors are weighing whether to seek an indictment against a man in New York who the authorities suspect was to have been the 20th hijacker in the Sept. 11 terror attacks. B7

The Biological Threat

A VICTIM'S CALL -- Hours before he died, a Washington postal worker called 911 and told the emergency operator that he suspected he had anthrax because he remembered that colleagues working near him had handled a letter with powder in it. A1

BRIEFING ON ANTHRAX -- Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, tried to reassure the public while acknowledging that the investigation into anthrax attacks had yet to provide satisfactory answers. B9

PROGRESS IN TESTING -- Drug companies say they have developed new tools that will greatly speed detection and diagnosis of anthrax. B9

VACCINE PRICING -- Three small manufacturers who lost out in the first round of bidding for a contract to make smallpox vaccine said they could produce the vaccine more cheaply than large drug makers. B9

ANTHRAX INQUIRY -- Investigators pursuing clues to the anthrax death of Kathy T. Nguyen in New York have begun using posters with her picture and tips from her friends and acquaintances. They said there was no sign that she had been exposed to the germ on the subway. B10

THEORIES ON INFECTION -- Some disquieting possibilities are being considered in the investigation of Ms. Nguyen's anthrax death: that she somehow crossed the path of the person responsible for the attack, or that she was nowhere near the perpetrator and still became infected. B10

Aftermath in New York

A CALL FOR SAFETY -- Now that the initial urgent searches are over, city officials and cleanup contractors are pushing for greater regularity and safety at the two-million-ton pile of debris known as ground zero. B1

RECOVERY EFFORT -- Mayor Giuliani doubled the number of firefighters -- to 50 -- assigned to dig for their colleagues' remains in the trade center rubble, in an apparent effort to calm a rancorous dispute. D1

NEW BOSS AT GROUND ZERO -- Contractors who have been clearing the trade center site for weeks are worried by reports that Bechtel, a San Francisco company, has been chosen to oversee the work. D10

TRADE CENTER SUIT -- The real estate developer who holds the lease on the World Trade Center filed a lawsuit demanding that an insurer promptly pay its share of the coverage, even as litigation continues to determine how much the insurers are liable for. B11

AID TO BE DISTRIBUTED -- Mayor Giuliani said the city's Twin Towers Fund would immediately begin to distribute $40 million to the families of the uniformed personnel who died responding to the terror attacks. B11

TALE OF A HOAX -- Prosecutors say that a man who wanted to return home to India made false anthrax reports in an effort to be deported. B11

The Arts

HELP FROM HOLLYWOOD -- Several dozen top executives in the film and television industry plan to meet with a senior White House adviser to discuss what Hollywood can do to aid the war effort. B8

PUBLISHERS CAUTIOUS -- The fear of anthrax has emerged as one more excuse for all but a handful of publishing houses not to read unsolicited manuscripts. E1

Circuits

THE MILITARY MARKET -- The makers of hand-held devices like Palm Pilots are trying to prove their usefulness to the military. First Circuits Page

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "ALONG THE NILE: EARLY PHOTOGRAPHS OF EGYPT" AND "THE PHARAOH'S PHOTOGRAPHER: HARRY BURTON, TUTANKHAMEN AND THE METROPOLITAN'S EGYPTIAN EXPEDITION," Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Dec. 30). "Along the Nile" is a gem of an exhibition of early, mostly amateur photographs of Egypt, including Maxime Du Camp's famous view of the colossal, half-buried face of Ramses II with an assistant posing on top of the sculpture, the ancestor of all those shots of Mom and Uncle Burt squinting into the camera and smiling next to the Sphinx. The show includes obscure figures like Ernest Benecke, a French wool trader of German descent, whose images are more remarkable for seeming accidental and serendipitous, and Theodule Deveria, whose photograph of the tomb of Ptahmose, the chief steward to Ramses II, is the only evidence of a site since reburied and lost beneath shifting sands. Pioneering works, these photographs have a virgin authenticity conveying the amateur photographer's amazement at seeing places through a device whose uncanny ability to capture those sights doubled the amazement. Half a century later Harry Burton photographed the excavation of Tutankhamen's tomb mixing Hollywood-style shots of Howard Carter uncovering Tut's mummy for the illustrated newspapers with documentary pictures made solely for the archives, which have an unintended modern beauty. The Burton show cleverly gives a fresh twist to the Tut craze, but the older photographs stick longer in the mind because they seem haunted from across a gulf of a century and a half. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* "BAMANA: THE ART OF EXISTENCE IN MALI," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through March 3). African art is about envisioning a moral universe and shaping the world through spiritual energy to conform to that vision. The positive effects are evident in objects and images that unite communities, ease pain, forecast the future and explain the past. Nearly 100 of them are included in this wonderful show by one of the best museums in town. Among the highlights are exquisite iron ritual staffs, personable hand puppets, grave carved-wood maternity figures and a whole herd of the infinitely stylish antelope-shaped crest masks known as Ci-wara. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50, students and 65+; free on Sundays (Holland Cotter).

* "BRAZIL: BODY AND SOUL," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 27). The rotunda is black and half filled by an immense altar. The French architect Jean Nouvel's installation is aptly over the top, considering that the show is about a culture gloriously, self-consciously excessive. A sampler of Brazilian culture, the show divides attention between the Baroque and the modern. Physicality, spectacle, eroticism and pleasure: the cliches of Brazilian culture are all leitmotifs, in stunning objects mixing indigenous, African and European roots. These include the works of genius eccentrics like Aleijadinho, Brazil's Bernini, and Arthur Bispo do Rosario, a seaman, boxer, doorman, bodyguard, jailbird and mental patient who died in 1989 at the age of 78. He sewed banners out of bed sheets and embroidered them with long incantatory lists of places and people, including a presentation mantle he made for himself to wear before God on Judgment Day. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8, students and 65+ (Kimmelman)

* "TOM FRIEDMAN," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Feb. 3). A suitably diverse survey of one of the less predictable artists of the 1990's, who has made his name by transforming common objects and materials into one-of-a-kind feats of sculpture, drawing or photography. Toothpicks, toothpaste, sugar, a pencil, a dictionary and soap are among the materials subjected to Mr. Friedman's carefully plotted, meticulously executed methods. The results can be engagingly manic or meditative -- and sometimes nearly invisible, in which case the work becomes a minimally accessorized punchline. But when Mr. Friedman changes an artwork in a way that keeps the before, the after and the intervening transformation equally clear, he stops time for a few luxurious instants. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, artists, students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

* "ALBERTO GIACOMETTI," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9480 (through Jan. 8). Giacometti as the Sartre of sculpture might lead you to imagine him the right subject for troubled times. But that would be the wrong reason to see this exhibition. The right reason is that like all perceptive and eloquent art, it tells you why it is good to be alive. It investigates the pleasure of thinking and looking long and hard, which is never as simple as it sounds. The work is more varied than you may think -- sometimes black-humored, playful, sensual, even devoutly tender -- and includes plasters, painted bronzes and even a clunky stone garden sculpture, a splendid oddity, that demonstrate the material virtuosity and subtle coloration of an artist too often presumed to be pretty much just dark and heavy. Spread chronologically across two floors, compressed then open, like the art they contain, the show has as its unnecessary excuse the centenary of Giacometti's birth. We don't learn much that isn't already known, but it is a thorough, serious, very elegant exhibition, and there is nothing the matter with being reacquainted from time to time with what great art looks like. Hours: Thursdays through Tuesdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, to 8:15 p.m. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* "NORMAN ROCKWELL: PICTURES FOR THE AMERICAN PEOPLE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through March 3). Coming after Sept. 11, the show gives everybody in town a chance to contemplate the Rembrandt of Punkin Crick, as a critic acidly dubbed him years ago, through altered eyes. In our flag-shrouded anxiety, Rockwell's cornball sentiments can seem less remote and contrived than they did. The debate about whether Rockwell was a good artist or not is as shopworn as his art. The sugar level can induce diabetic coma, and the late "serious" pictures replace the sugar with cod liver oil. That said, Rockwell's imagination and craftsmanship are obvious. What Rockwell painted was not what America, in its complexity, ever quite looked like. But at his best he captured what many Americans really felt and desired -- and many now feel and desire -- which is truth on a level deeper than surface appearance. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

"SIGNAC 1863-1935: MASTER NEO-IMPRESSIONIST" AND "NEO-IMPRESSIONISM: THE CIRCLE OF PAUL SIGNAC," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Dec. 30). These shows give an excellent view of the career of Signac, the first and most fervent convert to George Seurat's color theories and Pointillist technique, and their chief proselytizer after Seurat's death in 1891. Redolent of Signac's intelligence, discipline, faith in progress and unflagging energy, the first show moves in clear-cut chapters, beginning with his awkward attempts at Impressionism and a gallery of beautiful transitional works that are among the show's best. Next come his Seuratesque seascapes and more distinctive figurative works; the radiant St.-Tropez paintings in which he made Neo-Impressionism his own; and his exuberantly eccentric late paintings and not-eccentric-enough watercolors. The importance of Signac's color to the development of Modernism -- starting with Matisse and the Fauves -- is unmistakable, but so is his tendency to be mechanical and a little soulless. The smaller exhibition of work by the artists he knew, from Seurat to Matisse, clarifies both his deficiencies and his achievement. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

* "VITAL FORMS: AMERICAN ART AND DESIGN IN THE ATOMIC AGE, 1940-1960," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 6). The use of organic forms in the visual arts exploded after World War II, drawn from the human figure and its components along with plant, teardrop, amoeboid, cellular and molecular shapes. This ambitious display of more than 250 fine art and design objects tracks the use of these "vital" forms in mediums from highbrow painting to popular consumer products. The organizers argue that the artists were expressing humanism and humane values at a time of worldwide cataclysm, but not enough is made of the role that Surrealism and its dream imagery played. Still, the exhibition does a good job in demonstrating that by the mid-1950's the hard-edged machine esthetic of the prewar years had given way to a visual language centered more on natural forms, helped along by more flexible materials. There's some enlightening and enjoyable looking here, but in the show's broad coverage some of the work -- particularly the paintings -- gets a little lost. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (to 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3 for students and 62+ (Grace Glueck).

Galleries: Uptown

"EXQUISITE MOMENTS: WEST LAKE AND SOUTHERN SONG ART," China Institute, 125 East 65th Street, (212) 744-8181 (through Dec. 9). New York's big fall show of Chinese painting is installed in a very small space: two galleries at the China Institute that together could fit in a coat-check room at the Met. But square footage doesn't matter. Scale and quality do. Most of the 40 or so paintings in the show, on loan from premier American museums, are also small. Created in the form of album pages and fans, they are a one-on-one sort of art, meant to be brought out every now and then and savored, like love letters, in private. And as with love letters, the emotions conveyed are sweet, intense and sometimes deep (Holland Cotter).

* "NUMISMATICS IN THE AGE OF GROLIER," Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, (212) 838-6690 (through Nov. 17). A handsome show about an obscure subject: Renaissance illustrated books about ancient coins, with many of the coins and Renaissance medals they helped inspire. The illustrations, like the coins, are elegant and refined; the history offered in lengthy wall texts is a trove of obscure information. The larger fascination, for those not drawn to its elaborate scholarship, is the dialogue between media: how sculpture, in the form of these coins, influenced book illustration, which influenced sculpture, and so on. A curio: 16th-century prints of all the Roman emperors lined up in profile, with spaces left at the end, just in case, for future monarchs (Kimmelman).

Galleries: 57th Street

SOPHIA VARI, Nohra Haime, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 888-3550 (through Nov. 17). This Paris-based sculptor makes pedestal-scale bronzes in classic Cubist style but with a playful, contemporary feel. Selected planes of Ms. Vari's compacted, jumbled towers of spheres, ovoids, box shapes, pie sections and other sorts of volumes are painted in bright primary colors, which stand out against the near black sheen of the patinated bronze. The sculptures have a cheerfully decorative, slightly cartoonish appeal (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

JAYNE HINDS BIDAUT, "Natural Selection," Ricco/Maresca, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 627-4819 (through Jan. 5). You could mistake the shadowy, ghostly pictures of birds, museum dioramas and female nudes for experiments from the early years of photography. In fact, they were made by a contemporary artist using an old-fashioned process known as the dry plate tintype. Her most ambitious work is a mural of 50 large plates in a grid, on which she has orchestrated a vast collage of photogramatic images of plants, animals and human figures to represent the expulsion of Adam and Eve (Johnson).

TANIA BRUGUERA, "La Isla en Peso," LiebmanMagnan, 552 West 24th Street, (212) 255-3225 (through Nov. 17). This is the first United States solo show for Ms. Bruguera, a young Cuban performance artist who made a much-noticed contribution to last year's Havana Biennale. In her video installation in a black-out gallery, a taped cacaphony of animal noises fills the air. Eight screens carry the artist's contorted face moving in slow-motion: she seems to be floating under water. Her image is replaced periodically by lines from a poem, "Island Burden," which refers to water, animals, memories and entrapment in a hallcinatory account of a single day in Cuba, where "night closes over poetry, and forms blur" (Cotter).

MARY ELLEN CARROLL, "Mistakes and Lies, Part 2," Frederieke Taylor, 535 West 22nd Street, (646) 230-0992 (through Dec. 1). Works by this witty conceptualist include eye-buzzing paintings based on camouflage patterns found inside bank security envelopes; a quote from Gertrude Stein, slightly altered, in green neon lights; a video of auditioning, visibly sweating actors reading descriptions of the artist; and a panel with enlarged copies of corrections published in The New York Times, one of which concludes, "In fact, as Mr. Scott informed The Times yesterday, the wedding never took place" (Johnson).

LOIS DODD, "Mind the Gap," Fischbach, 210 11th Avenue, near 25th Street, (212) 759-2345 (through Nov. 17). Ms. Dodd has been making regular excursions to the Delaware Water Gap area in Warren County, N.J., since 1975; this 25-year selection of canvases reveals an accomplished painter deftly balancing particulars of place and Cezannesque abstraction (Johnson).

FLECHEMULLER, "Call My Mom," Gracie Mansion, 504 West 22nd Street, (212) 645-7656 (through Nov. 24). This painter and photographic prankster presents enigmatic, slightly weird paintings of children copied from old clothing catalogs and funny photographs -- some digitally altered, some not -- that include one of a dog jumping improbably high in a bathroom and another of a long black limousine with the words "God Is Invincible" written in big white letters across its side (Johnson).

SIDNEY GOODMAN, ACA, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 206-8080 (through Nov. 24). This veteran Philadelphia realist-turned-allegorist doesn't shy away from big visionary themes. On large canvases, in a portentously illustrative style, he depicts giant cartoon animal balloons menacing a terrified crowd; nude people levitating as though caught up in the Last Judgment; and a nude pregnant woman recumbent on a huge pile of toys as a naked, wild-haired toddler looks on like a fierce little god (Johnson).

FRANK HOLLIDAY, "Trippin' in American," Debs & Co., 525 West 26th Street, (212) 643-2070 (through Nov. 17). An infectious reckless abandon fuels Mr. Holliday's Neo Abstract Expressionist paintings. Pouring, dripping, splattering, smearing and brushing, he produces expansive vibrantly sensuous and psychedelically spacey pictures. In each, a thick, black, tubular line snakes across or into the illusionistic depths like the path of an ecstatic mental traveler -- or a tripping hippie -- through his own visionary mindscape (Johnson).

LANSING-DREIDEN, LFL Gallery, 531 West 26th Street, (212) 631-7700 (through Nov. 17). Lansing-Dreiden is the collective name of a group of young artists working with drawing, digital animation and music. Their collaborative efforts are based on, or inspired by, elements from the fragmentary output of two earlier artist-writers, Friedrich Lansing and Caspar Dreiden, who lived in South America in the 1950's. The main piece in this engaging show is a black-and-white animated film titled "Quiet Earth," an episodic, surreal adventure narrative with a trippy continuous rhythm and a gently propulsive score by a band called the Lines, who are Lansing-Dreiden members (Cotter).

MORRIS LOUIS, Paul Kasmin, 293 10th Avenue, at 27th Street, (212) 563-4474 (through Dec. 22). This excellent selection of canvases by the pioneering Color Field painter includes darkly glowing works from the "Veils" series; light-as-air examples of the "Unfurled" series; candy-colored stripes; and, most arresting, "Para III," which with its flowing pools of liquid red, green, orange and yellow is like a hallucinogenic light show (Johnson).

STEPHEN MUELLER, Bill Maynes, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 741-3318 (through Nov. 17). Glowing watery plaids, candy-colored stripes and checks and emblematic shapes that look Middle Eastern are playfully layered by Mr. Mueller in canvases both optically riveting and mystically suggestive (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

* "HEAVENLY VISIONS: SHAKER GIFT DRAWINGS AND GIFT SONGS," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166 (through Dec. 15). In mid-19th century America, the Shakers experienced a period of revivalist fervor that included a spiritual reconnection with the sect's magnetic founder, Ann Lee (1736-1784). The presence of Mother Ann and the early Shaker saints was felt at prayer meetings. A few community members received supernatural "gifts" from them in the form of symbolic visual images which they turned into drawings. At once didactic and decorative, the drawings have no parallel in American religious history or art and they are among the least familiar components of Shaker visual culture, famed for its no-frills domestic objects. Elaborate, intricate, dense with detail, they are ethical guides to life on earth and charts to the world beyond. Nearly 80 of the 200 or so drawings that survive are included in this fantastic show, organized by the Drawing Center (Cotter).

Other Galleries

"A BREEZE FROM THE GARDENS OF PERSIA: NEW ART FROM IRAN," Queens Borough Public Library, 89-11 Merrick Boulevard, Jamaica, (718) 990-0700 (through Dec. 29). This library not only serves one of the city's most diverse and ardently book-loving clientel, it also presents some memorable art exhibitions. The work in this show, organized in cooperation with the Tehran Museum of Contemporary Art and Tehran Arts University, ranges from miniature painting to modernist abstraction. Technical polish is high, though by current international standards the results are conceptually conservative. What's most interesting is the way artists play with traditional forms, sometimes almost obscuring them without abandoning them, as in the case of calligraphy, which finds some fantastic variations here (Cotter).

* "EXPANDING ON A LEGACY: AMERICAN ART FROM THE MONTCLAIR ART MUSEUM," UBS Paine Webber Art Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, near 51st Street, (212) 713-2885 (through Nov. 30). In the 19th century Montclair, N.J., was a thriving art colony whose best known member was the landscapist George Inness (1825-1894), and it had high-minded citizens with cultural aspirations. A splendid result was the Montclair Art Museum, which opened in 1914 and today is one of the country's leading small museums of American art. This sampler of some 80 paintings, sculptures and American Indian art is meant to bring its treasures to a larger audience while it completes a renovation. A 1782 portrait by Gilbert Stuart; a major Inness landscape; realist canvases by John Sloan and Edward Hopper; a good slice of early Modernist work by Arthur Dove, Stuart Davis and Morgan Russell; an early Abstract Expressionist theme by Adolph Gottlieb; a group of sculptures by names like Daniel Chester Frency, Louise Nevelson, Man Ray and George Rickey, and an elegant Tlingit totem pole from the Northwest Coast make this an appetizing prelude to the feast across the river (Glueck).

"LARGER THAN LIFE," Center for Figurative Painting, 115 West 30th Street, (212) 868-3452 (through Nov. 30). The standouts in this five-artist show are two painters of opposite but equally ambitious sensibility: Leland Bell, whose large, perfectly composed figure compositions project an Apollonian love of order and clarity, and Paul Georges, a passionate hedonist whose big, recklessly vigorous painting of wild pink roses under a bright blue sky evokes a summer day to almost unbearably delightful effect (Johnson).

Last Chance

* "CASPAR DAVID FRIEDRICH: MOONWATCHERS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sunday). Think of this exquisite, 19-work exhibition as a bit of fanfare played pianissimo. It heralds the arrival of "Two Men Contemplating the Moon," the museum's first painting by the supreme German painter of the Romantic era, who made nature his cathedral and placed figures before it as before an altar. Concentrating on paintings of figures transfixed by the moon, it brings out the more intimate and serene side of Friedrich's temperament. The show also includes a few paintings and drawings by his contemporaries and disciples. One result is a surprisingly vivid sketch of the artist and his circle, which offers the opportunity to get a sharper sense of his extraordinary achievement. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

ANNA GASKELL, "Resemblance," Casey Kaplan, 416 West 14th Street, Chelsea, (212) 645-7335 (through tomorrow). Ms. Gaskell continues to produce the staged, dreamlike photographs of young girls engaged in mysterious, vaguely sinister activities for which she is well known. More surprising, and in some ways more imaginative, are her spidery cartoon fantasy drawings; she'd be a good illustrator for a new edition of Grimm's Fairy Tales (Johnson).

RED GROOMS, "Selections From the Graphic Work," National Academy of Design Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Sunday). For all its ebullience, the art of Mr. Grooms as represented in this 100-piece print retrospective is curiously tedious. He produces teeming, riotously colored cartoons of metropolitan life and affectionately satiric portraits of artists from Courbet to Pollock to Chuck Berry. Many prints are made to be cut and folded into children's-book-style pop-up scenes or three-dimensional volumes, as in a boxy portrait of Gertrude Stein that looks like a parade balloon. But lacking the weird darkness of, say, James Ensor or the philosophical complexity of Saul Steinberg, Mr. Grooms's art remains psychologically if not formally one-dimensional. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $8; $4.50, students and 65+ (Johnson).

* DAVID HOCKNEY AND HENRI MATISSE, "Line Drawings," Artemis Greenberg Van Doren, 730 Fifth Avenue, (212) 445-0444 (through tomorrow). Not a few artists of the last half-century or so owe much to the wizardly draftsmanship of Matisse, and Mr. Hockney is a pretty good example. This show tries to suggest through their works on paper -- Matisse's from 1918 to 1948; Mr. Hockney's from the 1960's and 70's -- the effect of Matisse's spare but supremely articulate line on the younger artist. At its best, Matisse's sprightly drawing is a lesson in the eloquence of brevity. Mr. Hockney's work is tighter and fussier, his line more broken, his subjects more particularized by detail. Still, as his later portraits make clear (particularly of Vera Russell in 1983), he has learned much from Matisse's willful looseness, his ability to imply by the sketchiest of suggestion elements of hair, clothes and body language. The playing off of one's work against the other's makes an intriguing exhibition (Glueck).

GEORGIA O'KEEFFE, Gerald Peters, 24 East 78th Street, (212) 628-9760 (through tomorrow). This modest selection of works by the legendary American painter includes a small watercolor of grapes and oranges, painted in 1904 when the artist was just 17; atmospheric abstractions in watercolor, made with deft economy in 1916; and, best, two small oils, one a picture of a single dark purple fig on pearlescent gray cloth and the other of an almost supernaturally glowing red flower in a white glass (Johnson).

FAIRFIELD PORTER, "Drawings From the Estate," Hirschl & Adler, 21 East 70th Street, (212) 535-8810 (through tomorrow). None of the 83 drawings assembled for this well-produced show are nearly as memorable as Porter's best paintings. Sketchy and loose, they look hastily generalized rather than uniquely observant. Nevertheless, many have diaristic charm -- portraits of the artist's daughter playing guitar, for example, or views of small-town streets populated by cars and trucks. Some pictures of ocean waves could be mistaken for Cy Twomblys (Johnson).

* JAMES SIENA, Gorney Bravin & Lee, 534 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 352-8372 (through tomorrow). Mr. Siena's captivating abstract paintings look as though they were created by someone in an altered, mildly ecstatic state of consciousness. Spiraling lines, nesting boxes, complicated lattices and other patterns are executed by a patient but eccentric hand in glossy, richly colored enamels on smallish aluminum panels. The results are a combination of systematic complexity, comic style and seductive sensuality that is mesmerizing and irresistibly delightful (Johnson).

HEADLINE: INSIDE ART 

BYLINE:  By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:
A Pedigree With Pull
 Some names -- like that of the publishing magnate Malcolm S. Forbes -- carry a special cachet, especially at auction. Forbes, who died in 1990, was an avid collector of everything from antique toys to Faberge eggs to Orientalist paintings. His collection and those of his five children have been on public display at the Forbes Gallery at 60 Fifth Avenue. 
 This week, Christie's announced that it would auction 62 American paintings and sculptures from the Forbes Collection on Nov. 29. The works are expected to bring $7 million to $10 million. 
Later, the auction house will be selling historical manuscripts from the collection, including handwritten manuscripts from Abraham Lincoln, Albert Einstein and John F. Kennedy. The manuscripts, valued at more than $10 million, will be sold in two auctions, on March 27 and Oct. 11, 2002.
Monie Begley, a spokeswoman for the Forbes Collection, said the family had decided to sell some works because Forbes's children have different tastes and have decided to refine their collections. "As our interests and focuses change, obviously the nature of the collections change," said Steve Forbes, president and editor in chief of Forbes magazine, in a written statement.
This isn't the first Forbes property Christie's has sold. In 1993 it auctioned a collection of Orientalist paintings, drawings, watercolors and sculptures that had been housed at the Palais Mendoub in Tangier. In 1997 it sold a collection of toy soldiers.
"What's most exciting is the diversity of great material at the high end," said Eric P. Widing, head of the American paintings department at Christie's.
Among the offerings is "Moorish Courtyard," a 1913 painting by John Singer Sargent in which the artist combines the grand proportions of a building's courtyard with the less glamorous function it serves by showing two donkeys in the foreground. The painting is expected to sell for $1 million to $1.5 million.
The Forbeses are known for enjoying the American West, often vacationing at the family ranch in Colorado, and several paintings up for sale on Nov. 29 celebrate that interest. Among them will be an Edward Hopper watercolor, "Mount Moran," painted when the artist was visiting the Grand Tetons in Wyoming in 1946. It is expected to sell for $600,000 to $800,000. (The Forbes Collection sold its best Hopper, a large interior, to the actor Steve Martin privately two years ago for a reported $10 million.) By far the best work up for sale is "Buffalo Hunt" (1897) by the cowboy artist Charles Marion Russell, and it carries an estimate of $800,000 to $1.2 million.
But given the Forbes provenance, prices could go a lot higher. "We're hopeful, but who knows?" said Stephen S. Lash, chairman of Christie's in America. "It's a great name."

Miami Has to Wait
What is sure to be the hottest contemporary art fair in America and this country's answer to the famous Basel Art Fair -- Art Basel Miami Beach -- has been postponed.
The organizers of the Basel fair spent five years planning to bring 150 of the world's leading dealers to Miami from Dec. 13 to 16 for the first Art Basel Miami Beach. But it has been put off a year and is now to run from Dec. 5 to 8, 2002.
"The galleries and the collectors asked us to put the fair off," said Samuel Keller, the fair's director. "It was a combination of politics and economics. The effects of the attack on the World Trade Center meant transportation problems for many of the dealers."
There were other problems, too, Mr. Keller said. Insurance was a big worry for many dealers, and psychologically, many people said they were still afraid to travel.
"We need this show in the long term," Mr. Keller added. "It's better to do it next year."

Gallery in Transition
The fate of Colnaghi, one of London's oldest art galleries, has become a matter of much speculation in both New York and London ever since Jean-Luc Baroni, its managing director, announced last week that he was leaving the company, taking senior staff members with him, and that the business might close unless a new owner could be found.
Mr. Baroni, who has been with Colnagi for nearly 20 years, is one of London's major dealers in old master drawings. In July he paid $8.4 million at Sotheby's in London for Michaelangelo's "Study of a Mourning Woman" and in January he bought Cuyp's drawing of a panoramic view of Dordrecht at Christie's in New York for $2.8 million, a record for the artist. 
Mr. Baroni joined Colnaghi in 1982 to establish a new drawings department. In 1996 its owner, the Oetker Group, run by Rudolph Oetker, a German businessman, restructured the business and asked Mr. Baroni to take over the paintings side of the gallery as well. A five-year agreement was signed by Mr. Baroni and the Oetker Group, which has now decided to end its involvement with Colnaghi.
"They asked me to buy the entire business," Mr. Baroni said. "I felt torn about it, but there was just too much overhead." Instead, Mr. Baroni decided to set up his own more streamlined operation beginning Jan. 1. The entire senior staff of Colnaghi is to join him in his new venture, Jean-Luc Baroni Fine Art Ltd., in which he will continue to deal in paintings and drawings from the 15th to the early 20th century. He is looking for a new space for the gallery in London.
One person whose name has surfaced as a potential buyer for Colnaghi is Konrad Bernheimer, a leading old master dealer with a gallery in Munich and an office in London.
"Yes, it's true they've offered me the company," Mr. Bernheimer said. "That's all I can say. Right now we're in the middle of negotiations."

An Opening in Houston
Ned Rifkin has resigned as director of the Menil Collection and Foundation in Houston after not quite two years. This week he was named director of the Smithsonian Institution's Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, succeeding James Demetrion, who retired early in October after 17 years. Mr. Rifkin is to begin his new job on Feb. 1. Meanwhile, the Menil plans a search for a replacement.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edward Hopper's "Mount Moran," from the Forbes collection, is being sold this month. (Christie's)

HEADLINE: Tighter Fuel Standards? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Better Cars, Cleaner Air" (Op-Ed, Nov. 2):
 Daniel F. Becker argues that federal mileage requirements on vehicles should be tightened to reduce our dependence on oil. 
 But Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) regulations have already failed to do this, because increased fuel economy leads to an increase in miles traveled. Thus, oil savings have been less than a tenth of what they were projected to be.
And increases in mileage regulations would cost 100,000 jobs and increase new vehicle costs by thousands of dollars each -- to say nothing of the 1,300 lives lost each year in the smaller vehicles these mandates create.
Congress should meet our energy needs without tangling a struggling economy in red tape or wasting thousands of lives on America's highways.

KAREN KERRIGAN
Chairwoman, Small Business
Survival Committee
Washington, Nov. 5, 2001

HEADLINE: A Free Mitsubishi? No, Not Quite 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN 

 BODY:
THE hard-edged radio voice proclaims that Mitsubishi is offering "triple zero": zero money down, zero percent interest and zero payments until 2003. It sounds as though the company is giving away its cars. 
 But only about a quarter of the people who walk into a showroom and buy a car get the triple treatment, said Pierre Gagnon, president of Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America. The company divides buyers into three tiers of creditworthiness; only those at the top qualify for the full zero treatment. 
 Another twist: the free financing expires once the buyer actually starts making payments in 2003. The prevailing market rate will then apply.
Mitsubishi's average spending on incentives was less than $1,500 a vehicle last month, compared with an industry average of $2,900, the company said. "It's profitable for us," Mr. Gagnon said. The zero-percent, five-year deals offered by some manufacturers are "a lot more expensive than zero percent for 14 months," he added. "We're not giving away the farm."
But some industry analysts detect a whiff of desperation. Jeff Schuster, director of North American forecasting at J. D. Power & Associates in Troy, Mich., said Mitsubishi was caught between Korean automakers like Hyundai and Kia and the high end of the Asian import market, dominated by Toyota, Honda and a revitalized Nissan. He also said that Mitsubishi "runs the risk of hurting its brand with these special deals."
But Mr. Gagnon said Mitsubishi was headed for a record sales year and was attracting more savvy and affluent buyers. Consumer awareness of the brand is at an all-time high, he added. 
The triple-zero offer continues through November and may be extended month by month. WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN
