HEADLINE: Exchange Considers Move to Trade Center Site 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Four days before the city was to vote on $920 million in bond financing for a trading complex and office tower on Wall Street, Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, cast a cloud of doubt over the project yesterday when he said he would instead consider building a new home blocks away on the former site of the World Trade Center.
 The New York Stock Exchange has told the Giuliani administration that it will wait to see what the city's plans are for "rebuilding ground zero," Mr. Grasso said yesterday at the Securities Industry Association meeting in Boca Raton, Fla. 
 But, he added, if the city and the exchange do go forward with the original $1.1 billion plan to build a new trading complex across the street from the historic home of the New York Stock Exchange, the project will include a much shorter tower, "so it won't be the tallest building in Lower Manhattan." 
The three-year-old proposal entailed a 50-story office tower rising above a 10-story trading floor on a site bounded by Wall, Broad and William Streets and Exchange Place. 
"A 900-foot tower post Sept. 11 is not a salable transaction," Mr. Grasso said.
Government officials yesterday were fuming at Mr. Grasso's very public remarks about the exchange project. In discussions with the Giuliani administration recently, Mr. Grasso explained his misgivings about moving into what would be one of the city's tallest skyscrapers and a possible terrorist target. But they did not expect him to take his fears public, said one downtown executive, nor did they urge him to consider moving to a redeveloped complex on the site of the World Trade Center.
Neither Deputy Mayor Robert M. Harding nor Michael Carey, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, returned calls requesting comment. Ray Pellecchia, a spokesman for the New York Stock Exchange, said Mr. Grasso was unavailable for further comment.
The city's Industrial Development Agency is to vote on a proposal next Tuesday to issue $920 million in tax-free bonds to finance the project, which was first announced in December 1998. It is the largest bond issue ever proposed by the agency. Under the terms of the bond, the state and city's debt payments would be $52 million a year.
In addition to the $920 million in cash from the bond sale, the state and the city had agreed to provide the exchange with $160 million in tax breaks. The exchange, in turn, had agreed to invest about $400 million in new equipment and pay an annual rent of $10 million.
The deal has come under criticism as costs have soared and some analysts have questioned the need for an expanded trading floor.
In recent months, the city signed contracts to buy the office buildings and an apartment house on the site and to relocate the tenants, at an estimated cost of nearly $480 million.
The city is temporarily moving the Bank of New York, a tenant displaced by the Sept. 11 attack, into a 37-story building on the site, 15 Broad Street.
Some developers have suggested that the New York Stock Exchange and the Board of Trade, a commodities exchange that was at the trade center, would be ideal tenants in a development at ground zero.
But Mr. Grasso's decision to say publicly that the exchange would consider moving there has reopened a debate. More than three years ago, Mr. Grasso threatened to move the exchange to New Jersey because it had outgrown its quarters on Wall Street and could not find an alternate location in the financial district.
City officials scrambled to come up with a plan for a new trading complex. Landlords and city officials feared that the New York Stock Exchange's departure would ignite a real estate disaster if nearby investment banks followed suit. The Giuliani administration agreed to give the exchange the largest subsidy package in city history.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard A. Grasso says a tall tower "is not a salable transaction." (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Wall Street Lawyers Being Laid Off as Deals Drop 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

 BODY:
From her apartment in Forest Hills, Queens, M. Catherine LaTorre made her regular call to the unemployment office Monday morning, her 59th day as a lawyer without a job. Ms. LaTorre has been able to find one, and only one, headhunter to talk to her, but after the World Trade Center attacks the headhunter was laid off herself for lack of work.
 Last week, the San Francisco law firm of Pillsbury Winthrop, saying that "this is a difficult time for all who work in New York," told associates it would lay off 11 of the 109 lawyers in its Manhattan office. The move came a week after Shearman & Sterling, with 950 associates, announced layoffs of about 10 percent from its headquarters in New York and other offices. Even before Sept. 11, other New York law firms were lopping off associates by ones and twos, and in several big firms by 10 or 15 or 25. 
 These things add up. The legal services industry in New York City lost 4,200 jobs from June to September, according to the State Department of Labor. Although these numbers usually drop when the summer interns leave, the 5 percent decline over the summer was the biggest for that period in 25 years. Moreover, the latest figures do not reflect cuts made after Sept. 11.
"I wouldn't call it a groundswell, but there was so much more going on in the last three or four months than I've seen in years," said Andrea Eisenberg, the managing principal of the New York office of Right Management Consultants, who helps laid-off lawyers find jobs.
All New York is in the same recession, of course. But in law the turn is especially sharp. And it is sharpest in the legal culture that revolves around big Wall Street deals, a culture that in the last generation has grown riskier, richer and bigger by far.
A year ago, the big firms fed by financial work couldn't find enough legal talent, and as a result, it seemed that no one else could, either. Young lawyers were fending off headhunters and comparing "retention bonuses" while their firms tried to raid one another. But just when law firms caught up with the galloping economy of the 1990's, the economy was exiting the 1990's.
In June, legal services employment in the city reached an all-time high of 84,800 -- a figure that does not include partners, who are counted as employers, or corporations' in-house counsel. It does include secretaries, paralegals and other support staff workers, who hiring experts say are probably safer than lawyers but have also been hit by layoffs.
Lawyers who aid in financial transactions have been most affected. This year, and especially since Sept. 11, "people don't want to close deals, make investments, to commit to a transaction," said Laura Corrao, a legal recruiter in Manhattan. "You talk to people at some of these firms and they're doing nothing. There's nothing to bill on."
During the hiring binge, New York firms grew fatter faster than those in other cities, by hiring for the mergers, initial public offerings and other business generated by investment banks. Their associates' salaries grew fatter, too, as in 1999 and 2000 the elite firms bid up the price of new law graduates to the going rate of $125,000. (The leader, still standing alone, is Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, paying $140,000.)
Jon Lindsey, the managing partner of the New York office of the legal search and hiring firm of Major, Hagen & Africa, said that last year some firms heavily involved in technology ventures hired 30 or 40 associates. "Now they don't want any corporate associates," he said.
The $125,000-a-year 25-year-olds and their multimillion-dollar bosses are just a minority of the 71,000 lawyers in New York City. "The bread-and-butter guys are probably still doing well," said Jim Brown, a labor market analyst for the state. So are litigators and lawyers who handle smaller commercial transactions, recruiters said.
But big-firm associates and their salaries have a disproportionate influence on the New York lawyer mind-set. Their pay is charted by national publications, and their workload is legend. At least 2,000 billable hours a year is expected here, meaning a bare minimum of more than 40 hours a week chargeable to clients, and 60-hour workweeks are routine. 
Now, on the Greedy Associates Web site (www.greedyassociates .com), the forum of choice for those working at the firms that they collectively call Biglaw, crabbing about bonuses -- the standard last year was $40,000 -- has given way to mordant jokes about getting "Shearmanated." Shearman associates often refer to the partners' profits, which last year averaged about $1.2 million.
"I heard Shearman partners are sacrificing, in a bloody, gruesome manner, 1 of each 10 associates at midnight during the next full moon," one reported the day before Shearman & Sterling announced layoffs. "Nobody will be spared!"
Still, no one doubts that these lawyers will find new jobs. As they do, they will crowd out people in the middle of the market like Ms. LaTorre, who was paid $97,500 a year by a small Midtown firm and now collects $364.50 a week in unemployment insurance.
A 1998 graduate of St. John's University Law School, Ms. LaTorre handled a variety of corporate work, most of it international, that slowed ominously over the summer. Her last day of work was Sept. 7, she said; she got "a week's courtesy" and a severance package.
Ms. LaTorre, 34, speaks fluent French and Spanish and ran a translation service before law school. But as a lawyer, "I am not the best-credentialed person," she said. "I don't have an Ivy League degree, I didn't go to a top 10 or 20 law school, and I wasn't high in my class.
"I come from a small firm. That's my natural market, small firms, but that market is being flooded by these highly credentialed people who are being laid off."
A few years ago, while those people were being courted by elite firms, Ms. LaTorre was doing well, too. She easily found a job while still in law school -- "They called me," she said -- and landed her second job after interviews with two firms.
Now Ms. LaTorre's day starts with three or four hours online, checking Web sites for job postings. She goes to social, corporate and networking gatherings of all kinds, she said, and having kept a mental tally of people she meets, figures that about one in five is unemployed.
Her own search, at least 100 letters, Ms. LaTorre said, has yielded one phone call from a law firm, a few from placement agencies and no interviews. "I've done everything short of standing on a street corner handing out my resume," she said.
"Every day, I wake up thinking, 'This is going to be the day.' " she said. " 'I've invested more than $80,000 in this career. Today's the day I'm going to see a little bit of a return.' I'm one of the few attorneys who loves practicing. I love my career."

GRAPHIC: Photo: M. Catherine LaTorre, an unemployed lawyer, in her Queens apartment. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Argentina's Leader Comes Begging, Burdened by More Bad News 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 8 

 BODY:
President Fernando de la Rua's critical negotiations with opposition governors to curtail spending fell apart tonight, dealing him a severe setback just before he left for New York to seek emergency international help to avert a complete financial collapse.
 The failure of a month of intense negotiations over more than $4 billion in annual public spending was a major embarrassment for a government trying to recover from an overwhelming defeat in congressional elections three weeks ago and nearing political collapse. 
 But more immediately, the setback meant that Mr. de la Rua will not be able to offer a reliable accounting of his government's 2002 budget and lending needs when he meets with President Bush and international bankers and investors over the next three days.
Highlighting the problems, scores of Argentine truckers began blockading several crossing points today along the Brazilian, Paraguayan and Chilean borders in an effort to stop imports that they say take away Argentine jobs. There was no immediate police response despite strong protests from Chilean officials. 
President de la Rua had hoped to persuade President Bush to prompt the International Monetary Fund to speed up disbursements of more than $1 billion in financing already pledged. The money is to be used as a security guarantee for banks and pension funds that are being asked to swap up to $95 billion in bonds for securities at lower interest rates. 
The restructuring of the $132 billion public debt, which would save the government $4 billion in interest rates next year, is intended to avoid an outright halt on interest payments, which most economists believe would set off a run on the banks and a steep devaluation of the peso.
"If de la Rua comes to New York empty-handed, he'll leave empty-handed," said Arturo Porzecanski, chief economist of emerging markets at ABN Amro Securities, "and the chances are very high Argentina will not be able to meet its payments this year."
After providing two large emergency packages since December, I.M.F. officials have told Argentina that they cannot begin to consider fresh funds until the government and the country's 23 governors agree to sort out a complex revenue-sharing arrangement. The central government is already more than $500 million late in payments this year.
President de la Rua has offered to pay the governors in a combination of cash and bonds and cut future monthly financing by 13 percent, or $300 million a month. 
Governors belonging to the center-left Alianza coalition came to an agreement with the government on Wednesday. But the opposition Justicialist governors, who control 14 of the 23 provinces with 80 percent of the population, have balked, and it appeared highly unlikely that talks would suddenly succeed before President de la Rua's scheduled takeoff at 11:30 p.m. 
The governors threatened today to take the government to court to force it to comply with agreements made last year. "They are putting the responsibility for their own administrative failures on our shoulders," said Gov. Nestor Kirchner of Santa Cruz Province. 
Mr. de la Rua's spokesman, Juan Pablo Baylac, responded angrily to the opposition governors, saying they were irresponsibly jeopardizing the economy. "It's time to stop the cheap politics," he added.
Several of the provinces, which have combined debts of $22 billion, have already defaulted on their bonds and most are behind in paying their teachers and other public servants or are relying on scrip to meet their obligations.
Rising interest rates have slowed the economy and pushed unemployment to nearly 20 percent. Tax receipts have fallen by more than 10 percent in the last two months, and manufacturing and consumer sales have also fallen at quickening rates. 
Debt payments represent nearly a fifth of government expenditures and about four times its export earnings. Exports can rise only modestly as long as the value of the peso is pegged to the strong dollar, economists argue, but a devaluation would mean large-scale bankruptcies for the private sector, which has up to $30 billion in debts denominated in dollars.

HEADLINE: Democrats' Recovery Plan Moves Forward in Senate 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 

 BODY:
Democrats pushed their economic recovery plan through the Senate Finance Committee tonight, setting out their negotiating position on an issue that has left the two parties bitterly divided and at risk of deadlock even as unemployment surges and business activity slows.
 The $66.4 billion plan, which includes an expansion of programs to help the unemployed, a tax rebate for low-income people and tax breaks for some businesses, was approved by the committee on a vote of 11 to 10. The swing vote came from Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, whose departure from the Republican Party earlier this year to become an independent threw control of the Senate to the Democrats. 
 The bill now goes to the Senate floor, where it seems sure to set off a partisan free-for-all of amendments, delaying tactics and debate, with the outcome uncertain. Centrists in both parties said they would work on a compromise that would allow Congress to meet President Bush's request to complete work on the stimulus package by the end of the month. 
Both sides said they wanted to avoid an ideological standoff over how to combat a slowdown that began a year ago and intensified after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. But neither showed signs of budging today, with exchanges of caustic criticism of each side's position.
Democrats said they intended the legislation to serve as a counterpoint to the $100 billion Republican stimulus bill, which was passed last month by the House and which focused mostly on tax cuts for business. 
The Senate bill would provide $14.3 billion this fiscal year to extend unemployment benefits and provide unemployment insurance coverage to some part-time workers. It would provide $12.3 billion this year to pay up to 75 percent of health insurance premiums for laid-off workers who qualify for a government program that lets them keep their employer-provided health plans after losing their jobs.
The legislation provides $19.4 billion in business tax breaks, including a provision that would give companies an incentive to accelerate plans to invest in new factories, machinery and other equipment. For low- and moderate-income workers who did not qualify for the rebate checks issued under Mr. Bush's tax cut, the plan would provide a one-time payment of up to $300 for single people and $600 for married couples.
It also contains $1.8 billion this year in tax breaks for New York and other regions affected by the terrorist attacks, with the amount rising to $5.3 billion over 10 years. It would exempt families of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks from federal income tax liability this year and limit their estate tax liability. And it extends a series of small-scale existing tax breaks for a wide variety of industries and social needs, at a cost of $628 million this year.
Democrats said the plan would put money quickly into the hands of people who need it most and would give the economy an immediate kick without undermining the government's long-term fiscal health.
"It provides a strong, balanced stimulus for economic recovery," said Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, the committee's chairman. "It provides important assistance to workers who've lost their jobs. And the long-term cost is low."
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, said he would bring the bill to a vote on the floor next week, and would attach to it a $20 billion package of spending on what he called domestic security needs. 
The package includes $3.1 billion for bioterrorism prevention and food safety programs; $1 billion for local police and fire departments; $1.6 billion for border security; $1 billion for airport security; and $2.5 billion for highway construction and improvements.
Republicans said the Democratic approach would do little or nothing for the economy, create expensive new entitlement and spending programs and dole out money to interest groups. They said they would do whatever was needed to kill it.
Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, called the plan "pitiful" and "insulting." Senator Fred Thompson, Republican of Tennessee, called it a "grab bag of partisan spending proposals."
It is unclear whether Democrats can muster 51 votes for the bill, much less the 60 they would need to end debate and overcome procedural hurdles to its passage.
Just to get the bill through the committee, Mr. Baucus had to add a variety of special-interest provisions. They included $10 million in tax breaks for citrus growers, $3 million in tax breaks for crop-dusters, $4.4 billion of tax breaks in the next decade for Amtrak and $5.5 billion over 10 years to subsidize a variety of farm products.
"I admit it: I like pork," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the minority leader. "But in a stimulus package? I don't see how spending money on watermelons and bison meat will help the economy."
Much of the debate on the Senate floor is likely to center on how to make sure people can get health care even if they lose their jobs. The approach favored by Democrats would subsidize health insurance premiums by providing money to individuals. Republicans support a proposal put forth by Mr. Bush to have Washington provide $3 billion to the states for them to use as they wish on health-insurance programs.
The health care debate is likely to be complicated by the decline in states' revenues. The National Governors' Association said today that more federal financing of Medicaid, the state-administered health insurance program for the poor, was an essential part of any package. The Senate bill would add $1.4 billion this year in matching funds for the states to help deal with the issue.
"States cannot provide services for new people coming onto the Medicaid rolls in their current financial situation," said Gov. Paul E. Patton of Kentucky, a Democrat who is vice chairman of the governors group.

HEADLINE: A Homeland Pep Talk 

 BODY:
President Bush sought last night to bolster the confidence of Americans in his administration's efforts to protect their safety at home. It was a rather muted performance, less inspiring than his address to Congress in September. But his call on the nation to "live in a spirit of courage and optimism" was well taken.
 Mr. Bush had undoubtedly hoped by this point to have some positive news to convey about the war on terrorism, at home or abroad. But instead he had to acknowledge that the government has no idea yet who is responsible for the bioterrorism at home, and to repeat his previous assertion that the American cause in Afghanistan is righteous. It was a more difficult message to deliver than his original declaration of war against the terrorists. The president stressed his own optimism not only that America would prevail, but that the events of "two of the most difficult and most inspiring months in our nation's history" had made the nation stronger and better. 
 One of Mr. Bush's major points was that Americans could help win the war against terrorism by volunteering for community service at home. The public has shown itself eager to do something positive in the wake of Sept. 11, and Mr. Bush is right in trying to help channel that desire.
The president would have been more reassuring if he had offered new evidence of concrete steps being taken to keep the nation safe, including greater powers for Tom Ridge's homeland security office and more spending to help hospitals, health departments and public safety agencies cope with the new and uneasy world he described.
Mr. Bush's address, to cheering firefighters, police and postal workers in Atlanta, was part of a series of appearances that the White House has designed to provide coherence to the confused messages relating to homeland defense in the last several weeks. On that front he was less successful. He called on Congress to pass legislation on airport security and economic stimulation. But he gave no indication that he was prepared to help break the partisan impasse on Capitol Hill.
This week, for instance, the president told a closed-door meeting of Republican leaders that he would veto any attempt to spend more than the $7.7 billion that his budget aides say has been set aside for homeland security. He reportedly cited budgetary constraints. But Democrats have won some Republican support in Congress for worthy spending programs to increase production of vaccinations for smallpox, help local public safety agencies and improve security at borders, transit systems, nuclear facilities, dams and other sensitive parts of the infrastructure. Unfortunately, they have also loaded up their "emergency" spending with pork-barrel items like crop subsidies for apples, blueberries and pumpkins. That only makes it possible for the White House to ridicule what otherwise should be taken seriously as genuine efforts to strengthen the fight against terrorism. Mr. Bush should be using his prestige to push for a pork-free spending plan and an airport security bill that mirrors the bipartisan Senate approach rather than the more ideological Republican House version.
Mr. Bush did display the sense of positive determination that has become the hallmark of his approach to the war on terrorism. A primary responsibility of a president in a time of crisis is to give Americans confidence in themselves and their ability to defeat the enemy. So far Mr. Bush has performed that job well, and the nation has responded by giving him overwhelming support for the fight both at home and abroad. But Americans would have more reason to be sanguine if there were more of an aggressive effort to bring coherence to the management of homeland issues and not just to the discussion of them.

HEADLINE: BLOOMBERG VISITS HEADS OF 2 UNIONS OVER FISCAL FEARS 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY and STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg paid visits to the leaders of two of New York's most powerful municipal unions yesterday, moving quickly to build ties with officials who will be key players in dealing with the city's mounting budget problems and offering an early and sharp stylistic difference with the man he is succeeding.
 "This should not be an adversarial relationship between the mayor and everyone else that works for the city," Mr. Bloomberg said, standing beside Lee Saunders, the administrator of District Council 37, the city's largest municipal union. Then, to underscore the point, the Republican mayor-elect slipped a green District Council 37 T-shirt Mr. Saunders had given him over his shirt and tie, then smiled in front of a mass of clicking cameras. 
 Mr. Bloomberg met for 20 minutes with Mr. Saunders and for 15 minutes with Randi Weingarten, the president of the United Federation of Teachers. Both unions had supported Mark Green, the Democrat, in the mayoral election that Mr. Bloomberg won Tuesday. Most unions did not back him, in part because his company, Bloomberg L.P., is nonunion.
His decision to meet with the union leaders -- and to visit their headquarters rather than summon them to his offices -- signaled the importance that the unions will play as Mr. Bloomberg confronts huge fiscal problems when he takes office.
Mr. Bloomberg said yesterday that he expected next year's budget deficit to be about $2.5 billion. But other fiscal experts said that the figure could be closer to $4 billion, the result of an economy that was already sliding downward before the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.
Mr. Bloomberg declined to get drawn into contract negotiations yesterday, noting that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was still involved in them.
"At the moment, we have a mayor who's in office till Dec. 31, and Ms. Weingarten has to negotiate with Mayor Giuliani," Mr. Bloomberg said. "I'm not going to get in the way of those two -- hopefully they'll come to a resolution."
But unless Mr. Giuliani reaches last-minute agreements in the next seven weeks on some seemingly intractable issues, Mr. Bloomberg will assume office immediately facing complicated contractual disputes with unions that are no strangers to dramatizing their demands with street demonstrations. Mr. Bloomberg might have to bargain with unions representing 80,000 public schoolteachers, 28,000 police officers and 9,000 firefighters, all whose contracts expired last year.
The teachers and the police officers, seeking parity with surrounding suburbs, have pushed for raises of more than 20 percent, and were looking to whoever was elected to be more generous than Mr. Giuliani.
Beyond the potential pressure of negotiating a contract, if the fiscal situation becomes as bad as many experts think it will, Mr. Bloomberg may find himself returning to these unions to push for cost-cutting concessions that could help him balance New York's books.
The mere fact that the visits took place -- and Mr. Bloomberg's easy-going banter with two labor leaders who just three days ago were working against his election -- suggests, at least for now, a considerable change in tone in the way City Hall will be dealing with unions. Mr. Giuliani's relations with municipal unions, particularly with Ms. Weingarten, were often rocky. 
Mr. Bloomberg steered clear of a question about whether his visit meant that he might have a lighter touch than Mr. Giuliani, the Republican mayor whose support helped lead to the mayor-elect's victory. 
"I think he's been a very good mayor, and he's governed for the last eight years," the mayor-elect said of Mr. Giuliani. "But I'm governing in the future, and my style is my style. And I would hope that I have access to the people that represent the municipal workers, namely the labor leaders. And I want them to make sure that they understand they will always have access to me."
With Mr. Saunders looking on, Mr. Bloomberg continued: "They may not get the answer they want, but I'm a believer in dialoguing. I'm a believer in inclusiveness. I'm a believer in being open."
At that, Mr. Saunders stepped in with warm words for the mayor-elect.
"Don't underestimate this: This is an extremely important signal that the mayor-elect is sending to us, in reaching out with us and sitting down and talking with us," Mr. Saunders said.
Ms. Weingarten, in an interview after Mr. Bloomberg left, said: "The real breath of fresh air is, he is talking about working with, not working against, the people who work for the city and work for the schools."
Mr. Bloomberg made the visit on what was his second day as New York's mayor-elect. From the union headquarters, he went downtown to tour the 14th-floor transition offices set up by Mr. Giuliani across Broadway from City Hall.
The sweeping offices, filled with desks and computers, offered an enviable view of City Hall and the Brooklyn Bridge. But they are decorated in an austere municipal style quite unlike Mr. Bloomberg's campaign and corporate offices. Mr. Bloomberg seemed somewhat hesitant when asked if he planned to spend much time there.
"We'll use it for something," he promised. "There are plenty of things to do." An aide later said that Mr. Bloomberg might find it easier to work out of his opulent campaign headquarters off Park Avenue.
Still, Mr. Bloomberg enjoyed the moment, standing at the entrance and jingling a key ring for the photographers, including his daughter, Emma, who was on hand to record this step in her father's life.
As he left, Mr. Bloomberg and his aides took note of the new sign over the door that announced it as the offices of "Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg."
Mr. Bloomberg's press secretary, Edward Skyler, sighed as he took it in. "After all the press releases I sent out that said 'Mike, Mike, Mike,' they do this?" he said with a laugh.
Last night, Mr. Bloomberg attended a dinner of 100 Black Men, where he shook hands with the Rev. Al Sharpton. Mr. Sharpton declined to endorse Mr. Green in the election.
Mr. Bloomberg is facing conflicting pressures as he seeks to deal with labor demands and a potential budgetary crisis next year. As Mr. Bloomberg has repeatedly noted, personnel costs represent the largest area of discretionary spending -- in other words, spending a mayor can cut -- in the budget, and thus he will be looking to reduce labor costs as a way to balance the budget.
But Mr. Bloomberg will also be under pressure to provide teachers and police officers sufficiently large raises to deal with the problems the city faces in retaining and recruiting teachers and police officers, who have been tempted to leave by larger salaries outside New York.
During the campaign, Mr. Bloomberg said he would prefer to increase salaries for teachers, rather than hire more teachers, as a means of retaining experienced teachers in school.

HEADLINE: A Trade Agenda Tempts Murphy's Law; 
U.S. Sees Talks as a Test of Leadership, But the Road to Qatar Was Rocky

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: DOHA, Qatar, Nov. 8 

 BODY:
Just about everything that could go wrong has gone wrong in the prelude to the global trade talks that begin on Friday in this Persian Gulf nation.
 So now, the ministers from some 140 countries gathering here in what the Bush administration considers a test of Washington's leadership in the war on terrorism risk failing a second time to agree on an agenda for writing new rules governing global trade. 
 Success at the talks "is within our grasp," said Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, who has made this meeting the focus of his first 10 months in office. "But," he said, "there's lots of hard work to do if we're going to get there."
A setback could send shock waves through the recessionary global economy and imperil the umbrella World Trade Organization, which was created six years ago to expand trade and regulate conflicts. 
With five days of bargaining scheduled, trade officials are still deadlocked on several core issues -- farm trade, antidumping rules and textiles -- that top the agenda for the poorest countries and split the industrialized nations.
Negotiators also have to resolve a few new and highly politicized disputes, like whether patent rules deny affordable medicine to nations facing health crises.
Murphy's Law seems to have plagued the trade talks in recent years. Two years ago in Seattle -- the last time officials tried to initiate what they refer to as a new round of trade negotiations -- the attempt failed in spectacular fashion. It was a showcase not for free trade but for groups protesting globalization.
Protesters are few in this tiny, oil-rich emirate, the only nation to offer itself as a host after downtown Seattle was ransacked during the 1999 gathering. But after Sept. 11, a painful security headache arose as the threat of terrorism against a conspicuous gathering in the Middle East forced the United States and most other nations to send only skeleton negotiating teams. Hotels here are swarming with security agents carrying walkie-talkies.
On Wednesday, before most delegates had arrived, a gunman was killed after he opened fire on troops guarding an air base about 20 miles southwest of here. Officials said there was no evidence connecting the attack to the meeting and called it an isolated incident.
Despite or perhaps even because of the terrorist threat, President Bush and Mr. Zoellick made the talks a test of leadership. They say a successful outcome would show that Osama bin Laden had not succeeded in disrupting an open and interconnected world. Mr. Zoellick called the talks a mission to "counter the revulsive destructionism of terrorism."
The stakes are also high because all the world's major economies are experiencing a downturn this year, the first time they have retreated in tandem since the oil shocks of the mid-1970's.
The World Bank predicts that trade among nations will increase at an anemic rate of 1 percent this year after soaring 12 percent in 2000.
Yet while the need to stimulate overall trade is pressing, major industrialized and poor nations are trying to dictate the terms of these talks in ways that suit their individual interests. Even the strongest supporters of a new round, the United States and the European Union, are prepared to walk away if the agenda impinges too much on powerful domestic groups.
After repeated rounds of trade liberalization since World War II, industrial tariffs have fallen to an average of 4 percent worldwide. That has left more contentious issues on the table, including several protectionist measures in the richest countries that mock those countries' rhetorical support for free trade.
The talks will put pressure on the United States to loosen quotas and reduce high tariffs on textiles and clothing, for example, while agreeing to discuss its use of antidumping measures to protect against imports of steel and other goods that it contends are priced below production costs.
At the same time, the talks will collapse unless Europe and Japan are willing to discuss dismantling the elaborate protection they have long provided for their inefficient farming sectors.
"The issues are set up in such a way that all the key players can walk away from Doha with a trophy," said Jeffrey Schott, a trade expert at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "But they are also set up so that everyone will have to be willing to give up something that's important to people back home."
All the major members among the 142 nations that make up the Geneva-based World Trade Organization will attend the session, which will also feature the formal entry of China into the W.T.O. No member is publicly opposing the idea of beginning broad trade negotiations, which would last at least three years and aim to liberalize and standardize the cross-border sale of anything from mangoes to mutual funds.
Most participants say they are cautiously optimistic that the ministers will endorse at least a modest agenda for negotiations. Determined to avoid the unscripted clashes at the bargaining table that doomed the Seattle talks, W.T.O. officials have drafted a carefully worded 11-page text that they hope can form the basis of an agreement.
The impetus to conclude some agreement is strong because the implications of failure seem so great. Mr. Zoellick and other trade officials speak of the "bicycle theory" of trade -- the need to move forward to keep from falling down. That is especially relevant during economic malaise, when the political pressure to shield domestic industries increases. 
But when trade experts argue that nations have a collective interest in backing a trade round, it is a little like saying that both the Yankees and the Diamondbacks want to do good things for baseball. They do, but they are better known for competing on the field.
The most divisive contest this time concerns issues that divide some rich and poor nations. Led by Brazil, Egypt, India and Malaysia, many of the developing countries argue that the trading system and the world trade group itself are slanted to advance the interests of the industrialized countries. They say that any new round of talks should be a "development round" that is focused mainly on the poor.
The World Bank supports the notion that trading rights are skewed toward the rich. It argued in a report released last week that a new deal could raise incomes in developing countries by $1.3 trillion over 10 years, but only if the Doha talks focused on agriculture, textiles and clothing, the main exports of the poor.
Murasoli Maran, India's trade minister, arrived in Doha on Wednesday pledging to block a new round unless the draft text was rewritten to address what he called the current imbalances in trade. Because the W.T.O. operates by consensus, any member can veto an agreement.
India and Brazil, with support from some African nations, have also insisted on rewriting patent rules to allow a broad "public health" exception. They contend that existing protections benefit multinational drug companies by blocking cheaper generic versions of drugs to combat illnesses like AIDS and malaria.
The issue turned red hot after the Bush administration forced Bayer to lower the price of its anthrax drug, Cipro. Health ministers in developing countries accused Washington of hypocrisy for insisting that poor nations honor patents while it bent the rules at home.
The Bush administration calls that nonsense. W.T.O. regulations already allow nations to seize patents in times of crisis, officials in Washington say. But along with Japan, Canada and Switzerland, the administration is fighting the idea of allowing a public health exception to patents, saying that any country could casually claim public health reasons for copying anything from cold medicine to dialysis machines.
They argue that India and Brazil are using the issue for mercantilist ends: both countries have large generic drug industries that want to export more medicines.
In an attempt to defuse the dispute, Mr. Zoellick has offered to exempt the poorest of the poor countries from patent rules on medicine.
North-south tensions are behind other sensitive issues in Doha, though most of the others also split the interests of the European Union, Japan and the United States.
By far the biggest benefit to the poor would come from loosening protections for farmers. World Bank officials estimate that Europe, Japan and the United States together spend about $1 billion a day subsidizing farmers, six times the total foreign aid to poor countries from all sources.
Though the United States is a culprit -- its farmers get billions of dollars in annual subsidies and it restricts imports of sugar, peanuts and lemons -- it sides with developing countries against Europe and Japan, which protect their own farmers even more extensively.
The second-biggest benefit to poor countries would come from easier market access for low-end manufactured goods, notably textiles and clothing. Here, the United States is in the weakest position because it unabashedly shields its ailing but politically influential textile industry through quotas and tariffs.
Europe, which does less to protect such industries, has championed the push by developing countries for more market access. So far, the United States has resisted.
Europe has also called for negotiations on environmental rules. It wants the W.T.O. to allow it to ban imports -- like genetically modified foods -- if it fears environmental damage. It is largely alone in making that case.
Japan, under siege because of its towering 1,000 percent tariffs on rice, has lined up developing countries for an assault on antidumping rules, which it says are routinely abused by the United States to shelter steel makers and other industries.
The Bush administration is under heavy pressure not to compromise on this front. Seventy-five senators, led by Max Baucus of Montana, the chairman of the Senate Finance committee, wrote a letter to Mr. Zoellick defending antidumping measures as a vital tool to protect American workers against unfair trading practices. 
Conflicts with Japan prompted Mr. Zoellick to lash out at Tokyo recently, saying that "the Japanese have just said no to everything in the process, and that just won't work."
Japanese officials seethed, responding that Mr. Zoellick was setting them up as fall guys if the Doha talks failed. As one Japanese trade officials commented, "We're his excuse."

AGRICULTURE -- Reducing barriers to farm trade is a top priority for the United States, other major food exporters and most developing nations. But Japan and Europe are reluctant to limit support for their heavily subsidized farmers. HEADLINE: Panel Approves Plan of $5 Billion for New York 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 

 BODY:
Efforts to help Lower Manhattan rebuild from the recent terror attack moved forward today when the Senate Finance Committee approved a $5 billion economic stimulus package for the area.
 The package was tucked into a $66.4 billion bill that the committee offered as a way to bolster the national economy. 
The two senators from New York, Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton, pushed to have the economic package for New York included in the larger bill. 
 The entire package needs approval of the full Senate, where its future is uncertain.
Mr. Schumer and Mrs. Clinton introduced their proposal late last month, saying it would spur the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan by offering $5 billion in tax breaks and other incentives for businesses.
Mr. Schumer and Mrs. Clinton acknowledged that their plan faced an uphill battle. But they were heartened that the finance committee included it in the larger package. 
"This is a powerful message from Washington," Mr. Schumer said. 
Mrs. Clinton added, "It's a real lifeline for New York." 
The plan calls for giving a $4,800 tax credit per employee to any business that agrees to return to Lower Manhattan or set up shop there for the first time.
The cost of the tax credit is expected to be about $2 billion.
The Clinton-Schumer plan also calls for tax-exempt financing to help developers undertake reconstruction of buildings destroyed by the World Trade Center attack. 
In all, this program is expected to cost about $2.5 billion.
Finally, the plan allows businesses to deduct part of the costs they incur replacing equipment destroyed in the attack. The plan allows deductions for the portion of the expenses not covered by insurance.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: NEWS COVERAGE -- CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
British Take Blunter Approach to War Reporting

BYLINE:  By CARYN JAMES 

 BODY:
After taking a Taliban-guided tour into southern Afghanistan last week, along with other Western journalists, Simon Ingram wrapped up his four-day experience for "BBC World News." The cameras showed a crowd of village men in turbans, their fists raised in anger as soldiers looked on. 
 "Within the Taliban stronghold of Kandahar, evidence of the challenge Washington is facing," Mr. Ingram said. He described the men chanting their allegiance to the Taliban and death to America and added, "No sign here that the intensifying American bombardment is achieving its goal." 
 ABC's Dan Harris, who was also on the tour, summed up his experience for "Good Morning America." He, too, said the villagers were angry at America but emphasized how friendly they were to him. "It's not that they're not bitter about the almost daily U.S. bombings," Mr. Harris said, in a warm and fuzzy tone. "They simply don't blame individual Americans." 
A Taliban spokesman said Osama bin Laden should not be turned over "to Americans who are killing our innocent people," but Mr. Harris ended the report by saying: "Most people, however, preferred more pleasant conversation. Before we left, one Taliban soldier smiled and said he wanted to leave with us and go to America." 
The soft American and the stern British tone is typical of these reports, and the difference highlights the value of seeing the world from a broader perspective. If a priority of America's war on terror is holding a global coalition together, it helps to know, without sugar-coating, what the rest of the globe is thinking.
"BBC World News" is the best of several foreign-based, English-language programs available to American viewers, all with a wider scope and a blunter attitude than American networks and cable channels. These are programs from friendly nations, not from places spouting anti-American propaganda. In fact, Mr. Ingram included his own country in one of his harshest assessments about the difficulty of defeating the Taliban. "If the U.S. and Britain were hoping that this unusual regime was about to crumble, they may well be disappointed," he said. 
But the range of issues and less defensive tone are wildly different from what American viewers get on network or cable news programs, which share a myopic view and a tone that says, "They'd love us if only they understood us." 
From the time the antiterror coalition was formed, the BBC has offered a stark view of its fragility, something the American media have just begun to focus on (a valuable "Nightline" segment addressed the issue with European journalists on Tuesday). And in the midst of covering anthrax, foreign-based programs have continued to report regularly from Jerusalem and the West Bank, offering a sense of how volatile the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has become. For American television, with its relentless focus on a single issue, covering anthrax and the Middle East at the same time is the news equivalent of walking and chewing gum.
The differences are not only war-related. When President Bush spoke about the economic downturn last Friday, American networks assumed a tone of cautious pessimism while a BBC reporter said, "even the president is forced to admit" that the economic future looks "very grim." 
The increase in ratings for foreign-based news since Sept. 11 suggests a hunger for what is not being offered by American reporting, and alternatives are increasingly easy to find. 
The half-hour "BBC World News" program is updated and broadcast live 24 hours a day to countries outside Britain. The program can be seen five times a day on BBC America, a channel available mostly on digital cable and satellite services, but it reaches viewers most easily on public television. In New York City, "BBC World News" is on several times a day on Channel 21. Since Sept. 11, two dozen more public television stations have picked up the program, so it now reaches 160 of them, covering about 70 percent of the country. 
Also since Sept. 11, ratings have gone up 50 percent for ITN's "World News for Public Television," a daily half-hour produced in England for American audiences and carried on 92 stations, including Channel 13 in New York. Like "BBC World News," it offers a range of international stories. ITN's reporting is more perfunctory, but some of its stronger segments are included on the PBS "Newshour." 
Viewers willing to do a little searching have a wealth of other options. C-SPAN's three channels often carry foreign news and public affairs programs late at night on a random schedule. 
For years, of course, American television has been criticized for paying too little attention to foreign news, and the consequences are freshly obvious. After the terror attacks, stunned and baffled "Why do they hate us?" articles flooded the news media, addressing a public that had been blinkered to what other parts of the world were thinking. And a homebound point of view persists, even though plenty of American journalists are in Pakistan and northern Afghanistan. 
The Fox News Channel anchors are still wearing flag lapel pins identical to those worn by the Bush administration, a signal of their allegiance. (On local news, red-white-and-blue ribbons are common.) But usually the signs are more subtle. On a recent edition of the CNN call-in program "Talk Back Live," the question of the day was a loaded one: "Is it unpatriotic to speak out against the war?" And on ABC's "This Week," Sam Donaldson reminded a representative of Al Jazeera, the Arab-language television station that has been a conduit for videos from Osama bin Laden, "A lot of people in the U.S. don't like the idea that Al Jazeera broadcasts Osama's messages to the Arab world." 
Some of the American skittishness and us-against-them attitude is understandable. The attacks did happen here and created a war mentality. But after two months, American television's cautious approach has turned into knee-jerk pandering to the public, reflecting a mood of patriotism rather than informing viewers of the complex, sometimes harsh realities they need to know. Even as American reporters are expressing frustration at how fiercely the Pentagon is controlling information, the emphasis is not on getting better answers but on covering "the propaganda war" in the shallow, horse-race way elections usually are -- who's winning?
"BBC World News" and other foreign-based programs offer an essential supplement to this tunnel vision. In one of his reports from Kandahar, Mr. Ingram was skeptical of a villager's angry claim that Americans wanted only to stop him from feeding his family, as the camera showed a Taliban ministry building that had been destroyed nearby.
"Evidence like this could be less than wholly convincing, and the Americans could well dismiss it as propaganda," Mr. Ingram said of what the Taliban led him to see. "What's harder to deny is that the anger felt by the people here seems to be directed not at the Taliban but at the United States." 
That may not be pleasant to hear, but it does something American television usually does not: it assumes that the public is smart and grown-up enough to handle what the rest of the world thinks.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE PRESIDENT; 
Bush Seeks New Volunteer Force for Civil Defense

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 8 

 BODY:
President Bush called tonight for the creation of a volunteer civil defense service and told the American people that the specter of a long war against terrorism within the United States would force the country to confront "new responsibilities, both for the government and for our people." 
 In a speech here before an invited crowd of police officers, firefighters and postal workers and many of his political supporters. Mr. Bush tried for the first time to describe at length how he believes ordinary life must change in a country that is not accustomed to facing a serious threat of foreign-sponsored violence on its shores. Excerpts, Page B6. 
 He said the volunteer civil defense service would help police and fire departments, as well as public health agencies, in times of emergency. Mr. Bush said participants in AmeriCorps, a national service program created by the Clinton administration, and the Senior Corps, would be asked to participate. The White House said it envisioned using 20,000 or more volunteers next year, to perform routine tasks so that emergency workers can pursue more urgent duties. 
A similar proposal was introduced this week by Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Senator Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana. 
On Friday, Mr. Bush is expected to ask governors to call up more members of the National Guard to help with airport security in the holiday season. He also created a task force to examine ways citizens could better prepare for terrorism and asked it to report back in 40 days.
Tonight, the president drew a picture of a country that must keep going to soccer and baseball games, to churches, mosques and synagogues but that must also put citizens on the street, much as Londoners stepped out of their homes in World War II to stand up against nightly bombing. But he also called for Americans to trust that their government was up to the task of protecting them and was expanding its legal powers to do just that.
Those words contrasted sharply with the ones Mr. Bush used a year ago, when in the last days of his presidential campaign he complained that his opponent, Al Gore, "trusts government, which stands in stark contrast to our view."
But most of Mr. Bush's talk tonight was meant to be inspirational and help Americans adjust to a new era when normal life goes on against a background of the threat of catastrophic terrorism.
"Life in America is going forward," he said, calling that "the ultimate repudiation of terrorism."
After two weeks of debate in Washington over when and how the government should declare special alerts, Mr. Bush tried to end the argument with a call for vigilant normalcy.
"A terrorism alert is not a signal to stop your life," he said in a large auditorium in the heart of Atlanta, the South's most economically vibrant city. "It is a call to be vigilant, to know that your government is on high alert and to add your eyes and ears to our efforts to find and stop those who want to do us harm."
But Mr. Bush also warned, "There is a difference between being alert and being intimidated, and this nation will not be intimidated." 
Speaking before a giant screen that carried the words "United We Stand" and images of police officers and rescue workers, Mr. Bush concluded by invoking the last known words of Todd Beamer, one of the passengers who is believed to have moved against the hijackers on the flight that crashed in Pennsylvania on the morning of Sept. 11. "My fellow Americans," Mr. Bush said, "Let's roll!" 
Mr. Bush faced a difficult political task tonight, because he had to argue that the United States was winning the war at home, even while acknowledging that investigators were no closer to solving the mystery of who sent at least three envelopes of anthrax through the postal system. 
So far, 4 people have died and 13 others are known to have contracted the disease. And the Bush administration has been forced to fend off criticism that the government's initial response was disorganized, particularly the miscalculations by the Postal Service and health officials about how easily the anthrax could seep out of sealed envelopes.
In private, White House officials have conceded that they sent out contradictory, and sometimes wrong, messages about the precautions Americans should take, and Mr. Bush's talk tonight was partly intended to soothe a nervous country, while urging Americans to keep up their guard.
Mr. Bush did not offer the kind of stark warning his vice president, Dick Cheney, gave two weeks ago when he said that this might be the first foreign war in American history in which casualties at home outnumber those abroad. But the president did liken the battle to World War II, saying, "We are the target of enemies who boast they want to kill all Americans, kill all Jews, and kill all Christians."
He noted, "We have seen that type of hate before."
Recounting his recent visit to a high school in Maryland, the president said he "realized that for the first time ever, these seniors will graduate in the midst of a war in our own country."
He stopped well short of making the kinds of claims of early victories in the war against terror that some cabinet members had made in recent days. 
Just today, for example, Attorney General John Ashcroft said the United States had "emerged victorious in the opening battle in the war against terrorism" because "two periods of extremely high threat have passed" without additional attacks. That was the first indication from an American official that the high alert declared last week, amid considerable debate about whether the evidence warranted it, has now been dialed down. 
Mr. Ashcroft also said Americans had "endured the videotaped tauntings of Osama bin Laden," a name Mr. Bush never mentioned tonight, and he celebrated the fact that "we have not suffered another major terrorist attack."
Earlier this afternoon, touring the headquarters of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention here, Mr. Bush said for the first time that he was "looking at different options" about how to protect Americans against an outbreak of smallpox. Terrorism experts have warned that it is possible for that disease to be spread through American cities.
But Mr. Bush said he was hesitant to back universal vaccination of the American public because of the likelihood that a small percentage of those receiving the vaccine would die.
"I would be deeply concerned about a vaccination program that would cause people to lose their life," he said.
While estimates of mortality from the vaccine vary, roughly one in a million people inoculated could die from the vaccine. 
That would mean about 280 deaths in the United States or 70 times more than the four deaths attributed so far to the anthrax attacks. An additional 1,500 could suffer brain damage. 
Some of what Mr. Bush said in his speech tonight he has said before, in bits and pieces, as the White House has moved to a war footing. He urged Congress to end a deadlock and send him legislation on airport security and an economic stimulus.
But some was new. The president acknowledged that the image America has abroad needs a lot of improvement.
"Too many have the wrong idea of Americans as shallow, materialistic consumers who care only about getting rich and getting ahead," Mr. Bush said. "But this isn't the America that I know."
He recounted the acts of kindness and faith he has witnessed around the nation in the last two months and argued that from the tragedy of Sept. 11, a better country was emerging. 
"The moment the second plane hit the second building, when we knew it was a terrorist attack, many felt that our lives would never be the same," said Mr. Bush, whose own realization came as he was informed of the attack in a second-grade classroom in Sarasota, Fla. 
"What we couldn't be sure of then and what the terrorists never expected," Mr. Bush said, "was that America would emerge stronger, with a renewed spirit of pride and patriotism."

WEXNER-Bella C. The Officers and Board of the Columbus Jewish Foundation mourn the passing of Bella Wexner, one of its first philanthropic fund holders. HEADLINE: European Central Bank Cuts Key Interest Rate 0.5% 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Nov. 8 

 BODY:
With European nations slipping closer to recession, both the European Central Bank and the Bank of England reduced their benchmark interest rates by half a percentage point today, following the Federal Reserve's action by 48 hours.
 The rate cuts were deeper than many analysts had expected, and they were greeted with relief by investors. But they did not defuse criticism that the European bank had been too slow and too rigid in responding to deepening signs of economic distress in Europe. 
 While the Federal Reserve has steadily flooded American markets with money, cutting rates to their lowest levels in 40 years, the European Central Bank has been reluctant to change course from inflation fighting, and its pronouncements have seemed confusing. 
Today's decision came as something of a surprise, because central bankers were sending mixed signals even this week. The political pressure from leaders of European governments, worried that economic growth had nearly stopped, has been intense. Still, until today, bank officials insisted that they were more worried about restraining inflation.
The European Central Bank, which sets monetary policy for the 12 nations adopting the euro as a common currency, reduced its main refinancing rate to 3.25 percent today from 3.75 percent. The Bank of England cut its key rate to 4 percent from 4.5 percent. Switzerland's central bank left rates unchanged. 
Wim Duisenberg, the president of the European Central Bank, said its decision was not part of a coordinated move with the Federal Reserve or the Bank of England, despite the timing. Rather, he said, the bank saw evidence that inflation had markedly slowed. Mr. Duisenberg acknowledged that European economies had been hurt by the slowdown in the United States, and that the impact had proved worse than first thought in the weeks immediately after the terrorist attacks. 
"Our assessment of economic developments, especially after Sept. 11," he said today, "is that confidence has been harder hit than we thought it would be a few weeks ago. It also means it will take longer to recover than we thought earlier."
The deepening gloom is widely apparent. Business confidence in Europe was lower in October than it has been in five years. Industrial production and orders for manufactured goods plunged last month in Germany, the biggest European economy. In recent months, European corporations have announced plans to eliminate more than 400,000 jobs. 
Electronics companies like Siemens of Germany and Ericsson of Sweden are eliminating jobs by the thousands. Airlines are in trouble, and weaker carriers like Sabena of Belgium and Swissair have collapsed. Even Lufthansa, one of the strongest carriers, is pressing employees to accept a four-day workweek with corresponding cuts in pay. 
Unlike the Federal Reserve, which has come to regard promoting economic growth as part of its mandate, the European Central Bank is bound by the Maastricht treaty to focus primarily on fighting inflation. Because the bank has been in existence for just three years, officials have been preoccupied with establishing its credibility as a tough-minded and politically independent institution.
But many economists argue that its credibility has been diminished, not enhanced, because it has seemed slow moving and because its direction has been unclear.
Referring to the European Central Bank's governing board, Raymond van der Putten, an economist at BNP Paribas, said: "They lack an economist or a president who can lead the decision-making. Mr. Duisenberg does not have the same prestige in the council that Mr. Greenspan has in the Fed. They can only agree on very small steps."
The council, which includes the presidents of the 12 nations' central banks, has been hard to read. For example, when Ernst Welteke, president of the German bank, said on Monday that too-zealous rate cuts could lead to higher inflation, some analysts began to wonder whether any cut at all would come this week. As events turned out, the European bankers reduced rates more than expected. 
"This renewed volte-face has left financial markets even more puzzled about what the bank will do in the future," Michael Schubert of Commerzbank wrote in a report. 
The Bank of England has cut interest rates seven times this year, to the lowest levels since 1964. The European Central Bank, by contrast, has made three cuts this year.
To be sure, Europe's economic situation differs from that in the United States. Nico Mensink, an ABN Amro economist in Amsterdam, noted that European corporations do not have as much excess capacity as their American competitors. European factories were running at 81.9 percent of capacity in the third quarter; the figure for American factories was 75.5 percent.
And both European consumers and corporations tend to shoulder less debt than their American counterparts. "The fundamentals are worse in the U.S. than they are in Europe," said Ralph Solveen, a Commerzbank economist here.

 INTERNATIONAL A3-14

Bush Will Not Meet With Arafat at the U.N.
The national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, said President Bush would not meet with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, at the United Nations this weekend because Mr. Arafat did not appear serious about the war against terrorism. A8

Mexico Frees Prisoners
President Vicente Fox ordered the release of two rural ecologists who had been tortured by soldiers and jailed after leading a campaign to stop the destruction of forests in the Pacific coast state of Guerrero. Amnesty International has considered the men prisoners of conscience. A12

Argentina Fiscal Talks Falter
President Fernando de la Rua and opposition governors failed to agree on curtailing spending, dealing him a setback just before he left for New York to seek emergency international help to avert a financial collapse. A12

Editor Arrested in Zimbabwe
Geoff Nyarota, the editor of the country's only privately owned daily newspaper, was arrested for the second time in less than three months, raising fear of a widening government crackdown on the opposition ahead of next year's elections. A14

International Climate Talks
Negotiators from more than 160 countries haggled in Morocco over a few important details in an effort to complete a pioneering climate treaty, the Kyoto Protocol, intended to reduce heat-trapping greenhouse gases linked to global warming. The United States is on the sidelines, a result of President Bush's decision in March that the treaty would harm the economy and unfairly apply only to industrialized countries. A13

Deadly Storm in the Philippines
Officials said that a devastating storm ripping through the Philippines' central and southern regions might have killed as many as 350 people, most of them in an area known as Paradise Island. A5

Democratic Stimulus Plan Is Passed by Senate Panel
Democrats pushed their $66.4 billion economic recovery plan through the Senate Finance Committee, 11 to 10. The plan, which sets out their negotiating position on an issue dividing the two parties, expands programs to help the unemployed and offers a tax rebate for low-income people and tax breaks for some businesses. HEADLINE: Zero Percent: The Fine Print Counts 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN 

 BODY:
BY promising to shave hundreds or thousands of dollars in interest over the span of a car loan, zero percent financing deals have made auto sales one of the economy's few bright spots since Sept. 11. Cars and trucks sold at an annual rate of 21.3 million in October, the industry's strongest month ever. But many of those buyers ended up with loans that charged interest, and some may have agreed to higher prices than they would have under other buyer-incentive plans.
 General Motors kicked off the free-financing bonanza in September, a move that was quickly matched by Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler. Several other companies subsequently announced interest-free or reduced-rate financing, at least for a few models. Some deals have expired, but many have been extended through mid- or late November. Toyota said yesterday that it planned to stop offering free financing at the end of the month. 
 For consumers, the challenge is figuring out which models are covered, and whether the deals apply to leftover 2001 models, to new 2002 models, or to both.
And would-be buyers should heed the fine print, especially the stipulation that only "qualified buyers" are eligible for zero-percent deals. For instance, the little type at the bottom of Toyota's television ads says that only buyers with Tier 1 and Tier 2 credit ratings qualify for the best rate.
Even those who qualify -- generally buyers with pristine credit -- may find that the offers are restricted to loans of 12 to 36 months. In the fine print of G.M. advertisements, the key language is "length of contract limited." With short loans, the monthly payments may be more than a consumer can handle, which is why many buyers like to stretch payments over 48 or 60 months.
And if a buyer has a trade-in or wants to make a big down payment, it may be wiser to take a cash rebate and pay a slightly higher interest rate.
"Zero percent actually makes it more complicated" to buy a car, said Jeremy P. Anwyl, president of Edmunds.com, a Web site that provides information to car buyers. "Everybody is wheeling and dealing. It's a bizarre market."
While it would also seem to be a buyer's market, it is not yet clear whether customers are getting good prices as well as favorable financing. It will not be known for another month whether average selling prices have gone down or up -- whether cars are actually selling for less or for more than would have been expected if the special financing deals had not been offered.
If a customer is mesmerized with a zero-percent offer, he or she may be willing to pay a higher price. "If the percentage of folks qualifying for zero is lower than the percentage qualifying for low rates in previous incentive plans, that would be outrageous," said Jack Gillis, author of a buyers guide, "The Ultimate Car Book."
While some lawyers and consumer advocates say the climate is right for abuses of consumers, there appear to have been few complaints to consumer advocates or state attorneys general.
Dealers say they are trying to move metal at competitive prices. "You have to remember that we're not the only Chevy dealer in our town," said Bob Serpentini, who owns five Chevrolet dealerships in the Cleveland area. "People still shop. You still have to be competitive in the marketplace." His dealerships sold 850 vehicles last month, compared with an average of 400 in previous Octobers.
It is not clear how many buyers are getting zero percent; some dealers say it is only a quarter of the people walking in the door, and neither G.M. nor Ford would disclose what percentage of their recent sales were financed interest-free.
Consumers have some tools to navigate the complexities of zero-percent financing. A first step may be to figure out your credit rating. You can contact credit agencies like Equifax and TRW, or you can fill out an online questionnaire at Edmunds.com that can help you determine whether you rate as platinium, gold, silver or bronze, depending on your use of credit and your history of late payments.
Automakers' credit arms use slightly different terms and metholodogies -- G.M.'s financing unit, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, gives rankings of 1 through 5 to an individual's credit. But the concept is the same: there are tiers of creditworthiness that determine who gets the best deals. Manufacturers are loath to discuss credit policies, but some offer zero percent to the top two tiers; others like Mitsubishi restrict deals to only the top tier.
Cars.com offers another handy tool for shoppers. If you click the zero-percent icon on that Web site, up pops a list of which manufacturers are offering deals on which vehicles. The list is updated daily.
Then there is the challenge of pricing. Even before the sales frenzy of October, it was hard to pin down a fair price for a car. Mary Butler, senior editor at cars.com in Chicago, said consumers should start negotiating from the dealer's invoice -- not from the suggested price on the window sticker -- information that is readily available on her Web site, at Kelley Blue Book (www.kbb.com) and many others.
She urges buyers to keep a rational eye focused on the actual purchase price rather than being swept up in the emotion of zero percent. "You may be gaining in one area like financing, but losing by having your trade-in depreciated," she said. "Keep your eye on the ball, which is the final price when all is said and done."
For manufacturers, the big question is whether the burst of interest-free financing has permanently altered the marketplace. Gary Flom, president and chief executive of the Manhattan Auto Group, which sells various car lines owned by Ford, including Jaguar and Mazda, says he thinks the October frenzy "borrowed" some sales from September, when the market was ice cold, but not from future sales. "I do not think we have significantly changed the psychology of the shopper," he said.
Others are not so sure. Mr. Anwyl of Edmunds.com said there had been huge swings in sales numbers, on a daily basis, depending on whether the zero-percent deals were in place. "Without that sweetener in the marketplace, demand dries up," he said. 

CORRECTION-DATE: November 12, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A table in the Automobiles section on Friday showing the costs of financing new cars misstated the amount a buyer with the best credit rating would pay on a 48-month loan for a $30,000 vehicle. Based on an interest rate of 6.53 percent (the going rate for Manhattan), the payments would be $688.13 a month, not $604.17; the total cost would be $34,030.24, not $30,000.16.

HEADLINE: Women and Prosperity 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As you observe in "Living in a World Without Women" (Week in Review, Nov. 4), "everything the world has learned in the last decade about why some countries develop and others stay mired in poverty shows that women can make all the difference."
 Countries with higher population growth rates have tended to see less economic growth. 
Nations like Bangladesh, Tunisia and Jordan, which have invested in improving women's status, primary education and health services, have created a "virtuous circle," economically surpassing nations that ignored such investment. 
 Nations that consistently deny women rights and fail to invest in their well-being condemn themselves to an unending cycle of poverty and violence. To the extent that economic development takes root, the allure of radical fundamentalism withers.

STEVEN W. SINDING
New York, Nov. 6, 2001

The writer, a professor of public health at Columbia University, is the editor of a book about population.

HEADLINE: Wholesale Prices Posted Record Drop In October 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 

 BODY:
Wholesale prices posted their biggest decline on record last month as energy costs fell by the largest amount since 1989 and automakers turned to cut-rate financing to lure buyers, a government report showed today.
 The report from the Labor Department showed that its Producer Price Index, which measures costs at factories and farms, fell 1.6 percent, the biggest decline since records were started in 1947. 
 The October decline was about four times what had been forecast and it more than reversed back-to-back gains of 0.4 percent registered in August and September. 
A weakening global economy and the effort by automakers to clear out inventories by offering price and financing incentives both played a role in driving prices down.
Analysts said it was too soon to start speculating that there might be a sustained period of price declines, but clearly inflation was not a worry for Federal Reserve policy makers, who lowered interest rates earlier this week.
Prices for finished energy products fell 7.7 percent, the biggest decline since a 7.8 percent drop in August 1989, after rising 0.9 percent in September.
Gasoline prices dropped 21.2 percent in October after rising 6.3 percent in September and 8.7 percent in August.
Excluding food and energy products, the so-called core rate of wholesale prices declined 0.5 percent in October, the sharpest drop since a 1.2 percent decline in August 1993, after a 0.3 percent increase in September.
Financial markets appeared uncertain what to make of the data, especially after a subsequent report showed an apparent brightening in consumers' moods in November. The University of Michigan index of expectations and current conditions rose to 83.5 from 82.7 in October. Stocks ended the day with slight gains, while bond prices were off.
The Fed has cut interest rates 10 times this year in the face of slowing business and rising unemployment, though the University of Michigan data appeared to imply that consumers were weathering the storm.
New-car prices fell 4.7 percent in October after rising 1.3 percent in September. It was the biggest price decline since a 5.2 percent fall in October 1972 as cheap financing and sales incentives took effect. 
"Whether consumers respond to these incentives will play an important part in determining not so much the duration but the depth of the recession," Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said.
