HEADLINE: Promised Land No Longer; 
Dot-Commers Who Once Flocked to San Francisco Are Turning Elsewhere

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 

 BODY:
Michelle A. Lemire, 28, moved here from Denver 18 months ago to join the dot-com revolution. She remained enthusiastic when her first employer went bankrupt. She was undeterred when she was laid off from a second job, and even when told by her third company that she could stay -- though it had gone broke -- if she agreed not to be paid.
 Her fourth experience ended practically before it began. Netcentives, an ailing Internet advertising company, hired her this summer and laid her off a week later. Ms. Lemire, a technical writer, was shaken, but still hoped that she would see the revival of the dot-com dream, defined by fat salaries or enticing options packages, and promises that its denizens could change the world. 
 Then came Sept. 11. Even Ms. Lemire has admitted to herself that it is time to give the dream its last rites. "It seems so long ago," she said of the explosion of Internet start-ups. Now, she will take just about any job. "I don't care if it is technology related. Just give me something to be part of," she said. 
As summer ended, laid-off dot-commers, some of whom had taken time off to play and reassess, reinvested themselves in job searches, insisting in the face of doubters that their niche would rise again. But even these stalwarts, many of them 20-somethings who formed the backbone of thousands of Internet start-ups, are finally admitting that the highflying era has come to rest.
Some say they are reluctantly pursuing positions in fields not related to technology. Many others are leaving Northern California altogether, as mounting anecdotal evidence suggests an exodus is afoot among former dot-commers -- a departure that appears to have gathered steam since the terrorist attacks.
Truck-rental companies report being inundated with requests for one-way trucks out of San Francisco. The Valencia Street U-Haul, one of the company's main branches in the city, is getting requests for 15 one-way trucks a day, up from around 6 before Sept. 11. Bonnie Parks, the acting branch manager, said the renters, typically 20 to 32 years old, expressed angst about the high cost of living, an inability to get jobs, and living in a city where terror could strike.
On Craig's List, a Bay Area Internet site (www.craigslist.org) especially popular among the dot-com crowd, listings for available apartments have risen to 5,500 from 3,500 in the eight weeks since the attacks, after climbing steadily but slowly for a year. "It has exploded since Sept. 11," said Craig Newmark, the founder of the site.
Among those who have left are Sean C. Downey, 32; his girlfriend, Jessica Myer, 23; and Phoebe, their dog, who packed into a 17-foot Penske truck in late September and headed for Washington, D.C. Mr. Downey said it was almost comical how many other people they ran across on their drive, all packed into trailers, "all going the same direction."
But Mr. Downey said the couple had little choice. They had been laid off in February from T3 Magazine, which focused on consumer technology and ceased operating six months after it was started. Mr. Downey had been executive editor and Ms. Myer a features editor. He said they spent six frustrating months unable to find work, before concluding not only that they would find no jobs in their field, but that it might be hard finding any job at all in the Bay Area.
Even for Mr. Downey and his peers, the dot-com era "seems kind of forgotten," he said.
"We've become part of the recession," he said. "Now we're just normal people out of work." 
Last month, the unemployment rate in San Francisco hit 6 percent, up from 2.8 percent a year ago. Just south of San Francisco, in Santa Clara County, the heart of Silicon Valley, the rate was 6.4 percent, up from 1.6 percent a year earlier. But the downturn is not limited to Internet companies; it has also slammed the technology economy in general, with layoffs and other work-force reductions hitting heavyweights like Hewlett-Packard, Cisco and 3Com.
Stephen Levy, director of the Center for the Continuing Study of the California Economy, based in Palo Alto, said former dot-commers were experiencing a "double whammy." "Their niche failed at the same time the broader tech industry was entering into a huge decline," he said. 
Mr. Levy said he did not expect the downturn to be as marked or long-lasting as the aerospace collapse in Southern California in the early 1990's, when a million people left the area. But he did say that Sept. 11 "does sort of delay the recovery" in Silicon Valley and that former dot-commers face a "tough short-term outlook."
This is not to say there are no dot-com companies left. Many Internet companies and software start-ups continue to operate, having cut back their budgets to try to survive. A few are even thriving. And no one here disputes that the Internet is here to stay, or that it has contributed to fundamental shifts in lifestyle and business practices.
Besides, Silicon Valley has always been cyclical, as different technologies emerge and inspire great bubbles of enthusiasm; indeed, there are those who say a biotechnology boom is just around the corner.
But it is a far cry from the heyday of the dot-com bubble. When venture capitalists were pouring billions of dollars into start-ups, the companies could not hire quickly enough. People in their 20's and 30's who flocked to the San Francisco area to join the fray talked of being swamped with job offers; it was not uncommon to hear of people putting a resume on an Internet job site in the morning and having multiple job interviews by day's end. They often worked long, exhausting hours, but they enjoyed perks like free food at work and casual dress, to say nothing of inflated salaries and potentially lucrative stock options. 
One former dot-commer sticking it out in the Bay Area is Rob Devereaux, 26, a 1999 graduate of Eastern Michigan University who found a $1,200-a-week contracting job for Quokka Sports, a Web site that transmitted sporting events live over the Internet. He was laid off last October, and the company later went out of business.
At first, he was so optimistic that work would turn up that he devoted some of his free time to developing his own Web site, intended to build a sense of community in the area. But it soon became clear that jobs would not be as plentiful as he expected, and the freelance work he relied on started "drying up and drying up."
In June, he said, "I finally swallowed my pride and went on unemployment."
Lately, he has been doing some gratis Web site design for Zeplin Media, a company starting a dating site. He had been aggressively pursuing other work, while watching his bank account shrink daily, forcing him to cut back so much that he bought his clothes at second-hand stores and fixed his own car.
Then last week he finally landed a contracting job to design Web sites. The job will last only two to three months, but still, he said, it has left him feeling "stoked."
He remains uncertain about the future, though, particularly in light of the Sept. 11 attacks, which left him glued to the television. More recently, he has tried to keep the TV turned off, not just because the news is generally depressing, but also because it keeps reminding him that the decade-long era of unbounded optimism -- the only setting many young adults have known -- is not going to return anytime soon.
"The boom we had was built on everybody being excited about stuff and living life," he said. Now, he said, when he watches the news, "it feels like the world is going to hell, like nothing is going to get better."

HEADLINE: U.N. Will Send Food to Zimbabwe's Hungry 

BYLINE:  By HENRI E. CAUVIN 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 9 

 BODY:
The World Food Program has announced that it will begin providing emergency food aid to more than half a million Zimbabweans, a stark indication of a deepening hunger crisis in a country that has traditionally been one of Africa's most self-sufficient. 
 Relief agencies had hoped to head off the food shortage, which has been slowly building for months even as the government refused to acknowledge the severity of the crisis. 
 But after a three-week tour of Zimbabwe last month, a team of monitors from the World Food Program, a United Nations agency, concluded that they could no longer wait before providing direct aid, which will begin next month. 
The food shortage stems from an untimely convergence of political and natural problems. 
Many parts of the country have suffered from drought, while others have yet to recover fully from severe flooding early last year. 
Additionally, sometimes violent land occupations, driven by a government plan to redistribute much of the land owned by the country's small white minority, have disrupted food production and generally discouraged investment in agriculture. 
The economy has been crumbling and is expected to shrink by 7.3 percent next year. 
Taken together, the problems mean that many Zimbabweans have a lot less to eat. 
The government has tried to halt the surging costs of staples like bread with price controls. But the main effect has been a decline in supply from producers unwilling to settle for below-market prices.
While such problems may well spawn an even bigger crisis next year, the immediate concern of World Food Program officials is the hunger now affecting more and more of Zimbabwe's 11.3 million people.
"We think right now people are managing to cope, but we think in the next three or four months it could become very difficult," Judith Lewis, the World Food Program's regional director, said in an interview from Kampala, Uganda.
Grain reserves are at their lowest in two years, according to the Famine Early Warning System Network, an arm of the United States Agency for International Development. 
Those stocks, which are projected to run out by the end of January, would ordinarily be replenished with imports, but the country's economic crisis has left the government desperately short of cash.
The next harvest will not be on the market until May or June. But even that may not bring relief because farmers who should be starting their planting this month are finding it harder to buy supplies as inflation approaches triple digits. Fertilizer, for example, has more than doubled in price since last year. 
It is an unusual predicament for a fertile country that has in past years often recorded surpluses, and readily imported food when its harvests fell short.
For months, the government denied that any serious shortage was on the horizon, even as evidence mounted. Finally, a few months ago, the finance minister, Simba Makoni, publicly acknowledged the looming crisis and began laying the groundwork for an appeal for aid. 
But the bureaucracy was slow to move, perhaps encumbered by the pronouncements of some ministers who continued to insist that everyone would be fed without any aid. 
Zimbabwe's own request for aid, outlined in a petition last month to the United Nations Development Program, makes it clear that outside help is essential. 
In the letter, which asks for more than $360 million in international aid, the government details the huge food demands facing the country along with a host of other needs, like rebuilding damaged roads and bridges and repairing breaches in the water and sanitation systems. 
The need is greater than the resources available, Mr. Makoni wrote to the United Nations.
The World Food Program is starting almost from scratch as it lays the groundwork for the operation in Zimbabwe. "We're sort of fighting against time to get our operation up and running," Ms. Lewis said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES; 
Oil Prices Soar on Confusing Report About Russia's Output

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 9 

 BODY:
On the surface, it looked like big news: the Russian news service Interfax quoted Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov today as saying that a group of Russian oil companies might agree next week to reduce oil exports in support of the efforts by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise oil prices. 
 Western news agencies picked up the report, and traders started bidding crude prices up sharply. At one point they had risen 6 percent, the biggest move in more than a year, but they closed at a 5 percent rise, at $22.22 a barrel, up $1.05. 
 There was, however, less to the development than met the eye. In the original Russian, the prime minister's language was much more equivocal than the news headlines suggested, and industry analysts and some of the oil companies themselves said an agreement to cut exports was very unlikely.
Russia has been the fastest-growing oil producer among non-OPEC countries this year. Its rising exports have complicated OPEC's attempts to restrict global supply and prop up prices, a task that has become more difficult since the attacks on the United States on Sept. 11. Crude prices have fallen by more than one-third since then.
Seeking closer cooperation, the Saudi Arabian oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, is scheduled to visit Moscow on Sunday, in advance of an OPEC meeting next week. 
Speaking on condition that they not be named, executives at several of the biggest Russian oil companies said in separate interviews that they had no plans to cut production, and had not agreed to join a cartel within Russia.
"To limit exports means limiting production, and no one will go for that now," one oil company representative said. Referring to the prime minister's remarks, he said, "This looks like a good-will gesture for OPEC."
Dmitry Avdeev, oil analyst at the United Financial Group, an investment bank in Moscow, said, "There are a lot of questions about how this would actually work -- the government doesn't have any real ways of forcing private companies to cut."
Russia's oil industry, cash-rich from high oil prices and a currency devaluation that slashed production costs, has been stepping up output, and greater production is already built into their strategies and forecasts for next year. For example, Sibneft, Russia's sixth-largest producer, plans to pump about one-third more oil in 2002 than in 2001.
Mr. Avdeev estimated that oil exports from Russia would rise 7 percent to 8 percent next year. Crude-oil exports from Russia and the countries of the former Soviet Union account for about one-tenth of world exports.

HEADLINE: Beliefs; 
A military campaign, the calls for caution and some complex roots in Christian thought.

BYLINE:  By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
The American government is understandably concerned about convincing Muslims around the world that the war against Al Qaeda and the Taliban is justified. Washington officials might do well also to worry about another religious group: Christians. 
 On the face of it, that proposition seems preposterous. Sept. 11 was a direct attack on a nation where almost 9 of 10 citizens call themselves Christians. Since that day, there has been no absence of flags in American churches and no sparing of prayers for the families of victims, for the safety of American forces or for the wisdom of national leaders. 
 While dissent has come from a few traditionally pacifist Christian groups, most other church authorities have upheld a need to bring the terrorists to justice, even if it means war.
But many of the statements from Christian authorities also include reservations, with much talk of limits, restraints, sparing civilians and getting at "ultimate causes." Indeed, two bodies of President Bush's own denomination, the United Methodist Church, have issued statements in the last three weeks, one of them only yesterday, that come close to an outright condemnation of the campaign in Afghanistan.
Seasoned politicians, then, might be excused if they viewed official Christian support for the war in terms of the old cliche: a mile wide and an inch deep.
To many people, that is the way it should be. Wasn't Christianity's founder a victim of state power? Didn't his followers record in the Gospels that he refused to defend himself or usher in the kingdom of God by violent means? 
For Christianity's first three centuries, Christians stood apart from state power and military force, partly because of their founder's example, partly because Roman soldiering was permeated by pagan practices. That changed in the fourth century with Constantine and the coming of the Christian empire; now Christianity was stuck with political responsibilities. Soon, Augustine, arguing that taking up arms in defense of the innocent could be a moral duty, began devising criteria for distinguishing between just wars and unjust ones.
So for most of its history, Christianity has hardly been a nonviolent religion. But for many Christians, those earlier centuries remain a touchstone of the true, uncorrupted faith. 
In modern times, of course, Christianity was nudged away from state power. War became the extension of politics -- secular politics -- by other means and not of missionary work. Still, the habit of blessing arms and invoking God for national purposes continued until the slaughters of the last century rendered such gestures increasingly scandalous. 
In the United States, disillusionment with World War I combined with the Gospel renunciations of violence to produce a quasi pacifism among many Protestant leaders in the 1920's and 30's, often married to a belief that the world could be reformed without conflict. 
As an advocate of intervention against Hitler, Reinhold Niebuhr, the most prominent American theologian of the 20th century, rejected that view. What he called "Christian realism" held sway through World War II and the first dozen years of the cold war, only to give way again to antimilitary sentiments during the Vietnam War.
Today it is noteworthy that the two unofficial contemporary "saints" most frequently mentioned in Protestant and Catholic services -- Martin Luther King Jr. and Dorothy Day -- both advocated nonviolence. Some of the most creative contemporary moral theologians -- Stanley Hauerwas of Duke University, for instance -- are pacifists, while those who remain adherents of just-war theory are highly sensitive to its misuses and therefore typically emphasize the tight constraints it puts on the use of military force.
Moreover, the Christian voices that count in supporting or criticizing the war against terrorism are no longer limited to American and European sources. The extraordinary courage and vision of church leaders in places like South Africa, Central America, India, the Philippines, China, East Timor, the Middle East and Eastern Europe demand that their views get a hearing. Inevitably these views reflect a perspective different from those in America. 
So when the recent synod of Catholic bishops from around the world condemned terrorism and the "perversion of religion for violent purposes," it was not surprising that the denunciation appeared within a larger appeal to "remember those corners of the world which receive no media coverage and where our brothers and sisters are dying from famine and lack of medicine." 
In a world where 1.2 billion people exist on less than $1 a day each, those leaders were implicitly suggesting that countering terrorism, especially by arms, could not be Christians' single, all-consuming priority. And while they and other Christian leaders around the world are not beyond conventional anti-Americanism, they also need look no further than what their Scriptures say about rich and poor, the powerful and the lowly, to have doubts about the United States and its purposes. 
None of this means that American Christians will ever turn radically pacifist. They are likely to support the war against terrorism, perhaps more as Americans than as Christians. But their faith may produce a degree of moral uneasiness that could reinforce political doubts if things go badly.
American policy -- at least so far, and so far as is known -- has been consistent with one of the greatest concerns of church leaders: limiting civilian casualties. But perhaps the critical difference for affecting Christian opinion will be made not by anything done by arms in Afghanistan but rather by what is done -- or not done -- to address suffering there and elsewhere by other means. 
Will worldwide questions of humanitarian aid, economic development, debt forgiveness, prevention and treatment of AIDS, and advocacy of human rights, and even equality and justice domestically, be put on the back burner while resources flow freely to military efforts? The resulting message about the richest and most powerful nation could transform already guarded Christian approval into serious reappraisal.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
A Banker Leaving Seoul Warns Against Bailouts

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 4 

 BODY:
Wilfred Horie, lured to Korea nearly two years ago to run a troubled bank, has a word of advice for investors who are thinking about bankrolling large companies on the brink of failure: follow his example and do not do it.
 In his office in Korea First Bank, Mr. Horie talked recently about what he had done since becoming president of the bank in January 2000 and what he plans when he returns to Hawaii after retiring this month. 
 As he looked back on his record as the first president of the bank since Newbridge Capital bought 51 percent of it from the government in late 1999, he said his most significant accomplishment was refusing to participate in schemes to provide more credit to companies that should have simply died. 
Mr. Horie, who spent 17 years establishing the Japanese franchise for Associates First Capital and then built its operation in Dallas before coming to Seoul, avoided accusations of impropriety in the extension of fresh credit and rolled-over loans for Korean companies.
Implicit in his remarks, however, was the sense that the Korean governing establishment had indirectly influenced government-owned banks to extend loans to failing companies when all his analysis and instincts told him that was not the way to go.
"If you ask the regulators of the Ministry of Finance and Economy, their position is they have significant shares in the banks, but they are allowing the banks to operate on their own," Mr. Horie said. "My guess is there was quite a lot of pressure. There's probably indirect pressure."
It was that kind of pressure, he said, that led the creditors of Hynix Semiconductor, one of Korea's most troubled entities, to agree to a plan for providing about $500 million in fresh credit along with a debt-for-equity swap of about $3 billion.
"We don't want any part of Hynix," Mr. Horie said, talking about the decision of his bank to refuse to participate in the plan. He says he hopes the government-controlled banks responsible for the bailout plan for Hynix will buy Korea First Bank's loans for more than 25 percent of their face value. But he clearly prefers to write off the rest rather than risk more on a doomed operation.
The acceptance of the need to get rid of loans and write off losses is a concept that Mr. Horie says other banks should emulate more freely.
He said the government had helped pump about 150 trillion won, or nearly $120 billion, of private funds into tottering companies since the economic crisis of 1997 and 1998.
"There's more to go," Mr. Horie said. "The sooner they recognize that some of these nonperforming loans need to be written off, and they need to get on with life, the better off they'll be. Some of these companies need to go."
He spoke of the need to recognize failure with an urgency that is missing in the remarks of Korean officials, who talk abstractly of short-term fixes but do not give the impression that much is going to change when it comes to supporting industries.
Hwang Doo Yun, the trade minister, said that when the United States raised the issue of whether Hynix Semiconductor was in effect subsidized by the government, "We explained that underwriting was a temporary means, for one year."
As for why the government controlled some of Korea's biggest banks, Mr. Hwang said the government "had to assume the shares of financial institutions in the restructuring process in the economic crisis of 1997." The government, he said, "does not influence the institution's handling of economic loans."
Korea First Bank, in fact, was one of the first institutions taken over by the government. Burdened with loans to Daewoo group companies and others on the brink of bankruptcy, the bank was one of two that the International Monetary Fund insisted should be sold as a condition for the $58 billion bailout package that the I.M.F. put together in late 1997.
Since Mr. Horie took command, Korea First Bank has shed most of the loans to Daewoo and other troubled companies and reduced the corporate portfolio from 70 percent to 40 percent of total loans.
One of his proudest decisions came last January, when, he said, "we put our foot down on participating in the fast-track bond rollover, a scheme that required banks to participate in rolling over loans to a number of companies that we were not happy to participate in."
Mr. Horie recalled that an official at the Financial Supervisory Service, the government agency with responsibility for the banks, "got very upset and made comments to the local media." Then, he said, "the next morning he said it was all media hype," all part of the game here of testing public opinion and pulling back if the comments are not well received.
Against this background, Mr. Horie denied speculation in Korean newspapers that he had been forced out of his post after approving excessive loans to Hynix and others.
"This is my decision," he said. "Transformation of the bank has been ahead of schedule. Now I'm going to take it easy."
At the top of his agenda is charitable work in Honolulu, where he grew up. "The Honolulu Y.M.C.A. was very important to me in high school," he said. "Now I would like to give back."

HEADLINE: Mortgage Rates at a Low 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 

 BODY:
Mortgage rates dropped this week to the lowest level in 30 years of record keeping, helping to spur a further boom in mortgage refinancing.
 Rates for 30-year mortgages dropped to 6.45 percent, down from 6.56 percent the previous week, according to a nationwide survey released Thursday by Freddie Mac. 
 The mortgage company said the latest decline pushed 30-year mortgages to their lowest level since it began conducting its nationwide survey in 1971. It was the 13th consecutive week that 30-year mortgages have been less than 7 percent.
A number of forces are behind the drop in long-term rates, economists said, including the sinking economy, which many say they believe is in a recession, and the indirect impact of the Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts. The most recent reduction, a half-point cut, came on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Dynegy Plans to Acquire Enron for $9 Billion in Stock
The Enron Corporation agreed to be acquired by rival Dynegy for about $9 billion in stock and the assumption of $13 billion in debt.
 The deal is an extraordinary turnabout for Enron, a Houston-based company that had been a driving force behind electricity deregulation nationwide. Its chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, a major contributor to the Republican Party, provided political influence, while its former chief executive, Jeffrey K. Skilling, helped create financial markets for the trading of electricity and natural gas. But last winter, when California's effort to deregulate the electricity market led to soaring power prices and rolling blackouts, Enron was the subject of much criticism and political anger. Page A1. 

Dow at Highest Point Since Attacks
Stocks rose modestly, with the Dow Jones industrial average posting its highest close since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. The Dow closed up 20.48 points, or 0.2 percent, at 9,608. It was the highest close for the industrial average since Sept. 10, when it ended at 9.605.51. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.77 points, or nearly 0.2 percent, to 1,120.31. The Nasdaq composite index gained 0.71 points, to 1,828.48. C4.

Wholesale Prices in Major Decline
Wholesale prices fell 1.6 percent, the biggest decline since records were started in 1947, according to the Labor Department. C14.

Online Speech Rules Are Proposed
Racist speech and hateful content would be barred from the Internet under a protocol proposed by the Council of Europe, a group that represents 43 democratic countries and aims to safeguard human rights. C3.

Wall Street Hears Argentina's Case
Argentine President Fernando de la Rua went before Wall Street investors to defend his rescue plan for the country's weakening economy, saying a debt swap, is the best way to keep Argentina solvent. C3.

Japan Lowers Its Economic Outlook
Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's Japanese government reduced its economic forecast for the fiscal year and expects its economy to contract at its fastest pace in more than two decades. The outlook is the government's bleakest since the second oil crisis in 1980 and follows similar reductions in estimates by private economists and the Bank of Japan. C3.

No Apologies From a Korean Banker
Wilfred Horie, lured to Korea to run one of Korea's troubled banks, Korea First Bank, has a word of advice for investors who are thinking about bankrolling large companies on the brink of failure: don't do it. Mr. Horie didn't and as he prepares for retirement, he leaves the bank First in good shape. C3.

Oil Prices Rise on Russian Rumor
Oil prices surged in response to reports that Russia might agree to restrict production, but after further reflection, analysts decided that the statement that led to the rally was more equivocal than it had appeared and prices retreated. C4.

Trade Representative on the Spot
Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, will be the point man for this nation at global trade talks in Doha, Qatar, as he tries to persuade nations to talk about freeing up cross-border sales of farm goods and services, including everything from mutual funds to environmental engineering. A6.

Some Markets Closed on Monday
Some financial markets will be closed on Monday when the nation observes the Veterans Day holiday. Stock markets will be open during their normal hours. The bond markets will be closed.

HEADLINE: Office Vacancy Rate Climbs in New York 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
New York's office vacancy rate rose to 9.9 percent in October, the highest since 1998, as Merrill Lynch, Salomon Smith Barney and other financial firms shed workers and excess space.
 Lower Manhattan led the rise, where about 3.75 million square feet was put up for lease, an amount equal to more than one-third of the destroyed World Trade Center complex, according to the property brokerage firm Insignia/ESG. 
The city's vacancy rate is more than double what it was a year ago. 
 The data showed that the effects of a contracting economy outweighed the rush for space by companies displaced by September's terrorist attacks. In Lower Manhattan alone, the amount of space given up was nine times the amount leased, a condition known as negative absorption.
"There's not sufficient demand to stem the deterioration in occupancy due to the economy," said Bruce Surry, Insignia/ESG's executive managing director. "This negative absorption is greater in proportion than we've seen for many, many years."
The rise in vacancy rates, especially downtown, highlights the need to expedite government subsidies and benefits to encourage businesses to return downtown, Mr. Surry said. 
Average rents across the city fell to $50.06 a square foot from $50.75 in September, and $52.01 in August, the company said. The last time average rents in Manhattan were below $50 was in June 2000.
The economy contracted for the first since 1993 in the third quarter, and the jobless rate rose to a five-year high in October. Wall Street has eliminated about 18,500 jobs through Sept. 11, the biggest round of job cuts since 1987.

HEADLINE: Hollywood's Newest Star Is a Mall, And More 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 

 BODY:
Hollywood today greeted what it hopes will be its newest star: a $615 million development that includes stores, a hotel, restaurants, cinemas and a new home for the Academy Awards.
 Developers along with the city -- which put some $90 million into the venture -- hope that it can do for Hollywood what the Walt Disney Company and others did for a seedy Times Square in the mid-90's. 
 "Hollywood has gone through a lot of changes," Rob Reiner, the actor and director, said at the grand opening. "We've seen it go up and down. I'm announcing here today Hollywood is back." 
In recent years, several efforts have been made to revitalize Hollywood, which like many other urban areas had fallen into decline, becoming a home to drug addicts and the homeless. Although 10 million tourists are said to visit the area each year, there has been little to hold them after they have photographed Grauman's Chinese Theater and checked out its entryway with the handprints and footprints of celebrities.
"We've had a lot of false starts," said Jackie Goldberg, a state assemblywoman and a former Los Angeles City Council member who has been involved in the revitalization effort. "Anything smaller than this probably wouldn't be noticeable."
Anchoring the project is the 3,650-seat Kodak Theater, which was built with the Oscars in mind (the awards program will be held here in March) and was designed to resemble a 1920's movie palace. 
The retail shops surround Babylon Court, modeled after a set from D. W. Griffith's 1916 epic movie "Intolerance." Two 33-foot-high elephants, weighing 13,500 pounds each, flank the courtyard, and at one end an arch with Egyptian carvings frames the Hollywood sign in the distance. The complex is known as Hollywood and Highland, for the intersection at its eastern edge.
As part of the project, Grauman's Chinese Theater has been restored, and six screens have been added. The Renaissance Hollywood Hotel also got a face lift, including a $4,000-a-night rooftop suite. The open-air mall has more than 70 shops and a variety of restaurants.
"It should have been like this 40 years ago," said Ron Woods, a former resident, as he took in the courtyard. "We used to have people come out from back East. We'd bring them to Hollywood and they were disappointed. This is something you can show out-of-towners and be very proud of."
But a handful of protesters across the street were not so enthusiastic. 
"This is supposed to be the new Hollywood," said John Walsh, a resident who said he opposed the use of public money for the project and criticized the authorities as failing to rid his neighborhood of crime and gangs. "Hollywood is Raymond Chandler. It's not a Las Vegas mall."
Assemblywoman Goldberg said the Hollywood and Highland project by the TrizecHahn Corporation had served as a catalyst for other developments in the area.
But small-business owners in the area have a wait-and-see attitude.
"We hope it's going to bring us a lot of business, " said Emanuel Cohen, owner of J. M. Electronic , opposite the project on Hollywood Boulevard. Mr. Cohen added, however, his business had fallen 75 percent since Sept. 11, and questions have been raised about whether this is the best time to be opening such a project.
At least for today's celebration, any such possibility was brushed aside.
"Here is a place where dreams are made," said Chief William R. Bamattre of the Los Angeles Fire Department. "I think this is a kind of in-your-face response that Hollywood can show the world."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A 3,650-seat theater, which will become home to the Academy Awards, anchors a $615 million Hollywood development that opened yesterday. (Gerard Burkhart for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.N. 'Dialogue' Focuses on Sept. 11 Terror Attacks and U.S. Bombing of Afghanistan 

BYLINE:  By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 9 

 BODY:
From the sand-filled trucks on First Avenue to most every speech in a warm-up debate on "Dialogue Among Civilizations," the General Assembly has left no doubt of the centrality of the terror attacks on Sept. 11 in its delayed annual gathering.
 The "general debate" starts on Saturday, when President Bush -- preceded by a large truck parked outside marked "United States Secret Service" -- will address the Assembly. But already for the last two days, the "Dialogue Among Civilizations" has set the tone with a mantra of denunciations of the attacks and newly relevant calls for tolerance. 
 The strongest attack came not from the United States or Europe, but from President Mohammad Khatami of Iran, the initiator of the "dialogue" and its godfather. 
He declared the Sept. 11 attacks as "horrific" and said that they were "perpetrated by cult of fanatics who had self-mutilated their ears and tongues, and could only communicate with perceived opponents through carnage and devastation."
After that, the condemnation of the attacks as "indiscriminate brutality" and "the antithesis of all that we would hope to achieve in a dialogue of civilizations" by the American representative, Ambassador John D. Negroponte, sounded almost mild.
Mr. Khatami also issued an indirect and relatively moderate warning to the United States that "the perception of a need for revenge coupled with a misplaced sense of might could lead to failure to hear the calls of people of good will or the cries of children."
But the theme was set. Mr. Khatami had originally invoked a "dialogue among civilizations" as a code phrase for building contacts between Islamic governments like his and secular countries, but it gained new importance when it was adopted as the theme of the year by the United Nations. Now, after terror attacks by Islamic militants against Western symbols, it was the theme of the moment.
"If anyone had ever doubted the need for a dialogue among civilizations, let them doubt no more," said Secretary General Kofi Annan.
Not every speaker took as stern a line as Mr. Khatami. Some balanced a condemnation of the Sept. 11 attacks against an indictment of the American bombing campaign in Afghanistan. 
"Of course, the perpetrators of those crimes needed to be brought to justice and punished," said Kamal Aboulmagd of Egypt, a judge of the World Bank Administrative Tribunal who was among several "eminent persons" invited to speak. "However, wise people were starting to fear that the focus on reprisals might trigger a catastrophe."
Cuba's deputy foreign minister, Abelardo Marino, went further, assailing the United States for "bombing defenseless people" and more generally for undermining dialogue by seeking to impose its own ideological and cultural values.
There were others, like Prime Minister Zlatko Lagumdzija of Bosnia, who drew on the theme of the moment to recall his country's own grievances. These, he said, made him "especially sensitive to terrorism which misused religious feeling," and he said he was here "not to say, not to ask, but to scream and beg for the multiplication of efforts to speed help to innocent people who were the victims of their own leadership."
Hans Kung, a prominent theologian from Switzerland and president of the Foundation for a Global Ethic, who was another of the "eminent persons," elevated the theme to a new paradigm for international relations, guided by a "globalization of ethics."
So it went, with many of the speakers addressing an increasingly empty hall. Though it was tempting to see that as a reflection of the actual state of "dialogue," it was more closely related to the intensity of preparations for the parade of speakers next week. As in Congress, many of the speeches at the United Nations are made more for the record, or for a domestic audience, than for the enlightenment of other delegates.
In any case, it was a foretaste of the discussion to come, in which the terror attacks and the bombing campaign in Afghanistan will dominate innumerable speeches, meetings and back-room conversations. All the while, the severest security anyone could remember was there to remind delegates that the dialogue and speechifying were no longer theoretical.

HEADLINE: Security Tight for Start of United Nations Meeting in New York 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

 BODY:
Keenly aware that the United Nations General Assembly is a potential terrorist target, federal and New York City law enforcement officials are on the highest security alert for a week of meetings among world leaders scheduled to begin today.
 The convergence of so many leaders on a city still stunned by the Sept. 11 terrorist attack has provoked such deep concerns that the annual gathering has been designated a national special security event, said Brian Marr, a special agent with the Secret Service. 
 Military personnel and equipment will be at the ready. The East River will be closed during the day. Attendees will be screened by metal detectors on their way in and out of the 39-story United Nations building. Other security measures include sharpshooters on rooftops and sweeps for explosives in some areas. 
Some busy city streets will be shut down, especially today, when President Bush will be among more than 100 foreign leaders and ministers expected to attend.
"Basically, we emphasize the importance of prevention and deterrence," Mr. Marr said. "But also, the Secret Service is prepared to respond tactically to a threat, if the situation dictates."
With security increased for other recent city events, like the World Series, federal, state and city officials are already highly prepared.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that officials believed that this was a good time to hold the United Nations event and that it would help the economy.
Since Sept. 11, a stretch of First Avenue outside the United Nations complex has been barred to all vehicle traffic, said Farhan A. Haq, a United Nations spokesman.
Federal officials have familiarized themselves with the ID verification system the United Nations has in place for the more than 3,000 employees who work in the building.
In the air, private airplanes will be banned from a radius of 2.5 nautical miles from the United Nations building, up to an altitude of 18,000 feet, said Arlene Salac, a Federal Aviation Administration spokeswoman.
On the waters, teams of armed Coast Guard officers will patrol in cutters, along with harbor launches from the Police Department.
Officials are particularly focused on the East River and the coastal areas around the United Nations building, said Cmdr. Daniel A. Ronan, the chief of the waterways management division for the Coast Guard in New York.
Today and tomorrow, the entire East River, from bank to bank, will be closed to vessel traffic between the Queensboro Bridge and East 35th Street in Manhattan, from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m., he said.
On the roads, motorists can expect traffic delays and road closures on Second Avenue, between 42nd and 57th Streets, during the morning and afternoon today and tomorrow, the police said.
In addition, the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive will be closed in both directions from 1 to 3 p.m., and motorists can also expect delays and possible closures in the areas of Madison Avenue between 44th and 46th Streets and between 49th and 51st Streets.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A group of law enforcement officials in front of the United Nation in New York yesterday. Security is tight, especially today, when President Bush is among more than 100 foreign leaders who are expected to attend. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS; 
On High Wire at a 5-Ring Circus

BYLINE:  By SELENA ROBERTS 

 BODY:
In the first pew of a tidy brick church, Lloyd Ward, his mother and four siblings would sit as tight as piano keys while Rubert Ward soothed the 40 or so souls seated in front of him each Sunday.
 During the week, Lloyd Ward's father worked two other jobs to provide for a family that was shoehorned into a 20-foot-by-20-foot house that had an outhouse and a coal-fire stove as amenities. If he was weary, Rubert Ward never revealed it during services that lasted longer than daylight on some Sundays. 
 People lifted him, and he lifted the people. But while Lloyd Ward's father could deliver a sermon fit for a revival tent, he would also step down from his pulpit. Cloaked in a black robe with burgundy trim, Rubert Ward would glide down the aisle in the Church Temple of Science, seeking out the disaffected, the troubled or anyone with threadbare faith. 
He would stop, look into their eyes, let his hand fall firmly on their shoulders and speak in a voice soft enough to be personal, but loud enough to reach every corner of his Baptist church in Detroit. 
"It was powerful," Lloyd Ward said. "When he would touch you, he'd have a way of making everyone in the congregation feel like he was preaching to them personally. He wasn't preaching to the congregation, he was preaching to me."
In 1967, Rubert Ward died at age 47 from a heart attack. Lloyd Ward was only 18, but a childhood of Sunday memories helped spirit him through a remarkable business career and ultimately to a meeting room at a Chicago hotel on Oct. 21. 
In front of some wary executives of the United States Olympic Committee, Ward presented himself as a finalist for chief executive officer. Stepping from behind his laptop, wearing a lapel mike for optimum mobility, Ward swept around the room, making eye contact with each member, connecting his vision for the organization to theirs.
He preached the value of sports, about fair play and the importance of a drug-free Olympics, reminding each member why he or she had joined the Olympic movement in the first place. The witnesses were moved, enough to sway the vote in his direction. That day, Lloyd Ward was announced as the chief executive of the U.S.O.C.
"He was powerful," said the former U.S.O.C. president Robert Helmick, who, as a board member, saw an identical presentation from Ward when he addressed the U.S.O.C last week as the new chief executive. "Something like that could have been viewed as contrived, but it wasn't. It was completely sincere."
There is little doubt that Ward's charisma -- along with his star power as the former chief executive of Maytag -- helped seduce the U.S.O.C. into electing him to fill the position, which pays $500,000 a year.
But who needs whom the most? Some members of the U.S.O.C. wonder if Ward is making only a cameo with the organization to raise his profile after his inelegant departure from Maytag in November 2000. After four chief executives in two years, the chronically unstable U.S.O.C. would suffer another blow if Ward departed in the months after the Salt Lake Games in February.
"Certainly, continuity would benefit the U.S.O.C.," said Paul George, a member of the executive committee. "I think for Lloyd Ward this job offers benefits and meaning you can only receive by working with a nonprofit organization. There are different rewards. I think he's at that place in his career where that is valuable to him."
At 52, Ward insists he is ready to make a difference, not more money. He wears an expensive gold watch with a single diamond marking its face, and he has a taste for nice houses, clothes and cars. But Ward comes across as unaffected.
"I'm here because I've chosen to be here," Ward said last week as he sat in a leather chair inside his neat corner office at the U.S.O.C. training center in Colorado Springs. "It's about being part of something significant." 
If he can build a consensus inside an unwieldy organization that has been torn apart by self-interest, Ward could provide the committee with a needed morale boost and image makeover. If he can wield his marketing experience, he could polish up the Olympic brand name and court sponsors when contracts come up for renewal at the end of 2002. If he succeeds, Ward could make a difference in reviving the American Olympic movement.
It is a daunting job, but Ward has a background in working wonders. In a childhood home he said was about the size of his master bedroom today, Ward grew up thinking about what was possible, not impossible. His surroundings did not hold him back; they made him quicker and smarter, even as it related to the strategy behind an outhouse run. 
"In my mind, I was always making this tradeoff on how I was going to dress to how quick I could be," Ward said. "So you play this game in your mind. It toughens you up. As a kid, you do crazy things. You run out there in the snow with no shoes and bare feet, just your underwear on. You get very efficient with it."
Ingenuity was important. Ward also leaned on this trait to find his way to an engineering degree. In grade school, he decided to focus on basketball as a means to get an education, not to become an athletic star. On scholarship at Michigan State, Ward played point guard. His shot was not always perfect, but he passed with an archer's aim.
This ability to connect has been a thread throughout his career, from the moment he started at Procter & Gamble to the day he arrived at Maytag in 1996. Almost instantly, Ward was credited with turning the $1,000 Neptune washer from an immovable object on the showroom floor into a mainstream phenomenon.
Instead of promoting the washer for its energy-saving, ecologically sound features, Ward uncovered a human angle to sell a machine that went for $600 more than others that did basically the same thing. 
"We asked consumers, 'How many gallons of water do you think you use in a typical load of laundry?' " Ward said. "Most consumers say 5 to 10, but the answer is 40. The Neptune uses 20. But is that an emotional connection? No, it's information. We did the math on this, and for the average family throughout the year, if you used a Neptune versus a conventional washer, every year you saved enough water to satisfy the thirst of a human being for a lifetime. That's making a human connection."
Ward is not infallible in his human judgment. Named chief executive of Maytag in August 1999, he was forced to resign 15 months later. There were public relations missteps along the way, including Ward's desire to move the company from its roots in Newton, Iowa. His idea was met with outrage.
It was also bad timing for Ward's innovative thinking. As the economy slowed and profits plummeted, Ward kept pushing idealism while the board demanded solidity. Eventually, Ward's great attribute, energy, became his undoing. Instead of being celebrated for his ambitious approach, Ward left labeled as impatient.
Impatience will not work in the slow-bake decision-making world of the U.S.O.C. Ward is the first to note this distinction.
"I've worked on my impatience," Ward said. "I know it's not my movement, it's everyone's movement. It's like a rubber band. If I get so out there, the rubber band breaks and there is a disconnect between me and those I want to inform."
Bonding is his strength, but can Ward convert those disaffected U.S.O.C. members who have seen smooth corporate wizards come and go in a matter of months?
"I believe that those who are in this movement, from the executive board on down, believe in it, want to contribute to it, want to make it better," Ward said. "I think I'm dealing with a congregation of believers. Are there skeptics? Yes. Is there a basis for skepticism? Yes. But the basis for skepticism is that expectations haven't been met, not yet."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FAMILY CENTER; 
People in Need Criticize Plans to Close a Center of Help

BYLINE:  By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
The Family Assistance Center on Pier 94, set up by the city for people left jobless, homeless, bereaved or injured by the attack on the World Trade Center, is being dismantled, and the system replacing it is already generating complaints from volunteers and those seeking help.
 Last Monday, the Federal Emergency Management Agency, at the city's request, took over half of the building used by the Family Assistance Center. The city-run side is closing in about two weeks, a city official said. 
 Social welfare advocates and those aided by the Family Assistance Center have praised it as a model of sensitivity, comfort and efficiency. City, state and federal agencies were there to help the needy get financial aid quickly, and other services were provided by the Red Cross, the Salvation Army and Safe Horizon. 
The center offered a full buffet, child care and free access to telephones and computers.
But the main purpose of the Family Assistance Center was to help the bereaved, not the jobless or homeless, said a city official who did not want to be named. Now that the number of bereaved people seeking help is dwindling, the city plans to close that part of the center in two weeks.
When FEMA arrived at Pier 94, between West 53rd and West 54th Streets, the city and the federal agency set up a new system for handling requests: those who were injured or lost relatives in the attack were to line up on the city-run side; those who lost jobs, homes or their businesses would line up on the FEMA-run side.
"The difference is vast," said Diane, 35, who lost her job as a saleswoman at the Marriott World Trade Center Hotel when it was destroyed on Sept. 11. She had sought help at Pier 94 last month and returned yesterday. "They fed us. They had a large TV and music and free phones. Now they give us a bottle of water and a cup of juice and make us wait and wait."
Those seeking help say the lines on the FEMA side are very long, with waits of three to four hours just to make an appointment for the next day. Instead of a full buffet, the Red Cross distributes water, coffee and sandwiches. The city-run side has indoor bathrooms; the FEMA side has outdoor toilets.
FEMA opened the center at Pier 94 because its downtown center, on Worth Street, could not handle the crowds, said Ron Sherman, a FEMA official. More than 600 people go to the Worth Street center every day, he said, and hundreds are turned away. 
Yesterday, more than 600 showed up at Pier 94, and he said he expected an equal number in the weeks to come as people use up their savings and lose jobs to a sinking economy.
Over the past two months, 229,000 people have sought help at the Family Assistance Center, a city official said yesterday. But the number of bereaved or injured people looking for government help is rapidly decreasing. At the same time, the number of displaced or jobless people needing money is high and is expected to remain that way.
The help offered before FEMA arrived at Pier 94 has not changed significantly, Mr. Sherman said. The Red Cross, the Salvation Army and Safe Horizons, the city's main emergency assistance groups, have booths inside, as does the Small Business Administration and employment organizations. Registering with FEMA will streamline the process of obtaining aid from other agencies and organizations, he said.
People can register for unemployment, housing and other emergency assistance on the phone, without waiting in line, Mr. Sherman said.
But people who sought help weeks ago and are still in need say the restrictions have tightened considerably. Right after the attacks, government and private agencies gave out money freely, they said. Now, the organizations are requiring people to fill out more forms, wait longer and provide more documentation, like utility and rent bills and paycheck stubs, to qualify for help, they said.
Most of the complaints, however, centered on discomfort and inconvenience rather than on the quality of help. Several expressed dismay with the spartan decor, the lack of amenities and the long, cold wait outside, with the wind whipping off the Hudson River. 
Some employees and volunteers are also dismayed by the new workplace. 
"The workers are in cramped quarters," one said. "No more breakfast or dinner, though many are working 12-hour shifts." The screening and security checks, she said, are unreasonably long.
Mr. Sherman said the security precautions were necessary and the quarters adequate. Providing comfort to shellshocked people was a prime concern immediately after the attack, he said. But most people now need practical help, like rent money and assistance finding jobs or apartments.
The federal government has extended the deadline for emergency aid to Jan. 10, he added, to accommodate hotel, restaurant, airline and tourism employees who were recently laid off or will be shortly.
He added that the comforts, like the generous meals and upholstered chairs, were pleasant but expensive to provide. "I don't like those lines any more than they do," he said.

HEADLINE: JOURNAL; 
War is Heck

BYLINE:  By Frank Rich

 BODY:
I was also at Chicago's O'Hare Airport last Saturday when Subash Gurung, an illegal immigrant with no fixed address, slipped seven knives, a can of Mace and a stun gun through the X-ray machine at a "security" checkpoint. Eager to honor our toughened airport protocols, I had my ticket and ID ready for examination, but at the penultimate juncture, a smile and a wave were enough. The "guard" smiled back, never bothering to read or match the ticket with the ID. It was all so convivial you'd never guess this is a nation at war. 
 Maybe it's not. What I witnessed at O'Hare -- and eight other major American airports I've been to since Sept. 11 -- suggests that two months after hijackers turned commercial passenger jets into weapons of mass destruction, there's no great hurry to standardize or enforce airline security far beyond the ruthless crackdown on manicure scissors. Yes, National Guard troops are on duty, but as easily distracted onlookers. In Washington, Congress is AWOL, trying to forge a mishmash "compromise" out of competing security bills that would take many months to institute anyway. Our secretary of transportation, Norman Mineta, hasn't exactly filled the gap. Outraged at the breach at O'Hare, Mr. Mineta swore stiff retribution -- a farcical threat given that the many past infractions of the offending rent-a-guard company, Argenbright, have already been punished, with no deterrent effect whatsoever, by a seven-figure fine and even a jail term for one of its supervisors. 
 Mr. Mineta is so overmatched by events that he makes Tommy Thompson look like Patton. In a letter to The Times 10 days ago the transportation secretary argued that private security companies should be kept on the job in airports in part because the State Department uses them to protect our embassies abroad. Hel-lo! It was private guards who were presiding when Osama bin Laden's operatives bombed our embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in 1998, killing 224 and injuring more than 5,000. 
Perhaps Mr. Mineta and Congress are taking their sweet time on airline security because they buy the conventional wisdom that Al Qaeda won't repeat the same terrorist act again so soon. But isn't terrorism by definition dedicated to defying the conventional wisdom? Even so, the lack of urgency about airline security is more the rule than the exception in Washington as America's New War seems less and less new. Though the cable news channels use rubrics like "America Strikes Back," perhaps "What's the Rush?" would be more appropriate. 
Thus we learn in Senate testimony this week that, a month after the first anthrax case, the F.B.I. still hasn't located all the American labs that legally handle anthrax, let alone any suspects for its illegal dissemination. On Thursday John Ashcroft, who may be abridging more civil liberties while nabbing fewer criminals than any law enforcement official in American history, proudly announced that we have "emerged victorious in the opening battle in the war against terrorism." Thus he can turn his attention to hunting down doctors trying to ease the agony of the terminally ill in Oregon. 
The collateral damage to the economy can wait, too. Dick Armey promises that the House's stimulus bill "will create 170,000 jobs next year alone" -- even as 415,000 Americans lost jobs in October alone, bringing total unemployment to 7.7 million. The House's package also awards $5.7 billion in tax rebates to 13 Fortune 500 corporations while Congress earmarks at most $3 billion for fighting bioterrorism at a time when the American Hospital Association estimates that $11 billion is needed just to upgrade hospitals. But hey, what's the rush? As Tom DeLay said on Fox, "The American people need to learn that these terrorists are going after specific people, people that are symbols. . . . Somebody in Sugarland, Texas, shouldn't worry about anthrax."
"The new normal" is now the old normal. Before Sept. 11 the administration said we could have it all -- deep tax cuts, better schools, a surplus -- without paying any price. Now the tax cuts can be accelerated, and we can battle international evil too. Though President Bush talks repeatedly of sacrifice required by the war effort, so far any tough sacrifices have been mainly borne by those directly affected by the attacks and by our all-volunteer armed forces. No one is demanding that the rest of us pay for serious airline or bioterror security, or that we cut down on gas-guzzling to reduce our dependency on the oil of Saudi Arabia, whose other big export is terrorists. Instead we are told to go shopping, take in a show, go to Disneyland. On this war's home front, "sacrifice" is easy-to-crack code for "vacation." 
Nor does the administration want to let too much bad news dampen the fun, unless it's absolutely unavoidable. In a month we've gone from Mr. Thompson's sunny spin on the first anthrax death to Tom Ridge's declaration this week that he's "hopeful" the threat is over. (Given our poor bioterror defense capability, "prayerful" is the mot juste.) Such is these men's credibility that the president had to ride to the rescue with a prime-time pep talk on homeland security Thursday night, albeit one dumped by three of the four major networks, who reverted to the old normal of "Survivor 3," "Family Guy" and "Friends." (Karl Rove travels to Hollywood this weekend to enlist sacrifice from show-biz moguls -- but he better not ask for it during the Nielsen sweeps.)
Even before Mr. Bush's speech, the mixture of political dawdling and official happy-talk that have undermined confidence in the war's home-front battles had started to taint perceptions of the war in Afghanistan. Most Americans are still patient -- it's only been a month. But armchair hawks, most of them in Mr. Bush's own party and echoed by the allegedly liberal press, are turning against the president's military campaign, faulting it for being too "dainty" to send in ground troops, for failing to take on Iraq and for what one of the more articulate critics, Robert Kagan of the Carnegie Endowment, calls its "eerie similarities with the early stages of the Vietnam War." 
Because of one major dissimilarity with Vietnam -- journalists have far less access to what is happening in Afghanistan than they did to the incipient quagmire in Southeast Asia -- such conclusions are speculative. But it's easy to make the case that one similarity between Vietnam and the war on terrorism is already nailed down: the light-at-the-end-of-the-tunnel syndrome. Much as Mr. Thompson defied scientific reality to portray the first skirmish with anthrax as an isolated incident, so the military seems inclined to sugar-coat the war against Al Qaeda -- even when what few facts we have stand in the way. 
The Taliban, whom officials initially predicted would implode or be overthrown once bombing began, have since been described as "eviscerated" (by Lt. Gen. Gregory Newbold, Oct. 16); "degraded and diminished" (Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, Oct. 25); and "on their heels" (the chairman of the Joint Chiefs, Gen. Richard Myers, last Sunday). Boy, that was easy -- the Taliban on the run, without a single American battle casualty, even before the battle of Mazar-i-Sharif. 
We're also repeatedly told that the vastly outnumbered Northern Alliance -- poorly equipped warriors "who farm or do odd jobs when not at the front," as The Los Angeles Times put it -- is an able proxy with or without shoes. Then there's that U.S. Special Operations raid on the lair of the Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, which "went flawlessly" and "accomplished our objectives" (per General Myers) but was a "near disaster" (according to Seymour Hersh in The New Yorker) netting scant intelligence (according to The Times). 
Like politicians' assertions that terrorism at home can be deflected by cheap fixes and oratorical optimism, disingenuous official claims of our allies' strengths and our enemies' weaknesses will come back to haunt the administration if all does not go smoothly. Already a Newsweek poll shows that only 56 percent of the country believes "the war in Afghanistan is going as well as American officials say."
In a week in which Rudy Giuliani has begun to fade from the scene, it's worth remembering that his wartime leadership was matchless because he leveled with us as much as possible, even when he was the bearer of the darkest news. Most of the visiting dignitaries from Washington seem to have forgotten this lesson the moment they finished posing at Ground Zero.

HEADLINE: To Rebuild a Place That Lost So Much 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "State Plans Rebuilding Agency, Perhaps Led by Giuliani" (news article, Nov. 3):
 The important value of preservation as a stabilizing force must be part of the discussion of redevelopment and growth. 
Preservation's track record for revving up the economic engine of rehabilitation through adaptive reuse of historic resources has given us SoHo and TriBeCa, two brilliantly successful Lower Manhattan neighborhoods. 
 Perhaps the agency's most crucial task is to recognize that architectural and cultural landmarks and the sense of place they create are the foundations upon which thriving cities are built. While we miss the towers, what we miss most is the sense of place they created, a thriving community that was a cultural and architectural landmark. 
To succeed, redevelopment must reweave the damaged threads of fabric that terrorism sought to tear apart, and create a sense of place that fills the void and honors the losses of Sept. 11.

HAL BROMM
President, Historic Districts Council
New York, Nov. 6, 2001

HEADLINE: To Rebuild a Place That Lost So Much

To the Editor:

 Rebuilding New York poses enormous challenges and creates an unprecedented opportunity to revitalize the economy and to make our community stronger and better than ever.

HEADLINE: Despite Mail Tumult, Pitney Bowes's Long-Term Outlook Is Strong 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Logically speaking, this should be a perilous time for Pitney Bowes. The combination of a recessionary economy and bioterrorism has caused mail volume to plummet. Postal rates are almost certain to rise, which will probably prod many businesses to switch even more of their mailings to the Internet or to private deliverers like Federal Express. Since Pitney makes most of its money from renting out postage meters and running mailrooms, Michael J. Critelli, Pitney's chief executive, should be sweating badly.
 He's not. 
 "The short-term downside of the tumult is fewer pieces of mail and fewer copies made," Mr. Critelli acknowledged. "But the upside is more interest in mailroom management and postage meters." 
Wall Street seems to agree. "There's been a near-term hit to mail volumes, but it'll be a temporary hit," predicted Benjamin A. Reitzes, a UBS Warburg analyst.
In October, Pitney told analysts that it would probably earn $2.35 to $2.40 a share this year, well below the $2.60 it had been predicting. Pitney's shares closed yesterday at $38.41 -- nowhere near the $44.70 they hit in August, but well above the $28 they sold at a year ago. Most analysts maintain a solid buy recommendation on the stock. 
"They seem to be viewing the anthrax scares as a nonissue," said Charles L. Hill, director of research at Thomson Financial/First Call.
Terrorism is not Pitney's only challenge, of course. The company, which is based in Stamford, Conn., commands 85 percent of the American postage meter market and 61 percent of the global market. But competition is heating up. 
Neopost Inc., the French company that is Pitney's main competitor overseas, just bought Ascom Hasler, a Swiss company, and together they command 25 percent of the global postage meter market. Francotyp-Postalia, a German company, is also nipping away at market share.
But Pitney is bulking up, too. It recently bought the French postage meter company Secap.
"Neopost is a strong competitor, but Pitney is making progress in profitability and share in Europe," said Deane M. Dray of Goldman, Sachs. 
Pitney can expect to have resources soon to expand overseas even more. Much of its debt carries variable interest rates, so it will be helped by recent cuts in rates. And it is about to spin its fax and copier business off to shareholders, leaving Pitney free to concentrate still more capital on overseas markets. Nor has postal chaos appreciably stymied Pitney's domestic prospects. Every time postal rates go up, Pitney's meter customers must pay the company to have meters recalibrated. And because customers rent the equipment on long-term contracts, Pitney has a protected stream of recurring revenues. 
But mainly, Mr. Critelli is not panicking because he has been preparing for a drop in mail revenue for quite some time. Many companies already use e-mail for routine correspondence and customer promotions, and many have switched to a distribute-and-print model -- e-mail a document, and let recipients print it out themselves -- for handbooks, contracts and other papers that formerly would have been sent by mail. 
Many banks and utilities already have systems in place giving customers access to their bills online, and enabling them to pay those bills either online, via telephone or through direct debits of their checking accounts. Some 5 million of American Express's 30 million cards, for example, are registered with the company's online site, giving cardholders the option of paying bills electronically. 
Earlier this month, Verizon unveiled a newly designed Web page that will make it easier for phone customers to pay bills online. 
"The timing was absolutely fortuitous, but this is the way the world was heading anyway," said James Smith, a Verizon spokesman. 
Pitney is heading that way, too. It already derives more than a quarter of its approximately $4 billion in annual revenue from nonmail-related services, and it expects that to hit 35 percent next year. One example is the online bill-paying system Pitney now administers for several customers. And the company recently acquired Alysis, which specializes in electronic payment systems. 
"Our new products have a very different value-add from the old ones," Mr. Critelli said. 
For now, though, mail-related products are still the revenue leaders for Pitney and its competitors. Not everyone has a home computer, and most people who do still use the postal system to pay bills. And catalog companies say that customers who order from their Web sites usually make their selections first from a paper catalog received in the mail. 
"The feedback we're getting from customers is that moving away from the mails is simply not an option," said Larry Turner, president of Francotyp-Postalia.
More episodes of mail-carried anthrax or other diseases could change that. But Pitney and its competitors may find business opportunities in the postal fears, too. 
Most report a much larger volume of queries from corporations looking to farm out the management of their mailrooms, or to have their mail processed off site. Many are pushing equipment that opens letters automatically and lets handlers see the contents without touching them. 
Francotyp-Postalia is working with several European companies to find ways to build biosensors and decontamination technology into equipment that sorts and opens mail. 
Xerox Business Services is working on a technology that would enable post offices to receive mail electronically and print it out on site. "The carrier and the recipient would have the comfort of knowing the letter was generated in a secure environment," said Richard J. Leo, the Xerox unit's vice president.
Pitney, Neopost and Franco-Postalia are all offering digital meters that include information about the sender along with postage, as well as using codes that enable mail to be tracked and located at any time. Such monitoring capabilities may provide a comfort level that could increase the use of metered mail. 
"There's a tug of war between two dynamics -- potentially lower mail volumes, and a shift to metered mail and mailroom management," said Jonathan Rosenzweig, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney. "The short-term implications for Pitney are negative, but long term, they're positive."
