HEADLINE: Regulators Struggle With a Marketplace Created by Enron 

BYLINE:  By JEFF GERTH with RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 

 BODY:
For years, the Enron Corporation used its political muscle to build the markets in which it thrived, pushing relentlessly on Capitol Hill and in bureaucratic backwaters to deregulate the nation's natural gas and electricity businesses.
 Its achievement, as one Enron executive said today, in creating a "regulatory black hole" fit nicely with what he called the company's "core management philosophy, which was to be the first mover into a market and to make money in the initial chaos and lack of transparency." 
 Now, Wall Street's dissatisfaction with Enron's secretive ways has delivered the company into the arms of its much smaller Houston rival, Dynegy Inc., in a deal worth about $9 billion in stock and the assumption of $13 billion in debt. The combination of the two companies, energy experts and lawmakers said today, poses a novel set of challenges for regulators still struggling to grasp the complexities of the marketplace that Enron invented.
"We're in a supersonic-speed era of electronic trading with a horse-and-buggy-era regulatory system to protect consumers," said Representative Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat who has devised legislation to close the regulatory gap. 
Dynegy's acquisition of Enron is expected to be reviewed by numerous state and federal agencies, led by the Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.
Analysts said today that sharp scrutiny would be given to the combined companies' holdings in California, where Dynegy owns generating plants and Enron controls a large part of the market for trading natural gas -- the fuel for a big share of the state's electric power plants.
"Dynegy would now have a greater ability to take the dominant position in gas and raise the price of electricity," said Frank Wolak, a professor of economics at Stanford University.
Mr. Wolak, a consultant to the Justice Department on a 1999 antitrust case that led to limits on another merger of electricity and natural gas companies in Southern California, said he was skeptical that regulators were up to the task of reviewing today's deal.
The transaction "is something the Department of Justice needs to look at, and they are going to have a hard time looking at," Mr. Wolak said. "And it's beyond the ability of the F.E.R.C. to look at."
Pat Wood -- named chairman of the federal energy commission earlier this year with the backing of Kenneth L. Lay, the chairman of Enron -- acknowledged in an interview today that the agency had "a long way to go" in matching the sophistication of the companies it regulates.
But he said that the commission had made great strides in grappling with the new risk management techniques pioneered by Enron, Dynegy and other energy companies. It is hiring more experts, he said, adopting more restrictive rules on how much "market power" one party can control and requiring more disclosure of certain energy transactions.
In an interview this evening, Charles L. Watson, the chairman of Dynegy, said he did not believe that regulators reviewing the deal with Enron would require the sale of any assets. "We haven't really identified any pitfalls that require any sort of asset divestiture," he said. "There's not really any overlap." 
A senior executive at one of Enron's largest energy-trading rivals disagreed. "I don't think this deal gets through unscathed," he said today. "I'm sure the Justice Department and the F.T.C. will look closely at the pretty substantial concentration of market power these companies will have in the energy-trading area." 
Enron is mainly a trader of natural gas and electricity -- indeed, the biggest player in both those markets -- and it also owns a network of gas pipelines. Dynegy processes and sells natural gas and generates and sells electricity. Each company owns a local electric utility, too: Dynegy owns Illinois Power in Decatur, Ill., while Enron owns Portland General Electric in Portland, Ore., but last month announced plans to sell it to another Oregon utility.
For a decade, as it transformed itself from a gas pipeline operator into the nation's biggest energy trader, Enron enjoyed unalloyed lobbying success in Washington and the enthusiastic backing of Wall Street. 
In the early months of the Bush administration, Mr. Lay -- whose company was one of the biggest financial backers of George W. Bush's presidential campaign -- played a prominent, and some said unusual, role in helping the White House pick nominees to the federal energy commission. Enron executives met with Vice President Dick Cheney, whose energy task force backed many of the deregulatory initiatives pushed by Mr. Lay.
Now, "the company has become a pariah," an Enron executive said today. "The Bush administration doesn't want to have anything to do with us."
The problems began with the energy crisis in California, where Enron's outspoken defense of deregulation, even more than its electricity trading activities, made the company a favorite whipping boy of politicians and consumer advocates. In the financial markets, meanwhile, Enron's confusing disclosures, tolerated when its stock was soaring, drew disdain as the calming of the energy storms in California and other parts of the country beat the shares down, starting last spring.
"Enron fell victim to their own inconsistencies on transparency," Mr. Wolak said. As California officials sought to understand why energy prices had soared out of control, he said, Enron's "view was that we want everybody's data, but if you want ours, get a subpoena."
Energy executives and regulators said that sort of arrogance had long marked Enron's attitude about government oversight.
Electricity sales had for decades been the job of local utility companies, operating as monopolies and selling power at regulated rates within their service areas. A few entrepreneurs, led by Mr. Lay, conceived a different model in which power could be sold by generators or middlemen to big corporate users or utilities in faraway regions, at whatever price the market would bear.
In the early 1990's, Congress -- under heavy lobbying by Enron -- passed legislation that began to open up electricity sales to marketers. Before long, Enron became one of the first companies to receive government approval to sell electricity at market rates. The market for interstate sales of natural gas had been freed up a few years earlier, and critics complained that traders like Enron were gleaning their profits by stoking volatility in gas prices.
In the mid-1990's, independent gas producers backed legislation in Congress to allow the creation of a co-operative marketing organization, which, they hoped, would have helped stabilize prices.
Raymond Plank, the chairman of the Apache Corporation, a gas producer based in Houston, said that the big gas marketing and trading companies, including Enron, successfully lobbied to kill the plan, leaving prices as volatile as ever. 
"It was a great concept," Mr. Plank said. "We could have headed off the problems we have today."
Enron's final lobbying success came last year. With a strong push from the company's lobbyists, Congress passed futures trading legislation that exempted Internet energy trading platforms like EnronOnline, the industry leader, from oversight by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Enron takes the other side of trades on its exchange. In traditional markets like the New York Mercantile Exchange, which remain subject to oversight, the exchange acts as a middleman between buyers and sellers.
Under Mr. Watson, Dynegy has been less of a pathbreaker than Enron, and though California politicians denounced it, too, as a profiteer during the energy crisis, most analysts say it has been less aggressive than Enron in both its business practices and its lobbying.
Indeed, the rival energy-trading executive today predicted "a huge culture clash" as the Houston neighbors merge. "Blood will flow in Houston over the integration of the trading operation," he said.
But regulators may find Dynegy easier to deal with.
Earlier this year, the federal energy commission asked for comments on whether it should tighten scrutiny of dealings between natural gas pipelines and energy-trading shops owned by the same company.
Enron wondered what all the bother was. "Would stricter rules prevent real affiliate abuse that current rules do not," it wrote in a regulatory filing, "or would they instead merely restrict the activities of some of the more successful participants in the marketplace?"
Dynegy, by contrast, painted a grim picture and invited regulators to crack down. "Abuses abound," it said, "because of financial windfalls, difficulty of detection, lengthy investigations and increased complexity of the market."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Argentine Chief Tells Wall St. That Debt Swap Is Best Course

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
President Fernando de la Rua of Argentina went before Wall Street investors yesterday to defend his plan for rescuing the country's weakening economy, saying a debt swap was the best way to keep Argentina solvent.
 Although critics see the move as a sign that a default is imminent, Mr. de la Rua pledged that Argentina would find a way to pay off its staggering debt load and emerge from recession. 
 "Argentina has always honored and will continue to honor its obligations," he said in a speech to about 300 investors and analysts. 
Mr. de la Rua, who had met earlier with William J. McDonough, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said he was not in the United States to ask for money.
"We have come to explain the situation," he said.
The debt swap, which calls on investors to accept lower interest payments and postpones full payment by three years, would be the largest such restructuring.
Mr. de la Rua said devaluing Argentina's currency would be disastrous to the economy. He also said he would overcome opposition by powerful governors to a domestic plan to balance the country's budget.
On Thursday, the governors of the opposition Peronist Party refused to accept less money from the national government as part of the cost-cutting program. Without offering details, Mr. de la Rua predicted that the governors would change their minds.
The standoff over billions of dollars in tax revenue threatens the government's access to a $22 billion international rescue package.
Only eight governors from Mr. de la Rua's ruling coalition, along with one independent, have signed on to the plan. That is far short of the unanimous bipartisan support he will need to convince the International Monetary Fund and international lenders that Argentina is serious about deficit reduction.
In trading yesterday in Buenos Aires, the Merval index of leading shares fell 2.6 percent, to 228.36. Since July 1, the index has fallen 44 percent.
On Sunday, Mr. de la Rua and President Bush are scheduled to discuss the plan to reorganize Argentina's $132 billion debt. Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, has said that Argentina must carry out plans to end deficit spending and that Mr. Bush will probably tell Mr. de la Rua that.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home; 
Ideology As Usual

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
George W. Bush has focused effectively on the need for an international alliance against terrorism. But he has not yet understood what a wartime president has to do at home: Put aside ideological politics so he can be president of all the people. 
 With his evident approval, the ideologues in his administration are riding their conservative hobbyhorses as if the country did not have a higher purpose now. They, and the president, seem oblivious to the way those actions threaten national unity. 
 A striking example is the decision by Attorney General John Ashcroft this week to try to overrule the voters of Oregon and undo that state's assisted-suicide law. He said he would move to revoke the drug prescription license of any Oregon doctor who used drugs to help someone who wanted to die. 
Mr. Ashcroft is a fervent opponent of abortion and, like many social and religious conservatives, sees any state sanction of suicide in the same light. His decision this week was praised by the National Right to Life Committee. 
In terms of states' rights, which conservatives say they support, the Ashcroft decision was rank hypocrisy. He asserted federal power in an area that has always been pre-eminently a matter for state law, the regulation of medical practice. Oregonians approved the assisted-suicide law narrowly in a referendum in 1994 and reaffirmed it in 1996 by a 60-to-40 margin. Even some who had opposed the law reacted bitterly to Mr. Ashcroft's intrusion on Oregon territory. 
In another strange example of his priorities, Mr. Ashcroft last month sent federal agents to raid a Los Angeles center that supplied marijuana to desperately ill people under a state law allowing medical use. Does a wartime Justice Department really have nothing better to do than deprive cancer and AIDS patients of relief from their pain? 
Two weeks ago the British government decided to stop arresting marijuana users, adopting the policy now followed by most European governments. The U.S. law against users has not changed, but Mr. Ashcroft has discretion to use Justice Department resources where they are most urgently needed -- especially in a war situation.
The attorney general has heavy responsibilities on the domestic side of the fight against terrorism. He is in charge of the hunt for supporters of the Sept. 11 terrorists, and for the spreaders of anthrax. Pursuing his ideological desires can only divide the public and weaken respect for the administration's antiterrorist effort. 
Mr. Ashcroft is the most egregious example of an official unable or unwilling to curb his ideological zealotry at this time. But he is not the only one. 
The environment is another area where the Bush administration is pursuing highly controversial policies despite the country's preoccupation with the terrorist threat. Indeed, Secretary of the Interior Gale Norton and Secretary of Agriculture Ann Veneman are taking advantage of that preoccupation to push through ripper measures while no one is paying attention. 
The device being used is an ingenious one: caving in to lawsuits by interests that object to restraints on environmental damage. One such suit asks the courts to block a Clinton administration regulation that would stop further road-building in 60 million pristine acres of the national forests. The Bush administration has simply put up no defense of the regulation in court. 
The administration is also trying to scuttle a Clinton regulation that would gradually end the use of snowmobiles in Yellowstone National Park: a rule that the public overwhelmingly approves. When snowmobile manufacturers sued, the Bush people agreed to "reconsider" the regulation. 
Finally, there is the reeking scandal of the so-called economic stimulus bill passed by the House. It would give some of the largest corporations refunds for taxes paid over many years in the past: $671 million to General Electric, according to Citizens for Tax Justice, and $1.4 billion to I.B.M. Making the rich richer will do little to stimulate the economy, and less to stimulate our patriotism. 
During World War II, President Franklin Roosevelt publicly put aside his domestic objectives for the sake of the war. Dr. New Deal, he said, had to give way to Dr. Win-the-War. It is time for President Bush to curb his zealots and focus us all on the struggle against terrorism.

HEADLINE: Upstate Republicans in House Join Democrats in Fight for More Money for New York 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 

 BODY:
New York Republicans appear headed toward a showdown with the Bush administration and Republican leaders in the House, demanding billions of dollars in additional federal aid to help New York rebuild from the terrorist attack.
 In a rare alliance, New York Republicans are siding with their Democratic colleagues in the House, potentially provoking a confrontation that could force Republican leaders on the Hill and the Bush administration to support added spending for New York. 
 The fight is over the $20 billion that President Bush promised to give New York in the days after the attack. The administration and its Republican allies in Congress have been disbursing the money in installments, saying that New York will get the money as it is needed. 
But for several weeks now, many House Democrats from New York have been questioning whether the administration and Congressional leaders can be trusted to follow through on the president's commitment without public pressure.
Now, these Democrats are being joined by leading New York Republicans, who are not hurling accusations the way Democrats have but who are bent on achieving the same goal: getting New York the money it was promised.
The bipartisan effort took shape when Democrats secured the support of two upstate New York Republicans on the House Appropriations Committee: Representatives James Walsh and John Sweeney.
The two say they are prepared to join Democrats on the Appropriations Committee to push through a measure that would provide $9 billion to $11 billion in additional aid for New York next week.
At the same time, members of New York's Congressional delegation are hoping to enlist Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, both Republicans, to lobby the president directly when he visits New York this weekend.
To date, New York has been given about $9.2 billion of the $20 billion that President Bush promised. But New York lawmakers are worried that the White House and Congress will stall on the rest, particularly because Washington suddenly has to pay for antiterrorism measures and a war in Afghanistan, as the national economy begins to slump.
In an interview this afternoon, Mr. Walsh made it clear that he wanted more than just words of reassurance that New York would get the whole $20 billion.
Mr. Walsh noted that the money was supposed to come out of a $40 billion package that the president and Congress approved immediately after the Sept. 11 attacks in New York and Washington to help pay for disaster relief, military actions and counterterrorism measures.
Mr. Walsh said he decided to force the issue after it became clear to him that New York would get no more than the $9.2 billion that it had already received. "What we're saying is, 'Mr. President, here are the funds you need to keep your commitment to New York,' " he said. "We have to do this."
The developments provided a rare display of unity for New York's delegation, whose members have been on different, if not competing, tracks in the effort to extract additional aid from Washington. In particular, New York lawmakers have been at odds over whether to take the White House to task publicly for not delivering the entire $20 billion.
One faction of the delegation -- primarily the state's two Democratic senators, Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton -- had taken a more conciliatory approach in dealing with the White House, believing that words of encouragement, not criticism, would do more good to move the administration in New York's direction, particularly in this time of national mourning.
But today, both senators threw their support behind the bipartisan effort that their New York colleagues were undertaking in the House. "We have always argued that we should get as much of the $20 billion" as New York needs, Mrs. Clinton said.
Mr. Schumer said, "I think it's great that they are doing this."
The move by Mr. Sweeney and Mr. Walsh came after mounting frustration among some New York Republicans in the House. Privately, they had been arguing that they had helped deliver a crucial victory for Mr. Bush when the House narrowly rejected a Democratic bill to turn 28,000 baggage handlers and passenger screeners into federal workers. Some were hoping their loyalty would be rewarded.
Mr. Sweeney and Mr. Walsh plan to introduce their measure as an amendment to a $20 billion antiterrorism package that the Appropriations Committee is expected to take up next week. President Bush has threatened to veto such a measure.
The amendment includes $9 billion for the Federal Emergency Management Agency to pay for reconstruction efforts in Lower Manhattan, among other things. The amendment also provides another $2 billion in mandatory spending for unemployment insurance, workers compensation and the extension of so-called Cobra health insurance benefits.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE HOME FRONT; 
After Asking for Volunteers, Government Tries to Determine What They Will Do

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 

 BODY:
A day after President Bush asked Americans to respond to the war on terror with an outpouring of volunteerism, his administration began trying to figure out how to mobilize a vast force of Americans for a still sketchy role on the home front battlefield.
 Mr. Bush gave a task force on citizen preparedness, run by his homeland security and domestic policy advisers, 40 days to recommend ways for Americans to help with civilian tasks. 
 Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, said today at a White House briefing, "There is an inventory of things we believe we can give America to choose from to help us in this battle against terrorism." 
In an interview, Mr. Ridge said some of his ideas included drawing on the expertise of retired police officers and asking retired physicians to train disaster personnel and retired nurse practitioners to learn new emergency skills.
"We just have to identify those who have the greatest potential for service and go recruit," Mr. Ridge said.
He said he was also talking to the national Ad Council about helping to "inform and inspire" people to join such efforts.
In World War II, it was clear how Americans would wage the war at home: through gasoline and food rationing, tin foil drives, victory gardens and buying war bonds. Women entered the industrial work force, and all the steps made a crucial difference. President Franklin D. Roosevelt in a fireside chat called such efforts "the privilege of making whatever self-denial is necessary."
Now a debate has been rising over exactly how much sacrifice is really needed and how those at home should respond to what Mr. Bush calls "a different kind of conflict."
Mr. Bush can easily explain what that means in military terms: "It's a war that matches high-technology weapons with people on horseback," he said today. But many officials say it is less clear how people can respond at home to a conflict that may be more akin to the cold war.
Some commentators are even arguing for national conscription for the military and for homeland defense efforts like border patrol. Others by contrast say that a wartime mentality of sacrifice and a radical change in the way Americans live would mean that terrorists had won. Mr. Bush himself said much the same thing on Thursday night.
Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, expressed that view this way: "There are certain sacrifices we have to be prepared to make, but it's not like we need to be given something to do. Au contraire. The best thing you can do to defeat this enemy is live your normal life, because it will do two important things: keep the economic train running and it will demoralize the enemy more than the enemy would demoralize you."
Mr. Ridge said today that it was "a little bit misleading" to look to World War II as a model for today's homeland security effort.
"We had an economy, a country that was struggling economically, on its way out of depression," he said, "and we didn't have surplus resources so there was the need to ration meat and sugar. It's a little bit different today."
He said that Americans willing to volunteer now were, in fact, making a sacrifice. 
"They are taking time away from their family and their profession," he said. "That's a significant contribution."
Some of the impulse for the volunteer effort is to keep national spirit up and provide a role for Americans who want to do more than display their patriotism by flying and shopping again. Mr. Bush's advisers said it would be demoralizing if they could not find a way to harness the energies of Americans who want to help. Other political figures say it could also undermine the war effort if Americans become disengaged.
"People are going to have to get involved in this," said George Christian, who was President Lyndon B. Johnson's press secretary at the end of his term in some of the bitterest days of the Vietnam War. "So far it's a government effort, as it should be, but people aren't engaged."
Part of the federal government's task if it is to mobilize a vast homeland volunteer effort is to find ways to train people for their roles and to create an emergency structure for them to report to. New York City eventually had to send all but the most skilled and essential volunteers away from ground zero.
Stephen Goldsmith, the chairman of the Corporation for National and Community Service, which oversees the AmeriCorps and Senior Corps programs, said today that training, recruiting and managing volunteers was difficult to do well. Mr. Bush asked the corporation to start homeland security efforts in public safety, public health and disaster preparedness.
Mr. Goldsmith said the expansion in the ranks of the national service programs proposed by Mr. Bush might allow the corporation to use its enlistees in national service to manage other volunteers for public health and security efforts. "The goal here would be to leverage numbers," he said.
But others say volunteerism is insufficient for the times. "We're in a war," said Charles Moskos, a sociology professor at Northwestern University, "and this is the first time in American history that we have a serious war going on without a draft." Dr. Moskos dismissed Mr. Bush's call for volunteerism as "patriotism on the cheap."
In a recent article in The Washington Monthly, Mr. Moskos and a co-author, Paul Glastris, contended that a new draft would focus less on raising conscripts for the military than on enlisting men and women for such tasks as border patrol, tracking immigrants and guarding dams, nuclear power plants and sports complexes.
But many officials believe a draft would be too unpopular and that it would bring in more people than needed.
Representative Christopher Shays, Republican of Connecticut, who has long been a proponent of national service programs, said, "I believe the government needs to provide opportunities for people who want to be of service, but I'm not at the point where I think that should be mandatory."
Asked about mandatory national service, Mr. Ridge said: "You just don't put a volunteer out on the border. There are certain levels of law enforcement where you really want professionals involved."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tom Ridge, director of homeland security, said there was "an inventory of things" volunteers could do to help in the battle against terrorism. (Scott Robinson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Negotiators Push to Settle World Treaty On Warming 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
With momentum building for a treaty curbing global warming, delegates from 164 countries, cloistered in a convention center in Morocco, negotiated late into the night yesterday to resolve several lingering disputes. 
 If completed and enacted, the treaty, the Kyoto Protocol, would set the first firm restrictions on the amount of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases released by industrialized countries. 
 "We're in a state of hard negotiations, with everyone delivering a huge effort to find an agreement," said Vincent Georis, a spokesman for Olivier DeLeuze, the head of the European Union delegation, in a telephone interview from Marrakech.
The outlook for the treaty was substantially dimmed in March when President Bush rejected it, reversing the position taken by President Bill Clinton, whose administration negotiated the outlines of the accord in Japan in 1997. The United States, with 5 percent of the world's population, accounts for a fourth of all emissions of the so-called greenhouse gases, mainly carbon dioxide. 
Still, climate experts and government officials said that even without participation from the United States, adoption of the treaty would be a small but significant first step toward limiting the human impact on the atmosphere. 
"If this holds together, it is a piece of architecture in place and it is quite an achievement to get this far," said Dr. Henry D. Jacoby, co-director of the Joint Program on the Science and Policy of Global Change at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Most climate scientists say that a buildup of greenhouse gases in recent decades has contributed to a worldwide warming trend that could lead to droughts, floods and agricultural disruption, particularly in developing countries.
The treaty aims to introduce the first global trading system for greenhouse gas credits. The system would allow countries that surpassed targets for reducing emissions to sell extra credits to countries that lagged, creating an incentive to make the deepest cuts wherever they could be done at the lowest cost.
But big issues remain, Dr. Jacoby said, especially the challenge of fostering international environmental and economic cooperation without the United States -- the biggest economy and polluter. 
"How will we proceed when we have a fragmented system with us and perhaps others on the outside?" he said. "How does that evolve?"
A series of compromises, particularly between the European Union on the one hand and Russia, Japan, Canada and Australia on the other, cleared the way for a final push last night, according to some environmental experts. 
Remaining issues included how much credit Russia should get toward its emissions goals for the role its vast forests play in absorbing carbon dioxide.
Europe, the bloc most firmly fighting for the treaty, still differed with Japan over whether countries should first be required to accept the treaty as legally binding before they could buy and sell emissions credits.
Another issue involves Saudi Arabia and other oil exporting countries that want compensation for any lost revenue should countries reduce their use of fossil fuels.
Even with this workload, many delegates and observers said last night that they felt confident they would find agreement by today. 
The goal of many negotiators was to settle on language that satisfied enough countries to enact the treaty next year, the 10th anniversary of the Rio Earth Summit, where the first climate treaty was forged. To gain legal force, it must be ratified by at least 55 countries, including a group responsible for at least 55 percent of the heat-trapping emissions from industrialized countries in 1990. 
If that happens, the treaty will require by 2012 that participating industrialized countries cut emissions of carbon dioxide and similar warming gases about 5 percent below their levels in 1990.
With the United States on the sidelines, the support of Japan and Russia is crucial for ratification.
The Kyoto Protocol was framed as a successor to a 1992 climate treaty -- signed by Mr. Bush's father and approved unanimously by the Senate -- that set voluntary goals for greenhouse-gas reductions by industrial powers, but failed to come close to its target.
The Clinton administration sought to complete the treaty last year, but talks at the Hague last November fell apart. The issue then fell to Mr. Bush, who had long questioned the science pointing to human-caused global warming and was heavily lobbied by energy companies to reject it outright. 
When he did reject it, he said the pact could harm the economy and was unfair because the required emissions cuts applied only to industrial powers and not to fast-growing developing countries.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: DIPLOMACY; 
PAKISTANI LEADER SEEKS 'GESTURES' FOR BACKING U.S.

BYLINE:  By SERGE SCHMEMANN and PATRICK E. TYLER 

 BODY:
President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan said yesterday that he has come to the United States in search of major gestures from the Bush administration, including the release of American F-16 fighters sold to Pakistan when it was an ally against the Soviet Union and then withheld because of the country's development of nuclear weapons.
 In an interview with The New York Times, General Musharraf, who is in New York for the United Nations General Assembly, said he would be asking President Bush at their meeting on Saturday for concrete "gestures" in response to Pakistan's strong support in the campaign against terrorism. 
 The general said he could not predict how long the bombing campaign could continue before the opposition within Pakistan became a threat to his government. He said he felt the intensity of demonstrations was actually diminishing. 
But he said "visible gestures" of gratitude from the United States would help blunt public criticism of his decision to ally his country strongly with Washington. He placed special emphasis on the F-16's, because their arrival would be the most visible sign that the United States was restoring Pakistan to the stature of a genuine ally. 
Pakistan purchased 28 F-16's in the 1980's, but their delivery was blocked when Congress cut off all aid and military sales in 1990, citing Pakistan's secret nuclear-weapons development.
General Musharraf noted that the planes were paid for, and Pakistan was even sent a bill for their storages in Arizona. 
General Musharraf took power in a coup two years ago and had until Sept. 11 been kept at an icy distance by Washington as both the Clinton and Bush administrations tilted toward a strategic relationship with Pakistan's neighbor and longtime rival, India
The general was not reticent in voicing his grievance with this treatment. "Pakistan certainly desires a longstanding and sustainable relationship with the United States," he said, adding that "trust has to be built." 
Asked whose fault it was, he said, "as a Pakistani, I have to say the fault lies with the United States."
General Musharraf said there was a widespread sense that Washington abandoned Pakistan as soon as the Soviet Union pulled out of Afghanistan in 1989, and then applied economic sanctions when Pakistan developed nuclear weapons in response to India's nuclear program and both countries tested them in May 1998.
"The main issue is we were part of a coalition," he said. "We fought a war together and evicted the Soviet Union from Afghanistan."
The country's previous experience with the United States as an ally in the cold war, he said, had left the public "not very happy" and needing to "wash off their previous attitudes."
Asked whether he felt slighted by Washington and by the Indian prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, he hesitated and said, "Well, sometimes, yes." He said this was understandable because he was a military man who had seized power.
The gestures that would reverse these wrongs, he said, should include major debt relief, military assistance, and more understanding for the sensitivity of the Pakistani public on the issue of its nuclear weapons.
"The opinion of the people of Pakistan has to be molded, and it can be done through gestures," he said.
The general spoke as reports came that Mazar-i-Sharif in northern Afghanistan had fallen to the Northern Alliance. He commended the victory and said he had no reservations if the American-led coalition decided to set up a forward air base at the airfield near the town.
But he added that he was worried that the military victory had come when there still no broad-based coalition in the making to replace the Taliban if their grip on power dissolves. That problem would become more acute, he suggested, if and when the Northern Alliance began moving into Pashtun territory, where the Taliban has its strength, and especially into the capital, Kabul. Mazar-i-Sharif's population is predominantly Uzbek.
"I'm worried that Kabul should not be militarized because of the atrocities committed in the city," he said, alluding to the last time the Northern Alliance was in control of the city in 1996.
General Musharraf acknowledged that Pakistan bore a major responsibility in the efforts to forge a military alternative to the Taliban, but that this was still a work in progress. He said Afghans had been meeting in Islamabad and Peshawar to try to try to find some formula for a broad-based ethnic administration.
"There's no alternative on the Pashtun side," he said, referring to the dominant ethnic group in Afghanistan. "The ideal situation," he said, would be the creation of a Pashtun-dominated southern alliance that could displace the Taliban and counterbalance the Northern Alliance.
The search for such a coalition has been a major preoccupation of the United States and its allies, and of the special United Nations representative for Afghanistan, Lakhdar Brahimi, who returned yesterday from a fact-finding tour of the region.
Mr. Brahimi will be meeting with American and other leaders at the United Nations over the next week, and is expected to get a strong endorsement of his efforts from the Security Council.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell is expected to meet on Monday morning with Mr. Brahimi and representatives of the states on Afghanistan's borders.
The formation of a post-Taliban administration has become a central goal of the Bush administration and the United Nations as the bombing campaign increasingly clears the way for a push on Kabul.
In an unusual and forthright appeal, General Musharraf said Pakistan is more than willing to accept assistance from the United States to render Pakistan's nuclear arsenal more secure. But he added that reports emanating from the United States that the Pentagon may have plans to "pinch" or "neutralize" Pakistan's nuclear weapons to prevent them from falling into the hands of Islamic extremists "has a very negative impact on the public mind."
He reaffirmed that Pakistan's nuclear weapons are under "very strong custodial control."
The Bush administration has been debating how it could offer such assistance without passing on information that might improve the design or reliability of Pakistan's small arsenal.
A number of specialists favor offering "personnel reliability" programs to Pakistan nuclear commanders along with high technology security systems to physically guard the weapons and the highly enriched uranium that forms their cores.

HEADLINE: Trade Talks Hinge on Finesse of U.S. 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: DOHA, Qatar, Nov. 9 

 BODY:
With one of his first decisions as President Bush's chief trade negotiator, Robert B. Zoellick last spring quickly set himself apart from colleagues in the Bush cabinet who were eagerly overturning Clinton administration policies on everything from arsenic levels in drinking water to mining on public lands.
 When American pharmaceutical companies pressured Mr. Zoellick to do something about African nations' practice of buying generic knockoffs of popular AIDS drugs, he stood firm. Bush administration officials, he told them, had no intention of pursuing a trade policy that was "out of touch with our values." 
 Mr. Zoellick was convinced that such a policy change could lead to trouble, and it turns out he was right. A dispute over patent enforcement, dividing the richer North and the poorer South, is dominating world trade talks this weekend. Mr. Zoellick's diplomatic efforts at the sessions, held in this Persian Gulf emirate, are viewed by many as vital to preventing the issue from halting the negotiations completely.
The 48-year-old trade representative is trying simultaneously to assert firm American leadership -- President Bush said a successful conclusion here would foster more openness and strike a blow against terrorism -- while pursuing narrower American interests.
A key American goal is to persuade nations to agree to talk about freeing up cross-border sales of farm goods and services, including everything from mutual funds to environmental engineering. At the same time, Mr. Zoellick will be trying to repel a campaign by poor countries to pry open the American textile market and a Japan-led effort to review the use of antidumping rules to fend off low-priced imports.
"We are expected to be the leader, and the leader sometimes has to be tough," Mr. Zoellick (pronounced ZELL-ik) said in an interview. "But you are almost always more effective if you use your strength with discretion and grace."
It is too soon to tell if Mr. Zoellick will prevail here; the talks are scheduled to run through Tuesday and the outcome remains uncertain. But if the talks fail, few will blame Mr. Zoellick for lacking zeal -- or for not doing his homework.
To prepare for the meetings here, Mr. Zoellick dissected what went wrong in Seattle two years ago, when trade talks collapsed. He recently took home a RAND Corporation study of how negotiating styles vary across cultures. The secret, he suggests, is knowing when to cajole and when to harangue. One American trade official calls the strategy "an iron fist in a velvet glove."
Mr. Zoellick also worked to build a strong alliance with the European trade commissioner, Pascal Lamy, while mending strained relations with leaders of the developing world, including Malaysia, Indonesia, India and several African countries. He has courted the trade minister of Kenya in Swahili; he has badgered Japan to play a more cooperative role with the unusually blunt demand that the country practice "respectful followership."
The intensity that Mr. Zoellick has brought to these tasks is reminiscent of his work in helping to broker German reunification and the North American Free Trade Agreement a decade ago as a member of the first Bush administration. Though he is known for having a temper, Mr. Zoellick has begun to develop the political ear he needs to complement the skills he honed as a behind-the-scenes tactician for former Secretary of State James A. Baker III.
That political touch has perhaps served him well in dealing with the drug patents issue, his toughest test so far. India and Brazil have led the charge to insert a public health exemption in patent rules, a concept that appeals to African leaders who struggle to pay for Western drugs.
The United States and other industrialized countries fear that the exemption could undermine the whole patent system, but their case was perceived as having been harmed when American and Canadian officials last month pressured Bayer to reduce the price of the suddenly popular anti-anthrax drug Cipro.
Having already staked out an accommodating stance on African nations buying cheaper AIDS drugs, Mr. Zoellick worked quickly to defuse the issue. He offered to make the least developed African countries exempt from patent rules as they apply to pandemic diseases until they become much wealthier. He has also spent hours consulting African ministers on all issues under discussion in Doha, talking to people, as one trade official put it, "who hadn't heard from an American cabinet secretary in a decade."
The idea was to drive a wedge between them and India and Brazil, two countries that American trade officials say have a commercial, rather than moral, reason for wanting to weaken protections for patents. They have big generic drug industries that would like to be able to sell more goods abroad.
The overall message: this is not a unified South against an unrelenting North.
"This idea of the South does not show the vast diversity of the developing world," Mr. Zoellick said. "When you listen, be respectful, put yourself in their shoes, you can solve a lot of problems."
While trying to divide the membership of the South, he is also working to unify the North. The two biggest trading powers, the United States and Europe, did not cooperate much leading up to the Seattle talks. Now, Mr. Zoellick and Mr. Lamy, his European counterpart, act like best friends.
The two have spent a weekend discussing trade at Mr. Zoellick's home on the Potomac River near Washington. Leading up to the Doha meeting, they spoke on the telephone nearly every day, sometimes for up to three hours. Both runners, they swap tips on marathon training.
The Atlantic powers are still on opposite sides on agricultural trade, with Europe fighting to maintain an elaborate support network for farmers. And the United States has remained agnostic on Europe's push to get the World Trade Organization to consider imposing standards on investment and competition.
Yet in contrast to the ideological grandstanding in Seattle, the United States and Europe appear to have settled most of their differences privately. It is no magic formula, but Mr. Zoellick is betting that a subtle change in the "tone of trade" can provide the lift needed to get global negotiations off the ground.

HEADLINE: Benefits Panel Plans Array Of Choices For Solvency 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 

 BODY:
The co-chairmen of President Bush's Social Security commission said today that they intended to set out a number of alternative plans for achieving the administration's goal of creating personal investment accounts within the retirement system rather than present a single proposal.
 The co-chairmen, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the former Democratic senator from New York, and Richard D. Parsons, co-chief operating officer of AOL Time Warner, said that offering multiple ideas would allow the administration and the public a chance to study the pros and cons of different approaches. 
 The commission is scheduled to complete its work next month.
Critics of the administration's push to create private accounts said the decision on multiple approaches appeared to reflect wariness on the part of the White House about embracing the details of any particular proposal less than a year from the midterm Congressional elections. Nearly all plans to shore up Social Security include benefit cuts and other politically unpopular steps that could put Mr. Bush and his fellow Republicans on the defensive. 
Until the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, Mr. Bush had planned to make overhauling Social Security a top priority. He had suggested that he wanted the commission to come up with a detailed plan that he could use to sell Congress and voters on the merits of allowing workers to invest part of their Social Security payroll taxes in stocks and bonds.
But with the country at war, the economy deteriorating and Washington working at bipartisanship, members of the commission acknowledged that Mr. Bush was unlikely to wage an aggressive campaign in the coming year to win legislative approval for private accounts. 
Social Security will come under increasing financial pressure in coming decades as the baby boom generation retires and life expectancies continue to rise. Without any changes, the system will need to start redeeming the government bonds it holds in 2016 and will run short of cash to pay full benefits starting in 2037.
Mr. Moynihan said the decision to propose multiple ways of creating private accounts was not dictated by the White House, and primarily reflected a recognition within the committee that different approaches had different strengths and weaknesses.
"There are perfectly reasonable views that are not quite the same," Mr. Moynihan said. 
Mr. Parsons said the commission would come up with "a set of recommendations, each of which raises different policy issues but any of which enhance the fiscal soundness of the system."
Liberal groups that have been fighting the idea of personal investment accounts said the commission's decision not to put its weight behind a single, detailed proposal reflected a fundamental problem with Social Security privatization: it sounds good in general terms but requires such painful cuts in benefits to make the numbers add up that its proponents are forced to obscure the trade-offs.
Only when the administration embraces a specific plan will people be able to judge what they would be asked to give up in the way of guaranteed old-age benefits in return for the right to invest some of their taxes on Wall Street. The liberal groups say cuts in guaranteed benefits could be as high as 40 percent.
"Issuing a menu of options rather than a specific plan is an attempt to muddy the waters so that the public does not have a clear position to accept or reject," said Hans Riemer of the Institute for America's Future, an advocacy group that opposes personal accounts.
Advocates of personal accounts said their approach would leave retirees better off than under any other option, including doing nothing. 
Commission members did not specify which proposals they would back. But it was clear that they had differences of opinion over how to proceed.
One example is the issue of whether retirees should be free to use the proceeds of their investment accounts as they wish or whether the government should require that some or all of the savings go to buying an annuity that would provide guaranteed payments for life.
One camp within the panel said it would be wrong to tell people that the money was theirs to invest but then require them to do with it what the government dictated. Another camp said that allowing unrestricted use of the money in retirement could leave some at risk of poverty.

HEADLINE: The Return Of New York 

BYLINE:  By Jacob Weisberg; Jacob Weisberg, chief political correspondent for Slate, is a frequent contributor to the magazine.

 BODY:
Dealing with what happened to our city on Sept. 11 has involved a kind of progression, and for many of us, the initial phase included some level of incomprehension. One of the stranger images left in my head from that terrible morning is of a woman standing on my corner in TriBeCa, laughing into her cellphone. Survivors, many of them coated head to foot with ash, were processing mutely up Church Street. My wife and I had run outside to determine whether we should evacuate the children from our apartment. And this nicely dressed woman was chatting with a friend as if New York were the same city it had been an hour earlier. Perhaps this was simply some kind of hysterical reaction. But I think that on that day, and for days afterward, all of us faced in varying degrees the difficulty of wrapping our minds around the magnitude of the murderous destruction visited on the place we live. 
 For New York as a whole, disbelief and denial soon gave way to comprehension and grief. The uncountable dead were enumerated. Their killers acquired an identity. And in our public and personal ways, we mourned our losses. Some of us went to funerals and memorial services. Others joined impromptu wakes at firehouses around the city. Some just watched CNN and wept. 
 The mourning continues, punctuated by recurrent bouts of anxiety and fear. Even now, no one can say whether we are past the purely destructive phase of this calamity. But at the same time, another feeling has emerged: the need to turn from our losses to something positive, productive, redemptive. Rebuilding New York the way it was on Sept. 10 and continuing as before would not be an appealing option, even if such a thing were possible. This is a different city now. But we can, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has suggested, make New York into an even better city than it was. To do that, I think, we have to think about the work of "reconstruction" in slightly less literal terms. We must do something that New Yorkers were once famous for the world over but have in recent decades grown unused to: we have to think big about problems, solutions and possibilities. 
While the twin towers stood, many thought of New York as a place that could no longer be changed in large or dramatic ways. The character of the city and its citizens seemed fixed. In physical terms, we were halfway to Hong Kong: there was hardly any buildable land left on the island of Manhattan. The cost of constructing anything was high and the availability of public funds severely constrained. In political terms, the entrenchment of interests and the diffusion of power made significant changes in public policy difficult even to contemplate. But on Sept. 11, all of our old assumptions were suspended. The impossible became possible and the unthinkable thinkable, in the hopeful sense as well as the tragic.
Rebuilding New York, the topic of this special issue of the magazine, remains first and foremost a physical endeavor. At the center of the bittersweet opportunity we now face is the 16-acre chasm where the World Trade Center used to be, a hole in the heart of the city. But the World Trade Center, while a city unto itself, was also a part of the much larger organism that is New York. It makes no sense to think about the disaster site in isolation, without reference to its neighborhood, municipality, metropolitan region, nation and civilization. In deciding what to put there, we have to think about New York as a whole, about its needs, its feelings and its still great potential. Thus does what begins as a material and political task raise questions that are in the broadest sense social, cultural, even spiritual. 
There is ample precedent: the connection between catastrophe and progress is essential to the city's history. Many, if not most, of New York's great achievements and institutions, the infrastructural, political and social advances that made its continued growth possible, were responses to disaster or urgent need. When westward expansion threatened New York's status as the nation's leading commercial port at the beginning of the 19th century, the city's merchants supported Gov. DeWitt Clinton's visionary plan to build the Erie Canal. It was the cholera epidemic of 1832 that led to the creation of the Croton system, an extraordinary feat of sanitary engineering that gave the city a limitless supply of fresh water. In looking at such episodes, a pattern emerges: New York responded to challenge in ways that went beyond addressing the crisis at hand and prepared the city for the future.
Perhaps the most direct precedent for our current predicament is what happened after the Great Fire of 1835. Edwin G. Burrows and Mike Wallace tell the story in "Gotham," their magisterial history of the city before the 20th century. Although the fire killed only a few people, it largely destroyed New York's financial district, wrecking 674 buildings, putting thousands out of work and bankrupting 23 of the city's 26 fire-insurance companies. But after just four days, the New York Stock and Exchange Board managed to reopen. The city appealed for federal aid and got only a shadow of what it wanted. Nonetheless, within a year it had built a new financial district with wider, drier streets, lighted by gas lamps and lined with handsome fire-resistant Greek Revival buildings. This reconstruction kicked off a metropolitanwide economic boom. In short order, rubble-strewn lots in the fire zone were worth more than built-up land had been. 
After the fire, New York retained the habit of solving problems with public works of grandeur and foresight. The most famous examples of this are its physical graces still: the 843-acre public works project known as Central Park, the Brooklyn Bridge and the construction, in just four years, of the world's finest subway system. But its less tangible accomplishments were no less crucial. The commissioners' grid plan of 1811, the consolidation of the five boroughs in 1897 and compulsory education for a vast immigrant population, which became law in 1901, were all forward-looking responses to necessity that enabled the city to keep growing. 
To some extent, New York City's eventual loss of faith in the radiant future was the result of catastrophic overreaching by one man. Recognizing the need for open space, Robert Moses in the 1920's built a grand network of parks and recreation facilities. With prescient understanding of the significance of the automobile, he began constructing the bridges and tunnels that connected Manhattan to the world beyond, and vice versa, as well as the nation's first system of expressways. But by the 1950's, Moses' vision had turned from farsighted to backward-looking. After the great builder displaced thousands of residents to build the Cross Bronx Expressway, an attempt to redevelop a 14-block chunk of West Village "slum" (west of Hudson Street from Morton to West 11th) collided into Jane Jacobs and the community-based movement she spawned. In her famous 1961 book, "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," Jacobs contended that what appeared to the apostles of urban renewal as blight were actually the things that made communities livable and appealing. The real assets of neighborhoods, Jacobs argued, were diversity of use, human scale and an active, pedestrian street life.
Though tragedy has conferred posthumous nobility on it, the World Trade Center was a prime example of what Jacobs and her disciples rightly objected to in New York's taste for greatness. A venture by the Port of New York Authority, a politically insulated government body that had no business speculating in real estate, the project displaced a whole functioning business district in favor of ugly towers of fearsome size. Nor was the project successful financially. It meant tens of millions in lost tax revenues for the city and took decades to fill with private-sector tenants.
You can actually date the end of New York's romance with bigness to the completion of the trade towers in 1972. In his book "Divided We Stand," Eric Darton argues that the project simply could not have been built a few years later because of the shift in public attitudes. Local interests became far more devoted to protecting what they had than in dividing up new spoils. The new tools of regulation and legal activism let community groups tie projects up and kill them through attrition. As a result, no Robert Moses or Nelson Rockefeller would again have the kind of clout needed to push such a massive redevelopment scheme through. And then came the final blow to grand planning: the fiscal crisis of 1975. The bankrupt city of the 1970's lacked not only the will but also the wallet to do great things. 
Jane Jacobs was largely right, just as Moses had been in his prime. Her ideas were responsible not only for preventing some terrible things, like the leveling of SoHo, but also for the bottom-up revival of what are now among the city's most appealing neighborhoods: the Village, the Upper West Side, as well as various sections of Brooklyn and the Bronx. But Jacobs's philosophy also produced its own excesses, and these were excesses of smallness. After the World Trade Center was finished, hopes for doing anything big to improve New York City became pie-in-the-sky dreaming. Fiscal pressure and community-board power prevented any meaningful response to emerging systemic problems: the lack of affordable housing, the crying need for Manhattan office space, the absence of crucial transportation links, the deteriorating condition of our schools, the worsening of noise, traffic and congestion and so on. 
Any major change in the city's hardscape, like the redevelopment of Columbus Circle, was now a 20-year project -- and that was if you got lucky. Eternal time frames eliminated most of the incentive for credit-seeking politicians to push projects forward; they knew someone else would be cutting the ribbon. Neighborhoods from the East Village to Fort Greene to the South Bronx could, and did, revive in the 1980's and 90's. But the city could not build, plan or invest its formidable resources in ways that addressed its needs and aspirations as a whole. 
High on many people's list of things that should have happened in those years but did not is Westway, the plan to submerge two miles of the West Side Highway and build a glorious downtown park and beach. After a 15-year struggle, environmentalists killed the plan in 1985, on the basis that the Army Corps of Engineers had not sufficiently proved the project harmless to striped bass -- a far-from-endangered species that spawns in the Hudson. Unlike the enormities of Robert Moses' baroque phase, Westway would have displaced no apartment dwellers, businesses or charming old rows. It was a federally financed gift that the city rejected because of an attitude that nothing big done by government can be any good. 
In the last few decades, New York's important public projects have fallen into two categories: largely invisible infrastructural upgrades or high-profile restorations of beloved spaces like Bryant Park, Grand Central Terminal, Times Square and Union Square. In other words, they improved what was already here. The chief political achievement of the last decade has been making the city reasonably safe and clean. I don't mean to slight these accomplishments, which have made New York a lovable, visitor-friendly place once again. But preservationism alone does justice neither to the city's potential nor to its very great problems. 
It is understandable, of course, that economically vulnerable cities cling tenaciously to what assets they still have. That is how our politicians fell into the dubious habit of doling out tax incentives to keep employers from moving out. Since Sept. 11, New York's elected leaders have essentially proposed redoubling this costly rearguard action. They are seeking billions in federal aid to replace lost office space and bribe companies and residents to stay put downtown.
What might make more sense is focusing on making New York as a whole a more inherently supportive place for businesses and residents. Thanks to electronic communication, financial industries no longer need to be situated one on top of another. They have been diversifying away from downtown for decades, a trend now accelerated by security concerns and a poor economy. As a result, most of the office space lost on Sept. 11 is no longer needed. Nor is that necessarily bad news: while remaining the financial capital of the world is central to the city's economic health and global status, it doesn't matter whether financial jobs are on Wall Street, Park Avenue or Queens Boulevard. We can use the World Trade Center site for something creative instead -- a memorial, certainly, and perhaps a mixed-use neighborhood on the fantastically pleasant model of Battery Park City. 
New York remains a magnet for the region, the country and the world, even in dark times. The way the city reacted to catastrophe only intensified many people's pride in this place and our determination to be a part of it. That civic patriotism should also intensify our desire to make the city the best that it can be -- to address long-ignored livability issues, augment its functionality and enhance its cultural appeal. Those things, more than any tax incentives, will ensure that companies stay in town and that people continue to think of New York as a wonderful place to live and work despite the intrinsic difficulties. 
In the broadest sense, I think our goal ought to be restoring a sense of opportunity for the poor. Half a century ago, working people could expect that their children would find a better life here. That prospect depends more on education than on anything else; if a neighborhood's schools can be successful, everything else will follow.
At the level of functionality, transportation, so crucial to a densely populated metropolis, also needs a boost. Unlike education, transportation has not got drastically worse in New York over the past half century. But it has conspicuously failed to get better. It has failed to integrate in obvious ways: we still lack viable public transportation to the city's airports, and links between the major commuter lines (the Long Island Rail Road, the PATH trains and Metro-North). Increasing the ease of public transportation would relieve overcrowding on existing routes, diminish above-ground traffic and enhance the city's competitive position within the metropolitan region. 
And then there are all the amenities that make New York a global cultural attraction. This is the time to move some of the truly imaginative ideas currently on the boards -- Frank Gehry's design for a bigger-than-Bilbao Guggenheim Museum near South Street, say, or the plan to restore a semblance of the old Penn Station in the Central Post Office or a new West Side stadium for the Yankees -- onto the streets. We should aggressively campaign for the 2012 Olympics. The best of these plans have the potential to add to the city's functionality and its luster, its appeal to residents and to visitors at the same time.
And we can think bigger still. The largest continuing abdication, it seems to me, has been failing to reimagine New York City's 578 miles of waterfront -- a mostly wasted coastline with a few underwhelming improvements. When the city was built, people aspired to live as far from its industrialized shore as possible; hence the social status of Fifth Avenue. In the postindustrial city, our port facilities, the original source of the city's greatness, remain mostly derelict and inaccessible. They offer unlimited potential in terms of new housing, recreation and commercial uses. 
Each project and idea necessarily raises controversies. Each faces technical, bureaucratic and economic hurdles. Trade-offs and choices are unavoidable. But in some cases, the tragedy of Sept. 11 lowers barriers. Consider something relatively simple, the long-suffering notion of a link from the Long Island Railroad to Lower Manhattan, which would invigorate downtown, ease countless commutes and relieve congestion in midtown. A continuation of the railroad tunnel from the Atlantic Avenue stop in Brooklyn to the financial district could probably be built for less than $2 billion, a thinkable sum even without the promise of major new federal aid. It is what the Port Authority should have built instead of the World Trade Center three decades ago. Unfortunately, engineers have not been able to find a practicable way for the trains to turn around at the end of the line; there was simply no space left below Wall Street. That problem has now been horribly solved.
But even for projects that lack a direct physical relationship to Lower Manhattan, new possibilities are appearing. Everyone agrees that we must prevent whatever plan we settle on for the World Trade Center site from taking 20 years to finish. To avoid this familiar fate, officials and agencies at various levels of government are going to have to clear a path through the regulatory and legal thickets that hamper large-scale projects. In fact, we have already glimpsed what becomes possible when government agencies work together in a spirit of urgent, creative improvisation. Within days of the attack, city, state and federal bodies that were in many cases crippled themselves set up a one-stop shopping center for victims' families and affected businesses on a West Side pier. Now what would happen if we applied that same attitude and willingness to flex rules to, say, getting the city's average classroom size down to 22 students or doing something delightful with Governors Island?
Just as important as this new government attitude is the public spirit of Sept. 11. On that day, we New Yorkers lived through a horror beyond our previous imagining. But we also discovered assets in our city that we had never fully recognized: depths of courage, sacrifice, generosity, kindness, compassion, defiance, determination and resilience. Those qualities instantaneously created a new civic personality for New York, a stereotype at last worth living up to. In a strange way, it made us once again the envy of the world. That collective spirit now exists as a civic resource. We can call on it not just to recreate what we had but also to build the New York of tomorrow. And building, I think we will find, is good for us -- emotionally as a way of channeling grief, socially as a way of binding our community together and spiritually as a response to our encounter with profound evil. In this sense, bettering New York City is a means by which New Yorkers can restore themselves as well.
None of this is to deny that New York faces daunting obstacles to its revival. Over the near term, we face painful cuts in the city and state budgets. Our newly elected mayor lacks the political capital to bulldoze impediments. He also lacks longstanding relationships with the governor, New York's Congressional delegation, the White House and business leaders, without whom full recovery will not be possible. At the same time, he faces an unprecedented task in terms of reassuring an anxious city and capitalizing on the good will of the rest of the country. There are only two precursors I can think of for this task: Fiorello La Guardia in the 1930's and Rudolph Giuliani in September 2001. 
But regardless of how powerfully the new mayor is able to lead, constraints are surmountable in a city ready to think again in terms of its great possibilities. And whether the grandest aspirations can ever be realized, the very ability to entertain such ideas points to the next stage in the collective process of dealing with what happened on Sept. 11. For the wounded, hope for the future may be the truest sign of healing.

HEADLINE: Forecast: An Uncertain Climate 

BYLINE:  By JOE CUTTS; JOE CUTTS is a senior editor at Ski magazine.

 BODY:
IN recent years, the Gruskin family of Ossining, N.Y., has headed west each December. This year, they had Utah in mind. But while Stuart Gruskin is still ready to go, his wife, Adrienne, has been considering a car trip to Vermont, or perhaps not traveling at all.
 Mrs. Gruskin admits she is reluctant to fly, and not only out of fear. "I also wonder if, with all the new security and longer waits at airports, maybe it's more hassle than it's worth, especially during Christmas season," she said. "So maybe we'll go during February vacation instead, when we have a better sense of what the political climate is." 
 Travelers like Mrs. Gruskin may make their absence felt this winter, especially at ski resorts that depend on visitors who fly. In addition to safety concerns, there's the recent softness of the economy, which could also hurt business. Yet over all, resorts say they haven't seen vast numbers of cancellations. 
So far, it seems, while there is some nervousness, resorts aren't panicking, and hardy skiers and snowboarders hoping for fire-sale pricing at high-end destinations might be disappointed -- airlines and resorts are generally holding the line. Those with the most to lose, it would seem, are the so-called destination resorts, which rely heavily on fly-in visitors and which don't have significant numbers of customers who arrive by car. 
At Sun Valley, Idaho, for instance, "We're down 10 to 15 percent this year in destination bookings," said Jack Sibbach, marketing director. Jackson Hole, Wyo., -- equally isolated -- is off 8 to 10 percent, said Kari Cooper, vice president for marketing. But it's early, both added; individual reservations could still recover, barring any more catastrophes. What has hurt Sun Valley more, Mr. Sibbach said, was the loss of about 10 big-spending corporate groups.
At Telluride, Colo., however, preseason bookings are actually quite healthy this year, despite that resort's dependence on fly-in visitors. "We're up double over last year," said Matt McClain, director of sales. He attributed the rise to better publicity, interest in the recent expansion of Telluride's ski slopes (from about 1,000 acres to more than 1,700) and the fact that the resort is now easier to get to, with direct flights from Newark, Chicago and key Texas markets.
Mr. McClain also pointed to recent industry statistics on sales of ski and snowboard equipment and clothing showing an increase of 6.1 percent over last year, according to Snowsports Industries America. Skiers appear ready to ski, as is typical after an abundantly snowy season like last winter in the populous East.
But for the most part, calls to reservations centers virtually ceased in the days following the attacks, and are just beginning to pick up again.
"We saw our phones simply stop ringing," said Kip Pitou, president of Ski Utah, a marketing arm of Utah resorts. "Interestingly, though, the Web activity was about the same." He and others in the business, who noticed the same phenomenon, attributed that to Web surfers seeking bargains.
Sept. 11 was relatively early in the ski resorts' booking cycle, "because the trend of the past few years has been for consumers to make later and later reservations via the Internet," said Pat O'Donnell, president of Aspen. 
Around mid-October, he said, "we started to see a spike in calls from people looking for deals."
And in some cases, said Bill Tomcich, president of Aspen's central reservations agency, Stay Aspen Snowmass, prices are falling, as inventory remains. "I wouldn't call them fire sales, certainly not during Christmas, but some properties are getting nervous," he said. Premium holiday rates have been lowered to normal high-season rates and in a few cases even low-season rates, Mr. Tomcich said.
But it may be a matter of time before considerable discounts materialize at Western resorts, according to one tour operator. "There will be tremendous deals this winter," said Lance Cygielman, president of Ski Vacation Planners, in Jackson, Wyo., where bookings are down 35 to 45 percent from the same time last year. "But we're not seeing them yet." That may change in early December, Mr. Cygielman said.
Eastern resorts have reason to think they might fare better than those in the Rockies. Skiers wary of flying will instead get into their cars and stay closer to home, the thinking goes, choosing high-amenity resorts such as Stowe, Vt.; Bretton Woods, N.H.; or Whiteface near Lake Placid, N.Y.
Preseason bookings at Stowe are normal, said Hank Lunde, president of Stowe Mountain Resort, though he added "it still might be too early to get a good read."
Besides proximity to huge drive-in markets and inexpensive air fares from East Coast cities to Burlington, Vt., on JetBlue, Eastern resorts have another factor in their favor: snow. Last season was phenomenally snowy, with Jay Peak, Vt., reporting 571 inches. There's reason to believe that this winter will be abundantly white, too, said Jim Roemer, a meteorologist and avid skier whose company, Weatherrisk, provides long-range forecasts for resorts and commodities companies. 
"I looked back at all the years in which we had more than 300 inches -- going back to 1955 -- and 70 percent of the time the following winter we had at least 250 to 300 inches," Mr. Roemer said.
The West, meanwhile, would like more snow than it got last winter, especially in Utah, which will be the focus of the world when the Olympic Games begin Feb. 8. If sales of Olympic tickets (available online at www.saltlake2002.com) are an indication, travelers are not going to let fear keep them away. 
"We continue to have very robust ticket sales," said Mitt Romney, president and chief operating officer of the Salt Lake Games, where security spending was increased by almost $25 million to a total of $300 million in the wake of the attacks. "All indications are that sport continues to be a part of people's lives."
Concerned that the Winter Games would discourage ordinary travelers, as they and other big events have been known to do, Utah resorts are offering $20.02 off on each day's lift tickets to anyone staying three nights or more at participating lodging establishments (about 130 inns and hotels statewide, Mr. Pitou said).
Meanwhile, Utah has other enticements. "Interconnect" is the new buzzword among the tightly clustered resorts of the Wasatch Mountains. Alta and Snowbird can now be enjoyed on the same, slightly more expensive lift ticket, provided one is a skier (Alta still bans snowboarders). Solitude and Brighton have also hooked up, and the three areas just over the ridge in Park City -- Deer Valley, the Canyons and Park City Mountain Resort -- might not be far behind. (They're already accessible for backcountry skiers.) 
Also this year, Alta has one less comrade among resorts that forbid snowboarding. Aspen dropped the rope in April on its core terrain at Ajax Mountain. Now only Alta and Deer Valley, Utah; Mad River Glen, Vt.; and Taos, N.M., remain off limits to snowboarders.
Another trend -- everywhere in ski country -- is the concept of the dense, lively slopeside village, which has proved popular with skiers tired of being marooned in far-flung condos and lodges. Whistler-Blackcomb, British Columbia, and Tremblant, Quebec -- both owned by Intrawest Corporation -- are held up as the new ideal. Among the resorts that are building slopeside villages or planning to are Squaw Valley, Mammoth Mountain, Northstar-at-Tahoe and Kirkwood, Calif.; Aspen Highlands, Copper Mountain and Snowmass, Colo.; and Stowe and Killington, Vt. 
But no amount of snow or amenities will matter if another calamity occurs. Still, resorts are confident their customers aren't easily deterred. "Our experience is that skiers tend to be resilient," Mr. Pitou said. "It's the nature of skiers, given the sport they choose."
