HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 11-11-01: Sightlines; 
The View From Out Here

BYLINE:  By Vince Passaro; Vince Passaro is a novelist living in New York City.

 BODY:
We have a tendency to measure the life of New York by the habits and welfare of the upper-middle classes, which is rather like taking all your weather reports from 25,000 feet in the air. The vast majority of New Yorkers make less than $40,000 per year. This is their city too, though that version of New York doesn't have a series yet on HBO.
 Recently, I was talking with one of the doormen on my block, a Polish emigre studying business at CUNY during the day and working overnights in one of the buildings that make up West 110th Street. These are, for the most part, good-but-not-great buildings that have been tarted up over the last decade to look far more luxurious than they are. I asked him where he lived. 
 "Brooklyn," he said. "Park Slope."
"Where in Park Slope?" 
"Fourth Avenue and 23rd Street," he said.
"That's not Park Slope. That's Sunset Park."
"No," he said. "They call it Park Slope now." 
I was amused to hear that Realtors had so fancifully extended the boundaries of that adamantly rehabbed neighborhood. "My mother grew up on Fourth Avenue and 23rd," I said, "in a big building that takes up the whole block." 
"That's my building," he said.
The last time I saw it, more than 10 years ago, the building was rundown and heavily graffitied. In the 30's, the neighborhood was poor Irish and Italian and Polish. By the 50's it was equally poor or poorer Puerto Ricans and then, later, other Latinos. Now they are joined by a new group of immigrants, Poles and Russians and, the young doorman told me, Indians and East Asians. 
Stirred by the coincidence, I went out to Fourth Avenue on a warm October Saturday with a pale blue sky. At the moment, Brooklyn is New York's most fashionable borough -- the place where young people find affordable housing, fill a neighborhood with attitude, bring on good retail and then get driven out by the prices they help to create. 
But Fourth Avenue and 23rd remains pretty much out of Brooklyn's grooviness range. My mother's building, a block long and six stories high, looks enormous in this landscape of sagging three-story houses. Its ornate size testifies to a forgotten and misplaced ambition. The graffiti is gone but the building is still something of a wreck, with many clotheslines strung across the front facade. It has three arched, locked entryways. Inside, some boys were running around shouting in the courtyard; I stared in through the ugly gates. There were apple cores and large hunks of fried chicken on the sidewalk near my feet.
This autumn, the weather has been so lovely and soft, the universe's small mercy in a time of man-made afflictions. I had forgotten about the sky on Fourth Avenue -- a domed, 360-degree kind of sky. Almost every neighborhood in New York where you can see that much sky is poor, as if, when you're poor, New York will show you in the air what it so rarely yields to you on the ground: beauty and freedom.
Around here, all the signs are in English and Spanish, except when they are just in Spanish, or in Chinese, or in Polish. Across from my mother's building there is L&H Auto Services, a Chinese shop where the mechanics lean against doorways in the manner of profound boredom that mechanics everywhere display when they're not working on cars. The Alma Driving School. The Frank J. Dombrowski Memorial Association American Legion Hall. On 24th Street, there is the magnificent-looking Our Lady of Czenstochowa church, its spire the only interruption of the western sky. An elegant rectory and former school (used for karate and jujitsu classes now, "contact Sensei George Cermak") are behind it, taking up most of 25th Street. On Fourth Avenue is the Polska Agencja, where you can go for legal help, notary services, and travel assistance, not to mention Polish videos and greeting cards. 
A few blocks up Fourth Avenue, you can find the al-Joor health center and school in a building that looks like an out-of-place California-style motor lodge. A few more blocks away stands the Seafarers International Union of North America, A.F.L.-C.I.O., which rents space, apparently, to the Pomoc Inc. Human Service Agency. My sense that day was, if you were to find yourself needing to go to the Pomoc Inc. Human Service Agency, that wouldn't be a good thing. 
After that there was a small-scale construction site where, judging by the signage, some sort of chain Laundromat is coming in. Hanging slightly crooked on the fence was an unelaborate and slightly mysterious hand-painted wood sign: "Ask for Sadek." It seemed like an idea. I went up to the gated fence and looked in. There was a large man outside the long, low building. 
"Hey," I said. I was trying to sound friendly. "Is Sadek here?" 
"Sadek's not here," he said.
"Is this going to be a Laundromat or what?"
"You got to ask Sadek." 
Gates are not readily opened in this part of Brooklyn, to let people in or out. There is a dream at work here, certainly, just as there was a dream in my mother's day; people don't come all this way, to this hard, less-than-ideal place, for no reason. My young Polish friend, the doorman, clearly has money in mind, far more so than the Irish of my mother's generation did. Perhaps his own children will one day visit Fourth Avenue and 23rd, pilgrims to an obscure commencement. How will it be then? Well, it'll be Brooklyn. 
I walked that day north along Fourth Avenue, then down the hill into the old warehouse district, across the Gowanus Canal, and into Carroll Gardens and Cobble Hill. Carroll Gardens is an old Italian neighborhood that looks to be perhaps a third Italian, even now. Mixed in are second- and third-generation Latinos and newly arrived Manhattanites. This means the neighborhood is predominantly white, and vastly more prosperous than Fourth Avenue, though not prosperous enough for the rents.
As I walked farther north, the shops started to get fashionable, and suddenly I was back in familiar territory, the land of restaurants, bars, high-end dress shops and cafes with attitude. I saw three or four arty-looking young women who were pregnant, and I thought there was something noticeably grim in their faces. Who knows, it could have been anything -- it is hard enough on its own being pregnant -- but I imagined in those faces an anxiety that many of their generation, and mine, have had to face as we grow older in New York: their apartments are too small and already too expensive, their responsibilities are growing visibly by the day and they are confronting the unfailing economic laws of this city with a frightening new clarity. 
There is still money around in New York, but listen for the sucking sound -- it's draining away. The World Trade Center tragedy made desperate a financial decline that had already become palpable. On the phone booths outside my office building a few weeks after the attack, I saw a flier: "available immediately, gorgeous 3BR in GP, enormous rooms, sharing O.K., $2,800, call Kevin, broker." "GP" means Gramercy Park, a name that gets exaggerated wildly by Realtors, in much the same way that "Park Slope" has now come to extend from Prospect Park, as a friend of mine says, "all the way to Egypt." If it's true, the rent seems awfully low. The common denominator of all the hand-posted signs is "available immediately." We're hearing stories this fall of newly graduated business recruits who arrive for their first hours of work and are sent packing on the same day. My wife asks the guys at the coffee shop she frequents in Rockefeller Center how business is. Not good, they tell her. A man was in this morning, a regular, the owner said, and the man told them that 500 people were being laid off that day in his company. Not only that, but a few days ago, the shop went to deliver a lunch for a group at another company, and when they arrived there was no one to take the lunch. The woman who'd put in the order called the next day to apologize: they'd all been laid off that morning. So we can't complain, the owner said. 
Whole lives are suddenly "available immediately." 
We're coming to the end of something and starting something else, a fact that was plain even before the 11th of September. The near-present already feels like distant history: the Belgian-beer period, the Low Country-vodka period, the period of explicit cash and affectless public sexuality. Many of the new people won't stay here; the place relentlessly weeds out those who can't take it. 
Similarly, the money comes, the money goes, the money comes back again, but the money never makes it out to Fourth Avenue in any case. The whole idea of it lies in its restricted range. Those of us who are rarely touched by its ebb and flow might feel its absence from the tax base in services reduced, in streets less clean, in parks less green, in a grimmer set to people's faces and perhaps in a diminishing graciousness. The streets around Fourth Avenue, though, have been dirty for 40 years, and its graciousness resides in going on, in managing to get along and in not giving in to despair, despair being the route along which the gates are always open. 
Jimmy Breslin once said that nature's finest sight is a crowded street; my own nomination is also purely a human creation: the eastern face of Manhattan as seen from the Triborough Bridge, stretching from Harlem to the Lower East Side. This is a panorama that at its boundaries is poor, while the middle is rich, thus making it a face of New York that belongs to all of us. Some favorite buildings are very painfully missing now, but it is still a monumental facade, a five-mile textured surface of astonishing density and depth. Like the Black Mountains of Arizona, it changes with every shift in the light, every movement of cloud before the sun. At night, it sparkles like an immensity of haphazard jewels, diamonds and jagged heaps of coal. 
After the pain of terrible and sudden death has begun to fade, after all the rubble and steel and glass is hauled away, after the sense of our deep wound has slowly subsided, New York City will still have, we trust, its essential, ever-changing and thus inalterable soul -- its mad ambition and stolid cynicism about the fruits of ambition; its vulgarity and elegance; its muscular sexuality and physical ambiguity; its eight million faces, passing through the daily zones of nervousness, amusement and fatigue. We'll pray that nothing else awful happens, and we'll wait for the next phase in our history to make itself clear. It will take a long time. Perhaps, though, we'll be lucky. Perhaps we'll feel, as tends to happen in New York, as if it really seemed like no time at all.

LENGTH: 2257 words

HEADLINE: Theater; 
London Theater And the Cloud of War

BYLINE:  By BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE; Benedict Nightingale is the chief theater critic of The Times of London.

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
IN times of public anxiety in Britain, it has fallen to the royal family to stand up, be counted, show the flag and do the other things expected of national symbols. The obvious case is George VI, who refused to escape the blitz by fleeing to Canada with his wife and daughters. And in the anxious London of late 2001 it seems to have fallen to "The Royal Family" to perform a similar if smaller function.
 Peter Hall's revival of George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber's classic comedy is one of several plays helping to prove that Britain's theaterland won't be terrorized out of business. Not only is the piece bringing an impressive cast, led by Judi Dench, to the Haymarket but also advance ticket sales amounted to $1.2 million before it opened for a 14-week run on Nov. 1. 
 What is the general feel of the West End since Sept. 11? Contradictory. The lobbies at first nights are as jampacked as they always were, the streets outside still teem with gawkers and autograph-hounds, and getting a taxi after a show is just as difficult and just as likely to lead to a vendetta on the sidewalk. Yet restaurants and pubs seem less busy in the early evening, meaning you can actually get a drink without breaking Britain's unwritten law against queue-jumping. I can't say I notice many more police in the West End; but severe gentlemen in black suits now regularly unpack my briefcase for inspection when I enter the theater, which is both comforting and embarrassing. It doesn't contain anything toxic, unless you count the decaying sandwich one heavy extracted and held up to general view; but, with old papers and pens tumbling out, it provides distressing evidence of untidy habits. 
Since London producers differ from their Broadway counterparts by keeping their audience figures secret, the economic picture is not wholly clear either. Outside the Lyceum, I've seen a long line desperate for returns for "The Lion King"; yet the forlorn little phalanx of tourists that has gathered every night for years outside Her Majesty's in hopes of getting standby tickets for "The Phantom of the Opera" seems to have dematerialized. And a phone call to Drury Lane for a reputedly unobtainable seat for Trevor Nunn's revival of "My Fair Lady" revealed that on many evenings seats are perfectly obtainable. 
The Society of London Theater, the producers' organization, concedes that in the last few weeks ticket sales have been between 9 and 15 percent lower than they were in the same period last year. The reason must be that out-of-towners and foreign visitors are staying clear of London, fearful that the capital would be a logical target for anybody seeking reprisals for Britain's participation in the war on terrorism. But present-day Londoners, long accustomed to I.R.A. bombs, have come to share the view of their forebears when they were menaced by Hitler's doodlebugs: if disaster suddenly strikes, so be it.
This means that it's tougher than usual for musicals, especially long-running musicals, and for plays that don't fall into the must-see category. The critics didn't much like Ronald Harwood's worthy but stolid "Mahler's Conversion," and, even though Antony Sher excelled as the composer who self-servingly rejected Judaism, the play closed on Nov. 3 after just a month's run. But most reviewers were delighted by Alan Rickman and Lindsay Duncan in Noel Coward's "Private Lives" at the Albery, and Londoners are packing the theater. The revival of Tennessee Williams's "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof" at the Gielgud, which was equally well received, is doing almost as well. The prospects for "The Royal Family" are clearly excellent, too. 
That is largely because Judi Dench has a big following, and, on the evidence of her performance here, deserves it. She plays Fanny Cavendish, the oldest surviving member of an acting dynasty based on the Barrymores, and she uses the occasion to suggest a commitment to the theater as strong and pure as that of the Pilgrim Fathers to their Bibles. Other members of the family have doubts, show off, play skittish games with their lives: she sits in their gorgous Manhattan townhouse determinedly planning a road tour to Tulsa and Oklahoma City that is all too likely to ruin her already failing health. 
Sir Peter's production is brisk and lively, yet the play hasn't the tension one might wish. We never seriously doubt that, despite the lure of love or the distraction of scandal, the Cavendishes will continue to feel about their greasepaint the way some of the O'Neills did about their bottles. Nevertheless, it's amusing to watch Harriet Walter's Julie (the Ethel Barrymore character) wearily throwing life belts to Peter Bowles's Uncle Herbert and Julia McKenzie's Aunt Kitty, who are obsessed with refloating their becalmed careers, or helping Toby Stephens's wild, womanizing Tony flee from his latest breach-of-promise action. "I'm a madwoman in a family of maniacs," wails Ms. Walter. And when Mr. Stephens's glittering John Barrymore clone is narcissistically bounding around in his Cyrano costume, sword in hand, cigarette holder between his teeth, you see what she means. 
For all its mocking moments, "The Royal Family" is a bit too incestuously in love with the mystique of Dame Theater. Yet, at least for me, its fascination is precisely that it celebrates a period, namely 1927, when Broadway was confident and creative and its leading players as famous as any Manhattan model or Hollywood star now. And they weren't famous just because they were glamorous. Listen to Dame Judi's gloriously acerbic Fanny when she talks her rebellious family through the austere excitement of preparing for an evening's performance: "Fifteen minutes, Miss Cavendish! My costume, more rouge. How's the house tonight? Props, cue, enter." It's a defiant artistic credo: moving testimony to the power of the theater and to the hardy professionalism of people like Judi Dench herself. 
The financial success of this production and the probability of a longer than planned run for Howard Davies's elegiac revival of "Private Lives" (in my dissenting view, Mr. Rickman's doleful divorce displays more menopausal gloom than erotic glee at discovering his ex-wife in the slinky form of Ms. Duncan), has led some to conclude that escapist comedy is what London audiences currently crave. But "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," at the Lyric Theater, is a hot enough ticket to contradict that. True, Williams's Deep South saga has its comic moments, especially when the dramatist brings onstage caricatures of inheritance-hunters and their awful children; but neither the impending death of the object of their greed, Big Daddy Pollitt, nor the despair of the old man's favorite son seems particularly hilarious.
Death and despair do, however, seem particularly real: testimony not only to Anthony Page's meticulous production but to the quality of the performers he has persuaded to take a break from their movie careers. Frances O'Connor is Maggie, the precariously placed feline female of the play's title. Brendan Fraser is her husband, Brick, a boy-man for whom bourbon is the main escape both from his own repressed homosexuality and from Maggie's nagging attempts to stop his ostentatiously sober brother from inheriting the family plantation. And Ned Beatty is Big Daddy, the patriarch who is brutally informed by Brick that the pain in his guts comes from cancer, not a spastic colon. 
Ms. O'Connor doesn't flaunt her sensuality, as Elizabeth Taylor did in the film of the play, but you don't doubt the intensity of a frustration that is sexual as well as practical. Neither her charm, which is great, nor her intelligence, which is greater, can bounce her neglectful husband out of the emotional magnolias. You can see why she and her father-in-law like each other. They are two survivors who have known poverty and have got where they are now through the mental toughness so maddeningly missing in Brick. Indeed, what is refreshing about Mr. Beatty's performance is that he isn't content to show us the mythic cotton-king, the Mississipi minotaur or Delta titan. His Big Daddy is the one-time overseer who wangled his way to riches and power: a shrewd, practical, even sensitive man who may bully his wife and talk coarsely yet strains to understand his son and woo him from his bottle.
As a result, the climactic encounter between Mr. Beatty and Mr. Fraser's Brick, a defeated hulk adrift in a sea of booze, is as compelling as anything now in the London theater. The father's dogged prodding penetrates the son's imperturbability, some inner fuse ignites, the wreck turns wrecker, and all the suppressed anger and self-hatred explodes in a display of frantic vindictiveness. Williams once said that of all his plays "Cat" was his favorite and that of all his scenes this was the one in which he had most "reached beyond myself." After seeing Mr. Beatty and Mr. Fraser's intimate stag-battle, I believe him. 
America is richly represented in the West End this fall. Another Deep South play, Lillian Hellman's melodramatic "Little Foxes," is getting a decent showing at the Donmar. Michael Blakemore, whose revival of "Kiss Me, Kate" was a success on Broadway, has restaged the same musical at the Victoria Palace with Marin Mazzie and Michael Beresse as holdovers and a swaggering Brent Barrett joining them as Cole Porter's version of Petruchio. And Rodgers and Hammerstein's "South Pacific" begins previews at the National on Dec. 3, soon after the all-black cast that has brought August Wilson's fine "Jitney" to the same theater has put its props back in their hampers and returned to New York. 
But there is British work worth attention, too, notably a play at the National, expected to transfer to the West End soon. If I describe Charlotte Jones's "Humble Boy" as "Hamlet" as it might have been rewritten by Alan Ayckbourn and Tom Stoppard, it makes it sound less fresh than it is. But there is plenty to encourage the comparison, beginning with Simon Russell Beale, who recently played Shakespeare's prince to great acclaim at the same address, as well as at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in New York, and is now reborn as the Hamlet of Moreton-in-the-Mud: an overage research student who has returned from Cambridge to the country to cause embarrassment at and after his father's funeral. 
Mr. Russell Beale's Felix Humble dresses badly, behaves madly, combines a sharp wit with suicidal thoughts, and loathes his mother's lover, a cheerfully coarse businessman played by Denis Quilley. But when his mother tells him, "You're determined to turn this into a tragedy and you can't," we believe her, largely because she is played by Diana Rigg as the sort of exquisite ogre nobody can resist. So the result is a gently debunking variation on "Hamlet." The dead father, a dedicated beekeeper, was stung to death by his own swarm and reappears as a kindly, healing ghost. A surprisingly sturdy Ophelia-figure materializes, complete with the child Felix unknowingly sired ages ago. There is even a happy ending -- though the idea of Dame Diana's cool, ruthless Gertrude self-sacrificially rejecting her small-time Claudius smacks of a sentimentality Ms. Jones has hitherto avoided. 
Felicity Kendal will replace Dame Diana when John Caird's production transfers, but all else should remain intact, including the young author's humor and intelligence. Many critics think Ms. Jones should have won a most-promising-dramatist award with her "In Flame," her play about three generations of women, which was performed in the West End last year. And most agree that she'll soon be getting most-accomplished-dramatist awards if she can curb a tendency to ladle her work with self-conscious significance. In "Humble Boy," bees are a metaphor for everything from emotional orderliness to mental turbulence, and Felix's hopes of reconciling Einsteinian physics with quantum theory resonates rather too obviously in a village where issues big and little constantly collide. But Ms. Jones can write super scenes and roles, not least for the brilliant Mr. Russell Beale, at once as ungainly as a bumblebee and, intellectually, as agile as a wasp. 
ALSO doing well at the National is the latest, raunchiest and, for those of tender or homophobic disposition, most defiantly offensive play by Mark Ravenhill, best known for a piece whose unprintable title was pared to "Shopping and . . ." in some publications when it reached New York. His "Mother Clap's Molly House" again involves the transformation of sex into a consumer product. It opens in an 18th-century "molly house," meaning a place where men come to cross-dress and couple, and in the second half switches between there and modern London, where the same cast is holding what is clearly supposed to be a glum, pleasureless orgy, complete with cocaine, leather, chains, prying video cameras and desultory fellatio. 
Nicholas Hytner, the National Theater's artistic-director-elect, stages the earlier encounters with an exuberance that suggests his regime won't be timorous. But with Eros and even a character called God appearing to give their blessings to some graphically portrayed sodomy, and the cast occasionally breaking into "Beggar's Opera"-style choruses, the piece feels cluttered. Nor does Mr. Ravenhill bring much conviction to his attempts to indict that old villain Modern Capitalism. The 18th-century cavortings, though maybe more innocent and less businesslike, don't seem much more fun than their 21st-century counterparts. Both left me wanting a nice cup of tea.

HEADLINE: Habitats/89th Street Between First and Second Avenues; 
Fireman and His Family Find an East Side Condo

BYLINE:  By TRISH HALL 

 BODY:
MANY firefighters who work in New York City live in the suburbs, in houses with several bedrooms and grassy yards for their children. The suburbs are very practical for firefighters because they work two shifts a week of 24 hours each, making commuting far less frequent and onerous.
 So when Terrence McGann told his fellow firemen at Engine Company 42 in the Bronx that he and his wife, Karen Jones-McGann, were buying an apartment in Manhattan, they thought he was crazy. Why spend so much for so little? 
 But from the moment he met his future wife four years ago, living in Manhattan was a nonnegotiable part of their relationship. Stricken at age 24 with a brain aneurysm and left with no peripheral vision, she cannot drive. During her first marriage, she lived in New Jersey, and the isolation she experienced as a carless person left her determined never to make the same mistake again. "You lose your independence," she said.
Buying an appealing apartment in Manhattan is sometimes difficult even for people with quite a bit of money. Mrs. Jones-McGann, 36, works as an executive assistant for the president of Port Parties, which runs trade shows on the piers, and two middle-class salaries don't go far. Making matters even worse, Mr. McGann, also 36, had filed for bankruptcy after getting divorced from his first wife and finding himself unable to pay off the credit card bills they had accumulated.
But they had the assistance of Mary Beth Waite of the Halstead Property Company, a broker they describe as indispensable, and Mark Wenitzky of Chase, a banker who went out of his way to help. So they and their 3-month-old daughter, Samantha, are now ensconced in a cozy, light-filled one-bedroom condo on the top floor of a sixth-floor walkup on 89th Street between First and Second Avenues.
The couple bought it a year ago for $225,000, and then two weeks ago, with interest rates declining and Mr. McGann's credit improving, they refinanced.
The previous mortgage payment was $1,857; their new one is $1,600 a month, which includes taxes but not the common charge of $324 a month.
Mr. McGann was surprised that Chase would take them on. At first, he said, they had gone to "fly-by-night" operations looking for a mortgage, but Chase ended up being more helpful, initially charging an interest rate of 8.5 percent because of his bad credit history. "I was bankrupt," he said. "For me to even be considered was huge."
"He married me for my money," his wife teased.
"No," he countered. "I married her for her credit."
Their new loan rate is 7 percent, and their total monthly cost is substantially less than the $2,500 in rent they were paying for their apartment in the East 80's near First Avenue.
Not that finding their new home was easy. Mrs. McGann said she wanted a condo, not a co-op. "I said to Mary Beth, I don't want anybody telling me when I can and cannot run my washer," she said. Co-ops may be less expensive, but they have more rules. She said she liked the broker because Ms. Waite listened to what she wanted and didn't try to show her things that didn't match her interests, or apartments that were too expensive, and because "she's very aggressive but not annoying."
There were only six condos available in their price range on the Upper East Side when they were looking last year, and so they picked the largest one. It was hardly dazzling. "It was the middle of summer," Mr. McGann said. "There was no air-conditioning, and no fans. It was a sweatbox."
THEY bought it and immediately renovated, hiring firemen to do construction: new kitchen cabinets, air-conditioners, ceiling fans and better closets. 
As before, she walks to her job at 44th Street and 12th Avenue, an hour and a half trip, and he drives to the firehouse at 175th Street and Monroe Avenue, off the Grand Concourse, a drive of no more than 10 minutes when he leaves for work at 7 a.m. At home, he likes to sit on the stoop outside their new home. 
"We know everyone in the building," he said. "I sit on the stoop. They have to get past me." Since the World Trade Center disaster, where he worked the night of Sept. 11 on rescue operations, people on the street have been noticeably more interested and supportive. "They stop and say hello and ask how I'm doing," he said.
He grew up in Inwood, where he and his friends played ball against the stoop, and his wife was raised just 20 blocks away, also in Inwood. They met four years ago at a party in Riverdale.
They're beginning to think about getting a larger apartment, one with a bedroom for Samantha, who looks like a doll lying against the couch cushion.
"No matter what, we stay in the city," Mrs. Jones-McGann said. Another walkup would be fine with her, and her husband agrees. "They're more personable," he said. "People who are in doorman buildings have money."
The firefighters in his company, meanwhile, are amazed that one of their own is in Manhattan. "They get a charge out of me living down here," he said.

HEADLINE: REBUILDING; 
An Open Door

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Power, Imagination and New York's Future" by Herbert Muschamp Oct. 28 : 
 The New York City Infrastructure Task Force is not the effort of four architectural firms. 
It is a coalition of several hundred architects, planners, urban designers, members of the City Planning Commission, civic activists, representatives of government, real estate consultants, engineers, business leaders, artists, environmentalists and so forth. The door is open to anyone who has an interest in participating.
The coalition has divided itself into seven primary groups that are dealing with wider regional issues as well as the downtown area and the World Trade Center site itself. These include transportation connections, uses, growth strategies, quality of life and sustainability, the memorial process, cultural and historic resources, liaison and communication.
Our motivation is not to serve the interests of developer clients. Rather, our goal is to establish principles and guidelines that will ensure that the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site will be done in a manner that will: help sustain a vital urban center in downtown Manhattan; reflect the long-term interests of the city and region; create a place that responds to the emotional needs of the public; and cultivate a process that promotes the highest achievable quality of responsible architecture and urban design.

BRUCE S. FOWLE
Manhattan

The writer is a principal in the firm of Fox & Fowle Architects and is a co-coordinator of the Growth Strategies Committee of the NYC Infrastructure Task Force.

HEADLINE: RETHINK : Manifestoes For the Next New York; 
Times Square : Bring Back New Yorkers -- and Sex

BYLINE:  By Frank Rich; Frank Rich is an Op-Ed columnist for The Times and a senior writer for the magazine.

 BODY:
Labor Day brought the romance it always does to Broadway: the whiff of a new season. In the Times Square that Disney helped build in the late 1990's, you could squint your eyes and imagine that the crossroads of the world was as vital as ever. The blazing lights, after all, seemed even brighter than those of "42nd Street" lore, and foot traffic had become so dense that Broadway sidewalks had just been widened to accommodate it. 
 So the shock was real when the attack on the World Trade Center claimed Times Square's economy and optimism as collateral damage. As tourists fled, four Broadway shows folded. Others, playing to audiences of 300 or less in 1,500-seat houses, were placed in cost-cutting triage. Hotels, restaurants and sidewalks emptied out, unemployment spiraled and fear supplanted "The Producers" as the street's No. 1 topic of conversation. It wasn't idle talk when Rudolph Giuliani and even Colin Powell, another native New Yorker, urged Americans to partake of an activity as seemingly frivolous as seeing a play. Broadway's survival was at stake. Though a modest bounce followed, decimated advance sales suggest it will be short-lived. 
 Many of the gains of the area's redevelopment, led by the decline in crime, are undiminished, but the cataclysm of Sept. 11 revealed starkly what's missing when the office workers go home each night: New Yorkers. It's the paradox of the Times Square comeback in the late 1990's that the neighborhood that epitomizes New York to the world is no longer on the map of many of its own residents. According to one good barometer -- the League of American Theaters and Producers' surveys of Broadway ticket buyers -- the overwhelming majority of Broadway's customers were metropolitan-area residents through the 1980's. Now far fewer than half are, with less than a fifth of Broadway audiences coming from the city itself. The confirmation of these statistics could be found in the post-Sept. 11 ruins. It was the spectacles pitched at out-of-towners -- typified by "Les Miserables" and "The Phantom of the Opera" -- that were hardest hit. 
If Times Square is going to be revived at full throttle, it won't be enough to trot out a revised "I Love New York" campaign to get the tourists to return. To be truly disaster-proof, Times Square, we now know, needs the New Yorkers to come back and love it too.
This cannot be done by turning the clock back to some halcyon antique Broadway. The Automat is not going to be revived, and neither are Loew's Capitol, Orange Julius stands or Walter Winchell. But it is possible to retrieve for the new new Times Square some of what's been unnecessarily lost from its past without indulging in nostalgic fantasies or sacrificing the gains of the late 90's. 
Clearly Broadway will have to be made safe once again for plays, which New Yorkers favor over musicals. The only way more plays will be produced is if they are cheaper to put on and cheaper to see. (At a typical drama this season, "Dance of Death," even the back of the balcony goes for $50.) Already the Theater Development Fund, which runs the half-price ticket booth, is at work on a Theater Relief Fund to subsidize and discount tickets on a larger scale than ever tried before. 
But maybe even a more radical scheme is needed. A pathway is opened up by the post-Sept. 11 stunt of "The Producers" -- raising the $100 top to $480 for prime seats, so the excess can accrue to its producers rather than to some scalper in Jersey. This idea should be expanded industrywide -- but with a big hitch. Let all Broadway ticket prices float to their true market value -- which in the case of "The Producers" may in fact be closer to $1,000 -- but require the top draws to underwrite cheaper tickets to the same hits ($10 for all balcony seats) and maybe $35 orchestra seats at a drama that has overlapping management (as, say, "Proof" has with "The Producers"). Let the in-demand weekend orchestra seats of second-rung hits rise, too -- to $150, $300, whatever -- to underwrite a midweek top of one-fifth that amount. And why not conduct this rough-and-tumble market in public view? In the 1920's, a nightly bidding for unsold Broadway tickets took place at Gray's Drugstore at the Times Square subway entrance, where, in the words of Brooks Atkinson, "pitchmen barked the various attractions as if the shop were a midway." Maybe it's time to move TKTS indoors and expand it to the size of a trading pit at the stock exchange so that each rise or fall of day-of-performance Broadway ticket prices could be a pre-performance show on its own, more entertaining than eBay.
But the theater isn't the whole Times Square story and never has been. The beauty of the district has always been its rude amalgam of high and low, class and crass. The street's late-20th-century decline was in a symbolic way sealed when, in the period from 1966 to 1972, it lost its last old-time freak show (Ripley's Believe It or Not "Odditorium") and its last old-style showgirl cabaret (Lou Walters's Latin Quarter) as well as its last high-culture institution (the Metropolitan Opera House). 
That crazy-quilt hodgepodge is missing in the new Times Square, where the nontheater entertainments and services tend to be neither high nor low, but part of the bland middle of national chains. This familiarity may make out-of-towners feel as if they never left home, but in New Yorkers it can breed contempt. As an economic miracle is needed to restore plays to Times Square, so a similar one is needed to inject indigenous local businesses, whether bowling alleys or boutiques, into the faceless lineup of the Gap, Chevy's, ESPN Zone and the other cookie-cutter franchises. And why not restore the cultural high end too? Lure one of the feuding opera companies at Lincoln Center, City Opera or the Met, to an opulent new opera house in Times Square. 
Sex must also be in the mix. It has always been part of the neighborhood's DNA. Even before The New York Times moved into Longacre Square in 1904, prompting its name change, the West 40's were overrun by "parlor houses." In 1913, the New Amsterdam's roof theater -- right above the stage where "The Lion King" prowls now -- featured Ziegfeld's "Midnight Frolic," where a trick of lighting on a "see-through runway" displayed the pulchritude of chorus girls. A decade later the Shubert Theater housed "Artists and Models," a revue featuring female frontal nudity. Fiorello La Guardia stamped out the "incorporated filth" of burlesque in the 1930's, and his successor in spirit, Rudolph Giuliani, tried to do the same with porn. But there must be a way to get sensible adult sexuality back into Times Square entertainment. It wouldn't mean importing prostitution, 10-cents-a-dance halls or wretched XXX emporiums, but perhaps at least a touch of Vegas (which also tried to stamp out sex revues in favor of family entertainment in the 1990's but this year reversed course). 
At the very least, maybe the Shuberts should consider reviving "Artists and Models" alongside "Dance of Death." Tourists, no less than locals, know that sex is the dance of life, and its defiant spirit, now more than ever, is intrinsic to the next comeback of Times Square.

LENGTH: 1019 words

HEADLINE: RETHINK : Manifestoes For the Next New York; 
Boroughs : Put a Piece of Downtown in Flushing

BYLINE:  By Michael Sorkin; Michael Sorkin is the director of the graduate program in urban design at City College.

 BODY:
The radical act of the terrorists opens a space for us to think radically as well. While many of the billions that will be available for rebuilding -- from insurance, from federal aid, from city coffers, from developers -- are surely needed to restore the health and character of Lower Manhattan, it seems reasonable to question whether such massive expenditure should be focused exclusively downtown rather than throughout the city at sites of need and opportunity.
 Although many think of Manhattan and New York City as one and the same, the majority of the city's population and geography do not lie on the island: Manhattan holds only 6.8 percent of the city's land area and 19 percent of its inhabitants. It is, however, our economic motor, accounting for two-thirds of New York City's jobs and almost half its retail sales. The great infusions of capital and the artificial fortunes of the last decade have propelled the price of real estate in much of Manhattan to stratospheric heights, accelerating the flight of the middle class and the poor and making Manhattan increasingly monochrome, the differences among its neighborhoods merely physical. While our ethnic and cultural quarters solidify and thrive outside the borough -- in Flushing, Astoria, the new bohemias of Dumbo, Williamsburg and Long Island City, and along Atlantic Avenue -- Manhattan becomes a place of privilege, inhospitible to striving, less and less like New York. 
 But these big changes also suggest an opportunity for transforming the city, making it more sustainable, more livable and more likely to benefit those neighborhoods struggling to find form or merely to keep up. Because of its dynamic population and superb movement infrastructure, New York City can become a model of a new kind of many-centered metropolis, with Manhattan -- the world capital -- remaining its center of all centers. The 10 million square feet of office space that were lost to terror could be reconstituted in 1-million- or 2-million-square-foot increments in neighborhoods around the city that already house large populations ready to work.
Such a plan would capture jobs that might head out of town otherwise, reinforce the centrality of New York as a whole and take advantage of the downscaling of individual locations that is becoming corporate writ. Manhattan itself is already polycentric: the easy movement of financial services from downtown to Midtown in recent years suggests that convenient movement and strong local character can substitute for immediate adjacency. The point is not to make New York more like Phoenix or Los Angeles, but to make the city as a whole more like New York, restoring a network of semiautonomous "villages" within an overall context of density.
Building on New York City's natural polycentricity would multiply opportunities for more self-sufficient "green" neighborhoods in which people might walk to work, to school, to recreation and to culture, pushing the city in the direction of greater sustainability by reducing commuting, taking fuller advantage of mass transit and introducing green architectural technologies. 
The expressive singularity of each of these neighborhoods -- the Asian flavor of Flushing or the Latin American atmosphere of the Bronx Hub -- would reinforce New York's blessed diversity. Imagine a day at a riverside office overlooking Yankee Stadium, a night spent clubbing in the Hub and a leisurely stroll back home to the Concourse.
The mixed-use character of these neighborhoods would be assured by including residential construction matched to the numbers of new workplaces, a pattern that had already begun downtown, where substantial office space had been eliminated by conversion of "obsolete" buildings to residential use.
This sense of self-contained locality would also be reinforced by the decentralization of cultural growth (the City Opera, the Guggenheim, the Whitney and the Met are all seeking new or additional space) and by encouraging the development of new cultural, educational and commercial institutions to enhance the variety and life of these neighborhood centers.
To create this energetic mix, these centers must be envisioned and planned as autonomous, not simply ancillary. Downtown Brooklyn is already one of the largest "central places" in America but continues to be thought of as a back office for Manhattan, Jersey City with a sales tax. Zoning and design for new centers must reinforce difference, not simply create a series of mini-Manhattans. Although the skyscraper is a pre-eminent symbol of 20th-century technology and of the culture of the corporation, other greener paradigms must now emerge that modulate the machismo of height and foreground strong environmental values.
A comprehensive re-examination of transportation is crucial to this transformation. Movement must be facilitated not simply in and out of Manhattan but between the developing centers of lived life. Our waterways, in particular, offer a tremendous opportunity for creating such links with great economy. In addition, the city's large areas of public green space and municipally owned property can be used to begin to create a third transport net -- for pedestrians, bikers and nonaggressive zero-emissions vehicles -- to supplement the street grid and the subway. This is simply leveraging the city's existing advantages. With the city having just spent over a billion dollars on a rail link from Kennedy Airport to Jamaica, doesn't it make sense to enhance this new, incredibly well-serviced node with careful development? 
Rushing headlong back to the status quo without thinking deeply about the future of the city does no honor to the victims or ourselves: we need now consider the widest range of possibilities, not the narrowest. Reflecting on the future of the city in this irrevocably changed environment, it is urgent to remember that business-as-usual in New York is more than the compulsion to repeat patterns of the past: our greatest talent is creating the new. Perhaps we can reply to the terror by showing that evil acts can have unintended positive consequences.

HEADLINE: RETHINK : Manifestoes For the Next New York; 
Mass Transit : Connect the Connectors

BYLINE:  By Alex Marshall; Alex Marshall is the author of "How Cities Work: Suburbs, Sprawl and the Roads Not Taken."

 BODY:
When the World Trade Center fell to the ground, it knocked out train and subway lines and in doing so made the public aware of the incredible machinery that pumps people into our streets and buildings. We saw one thing very clearly: this machinery is ancient. The subway line that ran directly under the fallen towers, for example, began service in 1918.
 The New York City Transit Authority has spent $30 billion in the last 20 years to improve the subways and commuter trains. Nearly all the money went to make amends for decades of neglect. Very little went to build new lines and connections. We are now entering a period of fiscal austerity in which it will be especially difficult to make such massive infrastructural investments. But it is essential, all the same, to look ahead to economic recovery, and to understand that the most effective means of creating jobs and improving the city's economy is through transportation. We are already pitifully behind cities like London, Tokyo, Shanghai and Paris, which have each spent heavily on ultramodern subways and high-speed trains that will support and enrich those cities for decades to come. 
 Even in times of economic prosperity, New York City cannot pay for new mass-transit systems by itself, any more than London or Paris could have paid for theirs alone, or cities in the Sun Belt could have built their own Interstate highways. So our task will be twofold: we will have to decide exactly what we want, and we will have to build a political case for getting Washington to help us pay for it.
Let's start with what we want, beginning in Lower Manhattan where, sadly, the terrorists have already done much of the demolition work. The Regional Plan Association, a public-interest planning group, has proposals for a beautiful series of new stations in the financial district that seamlessly connect ferries, subways and train lines. These would include a magnificent central subway station at Fulton Street, where 13 subway lines, a commuter train and ferries from Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and New Jersey all converge, opening up the hideous rat's nest that's there now with skylights and gleaming concourses. 
We should also build the long-awaited Second Avenue subway. Right now, the single East Side subway line is so congested that, among other things, Metro-North commuters coming into Grand Central Terminal look for any excuse to avoid it. If it were easier for them, and everyone else, to get downtown, Lower Manhattan would be more attractive to businesses that now cluster tightly around Midtown. The commuter trains that come into Penn Station and Grand Central still aren't connected because, a lifetime ago, they used to be operated by rival firms. Now that they are both managed by the public sector, this anachronism ought to be corrected. 
Intercity train travel is also vital to New York. In the best of times, the airports are crowded and inconvenient. We can improve connections in and out of town by insisting that Amtrak receive a fairer share of federal subsidies. Last year, Washington lavished $12.5 billion on air travel, $33.4 billion on highways and a mere $520 million on Amtrak. This is a ridiculous imbalance, all the more so when you factor in the $15 billion that went to prop up the airlines after Sept. 11. It's also dangerous. Relying so much on air travel is what military planners call a lack of necessary redundancy.
How do we pay for it? Paris recently financed part of its $35 billion subway renovation (the national government paid most of it) with a regional payroll tax, a hard sell in New York. But our private sector could do its part by not demanding the tax breaks and other bribes they often get for merely not leaving the city. These public resources could better be spent on transit, a true form of economic development.
Another idea is to create tax-increment finance zones along a new Second Avenue subway line. When property values rise, as they inevitably would when the subway is put in, property tax receipts would rise, too, and this extra money could be used to pay off the construction bonds.
No matter what, though, we will need the federal government on our side, in a way it never really has been. We must convince legislators that helping New York doesn't mean just subsidizing the parochial interests that have long controlled the city. Part of this will certainly mean working with the trade unions to lower costs and show that public-works projects need not be mere boondoggles.
But the larger argument is this: New York is the country's only truly global financial center, a status that is by no means guaranteed. When the Sept. 11 attack paralyzed many New York firms, it wasn't just New Jersey, Connnecticut, Chicago and San Francisco that picked up the slack. It was also London, the natural place for global finance to migrate should New York falter. That would leave a gaping hole in the American economy, not to mention the federal budget. Last year, New York City produced federal tax receipts of $49billion and received roughly $41 billion back in federal spending. Just making up half this annual difference would pay for roughly four miles of the eight-mile Second Avenue subway.
New Yorkers must resist the urge to adopt a survivalist mentality and scale back our ambitions. Mass transit produced this city -- its unique scale, its marvelously high density and all the good things that entails -- and mass transit can revive it in a way that no other single thing can. The best part is that if New York improves its subways, trains and ferries, it becomes not only a better place, but more like itself, more New Yorkish.

HEADLINE: RETHINK : Manifestoes For the Next New York; 
Labor : Capitalize on Blue-Collar Heroism

BYLINE:  By Sara Mosle; Sara Mosle is writing a book about East Texas in the 1930's.

 BODY:
For the first time in decades, America's heroes are everyday working people: firemen, postal workers, E.M.S. technicians, police officers, soldiers. In celebrity magazines, iron welders appear, in their beefy union T-shirts, like movie stars, and outside the city's firehouses, crowds continue to linger -- the buckets of flowers still fresh, the candles still lighted. As David Letterman said, summing up the nation's sense of gratitude: "I hope we never, ever take these people for granted."
 If ever there was a moment for the revival of organized labor, it is now. Yet Congress and corporate America seem shockingly unattuned to this extraordinary shift in the national mood. Of the government's $15 billion bailout of the airlines, not one cent went to laid-off workers. Only 2.3 percent of the House of Representatives' $100 billion "stimulus" package went to extending unemployment and health insurance to the more than half a million newly unemployed. And because the rules governing such programs have not kept pace with the changing face of labor, vast sectors of working-class Americans -- especially the immigrants and single working parents in part-time, seasonal and minimum-wage service jobs -- won't qualify for even this meager aid. In many states, even legal immigrants are denied assistance, and welfare caps are kicking in at just the wrong moment. 
 This neglect creates enormous challenges -- and opportunities -- for labor. The most visible heroes of Sept. 11 belong to the city's municipal unions, who put a heartbreakingly human face on the values labor has historically embraced: sacrifice, solidarity, brotherhood. Yet they will have a hard time capitalizing on this overdue recognition in a city facing a huge budget deficit. New York's private-sector unions will be even harder-pressed. The city estimates that by the end of the year more than 100,000 New Yorkers will have lost their jobs because of the attacks, many of them low-wage, immigrant service employees.
The first job of organized labor has been to help these workers, and the families of those who died, get the benefits they need. Now labor needs to argue vociferously for changing the immigration laws, joining forces with those Republicans who, before Sept. 11, supported extending the benefits and protections Americans enjoy to all immigrants. No city is better poised than New York to show the country how vital immigrants are to our economy. They are equally vital to labor's future. Service jobs, by definition, can't be shipped overseas, which means low-wage, immigrant service employees are ripe for unionization. "Our mission," says Bill Granfield, president of New York City's Local 100 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International union (HERE), "is to organize the unorganized."
This won't happen on a large scale without reform of our labor laws. In the past, that prospect seemed like a pipe dream, but now that the nation is re-evaluating the importance of some of its humblest workers, it's time to put it on the agenda. The present rules are so wildly skewed to favor employers -- who can subject employees to antiunion propaganda meetings while denying unions any access whatsoever and firing workers illegally for union activity -- it's a miracle if a union ever wins an organizing drive. We should end all that and instead follow the lead of Canada, which allows workers to indicate their preference by simply signing a card, a process known as "card checks." And once the cards are tallied, we should prevent the loser from litigating the results for years on end. New York can lead the way by requiring all rebuilding be done with union labor and all businesses that are restored with government money to agree to card checks for employees pursuing union representation. 
While it's important to acknowledge labor's past failings -- mismanagement, fraud and a few former associates swimming with the fishes -- few other institutions can do as much for the city's economy. By putting money into the pockets of average Americans, a union can be a surprisingly effective stimulus program. In New York, for example, where labor represents 95 percent of the city's maids, they can earn upward of $15 an hour, with benefits. And their salaries exert an upward pressure on those even in nonunion shops. HERE Local 100, however, represents just 10 percent of the city's dishwashers, who make $8 and $9 an hour -- better than the minimum wage, but not enough to escape poverty. And as for the charge that unions are bad for business, has anyone noticed that Southwest, one of the few airlines still making money, without layoffs, is also the airline with such famously good management-labor relations? 
"We helped propel the recovery of many cities in the 1990's," says John Wilhelm, the president of HERE. In Las Vegas, home to HERE's largest local, its 50,000 members helped make the city the fastest-growing in the country, partly because they had decent wages to spend. "We employ the largest number of immigrants, the largest number of welfare-to-work people, the largest number of single mothers," says Wilhelm. How they fare will shape society's fortunes. The World Trade Center attack taught us how interconnected we all are: the dishwasher at Windows on the World, the bus driver at Port Authority, the security guard at Morgan Stanley.
Labor has always relied on public opinion, and during the 1930's, through the worst possible economic times, unions made their greatest gains because their message of sacrifice and solidarity resonated with all Americans. It is now up to the city's labor leaders to make the connection between the heroes of Sept. 11 and the organizations that can best represent them.

SECTION: Section 6; Column 3; Magazine Desk; Pg. 128

HEADLINE: RETHINK : Manifestoes For the Next New York; 
Economy : Bring Back the MAC

BYLINE:  By Felix G. Rohatyn; Felix G. Rohatyn, ambassador to France from 1997 to 2000, was chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation from 1975 to 1993.

 BODY:
There is no question that New York City and New York State are facing not only a serious financial crisis, but an economic crisis as well. The crisis of 1975 was essentially financial: with a $1.5 billion deficit on a budget of about $15 billion and $6 billion of short-term debt coming due, the city was unable to finance itself in the marketplace. However, the city's economy was turning around, and once the debt was refinanced and the budget was brought under control, the economy recovered strongly.
 This is not the situation we now face. The city is not facing bankruptcy, the debt structure is leveled out, the accounting is transparent and up to now the budget has been under control. The total debt, however, is almost $35 billion (or about $4,000 per capita), and as a result of the terrorist attack and an already weak economy, the city's financial situation is deteriorating markedly. This is leading to big budget deficits -- already over $4 billion for the city and what may grow to $6 billion for the state -- that cannot be closed in short order without permanently damaging the city's social and economic structure. 
 The trauma of the attack and the fear of future incidents, together with the city's uncertain financial posture, are causing a number of businesses to rethink their future here. Some, wary of service cutbacks and tax increases, are considering relocating. Others, directly affected by the disaster, are facing bankruptcy. The city's restaurant-industry leaders warn that their sector alone could lose 150,000 jobs if credit assistance is not available soon. 
Counteracting this alarming trend will require inspired leadership on the part of Governor Pataki and the mayor. A number of the mechanisms that were set up during the crisis of 1975 are still in place, and politicians might wish to use them. Furthermore, the alliance among business, labor, city and state should be reconstituted and should put out a sustained call for business to stay in New York. The mayor and the governor must be the cheerleaders of this effort. 
In the light of the city's looming deficits, the Municipal Assistance Corporation (MAC) and the Financial Control Board, whose deficit financing and budget control returned the city to the financial markets in the 1970's, could be reactivated. MAC is an existing structure, presided over by the former state comptroller Edward V. Regan, with an independent board, investment-grade credit ratings and transparent public accounts. MAC issued $10 billion in bonds between 1975 and 1985, of which all but $3 billion have been repaid. The balance will be paid back by 2008. MAC's free cash flow is $3.4 billion annually. With renewed borrowing authority it could significantly assist a plan to bridge four to five years of deficit financing. The Financial Control Board, consisting of the governor, the mayor, the city and state comptrollers and three private citizens, is useful not only in assisting the mayor on difficult choices but also in reassuring the agencies that rate city and MAC bonds. 
Other agencies, like the New York City Transitional Finance Authority and the Industrial Development Authority, are also able to participate in this effort. 
However, to obtain additional federal assistance, we will need to show a significant local effort. In the 1970's we did this, with the cooperation of the unions and of the banks, by freezing expenses, increasing certain taxes, restructuring debt and handing some city functions over to the state. In this case, those particular taxes would be counterproductive, but the commuter tax is a different matter. There was never a valid economic reason for repealing it, since it requires commuters to share some of the costs for city services that they enjoy, and in this period of emergency it should be reinstated promptly. It would provide $400 million annually to the city.
But local strategies alone won't solve the problem. In contrast to the late 1970's, today the national economy is heading into a recession and aggravating the city's problems. The first national relief effort we should pursue is an alliance of mayors and governors to promote a national revenue-sharing program, which would offset the harsh fiscal contractions that practically every state will require. A five-year plan that would return $100 billion to state and local governments could provide nearly $20billion of budgetary assistance to New York under the sharing formulas presently used in federal transportation bills. This was a program that was begun by President Nixon in 1972 and that functioned very successfully until 1981, providing grants to 50 states and 37,000 localities.
Second, we need a plan to encourage infrastructure investment. Public pension funds that currently manage almost $500 billion of assets could invest in special state and city bonds to finance projects like transportation, schools, roads, buildings and many others, making our public facilities safer and more modern. A national program of $25 billion annually would create nearly one million jobs per year and significantly improve the country's productivity and quality of life. New York's share of such a program could be as much as $5 billion annually. The bonds would have to be guaranteed by the federal government to meet the fiduciary obligations of the pension-fund trustees, but they would ultimately be paid off by the revenues generated at the state and local levels. (The city's pre-Sept. 11 needs for normal capital projects total nearly $20 billion.)
The Bush administration's refusal to consider Governor Pataki's request for $54 billion of assistance is not surprising, given our history with Congress. "I Love New York" does not necessarily translate into open-ended federal assistance. So it's clear that solving the current crisis will require different approaches, some old, some new. But whatever they may be, some fundamentals cannot be allowed to change: the city must continue to be a magnet for people and for ideas, for culture and for commerce, for science and for technology. New York is an irreplaceable national asset; our governor and our mayor must see to it that it is treated as such. They must set a clear objective for the New York of tomorrow.

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 118
