HEADLINE: REWRITE; 
Post-9/11: The Series

BYLINE:  By Lynn Hirschberg; Lynn Hirschberg is a contributing writer for The New York Times Magazine.

 BODY:
 LYNN HIRSCHBERG: Television shows from "N.Y.P.D. Blue" to "Seinfeld" and "Sex and the City" have projected an image of New York City to the world. Now that we've entered into a new moment in the city's history, is it up to television to help re-establish that image. And how do you, as television producers, go about doing that?
PAUL SIMMS: It might be too soon to say. I was thinking about this last night -- if I were doing a show about New York right now, what would be a safe avenue for comedy that could reflect how people are feeling in this changed city. And I thought, Well, you know, you could do a silly story about gas-mask hysteria. All your characters are desperate to get a gas mask. And then 10 minutes later I turn on the Internet and a 7-month-old baby has anthrax, and suddenly that joke isn't so funny. One of the problems with being overly topical on a sitcom is you have at least a one-month lead time. And these days, things are changing very quickly.

DARREN STAR: There has also been a powerful shift in the country's perception of New York City. Suddenly New York isn't perceived as "over there," a separate entity from the rest of the country, a place where people are somehow different. The country really has embraced New York. And there's a flip side to that: people have always come to New York to be the outsiders and the radicals and a little apart from everything. And now we're being embraced, and I'm not so sure how everyone feels about it.
SIDNEY LUMET: I don't think we like it.
SIMMS: There's always been a disjunction between the general notion of how the country perceives New York -- as this strange, crazy place -- and how much they identify with shows set in New York. People who watch "Seinfeld" and "Friends," and probably going back as far as "The Honeymooners" and "All in the Family," they think, Oh, those characters are just like my buddies whom I hang out with. There's something generically cosmopolitan about those shows. Probably when people watch "Sex and the City," they see New York and feel like they're in a specific place. But I don't get the sense that they do that with "Friends" or "Will and Grace."
STAR: In "Sex and the City" I think we try to make New York look specifically glamorous and exotic.
SIMMS: And "Sex and the City" is the one comedy that is probably most affected by what happened.
STAR: I agree. We have a real challenge because we film in New York, and it's not a traditional sitcom. We don't have a laugh track.
SIMMS: I also think "Sex and the City" is the sitcom best equipped to deal with the city's changed mood.
STAR: "Sex and the City" always took as its core material this great frisson of silliness and fashion and an enormous amount of money and superficiality. We had fun with it, we celebrated it, we did a lot of things with it. And now there is a shifting mood. But luckily, the characters were heading in that direction anyway. This past season the show took a more dramatic turn, a more thoughtful turn. Still, I think it would be a mistake to make a direct correlation in the show between the trade center catastrophe and how the characters are feeling.
SIMMS: No matter how well it's done, when a sitcom tries to tackle a serious issue, it always reminds me of the episode of "Mr. Belvedere" about AIDS. It was a noble attempt, I guess, but it's like listening to someone play "Ave Maria" on a kazoo. As well as they might be able to play, and as much as it touches you, it's still a kazoo. And there's nothing wrong with kazoos, and there's nothing wrong with a sitcom, but it's a fantasy world -- and I mean that in an absolutely positive sense. It resembles reality, but you know no one's going to die. No one's going to be the victim of a violent crime. No one's going to have a terminal illness. And I like it that way.
 I mean, the first non-news thing I watched after all this happened was the season premiere of "Friends." Until then I'd been thinking, Who cares about make-believe TV? But then "Friends" was funny, and it made me laugh -- partly because I knew nothing terrible was going to happen to these people.
HIRSCHBERG to LUMET : You do a show set in New York. Are you planning to incorporate anything about Sept. 11 into "100 Centre Street"?
LUMET: No. I don't think we should touch it.
HIRSCHBERG: Why not?
LUMET: It was a cataclysm. The worst that I know of in 50 years. Anything you might try to do would turn out sentimental. It's the very definition of sentimentality -- you're not creating the emotion; the emotion is happening because of an echo that has nothing to do with the work you're doing. So right away, that's exploitative.
 Also, no matter what you say about television -- good, bad or indifferent -- it exists for only one reason. It exists to sell something. And I don't think it's right to use subject matter like this to sell something. 
SIMMS: Even if you don't want to deal with the actual event, Sidney, is there a way in a drama show like yours that the difference between before and after can be reflected?
LUMET: I think it'll happen automatically. It'll happen in the writing; it'll happen in the performances; it'll happen through the direction. Assuming that you're functioning well, which to me means that you're pouring yourself into your work, whatever you are at that moment is going to show up on the screen. I don't want to go searching for the way to do it. I'm just going to assume it's going to show up.
STAR: Don't you also think it's only with hindsight that you can see the effect certain events have on television? I think if you look at television in the 60's, you saw a very specific reaction to the Vietnam War, which was, Let's ignore it and pretend that everything's right with this country.
HIRSCHBERG: Isn't there such a thing, though, as entertainment that consciously reflects social issues and moments in history? Is it possible to turn those moments into entertainment that's meaningful to people, that helps people understand what's happening in their world?
SIMMS: I guess so. Shows like "All in the Family" and "M*A*S*H" were designed to do that from the STARt, and they did make it work. But when you take regular sitcoms, which are like Broadway musicals without the music, and you try to graft social commentary onto it, that's when you end up with the most useless, embarrassing stuff.
STAR: Right. Which is why I don't know if on "Sex and the City" we're going to do a gas-mask episode anytime soon.
SIMMS: Topical material on sitcoms, when you see it a few years later in reruns, you feel so embarrassed. Even with "M*A*S*H," the more serious episodes are the ones that when I turn on the rerun and see it I go, "Ugh." They don't age well. And the topical stuff I did on "News Radio" -- an episode about controversial hip-hop lyrics or a reference to Joey Buttafuoco -- at the time those seemed funny as hell, but a few years later they just make me cringe.
HIRSCHBERG: Do you feel like the era of "M*A*S*H" and "All in the Family" was one where television was allowed to be more socially conscious?
STAR: Sure. We've just been through a long sustained period of prosperity, and we haven't been provoked into thinking very much.
SIMMS: Two and a half years ago I did a pilot about a bunch of young American kids in the Peace Corps, set in a fictional country that was supposed to be somewhere between Pakistan and India. I thought, It's an isolated location, it's young kids away from America, it's the clash of cultures, it'll be great.
HIRSCHBERG: What kind of reaction did you get?
SIMMS: It was a miserable failure. The network did audience research, and on a scale of 1 to 100, we got like a 5 or a 6. They said, The audience is actively rejecting this concept.
LUMET: The interesting thing about both "M*A*S*H" and "All in the Family" is that they were created -- I'm not bragging, gang -- but they were created by producers from my generation. Larry Gelbart and Norman Lear are from my time. They came out of the same experience that I did.
STAR: I agree. Paul and I were both born in the 60's, and our generation really didn't have a lot to challenge us. And a lot of the product we're creating reflects that. It's not a coincidence that in the fairly cushy period that we've just lived through, a lot of the shows that have been successful have relied on the comedy of self-involvement.
SIMMS: When everything else is going so well, you can focus on the little things that aren't.
STAR: And that does come out of a certain experience -- in the same way that once you've been through a war, as Sidney has, it changes you, and you write from that point of view.
HIRSCHBERG: If you were STARting from scratch to create a show to reflect the new New York, what kind of setting would you think about?
SIMMS: On the nuts-and-bolts level the first thing I would say, and this is partly selfish, is you have to shoot it in New York. Put the money into the local economy and use all the resources and all the tremendous actors and writers that are here. The idea of doing a show about New York from Los Angeles right now just doesn't feel right. As far as the concept, you can make anything work. I mean, firefighters -- women love firefighters, and firefighters know that women love them, so that could be funny.
STAR: I think this is like before-and-after New York. I think people are just staggered, they're kind of reassessing everything and really thinking about life.
SIMMS: There probably could be a good drama about soldiering on. Though to be honest, I don't know if I would watch it. The show I'd like to see is a "Law and Order"/type show about all the investigative work that's being done right now to piece all this together. But I don't want to see it now; I want to see it in five years.
HIRSCHBERG: Why don't you want to see it now?
SIMMS: Because now it would be all make-believe and made up.
STAR: You can watch the news every day.
SIMMS: Although, I have to say, I watched that new C.I.A. show. What was it called? Silence. Come on, you guys. Am I the only person here who actually watches TV? All right, I remember now -- it was called "The Agency." Before I watched it I thought, How can this beat the news? Then I watched it, and I have to say there was some appeal in seeing competent intelligence agents anticipating problems and solving them.
HIRSCHBERG to STAR : All the way back to "Beverly Hills, 90210," your shows have been peace-and-prosperity shows -- with the emphasis on prosperity. If the city and the country are changing economically, does that worry you? Does that mean your sort of show is harder to do?
STAR: Actually, "90210" was really popular during a big recession and the gulf war. That's when it became a hit. It created a comforting fantasy of wealth and family and a tight-knit group of friends. It was a world that you fantasized about but weren't really experiencing.
HIRSCHBERG: So would you still go for glamour and fashion now?
STAR: Glamour and fashion without characters doesn't mean anything.
SIMMS: But it can be the hook that, at least initially, gets people to try a show out.
STAR: It can be, yeah. But I'd love to write a show about my family's experience of growing up in the 1920's as the only Jewish family in Gettysburg, Pa.
SIMMS: I love it. Give me 22 episodes.
STAR: I'd call it "The Valtons." I think that would work now.
HIRSCHBERG: Have any of you ever heard from a network that a show is "too New York"?
LUMET: Oh, yeah. You hear that all the time.
SIMMS: Didn't they say that about "Seinfeld"?
HIRSCHBERG: Yeah, it was code for "It's too Jewish."
LUMET: Back in my live television days -- and this was a long time ago -- there were only so many times you could use the guy in the cardigan before you'd get a word from the advertising agency. Cardigans and diamond bathrobes.
STAR: I'm not quite sure what that represents.
LUMET: It represents old Jews.
STAR: Coming to New York as a kid, I found a Jewishness to New York. But now I think that New York has been embraced by so many other people that have come here in the past 20 years. To me, the city has evolved. Now I think of it as Jewish plus everything else.
SIMMS: If there's a pejorative image people have of New York now, it's probably gone from being the Jewish thing to the John Rocker image of a place full of immigrants and weirdos. Which is of course exactly what makes the city great.
LUMET: It's one of the joys, by the way, of shooting in Astoria. It's the most integrated place I've ever been in the United States. And beautiful. It's right out of a Norman Rockwell drawing. When you pass a school at 3 o'clock and those mothers are waiting for the kids to come out -- Pakistani, Korean, Chinese -- I mean, it's extraordinary.
HIRSCHBERG: And is that something you try to reflect through TV?
LUMET: On our show we do. I think whites are in the minority on the show.
SIMMS: But when we talk about all of these New York shows, that multicultural idea really hasn't been reflected very often. I mean, the show that probably came closest to reflecting it successfully was "All in the Family." And even that wasn't particularly multicultural unless Sammy Davis Jr. stopped by for a guest appearance. But it was dealing with all those -- I hate to say dealing with issues, because it did much more than that -- but it tried at least to acknowledge the reality of the city.
HIRSCHBERG: Sidney, would you have an Arab character on "100 Centre Street" as a way to comment on anti-Arab racism?
LUMET: It wouldn't bother me.
HIRSCHBERG: But would you intentionally introduce a character to do that?
LUMET: No. If it's not organic, it'll stand out.
HIRSCHBERG: But isn't that one way that TV really does have power? Like the coming-out episode in "Ellen," it can open up a public conversation.
SIMMS: I know what you're saying, but I think it would feel weird to inject an Arab or Arab-American character onto a show in hopes of changing people's attitudes. It's going to be the AIDS episode of "Mr. Belvedere" all over again, except with a Lebanese guy.
HIRSCHBERG: What about class? The city's heroes now are very working class: firemen, policemen, construction workers. Their status in the city has been elevated vastly and the rich and famous suddenly don't seem quite as heroic. Is that something you'd want to reflect in a show?
SIMMS: Sure, but I don't know if people -- at least with comedy -- are really looking for a show about their heroes. That's the problem right now. If someone twisted your arm and said, all right, you have to do a sitcom about firemen because everyone loves firemen now, it would be a nightmare to try to do. To make the characters real they would need to have flaws. And I don't know if the network would want to see firemen depicted right now with any kind of flaw.
STAR: I was thinking the other day, if my show "The Street" were still on the air, it would be the only show -- because it was about Wall Street -- that would have to deal directly with the World Trade Center. We would have had no choice.
HIRSCHBERG: If you were pitching "The Street" now, what would you do?
STAR: Not pitch it, I'm guessing. It'd be a very tough sell: Wall Streeters picking up the pieces of their lives.
HIRSCHBERG: But you could argue the opposite too. CBS is doing a pilot in which a widow falls in love with a widower and they both lost spouses in the World Trade Center.
SIMMS: Yeah, but I read on the Internet last night that the widower and the widow was a pre-existing concept that CBS was already developing. And then Les Moonves, the president of CBS, said, "Let's raise the stakes."
HIRSCHBERG: "Let's raise the stakes"?
SIMMS: You guys have probably heard that a few thousand times.
STAR: Yeah, of course. You always hear "Let's raise the stakes."
LUMET: What's that?
STAR: You've never heard "Let's raise the stakes"?
LUMET: Pardon my ignorance.
SIMMS: It's not ignorance, Sidney, it's the fact they respect you. They wouldn't dare say to you, "Let's raise the stakes."
LUMET: What does it mean?
SIMMS: Make it more dramatic or --.
STAR: Put more at jeopardy.
LUMET: They certainly don't mean, "Let's take a bigger chance."
SIMMS: No, it doesn't mean take a bigger chance. Just create more jeopardy for your characters.
HIRSCHBERG: Speaking of jeopardy, we haven't talked yet about reality TV. Is there still an audience for it?
SIMMS: Everyone's theory right now is, Who's going to care about a bunch of survivor people playing make-believe, having their mettle tested in a make-believe world? But the thing people forget about reality TV is that it's as much a fantasy as scripted TV. You know, you're not watching eight people living in the desert. You're watching eight people who want desperately to be famous living in the desert, knowing that there are cameras all around them. Which is much more entertaining. "Fear Factor" was the other big show of the summer, and people are saying, Who's going to care now about that? But right now I'd be fascinated to see people confronting their own fears. It's what we're all doing.
HIRSCHBERG: But there's lying in a tub of sheep eyes, and then there's anthrax.
SIMMS: That's true. But when you see a reality show, the fascination is watching how it plays out. You're dealing with some seriously damaged personalities who desperately want to get on the lowest rung of fame. You don't care whether they get more drinking water or someone wins a can of beans. You want to watch them compete for camera time and to be the most interesting one.
STAR: I've never been a big reality TV fan, but you're making it sound really good.
SIMMS: Just watch the season finale of "Love Cruise," and I guarantee you'll be calling someone at the studio to get the tapes of the rest of the episodes. There is another kind of reality TV right now, though, which is "20/20" and "48 Hours" and "Dateline." I've found those very compelling recently. The half-hour episode one of those shows did about rescue dogs was great. Even at its most sensationalistic, it's a return to straightforward documentary storytelling. And I love documentaries.
HIRSCHBERG: Would it be safe to say that you guys basically think that New York doesn't need rebuilding through television?
SIMMS: No, television isn't going to rebuild anything or heal anything. I think it affects people profoundly, but I'm skeptical of its ability to change the world or even people's attitudes. TV's transformative power is an idea that TV people repeat over and over. It's artistically self-congratulatory, but I don't know if it's actually true.
STAR: Yeah, but TV does shape people's image of New York to a degree. And I think in that sense, it's important not to recoil from New York as a place to set stories. I think that the character of the people that has been on display here the past couple of months is just so demonstrative of the city.
HIRSCHBERG: As a kid growing up in L.A., I thought television was a window onto the glamorous world of New York City. Letterman, especially. I just thought he was the coolest thing in the universe. And his was such a New York world. Did you guys feel that?
SIMMS: Writing for Letterman was the only job I ever wanted, and for exactly those reasons.
STAR: Yeah, Letterman and "Saturday Night Live" defined a certain comedic sensibility that was very New York.
SIMMS: And whatever happens, I don't think that's going anywhere.

The Participants
Sidney Lumet is the creator of "100 Centre Street" and the director of many movies, including "Serpico," "Dog Day Afternoon" and "Network." Darren STAR is the creator of "Sex and the City," "Beverly Hills, 90210" and "Central Park West," among other programs. Paul SIMMS is the creator of "News Radio" and a former head writer of "The Larry Sanders Show."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/The Federal Reserve Bank of New York; 
Mix of Limestone and Sandstone, in Florentine Style

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
BUILT in 1924, the Florentine-style Federal Reserve Bank at 33 Liberty Street had long ago acquired an ancient-looking patina of black crust on its noble stones. When a yearlong facade cleaning was completed late this summer, it revealed a fascinating variety of coloration and pattern in the huge blocks of stone. In the last few weeks, after the attack of Sept. 11, the stones have had to be dusted off again.
 The Federal Reserve Bank, with its 12 regional divisions, was established in 1913 by a Congress wary of the growing concentration of giant banking interests and weary of the repeated bank panics of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, which severely disrupted the economy. Benjamin Strong, who became the dominant force behind the Federal Reserve, originally opposed the regional system; he had favored a strong central bank. 
 Born in 1866, Strong had left school at 18. He worked as a clerk in finance in the 1890's and then moved to Bankers Trust Company after 1900. There he advised the financial titans George F. Baker and J. P. Morgan on which banks to save in the Panic of 1907. 
Strong was selected to head the new Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which because of geography already held a leadership role in the system. And Strong's effective, aggressive leadership on bank issues made him the de facto leader of the Federal Reserve System.
World War I increased the United States role in international finance, and by 1919 The New York Times reported that the Federal Reserve Bank of New York had doubled its staff in the last year, to 2000. 
The bank had been using rented quarters, but in 1919 it held a competition for a new 14-story headquarters on the block bounded by Maiden Lane and Nassau, Liberty and William Streets. The Real Estate Record and Guide said that "no sensational type of building would be entertained by the bank." The submission by the firm of York & Sawyer took the prize. 
Starting in 1899, Edward York and Philip Sawyer had become the Northeast's specialists in bank design by infusing a sensuous quality into what are normally considered simply impressive buildings. Their design for the new Federal Reserve Bank of New York recalled the fortified Florentine palazzi of the Medici period in the Renaissance, with a deeply rusticated stone base banded by barred windows within pointed Florentine arches.
In 1929 the magazine Architecture quoted a young American who had come back from Europe marveling at everything he had seen except for one city. "Well, Florence didn't astound me so much," the anonymous American said jokingly. "Everywhere I looked I saw a building by York & Sawyer."
York & Sawyer also carefully mixed the stone on the facade, using both the traditional Indiana limestone and a richly mottled Ohio sandstone. The walls' meeting point with the sidewalk rises and falls on the irregular, hilly site like a ship on a pitching ocean. It is quite different from the usual rectilinear bank site, because each wall is alive with texture and movement. 
On the interior, the three-level gold vault was cut into raw stone, which itself was below the waterline, making a robbery attempt by tunneling unlikely; the vault doors each weighed 230 tons. The $500 million in gold then on deposit was also protected with listening devices to detect any drilling or cutting. Peter Bakstansky, a spokesman for the bank, said that the building now stores $63 billion in gold, almost all of it the reserves of foreign countries. 
In 1929 a writer for The Saturday Evening Post asked a guard outside the building what time it was; the guard grabbed the handle of his gun, directed the writer to a nearby sidewalk clock and instructed him to move on. 
THE Federal Reserve Bank could not at first gain control of the William Street end of the block, and bank construction went ahead without that portion, leaving an observable seam between the two sections when it was filled out in the mid-1920's.
In 1927 the critic Margaret Law, writing in the magazine Architecture, said the building had "a quality which, for lack of a better word, I can best describe as epic." The dignity of the building is enhanced with extensive ironwork, designed by Samuel Yellin.
Strong died in 1928, leaving a power vacuum at the Federal Reserve; although President Herbert Hoover blamed the severity of the Depression in part on Strong's aggressive efforts for European recovery in the 1920's, some analysts say that the Depression would not have lasted as long had Strong been alive to direct Federal Reserve efforts.
By the 1960's, airborne soil had given the building a striking checkerboard look. The Ohio sandstone, more porous than the limestone, became blackened, making the building appear almost black and white. Last year the Federal Reserve began a cleaning campaign, overseen by the architects Beyer Blinder Belle and the Turner Construction Company. 
Peter Mead, project superintendent for Turner, said that the cleaning had addressed both aesthetic and repair issues: with the soil off, the individual stones could be surveyed for damage. The work was finished this summer, and now the intermittent Ohio stone is freed of its black shroud, displaying exuberant whorls and eddies in the stone, swirling lines of whiskey brown in a matrix the color of heavy cream, as sensual as some exotic cheese or pate.
The only effect on the building since the destruction of the World Trade Center has been the continuing deposit of dust on ledges and stonework -- a filmy, stringy coating remains, although a fire hose has been used to clean some of it off.
The architectural pilgrim should not tarry too long: a recent admirer closely inspecting the newly cleaned stone was politely but firmly challenged by a guard, told to move along and to appreciate the facade from across the street.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Federal Reserve Bank of New York in 1924, left, the year it was built, showing varied coloration of its bricks. The building now, after cleaning. (Aaron Lee Fineman for The New York Times; Museum of the City of New York)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
Office Vacancy Rate in County Continues to Climb

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
UNCERTAIN" is a word heard often these days in Westchester when real-estate professionals discuss the commercial real estate market.
 Brokers are trying to fathom whether the current office market is experiencing a downturn or a full-blown recession -- and whatever they call it, how long the market will continue to slide. Also, they are asking: is there any relief in sight? 
 "We're trying to figure out what's real and what's not real in terms of the market," said James C. Fagan, a senior managing director for the regional office in Stamford of CB Richard Ellis, the real estate services company. "And we're trying to decide where we go from here. How does one make logical plans for the future in an illogical world? It's not an easy thing to do." 
A hoped-for bump in Westchester's struggling office market -- from displaced companies relocating from New York City after Sept. 11 -- has not yet materialized, Salvatore J. Carrera, director of economic development and real estate for the county, said.
So far, just a few companies have leased space in Westchester since the attack on the World Trade Center. Among them is RBC Dominion Securities, the investment banking division of RBC Financial Group, formerly Royal Bank of Canada, which rented space in RiverView at Purchase. Mr. Carrera would not identify the others.
Most companies forced to relocate did so within New York City. "It's unpatriotic -- they can't just leave New York behind," Mr. Fagan said.
THE vacancy rate for Class A office space rose in the most recent quarter, both in the county as a whole and in the biggest commercial area, the White Plains central business district.
In the county, the vacancy rose to 14.6 percent at the end of the third quarter, from 13.1 percent the previous quarter and 12 percent at the end of the third quarter a year ago, according to figures from Insignia/ESG, another commercial real-estate services company. 
In downtown White Plains at the end of the third quarter, the vacancy rate was 21.1 percent, up from 18.9 percent at the end of the previous quarter and up from 15.6 at the end of the third quarter of 2000.
Westchester, which already has a number of vacant buildings waiting for tenants, was further burdened this fall with Texaco's addition to the market of its 775,000-square-foot headquarters on Westchester Avenue in White Plains, referred to as the county's "Platinum Mile" corridor. The strip earned that appellation in the 1980's when many Fortune 500 companies were located there.
Texaco put its 24-year-old, four-story glass and travertine marble headquarters -- along with 107 acres of land and a two-tiered underground parking garage for 1,400 cars -- up for sale as a result of its merger with Chevron. The new company, ChevronTexaco, is based in San Francisco. 
The large chunk of Texaco's space is not reflected in the third-quarter vacancy rate because the merger did not take place until October, and the company is still vacating the building. It is expected that the already increasing vacancy rate will spike when Texaco's departure is reflected in the end-of-the-year figures, said Kenneth Krasnow, regional managing director in Connecticut and Westchester for Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services concern. 
"It means yet more space that needs to be absorbed in this market," Mr. Krasnow said.
In another troublesome sign, the amount of sublease space on the market has increased, reported Richard Rakow, owner of Rakow Commercial Realty Group in White Plains, which represents tenants. He said there is 7.3 million square feet of sublease space -- about 15 percent of all available office space -- on the market now. Last year at this time, there was 6.3 million square feet on the market, about 13.1 percent of all space available, Mr. Rakow said. 
SEVERAL years ago when leases came due, "tenants not only renewed them but grabbed whatever contiguous space they could," Mr. Rakow said. 
"Then, everyone was always thinking in terms of expansion," he explained. "Now, we're seeing tenants who aren't even using the space they have. Instead of looking for more space, they're seeking smaller quarters."
Reviewing the past 18 months, Mr. Krasnow of Cushman & Wakefield described the office market as "very active" in 2000, in large part from business generated by dot-coms and "coming back to earth" during the first part of this year.
"Then Sept. 11 changed the landscape dramatically," he said. "Companies that were in an uncertain position before then, like telecommunications firms, are even more uncertain now, although the bread-and-butter market is still doing fine."
The latter, he explained, are service-oriented enterprises, like marketing companies, law firms and accountants. Those small and midsized businesses are considered by most brokers to be the mainstay of Westchester's office market, fueling the growth from within.
Mr. Carrera said the county could no longer rely solely on the types of large companies that populated the Platinum Mile and other top corporate addresses in Westchester during the 1980's and early 1990's to support the office market, because if they downsize, it sends severe shock waves through the economy. He said Westchester's future economic health depended on a diversified base.
Looking ahead, Mr. Krasnow observed that even if some growth comes to Westchester from large New York City companies, it will probably be in the form of regional offices.
Judging from inquiries he has been receiving from Manhattan-based companies, Mr. Carrera said: "Westchester is high on the radar screen for satellite offices. I expect we'll see some definite activity later this year or early next year."
At Insignia/ESG, Dean J. Shapiro, the executive director of the company's Westchester-Fairfield office, said some satellite offices may take the shape of disaster recovery centers -- empty of people but equipped with phones and computers for emergencies.
"There is a fear among a number of companies of overcentralization and of not having backup resources," Mr. Shapiro explained.
For now, the market seems to be in a pause, he said, adding, "There's a lot of confusion and apprehension, and when we see that, we also often see a lack of decision-making."
IF companies from New York City decide to relocate at least some of their resources to Westchester, the following are some larger properties that brokers are showing them in addition to Texaco's building:
*Westchester One: a 850,000-square-foot building at 44 South Broadway in White Plains with 450,000 square feet available. The 30-year-old black glass structure currently houses Oxford Health and I.B.M.
*445 Hamilton Avenue, White Plains: a 320,000-square-foot building owned and partially occupied by MetLife, the giant insurer. Built in the late 1960's and occupied from mid 1980's until the late 1990's by Prodigy, it has 260,000 square feet available.
*333 Westchester Avenue, White Plains: There is 500,000 square feet in four connected buildings available in the former Kraft General Foods Building. The complex at North Street and Westchester Avenue became empty in July 1997 and has since started to add tenants. 
*900 King Street, Rye Brook, a former I.B.M. building that has been empty since the early 1990's. It is a three-story, 201,460-square-foot structure on a 17-acre campus.
*The Mount Pleasant Executive Center, a 383,000-square-foot building that was a former I.B.M. data center.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The last employees of Texaco Inc. are to leave the former headquarters in White Plains by the end of the year. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
For Some Companies, a Post-Sept. 11 Surge

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
THE terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 took thousands of American lives and helped push the economy toward a recession, bringing a number of companies to the brink of bankruptcy. At the same time, the attacks have provided an economic opportunity for others by creating a sense of urgency for products and services that could reassure a public suddenly preoccupied with bioterrorism, information security and personal safety.
 Some companies found that the attacks primed demand for products and services that had long been available. Others hastened to introduce new products and new services or reposition what they have always made or done in a new post-Sept. 11 light. 
 Among the businesses that have benefited in this new security-conscious environment are aviation engineering companies, disaster recovery concerns, industrial filtration manufacturers, security-system designers, wireless technology companies, biotechnologists, information technology experts and a host of others. 
Tom Roslak, the senior director of what Symbol Technologies of Holtsville calls its Security Initiative, said that Symbol, the wireless technology company best known for its hand-held bar-code scanners, had been upgrading wireless systems already in place to bolster security in airports, hospitals, schools and post offices. 
Two airlines, American and Delta, are currently testing a Symbol system that stores an encrypted photograph of a passenger's face in what the company calls a portable data file, essentially a series of different-sized bars. Advocates of wireless technology contend that the system is less vulnerable to disruption than wired systems dependent on pipes or cables and less a threat to personal liberties than systems that accumulate information about an individual in a centralized location. 
As is ever the case, marketers on Long Island and elsewhere are aggressively touting the benefits of using their products, but they are moving forward cautiously lest they be accused of exploiting a tragedy. 
But moving forward they are.
Last month, Michael O'Reilly, an environmental disaster specialist, sent a cleanup crew to decontaminate Governor Pataki's office in Midtown Manhattan after a room there tested positive for anthrax. It was the third anthrax job his company, Trade-Winds Environmental Restoration of Bay Shore, handled that week.
The company, which in normal times does routine chemical cleanups, was already in "disaster response" mode when the anthrax scare hit. Mr. O'Reilly had tripled his work force to 600 people on Sept. 11, responding to calls from clients, and kept on many of the new workers to respond to the subsequent anthrax threats. Sure, he's making money, but Mr. O'Reilly is hardly crowing about it. 
"I'm nearly exhausted," he said.
Brian Gertler, an information systems specialist at Leslie Digital Imaging's office in Hauppauge, said the anthrax scare had heightened interest in his scanners. Mail can be opened at a safe, remote location and digitally scanned; clients can then read it on their computer screens. 
"Now," he said, "I'm getting three times the number of call-backs I was before," Mr. Gertler said. 
Law firms, too, have gotten into the act. Ruskin, Moscou, Evans & Faltischek in Uniondale is now developing a security audit service aimed at the corporate and municipal markets. Wayne Kaplan, the lawyer there who is spearheading the project, said the service would help clients determine exactly how vulnerable their businesses are, whether the threat comes from natural disaster or human attack. A price for the service has not yet been determined.
Dr. Yacov Shamash, the dean of College of Engineering and Applied Sciences and of the Harriman School for Management and Policy at the State University at Stony Brook, said that a number of the Island's high-technology companies have already introduced products and that more will do so in the weeks and months to come.
Successful ventures will, in many cases, be the results of collaboration, Dr. Shamash said, reflecting partnerships that local business leaders are encouraging between companies and institutions. 
"Long Island isn't going to produce the tanks and airplanes to fight this war," he said. "We are going to produce the sensors, the avionics and the wireless telecommunications products that will be needed to fight it. There is no region in the country better suited to doing this than we are."
Peter D. Rettaliata, an aviation executive in Bay Shore, predicted that many Long Island companies would be bidding for military contracts in the fight against terrorism, reversing a pattern that has existed for a generation.
"Long Island aerospace companies grew up at a time when they could depend on local contractors like Grumman and Republic, and they did very well servicing these companies," said Mr. Rettaliata, the president of the Air Industries Machining Corporation and the chairman of the Aerospace & Defense Diversification Alliance in Peacetime Transition, an industry group known as Addapt. The alliance, he said, has helped more than 100 Long Island aviation companies, many of them dependent on military orders, to succeed in the commercial aviation market.
Now, he said, the financial crisis that currently grips the nation's commercial aviation industry means that local companies will need to replace revenues from that sector. He anticipates that the region will lose about a quarter of its revenues from commercial aviation but that it will make up the deficit through new military contracts.
"What has changed since Sept. 11 is that the focus of our members will probably be more toward defense because of the budget increases that seem to be occurring," Mr. Rettaliata said.
Already, shifts in aviation spending are reverberating on Long Island. Scott Abrams, the president of the Omnicon Group in Hauppauge, an engineering company specializing in aviation, said that the current national preoccupation with security systems for airplane cockpits has turned into a sudden source of new business.
"People would like to put in a cockpit door that stays locked, but you just can't do that," Mr. Abrams said. "If there's an incident in the passenger compartment, the plane instantly depressurizes and the cockpit door has to pop open," he said, to prevent an implosion. 
"There are real problems if that doesn't happen," he said. "So the solution has to be more sophisticated than some people realize."
Along with this new business, he said that he was also getting calls from customers who say they are now short-handed. "Everybody in aviation is cutting back," he said, "and they no longer have the manpower or resources to complete the design process of the projects they've got on the table. So they call us and see if we can act as their SWAT team."
Last month, the Long Island Association convened the first meeting of the Defense Industry Council, some 35 military contractors handpicked by the association's president, Matthew L. Crosson. At the council's first meeting, executives from such companies as BAE Systems, EDO, Lockheed Martin, Northrop Grumman, Telephonics, GSE Dynamics and IMS sat down for a face-to-face session with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. Senator Carl Levin of Michigan, the chairman of the Senate's Armed Services Committee, has agreed to meet with the group, but no date has been set. 
The purpose is to connect the region's leading defense contractors with the people in Congress who make, or who influence, procurement decisions. 
"On the positive side, there is some possibility that certain companies in defense may benefit" from the post-Sept. 11 environment, Mr. Crosson said.
"Beyond that," he added, "it is highly speculative to say that specific areas of Long Island's economy will benefit from the new circumstances."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter D. Rettaliata, right, of the Air Industries Machining Corporation says that military contracts will take up slack left by commercial aviation. With him is Al Bistrais. (Phil Marino for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For Latin Dancing, Follow the Beat and the Crowd 

BYLINE:  By MARC FERRIS 

 BODY:
FIVE years ago, Eddie Perez moved from the Bronx to Stamford and was surprised to find such a pronounced Hispanic presence in his new neighborhood.
 "In the Bronx, people think that Connecticut is a whole other country," he said. "They think it is the country. I never realized that there were so many Latinos up here until I moved here. I said, 'Wait a minute, there's something happening up here.' " 
 Census figures support his perception. In the last decade, the Hispanic population almost doubled in Stamford (to more than 19,000) and in Norwalk (nearly 13,000). Danbury's Hispanic population more than doubled (11,000-plus).
In New Haven, 21 percent of the residents are Hispanic, as is almost a third of Bridgeport's population. Those figures do not factor in the numbers of Brazilians, who speak Portuguese but whose cultural traditions are counted as Latino.
The population rise, added to the success of pop stars like Ricky Martin, Marc Anthony and Jennifer Lopez, has helped increase interest in Latin dancing in local night spots.
That phenomenon has enabled Mr. Perez to quit his job in publishing and work full time at his first love, salsa dancing, which he teaches in several clubs.
"My students come from all walks of life," he said. "I've got Russians, Romanians, Hungarians and Jewish students, who range from age 12 to 70. It's all about fun. It's not like ballroom, which is all serious.
"It doesn't matter if you're a beginner or a professional. All levels dance with each other. You never stop learning new moves."
One of the most elegant places to dance to a Latin groove is at the Terrace Club in Stamford, which has held a Latin night for two years.
"At first we drew 100 people, now we get four or five times that many," said Chris Donahue, a co-owner, who contends the club has the biggest dance floor between New York and Boston. "There are a lot of little cafes, but none of the big clubs cater to Latinos. People who come in appreciate the place and respect it. We've definitely found our niche for Saturday night."
Before the crowds show up around 11 p.m., Mr. Perez teaches a beginner salsa class. After his lesson, he holds court at a prominently placed table between dances.
Several of Mr. Perez's students first dabbled with ballroom styles.
"My wife and I took six or seven ballroom lessons that covered several different dances, but we didn't learn anything," Michael Saunders of Westport said. "With salsa, we concentrate on one dance and you really feel the beat in your gut. It's more sensual.
"It brings couples together, and also crosses a lot of social and economic boundaries. We've taken lessons with rich, poor, black, white, Chinese, young, old and all different types in between. You don't get that with ballroom."
Initially, Andrew Ilowitz, a Weston doctor, was cool to salsa steps. Now he is a self-proclaimed "salsa Jew" and is conducting beginner classes under the auspices of Mr. Perez.
"I like to do things well and I wasn't good when I started, but over a period of time, I surrendered and began to focus on the beat," he said. "Then it just clicked and I realized I could do it."
For Mr. Ilowitz, who enjoys skiing, rock climbing and mountain biking, salsa dancing is more than just a night out.
"When I hear that beat, it makes me nuts," he said. "I can't sit still. It's infectious. It offers a lot of sensory stimuli that's pretty potent. The nonverbal communication is so outrageous.
"Some people have problems articulating through words, but when you're out on the floor you could be with a perfect stranger from a different part of the world, yet you can come together through a certain set of rhythms and notes. It fits well with my other interests. I've got an adrenaline jones."
The Latin theme is so popular at the Terrace Club that it began to offer Brazilian nights on Fridays. The club's smaller sibling, the Next Door Cafe, which caters to a younger, less formal crowd, offers Latin night on Fridays and Brazilian night on Saturdays.
Other spots that move to a Latin groove include El Dorado in Norwalk and Mambo Cafe in Danbury. 
In New Haven, VanDome is a sophisticated place that has attracted a diverse crowd for six years. It focuses on the four most popular styles of Latin club music: salsa, merengue, bachata and cumbia.
"They play great music and try to capture the elegance of a supper club," said Cynthia Richtman, who teaches Latin steps at Dance Dimensions in Norwalk and often visits VanDome with her students.
In the cozy main room, spectators sit at tables or stand around the worn wooden dance floor. Since it is in an industrial area, and traffic on I-91 thrums just outside the back door, the club has an outdoor area with a separate disc jockey and offers Latin barbecue.
"We've always been Latin, we're not jumping on any bandwagon," said Nando Colon, the club's general manager. "When we started we had 10 people show up, and then the word got out. There's been quite a craze lately, though, after Ricky Martin brought it out, but not so much with the Latin market as with the American market. We get about 60 percent Latinos in here and the rest is mixed."
Coupled with the rising number of Latinos, salsa's crossover appeal suggests that the broad appeal of Latin music and dance is more than just a fad.
Janice Mahinka, who lives in Danbury and got her introduction to salsa dancing at the Mambo Cafe two and a half years ago, now teaches salsa steps in adult education programs and studies the music's history.
"Latin dancing gives you a chance to be one with your body," she said. "You can make mistakes; it's no big deal. You get to sweat and that's good. It's about being human in the purest sense."
A Latin beat can be heard at: The Terrace Club, 1938 West Main Street, Stamford, (203) 961-9770; Next Door Cafe, 1990 West Main Street, Stamford, (203) 316-8101; El Dorado, 24 Isaacs Street, Norwalk, (203) 299-0083; Mambo Cafe, 40 Elm Street, Danbury, (203) 790-1766; VanDome, 102 Hamilton Street, New Haven, (203) 789-2066.

HEADLINE: Islip Puts Huge Fee on Late-Night Flights 

BYLINE:  By PETER BOODY 

DATELINE: ISLIP 

 BODY:
AS air travel boomed in recent years, Islip's Town Board welcomed increased jet service at the town-owned Long Island MacArthur Airport as an economic boon and a convenience for most residents. When Southwest Airlines arrived in 1998 and steadily expanded service, neighbors who complained about all the noise got something close to a cold shoulder in Town Hall.
 So pilots, airport operators and the Federal Aviation Administration were astonished in September when the Town Board voted to impose a huge fee -- $50,000 -- on any plane landing at or taking off from MacArthur after 11 p.m. and before 6:30 a.m. 
 "It's as if they had no idea what the rules are," said Jeffrey Gilley, who oversees airport issues for the National Business Aviation Association, which lobbies for corporate operators. He said the fee violated federal rules requiring extensive cost-benefit studies before municipalities can restrict access to airports. 
"It's ridiculous," said John Fiore, a captain with AOL-Time Warner's three-jet corporate fleet based at the airport. Mr. Fiore said AOL-Time Warner had been juggling crews, airplanes and passengers ever since the fee was imposed to avoid it.
The $50,000 charge was unanimously adopted Sept. 10 and was supposed to go into effect in a matter of days. It's probably the highest fee ever legislated for any airport in the country, according to the business aviation group's Mr. Gilley.
"There are a number of airports that have imposed fees in the $500, even $1,000 range, and some operators might be able to absorb that," he said. "But I think the Town of Islip wanted to make it so onerous that it would scare off everybody" who wanted to use the airport at night.
Until the new measure, there was never a charge for light single- or twin-engine private planes landing or taking off from MacArthur, and commercial flights were charged according to weight -- about $130 for a Boeing 737, the kind of plane Southwest flies.
"I think the F.A.A.'s concern," he added, "is that Islip is attempting to make an end run around the federal requirements," which also mandate "fair and reasonable terms without unjust discrimination against users" of airports supported by F.A.A. grants, as MacArthur has been. 
Despite all the sound and fury, the fee so far is not being enforced, according to Trish Pasciutti, a spokeswoman for the town, and won't be "until we feel it's appropriate to do so." She referred further questions to the town supervisor, Peter McGowan, who did not respond to repeated requests for comment.
Residents of nearby communities who have been complaining about the increased noise emanating from the airport might be expected to applaud the new fee. But last week, Deborah Slinkosky of the Committee for the Enforcement of MacArthur Airport Control, a civic group that fights airport noise, said the fee was just a political prop signifying nothing more than pre-Election Day saber-rattling and posturing.
Mrs. Slinkosky said the town had had an ordinance on the books for years that bars noisy arrivals and departures, but has never enforced it. She asserted that the new fee was just for show to make the Republican-controlled Town Board look responsive as two Republican councilmen sought re-election. The councilmen, Christopher Bodkin and Brian Ferrugiari, won easily on Tuesday.
Mrs. Slinkosky complained that until the slump in air travel after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, Islip area residents had been suffering with increased jet noise as airlines boosted service at Islip to meet rising demand. But she blamed noisy off-hour departures on "Learjets leaving at 4 a.m. so they could tee off down in Florida at 6 a.m."
Told of Mrs. Slinkosky's remarks about boorish high rollers, Mr. Fiore of AOL-Time Warner said: "We don't do that. These airplanes are used for business. They are people being moved for meetings and doing business all over the world."
Small single-engine and twin-engine prop airplanes, which keep Islip busy even when there's a lull in jet traffic, don't bother her at all, Mrs. Slinkosky said. The $50,000 surcharge fee applies to all aircraft, however, even a two-seat Cessna, so the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, the national organization of general aviation, is aggressively pushing the F.A.A. to crack down on the town.
"At our end of aviation there's usually not a noise problem," said Warren Morningstar, a spokesman for the group. "With a typical general aviation airplane, it's making less noise than the neighbor's lawn mower once it's climbing above the airport fence." Even most modern jets conform to the town's ordinance on aircraft noise, he added.
Less than a year ago Mr. McGowan rejected Ms. Slinkosky's demand that the town adopt a "homeowner's bill of rights" that would include a night curfew on airport takeoffs and landings, although he did agree then to talk to the F.A.A. about halting private flights late at night.
Mr. McGowan considers the airport "Islip's crown jewel," Ms. Slinkosky said. Operations there have soared during his term and he favors its continuing expansion, she said.
There are no scheduled airline flights at MacArthur between 11 p.m. and 6:30 a.m. A spokeswoman for Southwest Airlines said the surcharge had no effect on the airline's operations. Even if a flight arrives after 11 p.m., the ordinance imposing the $50,000 fee includes an exemption for late arrivals due to traffic and weather delays, she noted.
The business aviation lobby and the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association have asked the F.A.A. to investigate the legality of Islip's $50,000 surcharge. In early October, the F.A.A.'s deputy associate administrator of airports, Paul Galis, wrote Mr. McGowan warning that the fee violates the Airport Noise and Capacity Act of 1990 by restricting access to the airport for all airplanes, "regardless of their noise emissions." Mr. Galis asked the town to send him a written promise that it would either rescind the fee or agree never to enforce it.
The town attorney, Vincent J. Messina Jr., answered with a letter on Oct. 12 pointing out technical errors he had found in Mr. Galis's letter and demanding "a clear, unequivocal determination of the F.A.A.'s position."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Manhattan; 
Amid Uncertainty, Few Office Buildings Are for Sale

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
OWNERS of office buildings think their properties are still worth what they were before the attack on the World Trade Center, many real estate executives say. But prospective buyers think that a slowing economy and the aftereffects of Sept. 11 have reduced those values. The resulting disconnect means that few properties in New York are changing hands or are even for sale.
 "Nobody knows what's going on; there is a lot of confusion out there," said Scott R. Latham, a senior vice president at CB Richard Ellis, the brokerage and services company. Nevertheless, he said, there has been a great deal of interest in one of the few properties on the market, the 1 million square foot building at 450 Lexington Avenue at 45th Street. He said buyers are interested despite the building's having a large Post Office branch, and its location adjacent to the landmark Grand Central Terminal, both seen as drawbacks since the attack. 
 The marketplace uncertainties have multiple sources. Office rental rates are the economic underpinning of the sale prices of buildings, but the outlook for rental rates is unclear, the executives say. The attack removed 13.5 million square feet of space from the market, but 6 million square feet of sublet space became available within weeks of the event, leading some to wonder if the space needs of companies displaced from downtown have been satisfied, particularly since many have relocated at least parts of their operations to New Jersey and other suburban markets.
"There is a lot of concern about rents relaxing, but with very little leasing velocity it is hard to tell where rents are going," said Warren M. Heller, a managing director at Jones Lang LaSalle, the brokerage and services company.
Interest rates are down to near record lows, which would seem to promote sales, since borrowers have to pay less for money to make an acquisition. But those same low interest rates give owners an incentive to hold out for a top price, since they have the option of pulling cash out of a property by refinancing. This strategy allows an owner to liquidate much of the gain in the value of a building in a tax-free manner while still retaining the property.
Another uncertainty involves possible incentives that the city and state governments may devise to repair the damage downtown and to lure tenants back to the area. According to a recent report by Williams Real Estate, officials are "considering a package of incentives that will bridge the gap between the approximately $30 to $50 a square foot rental rate tenants were paying before the attack and the $70 to $80 a square foot developers will need to cover the cost of construction in Manhattan."
Since Sept. 11, "it has become more complicated to buy office buildings," said Adam I. Popper, an executive of Tishman Speyer Properties, an investment and management company. "There is a big spread between the bid and asked price, and we are not seeing many transactions."
Despite the current lack of willing sellers, he said, Tishman Speyer expects to find investment opportunities in the United States as conditions become clearer. He said the company is raising a fifth investment fund of $600 million for use in acquisitions over the next several years. The original intent was to balance the investments evenly between domestic and international properties, he said, but now the balance is likely to be $400 million in the United States and $200 million internationally.
A lot of property changed hands or was financially restructured before Sept 11, noted Darcy Stacom, an executive vice president at Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage and services company. "In a typical year there is about $6 billion in sales volume," she said. "We had already done $9 billion this year, although that comes down if you take out Rockefeller Center and the World Trade Center."
Rockefeller Center was sold to a group led by Jerry I. Speyer for $1.85 billion, and Larry A. Silverstein and a group of investors paid $3.2 billion for a 99-year lease on the twin towers. 
One reason for the current lack of sales is that owners are not sure what to do with the proceeds of a sale, Ms. Stacom said. "People do not know what to buy, even if it is a tax-free exchange."
THE continuing decline in interest rates -- the Federal Reserve cut its federal funds rate to 2 percent last week, a level not seen since the early 1960's -- may induce banks to lower their rates and prompt more refinancings, she said. "A lot of lenders have had interest rate floors -- they would not go below 7 percent," Ms. Stacom said. "Now they may go to 6.5 or 6 percent.
"But we may see a tightening of underwriting standards at the same time, with lenders projecting only flat rents," she added, noting that lowered rent assumptions would tend to reduce the value of buildings. 
The issue of the real post-Sept. 11 value of properties has become so uncertain that professional appraisers are being urged by their trade association, the Appraisal Institute, to attach a note to their reports saying the numbers do not include the effects of the attack.
"The appraisal process is retroactive," said Kevin Nunnink, chairman of Integra Realty Resources, a company specializing in appraisals. "Until we have enough post 9-11 data, nobody knows what the impact was."
He described the current period as "a temporary lull, with the bid and asked prices still apart." He said, "The lowest interest rates in 50 years" will trigger a buying boom starting early next year that will close the gap as buyers use cheap money to pay full price.
"There has not been an opportunity like this since the R.T.C.," he said, referring to the Resolution Trust Corporation, which disposed of properties controlled by failed thrift institutions at what are now thought to be low prices.
In the meantime, many building owners are reluctant to offer their properties for sale out of a concern that low bids in the current environment will depress the value in the future, said Peter Hauspurg, chairman of Eastern Consolidated Properties, a sales and financing company. "The office category is not trading," he said. "There are only eight buildings on the market in Manhattan."
That helps to explain the interest in buildings like 450 Lexington, said Ron Cohen, an executive managing director of Insignia/ESG, the brokerage and services company. "There is so little on the market that whatever becomes available attracts a lot of interest," he said. But banks have become more conservative in the post-attack environment, making it difficult to conclude sales, said Richard Baxter, also an executive managing director at Insignia. "Lenders that would do 75 to 80 percent loan-to-value deals formerly are now at 65 to 70 percent," he said. 
Mr. Hauspurg said there is a "general perception" on the part of buyers that there should be a discount on pre-Sept. 11 prices, but prospective sellers have not been willing to offer their buildings to bidding by multiple prospective buyers at this time. "Rather than go out into the market, some owners are trying to do private transactions, which we love to arrange," he said.
Prospective buyers and sellers are also waiting to see what kind of government incentive package will be offered for downtown, said Dov Hertz, a vice president of Lawrence Group, a brokerage and management company. 
"Everyone is waiting to see what the incentives will be," he said. "That's why buyers are not buying. They want to see the upside."
"Public-private partnerships will be important to the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan," said Norman Livingston, an executive vice president of Grubb & Ellis, a brokerage and services company.
He said that many usual investors in real estate have paused in making purchases until incentives are in place and the trend of the market is clearer. "Pension funds are on the sidelines now, and opportunity funds are finding less compelling opportunities," he said.
But he said gyrations in the stock market may prompt a wave of selling next year as the funds seek to rebalance their portfolios. "Because of the decline in some stock prices, funds that allocated 10 percent to real estate may now have 15 percent," Mr. Livingston said. "We can look for them to start selling next year because they need to monetize those properties."

HEADLINE: Postings: 1920's Building Between 43rd and 44th to Be Filled In; 
Facelift for Madison Ave. Block

BYLINE:  By Rachelle Garbarine 

 BODY:
The owner of a mostly vacant beige brick 1920's office building on Madison Avenue near Grand Central Terminal is planning a renovation that will give it a blocklong glass facade and add 50,000 square feet to the 650,000-square-foot E-shaped structure.
 Interior demolition recently started on portions of the 22-story building, which has a midblock section that stretches from 43rd to 44th Streets. As part of the $50 million renovation, the building will change its address to 340 Madison Avenue, from 342. The existing 25 tenants have been relocated to 75,000 square feet on the tower's top floors. 
 The reconstruction, expected to take 13 months, is subject to approvals from the City Planning Commission and the Board of Standards and Appeals because it involves the transfer of development rights from several low buildings on 43rd and 44th Streets, according to Macklowe Properties of Manhattan, the developer. 
William S. Macklowe, the company's executive vice president, said he was hoping to get the necessary approvals by the end of the year.
When Macklowe Properties bought the Madison Avenue building in late 1998 the structure was 60 percent occupied, mainly by small tenants because of its irregularly shaped floors of 23,000 to 30,000 square feet each.
Mr. Macklowe said he never wavered from turning it "into a modern building with big efficient floors" because there was and still is a demand for such space.
Asking rents are to be about $65 a square foot.
Mary Ann Tighe, vice chairwoman of Insignia/ESG, the building's leasing agent, said the additional space "is what Midtown needs because of the rapid absorption of space by downtown tenants displaced by the Sept. 11 attack." 
The developer has secured financing from Deutsche Bank, bought out some leases and let others run out. Leases for the 25 remaining tenants expire in three to four years. 
The developer plans to use the development rights, or air rights, to fill in the hollow portion of the E-shaped building formed by the pair of two- and three-story structures -- holdouts from the time the surrounding edifice was built in the 1920's. Filling in that space to the 17th floor, where the tower sets back, would create the 50,000 square feet of new space as well as larger floors of 28,000 to 39,000 square feet each. 
The architects for the renovation are Gensler and Moed de Armas & Shannon. RACHELLE GARBARINE

HEADLINE: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; 
Goodat Her Job, She Walked Away

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KENNEDY; The writer is a newspaper columnist and radio commentator in Green Bay, Wis. Submit your account of struggling or succeeding as a worker, consumer, investor or entrepreneur to My Money, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or e-mail mymoney@nytimes.com. All submissions become the property of The Times. They may be edited and may be republished in any medium.

 BODY:
HELLO?" A tentative voice answered the phone. 
 "Good morning, ma'am," I said. "This is Michelle from the bank, and I'm just calling to find out why you decided to give up your platinum card." 
 "Well," the voice stammered, "you charged me late fees when I was only late once in 10 years, and then you all were rude to me on the phone."
"Did we do that?" my voice sounded shocked, although I was not in the slightest. I proceeded to clean up the damage. 
"Oh my goodness," I continued, "the computer says that we did do that, and I am just so sorry. Let me fix that for you, and tell you what, between you and me, I'll drop your interest rate to 2.9 percent. Would that help you decide to take the card back?"
Got her! I checked her off my list and signed her up.
You bet I could do that. I could do just about anything if it meant the person on the other end of the phone would take back the credit card. 
All day long, I would talk to people who had given up their credit cards in a noble effort to whittle down their debt or because they were angered by customer service or just had enough cards already. They were people with medical bills or with college tuition payments, but none of this mattered to me because I had one goal in mind: to sign them back up. That was my sole duty. I was a customer retentionist.
Of course, I didn't start out wanting to sell people things they had already given up, but after a long stint of bartending and cleaning houses, a "corporate job" seemed like a good idea. There were benefits for me and my children -- steady hours and steady paychecks.
Since college, I had more or less subscribed to the if-it's-not-fun-don't-do-it school of job placement. In an effort to find that one true calling, I had held many jobs: nursing assistant, Ben & Jerry's tour guide, weed puller, baby sitter, restaurant owner. I even attended nursing school briefly. Through every single job, one thought stood out in my mind: How can I do this every day for the next 30 years? I could never resolve that part in my head. 
In fact, reading the Sunday newspaper has become a fantastic experience for me. It not only gives me a look into the world, it allows me to envision whole new lives for myself. Flipping through the help-wanted ads, I can see the choices: marine biologist, teacher, bartender, computer specialist, waitress, engineer. And while it does occur to me that I am only qualified for a couple of these positions, the possibilities seem endless. 
So the possibilities seemed very real a few years ago when I read: "Wanted: friendly people to help large credit card company. Excellent pay and benefits." I got the job, and unfortunately for debt-ridden Americans, I became quite good at it. 
Then came that particularly ruthless call involving a woman who had given up her card because of her medical bills. After a nice conversation during which I was only half listening because I was waiting for my opening to sell her back her card, she told me that ever since she had been found to have inoperable cancer she had been trying to reduce the debt she would leave behind. 
I was about to regale this poor woman with a tale of a lower interest rate intended to make her debt load easier when I caught myself. I told her that she certainly didn't need this card or any other. I also confided that I didn't even have a credit card, and then we spent much of the rest of my shift talking about the evils of credit card companies. 
Big Brother taped every call, so I was sure that this one was on the top of the agenda for the next staff meeting. But it didn't matter; I called in sick the next day and never went back. 
Corporations are funny. Even though I had been promoted three times in as many months, no one seemed to notice that I was gone. How do I know? They kept paying me three months after I left. Every other week another paycheck would be deposited in my bank account. I called and told the people at the credit card company, but they told me I was wrong, that that couldn't possibly be happening. So I kept the money and was blissfully jobless for a few months. 
Then I was at my parents' house reading the Sunday paper when I saw it: "Looking for an exciting career?"
Always!

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
One View Of Fallout Over Ending Long Bonds

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
THANKS to the Federal Reserve, since January, the cost of servicing short-term debt has been dropping.
 On Halloween, the Treasury Department unexpectedly got into the act when it said that it would discontinue sales of its benchmark 30-year bonds. Long-term interest rates, which had been on the sticky side all year, fell sharply after the announcement. 
 John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's, spoke about the implications of the Treasury's action. Following are excerpts: 

Q. Why were financial markets surprised by the Treasury's decision to eliminate the 30-year bond?

A. There had been an expectation the Treasury would stick to plans to cut back on the supply of 30-year bonds, but investors had all but given up on that because expectations of federal budget deficits had supplanted earlier expectations of budget surpluses.

Q. Was the Treasury's decision a smart thing to do in a longer-term sense?

A. This is going to make it more difficult for investors who want some certainty, looking ahead 10 years to 20 years to find a low-risk, long-duration investment.
Insurance companies will have a more difficult time matching their long-term liabilities with risk-free bonds. And getting rid of the 30-year bond makes the capital markets less efficient at longer maturity levels. For example, we have seen few if any new 20-year to 30-year corporate bonds since this was announced. Going forward, what is the representative benchmark going to be? 
Finally, it could well be the government is not minimizing interest costs over time by doing this, especially if current dosages of monetary and fiscal stimulus rouse the economy from its current slump. It may well be, for instance, that a year from now yields on 10-year Treasuries, currently at 4.25 percent, will be higher than the 4.85 percent 30-year bond yield. 

Q. The credit markets did pretty well before 1977 when the Treasury Department began issuing 30-year bonds. What is different now?

A. Prior to 1977, we had a good deal of long-term corporate bond issuance. At that point you could use long-term corporates as a proxy for very low-risk instruments. But since then we have lost so many AAA-rated corporate bonds, and debt protection measures are not as strong as they were in the 1950's and 1960's.

Q. The Fed, and now the Treasury, are trying to stimulate the economy by driving down borrowing costs. Is it working?

A. Corporate bond issuance will be a record this year. In October, $74 billion of investment grade bonds were issued, as well as $5 billion in high-yield debt. In September, the total was $43 billion in investment grade debt, and $1.5 billion in high-yield debt. But remember the markets were closed for a week.
The Treasury made its announcement on Oct. 31, and through Nov. 7, $13.85 billion of investment grade debt had been issued, and another $1.2 billion in high-yield debt. 
The large majority of this activity is refinancing. In addition, year to date we have had a better than 200 percent increase in early redemptions of outstanding corporate bonds.

Q. Have lower rates affected households?

A. The decline in mortgage rates has been incredible. Year to date, applications for mortgage refinancings are up more than 500 percent.
The last time we had mortgage refinancings jump like this was in 1998, and consumer spending in 1999 and 2000 was very strong. In late 1998, you might recall, there was a lot of worry about what would happen to the economy in 1999. As it turned out, the economy grew at nearly twice the rate that was anticipated. In part, that was due to the delayed benefits from what was a record pace of mortgage refinancings. 
I'm not saying we are going to have a replay in 2002, but it could provide valuable support for consumer spending next year and help bring about a better than anticipated showing by the economy over all. 

Q. Is there a danger that Congress will produce a fiscal package that overheats the economy?

A. With unemployment rising and the capacity utilization rate at 75 percent and falling, it is hard to fear overheating. But I would be willing to bet a year from now we will be talking about a tightening of monetary policy as opposed to an easing or neutral monetary policy.

Q. What are the odds that the Treasury will be back in the 30-year bond business within the next three to five years?

A. I think there is a 60 percent chance the Treasury will be back issuing 30-year bonds in that time frame. But faces change quite frequently in Washington, so I don't know if that would have a long-term impact on the credibility of those who manage the funding of United States government debt.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Lonski
